HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Rally in Gold Prices Begins On Signs of Mideast Buying

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold futures prices surged to their highest levels in two months yesterday as sharply lower stock prices, a weaker dollar and signs of Middle Eastern buying revived investors' interest in the metal.
On other commodity markets, silver rose; energy futures climbed; livestock and meat futures retreated, and grains and soybeans were mostly higher. 
Gold futures settled $7.70 to $7.80 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange, with the contract for delivery in August up $7.70, at $369.70 an ounce. The spot July contract settled at $369.10 an ounce, the highest settlement of a spot contract since May 22.
Silver futures settled 3 cents to 3.4 cents higher, with July at $4.882 an ounce.
Gold opened with a surge in New York following news of a large purchase of gold bullion in London that analysts believe originated in the Middle East. Some previous Middle Eastern transactions have been large enough to swing prices wildly, leaving the market sensitive to signs of interest in the region.
And the Dow Jones industrial average's early plunge of 107 points sent many stock investors fleeing to the perceived safety of precious metals. The stock market slowly trimmed its losses throughout the day, but gold remained strong. New support stemmed from higher oil prices - an inflationary signal - and a weaker dollar.
Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with Paine Webber Inc., said the Federal Reserve Board's recent moves to lower interest rates had been a boon to the gold market.
Energy futures continued to rise amid optimism that OPEC oil ministers meeting this week in Geneva will agree on measures to reduce their crude output and raise prices. The organization's midyear meeting begins Thursday.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Educating Engineers For Top Posts

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
MANY engineering schools have been broadening their curriculums to hone the management skills of their students, so that they can hold more top management positions.
The changes are coming at a time when deans of many engineering schools are struggling to stay abreast of the rapid changes in technology.
''Curriculum changes are constantly under study,'' John R. McLaughlin, associate dean of engineering at Purdue University, said recently. ''We have to prepare our engineers today for things that we cannot even imagine. So the best we can do is to identifiy building blocks with enough humanistic and communication skills so engineers can continue to grow after graduation.'' 
Dr. McLaughlin said that when he graduated from engineering school 40 years ago, ''I could have lasted 10 years before becoming technologically obsolete.'' Now an engineer ''has only five years at best before obsolescence,'' he added. ''Engineers need education every day.''
But Dr. McLaughlin said he did not foresee radical changes in Purdue's engineering program. Instead, the university will stress the importance of continuous postgraduate study to keep up with change.
A few years ago there was talk that leading engineering schools might urge undergraduates to take five years to complete their education. Dartmouth College requires this, and so do a few other schools, permitting more liberal arts programs. ''Cornell and Ohio State used to insist on five years also, but no longer,'' Dr. McLaughlin said. He noted that engineering schools had not agreed on such an approach and said that ''our product seems to be quite acceptable to United States companies.''
At least a fourth of engineering school graduates eventually work toward master's degrees. Others keep up with change by participating in seminars, many of them sent by satellite or television links.
''We granted more than 40 master's degrees in engineering this year to students who never set foot on the Purdue campus,'' Dr. McLaughlin said. They listened to lectures in a company auditorium or on local campuses by means of a television network called the Indiana Higher Education Television System, and they were able to interact with students and professors at other locations.
The National Technological University, which has its headquarters in Fort Collins, Colo., and offers master's degree programs in a similar way, provides more and more short courses aimed at broadening an engineer's education. These have titles like Fundamentals of Crisis Management, Moving Into Management, Economics and Statistics for Managers of Technology, Sales Management and Marketing for Customer Retention in the 90's.
David G. Vice, vice chairman, products and technololgy, for Northern Telecom Ltd., one of Canada's largest companies, recently stressed the need for broadening engineering education at a joint session of American and Canadian engineering groups. ''A broad education leaves engineers better prepared to communicate, to avoid technological obsolescence and to learn new skills as technology advances,'' he said.
He added that the discipline had some pressing needs, including increasing the number of women engineers. ''Young engineers must learn foreign languages and cultures,'' he said. This could be done in part by more bilateral exchanges ''to advance international cooperation and knowledge,'' he added.
Mr. Vice urged that there be more ''joint research endeavors'' between universities and companies. With the use of computers and other tools, engineers ''will be less involved in routine work and more involved in the formulation of ideas and in the making of choices,'' he told the engineering groups.
He urged other companies to do what his did - ''work hard to give engineers status and keep them informed about how important they are to our success.''
They must be taught managerial and business skills, he said, if they wanted to be a more important part of management. He emphasized the importance of subjects like international economics and technical communications, along with continued broadening of undergraduate backgrounds in the humanities and the social sciences.
He said he was concerned about a shortage of faculty in engineering schools and about the lack of industrial experience of professors, and urged that companies ''encourage professors to spend their sabbaticals working in offices and laboratories.''

HEADLINE: Manville Net Declines 24%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DENVER, July 23

 BODY:
Citing eroding construction-related markets, the Manville Corporation today reported second-quarter earnings of $52.6 million, or 41 cents a share, down 24 percent from $69.4 million, or 55 cents a share, a year earlier.
Sales were $561.1 million in the quarter, down slighlty from the $564.6 million reported a year earlier. 
For the first six months of 1990, the company reported net income of $77.5 million, or 58 cents a share, down 25 percent from $103.8 million, or 80 cents a share, in 1989. Sales were up slightly over the first six months of last year, at $1.08 billion, compared with $1.07 billion during the period last year.
''Our second-quarter results reflect a mixture of forces driving our company,'' said Tom Stephens, chairman, chief executive and president of the Denver-based building products company.
''Construction-related markets continued to erode slowly, and while demand for our coated paperboard products was strong, packaging sales were down,'' he said.
''In Brazil, our domestic markets continue to be negatively affected by the country's new economic program, but our exports from Brazil remain on target,'' Mr. Stephens said. ''We remain confident about Manville's long-term prospects in Brazil and continue to strengthen our position in worldwide paper markets.''
Mr. Stephens said the competitive pressures in all of the company's product lines were expected to intensify during the second half of 1990.
Manville, which employs more than 18,000 worldwide, filed for Chapter 11 reorganization in 1982 as it faced billions of dollars' worth of lawsuits stemming from asbestos-related operations. The company emerged from Chapter 11 protection in 1988 with a plan to repay creditors and people claiming personal injury or property damage from asbestos.

HEADLINE: U.S. Policies Criticized by Allies in Asia

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 24

 BODY:
America's allies in Southeast Asia today bitterly criticized Washington's policies on Indochina and refugees as inconsistent and counterproductive.
The nations at the annual meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations here issued a joint statement repeating their collective threat to stop giving asylum to Vietnamese boat people unless Washington altered its stand and allowed the mandatory repatriation of Vietnamese judged to be not refugees but economic migrants.
The open and sometimes patronizing criticism of American policy by the foreign ministers of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean, will make the visit here of Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, starting late Thursday, less ceremonial and polite than usual.
''I think Mr. Baker is in for a rough time,'' a senior Asean official said. 
 
Criticism of Washington Policy
The Foreign Ministers of Asean members - Indonesia, Thailand, Singapore, Malaysia, Brunei and the Philippines - are here for their annual meeting, which is followed by discussions that are usually routine with their colleagues from major allies like the United States, Canada, Australia and Japan.
Criticism from the Asean nations continued today over the American shift on Cambodian policy last week, when Washington withdrew diplomatic support at the United Nations for an opposition coalition including the Khmer Rouge. Among those who complained about the shift today was Singapore's Foreign Minister, Wong Kan Seng, who said he was unable to understand the logic of the American move.
But after a joint Asean statement on Cambodia issued Monday night, it was Washington's policy on Vietnamese boat people that got the most attention today.
A joint statement by Asean criticized the United States for being inconsistent and risking the ''breakdown of international understanding'' on protecting refugees.
 
Screening of Boat People
The statement repeated Asean's threat to abandon its commitment to provide refuge to boat people ''in a more coordinated and concerted manner'' unless Washington shifted position. For over a year now, only Malaysia has been turning away Vietnamese boats.
In Geneva two weeks ago, a 28-nation conference on Vietnamese boat people, which was to have been held at the headquarters of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, was postponed when it became clear that differences between the United States and Vietnam on one side and the Southeast Asian nations and Hong Kong on the other had not been bridged.
In June 1989 Washington agreed that Vietnamese boat people landing in the region should be screened to see if they are real refugees, fleeing persecution, or only economic migrants seeking a better life. But unlike its policy with Haitians or Mexicans, Washington will not allow Vietnamese economic migrants to be deported against their will back to Vietnam.
In that policy, which ''sees Vietnam as a uniquely reprehensible nation,'' an Asean diplomat said, the United States finds itself in agreement only with Vietnam, which says it will not accept the forcible repatriation of its citizens on humanitarian grounds.
 
Threat to First Asylum
The American position has infuriated Hong Kong and the Asean countries, who provide first asylum, or temporary refuge, to the boat people. While those judged refugees are guaranteed resettlement in the West, the rest are ''piling up,'' as a Malaysian official said.
The Malaysian Foreign Minister, Abu Hassan Omar, said today that the American position only ''provides comfort and protection to Vietnamese intransigence.'' By insisting Vietnamese migrants are different, he said, America ''puts the very principle of first asylum in peril.''
American and United Nations officials say that Malaysia has already done that by pushing off the boats of Vietnamese refuge seekers. Since May 1989, United Nations officials say, the Malaysians have pushed off more than 8,700 Vietnamese, many of whom have since landed in Indonesia. How many may have died on the way is unknown.
In an effort to change Washington's stand, or at least get Washington and Vietnam to house those rejected economic migrants on their territory, the Asean countries and Hong Kong said in May that they reserved the right to abandon first asylum ''to safeguard their national interests.''
 
Forced Repatriation
The countries set a deadline of July 1, but only Malaysia is now pushing off boats. They wanted to allow the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to try to work out a deal with Washington.
The Commissioner has pursued a distinction between ''involuntary repatriation,'' which Hanoi says it will accept, and ''forcible repatriation,'' which it will not. If migrants can be induced to return home without volunteering to do so, but without the use of force. Hanoi, it seems, is satisfied.
But Washington is not, officials say. The Bush Administration, in particular the National Security Council, ''has put so many conditions on involuntary repatriation that it is in reality voluntary,'' an Asean diplomat said today.
''We need a clear statement from the U.S. supporting involuntary repatriation,'' he continued. ''Otherwise there is no solution and no deterrent.''
 
Flexible Stance for Baker
WASHINGTON, July 24 (Special to The New York Times) - Secretary of State Baker will try to head off confrontations with the Asean nations in Jakarta by seeking to take flexible positions on Cambodia and Vietnamese refugees, State Department officials said today.
As Mr. Baker prepared to leave Wednesday for a 12-day tour of Indonesia, Singapore, the Soviet Union and Mongolia, American officials privately commented that it was a sign of the times that his easiest stops would be in the two Communist countries.
On the Administration's Cambodia policy, one State Department official said Mr. Baker would combine ''explanation and co-optation'' to demonstrate to the Asean officials that ''we have not shifted our policy as much as reports seem to indicate.''
Administration officials say Mr. Baker will stress that the Administration remains pledged to providing assistance to the two non-Communist guerrilla groups loosely aligned with the Khmer Rouge, who presided over the deaths of more than a million Cambodians during their reign in the 1970's.
He will continue to oppose the involuntary return of Vietnamese, which is proposed by Hong Kong and the Southeast Asian nations to clear out their teaming refugee camps. But Mr. Baker will discuss ways in which the nations might cooperate in generating ''voluntary repatriation,'' stressing improved screening and counseling to convince Vietnamese that life in the refugee camps will be hard and will not necessarily lead them to lives in the United States.

HEADLINE: ASYLUM-SEEKERS STRAIN CUBA'S TIES

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAVANA, July 24

 BODY:
An influx of Cubans seeking asylum in foreign embassies here has strained relations between the Castro Government and the country's two most important Western economic partners, Spain and Canada. Several unexplained incidents during the crisis have raised suspicions among some Western diplomats that Government agents have infiltrated the would-be refugees.
The refugee flow began on July 9, when five Cubans known as dissidents entered the Czechoslovak Embassy in Havana, saying they suspected their activities put them at risk of arrest.
After five days inside the embassy, some of them left voluntarily. Appearing on Cuban television later, one of the dissidents, Lazaro Cabrera, asserted they had been encouraged to seek asylum by the Czechoslovaks in a plot with the United States to provoke a refugee crisis. His statement led some in Cuba's dissident community to voice suspicions that he had been working with the authorities. 
In the days after the first asylum effort, several more Cubans made their way into the Czechoslovak and Spanish Embassies, some of them managing to get through cordons of barbed wire and numerous police guards at wooden and metal barricades placed around the missions, raising suspicions about their true identities among diplomats.
 
Harsh Diplomatic Exchanges
Last week, several of the Cubans who had made their way into Czechoslovak diplomatic premises became violent, briefly taking diplomats hostage, destroying property and threatening to blow up the mission. Western diplomats say that those Cubans were almost certainly disguised agents.
The crisis escalated on Friday, when Cuban police officers fired warning shots and followed a man onto the patio of the Spanish Embassy before dragging him away. The incident led to a series of increasingly harsh diplomatic exchanges between Havana and Madrid, with Spain cutting off its economic aid and recalling its Ambassador on Monday to protest Cuba's handling of the refugee crisis.
As of today, 18 Cuban asylum-seekers remained inside the Spanish Embassy, four were at an Italian diplomatic residence and three were inside the Swiss Embassy. And the West German and Canadian Embassies have been publicly accused by the Cuban Government of taking part in an effort to fan the crisis and have been sealed off by the police.
Canada is the largest source of Western visitors in Cuba's increasingly vital tourism industry.
 
Western Conspiracy Asserted
All of the Cubans who had sought refuge at the Czechoslovak Embassy left voluntarily last week.
Havana has sought to portray the crisis as a Western conspiracy aimed at creating a political crisis at a time of growing economic difficulty.
Western diplomats uniformly deny the Cuban assertion and say that the crisis was either manufactured from the start or quickly manipulated by Cuban authorities anxious to prevent a repetition of the 1980 refugee crisis, when thousands of Cubans sought refuge at the Peruvian Embassy, leading to an embarrassing exodus through the port of Mariel by 125,000 disenchanted Cubans to the United States.
By sending agents into the embassies to commit violently disruptive acts, the diplomats say, the Cuban Government was attempting to depict all asylum-seekers as dangerous criminals. But the diplomats have different theories as to whether the authorities instigated the entire affair, or acted to take advantage of a spontaneous incident.
 
'Quite a Novel Technique'
''The basic objective of Castro here was to try to pre-empt the whole asylum issue to prevent the kind of thing that happened in Albania recently,'' said a senior Western diplomat, who suggested that the crisis had been planned from the start by Havana but quickly got out of hand. ''It is quite a novel technique to teach a lesson to any would-be asylees, and also to send a message to the foreign missions.''
''But it is kind of a risky business, and besides, it won't work,'' said the diplomat, who spoke on the condition he not be named.
A Western diplomat from another country who also insisted on anonymity discounted the idea that the crisis had been instigated from the start by the Cuban Government, but said that several security agents had infiltrated the embassies soon after the initial rush began.
That diplomat said that the Cuban Government appeared to have wanted to use the crisis to rally the population in anticipation of the expected announcement next month of dramatic reductions in Soviet subsidies for Cuba. The diplomat said the dispute with Spain will likely have the greater costs in terms of economic support.
 
Dissident Appears on TV
One of the dissidents who appeared on Cuban television to implicate the United States, Tania Diaz Castro, is a prominent leader of the Cuban Human Rights Party who has spent most of the last two years in jail.
Diplomats and fellow dissidents said they believed that Miss Diaz had cooperated with officials to gain lenient treatment for herself. She is in prison currently, and could face execution or a long sentence for her supposed involvement in a terrorist conspiracy.
''They broke her,'' said one prominent dissident of the Government's use of Miss Diaz. ''It is sad, but it does not surprise me. These are manuevers of the cold war.''

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about refugees in embassies in Havana referred incorrectly in some editions to the diplomats who voiced suspicions that Cuban Government agents were posing as asylum seekers. The diplomats were Western, but not West German.

HEADLINE: Deficit Raises as Much Alarm As Illegal Drugs, a Poll Finds

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. KAGAY

 BODY:
The American public now cites the Federal budget deficit as frequently as it mentions illegal drugs as the most important problem facing the country, according to the latest Gallup Poll.
The shift to parity between the two problems is significant because the drug problem had dominated the public's agenda for more than a year, previously swamping people's concern about the deficit or other problems.
Twenty-one percent of the 1,242 adults interviewed by Gallup from Thursday to Sunday said the Federal budget deficit was the most important problem facing the country. This was virtually identical to the 18 percent who cited the problem of illegal drugs. 
But both priorities had shifted since an April Gallup Poll, when only 6 percent of the public mentioned the deficit as the nation's No. 1 problem while 30 percent mentioned drugs.
Both national telephone polls had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
 
Shift to Dissatisfaction
On another question in the new poll, 51 percent of the public expressed dissatisfaction with ''the way things are going in the United States at this time,'' while 45 percent said they were satisfied.
This represents a shift toward greater dissatisfaction since Gallup last asked the question in February. At that time, 55 percent expressed satisfaction with the country's direction, while only 39 percent were dissatisfied.
In the new poll, 60 percent of the public approved of the way President Bush is handling his job. That is virtually unchanged from the 63 percent who approved in a Gallup Poll taken earlier this month, but clearly down from the 69 percent approval level in a June Gallup Poll.
But the Gallup Poll taken earlier this month, just after Mr. Bush renounced his ''read my lips - no new taxes'' pledge, showed that majorities disapproved of the President's handling of several economic particulars that may be coming together in the public's mind. For instance, 58 percent disapproved of Mr. Bush's handling of the savings and loan crisis, 64 disapproved of his handling of the budget deficit and 54 percent disapproved of his announcement that he would consider increasing taxes, if necessary, to reduce that deficit.
President Bush's peak to date was 80 percent in January, in the aftermath of the United States invasion of Panama.
Fifty-six percent of the public said the savings and loan crisis was very serious for the United States. But in their analysis of the poll, George Gallup Jr. and Frank Newport found ''no clear evidence that the savings and loan crisis is behind general dissatisfaction or the declines in Bush approval.'' Whom to Blame? The Gallup researchers pointed out that very few Americans spontaneously mentioned the savings and loan crisis as the No. 1 problem facing the country, and that more people put the blame for the situation on savings and loan management or on government in general than on President Bush, former President Ronald Reagan or Congress.
An optimistic finding in the poll was that when Americans were asked about their own personal lives, rather than the direction of the country, the satisfaction level remained high and unchanged. In the latest poll 81 percent said they were satisfied with the way things were going in their personal lives, virtually identical to the 83 percent who gave that answer in a February Gallup Poll.

HEADLINE: The Right Way to Raise Taxes

 BODY:
An attitudinal dam broke when President Bush last month grudgingly acknowledged he could swallow new taxes. There was a wave of relief that finally the country could control its towering fiscal deficits. But now the rush has worn off and the Congressional budget negotiators are finally getting down to the hard part: deciding how to raise revenues. 
Many Democrats want to raise the tax rate on the highest incomes. Others, especially Republicans, want to leave tax rates largely undisturbed but achieve more revenue by limiting deductions that mainly benefit the rich. If the budget negotiators don't lose sight of the need to raise revenues fairly, agreement could be in sight.
By limiting deductions, Congress could raise large amounts of revenues and protect the poor, all without unraveling the tax brackets negotiated as part of the 1986 tax reform. That would amount to a notable fiscal achievement.
Capping deductions would not be a necessary evil brought on by fiscal crisis. It would be no evil at all. Fringe benefits and itemized deductions have mushroomed into glaring tax dodges for upper-income families. About half of all itemized deductions are taken by families earning more than $50,000 a year. Limiting these deductions would target upper-income families. Meanwhile, the economy as a whole would be spared many of the negative effects of increasing tax rates on decisions to work and invest.
Congress could cap dozens of deductions. For example, individuals do not pay tax on the value of medical insurance paid for by employers. Even if Congress wishes to promote basic health insurance, why should taxpayers subsidize lavish policies for high-paid executives? A sensible policy would allow deductions for basic medical care, but require individuals to pay tax on anything more.
The same principle applies to mortgage interest. Whether Congress needs to subsidize home ownership at all is debatable. But current rules subsidize the purchase of fabulously expensive mansions and vacation homes. Further limiting the deduction would make the tax code fairer.
Why should the Federal tax code lessen the impact of state and local income taxes? After all, residents reap the advantage of these taxes in the form of improved schools and other public services. Capping just the deductions for mortgage interest and state and local income taxes could easily generate at least $1 billion a year.
To gain revenue from deduction caps rather than tax rate raises has another important advantage. Rate increases on high incomes would traduce the 1986 tax reform. If that deal is undone, it would clear the way for President Bush to pursue his misguided attempt to grant special tax treatment for capital gains.
Special treatment for capital gains is unwarranted. But Congress could use this opportunity to index capital gains, thereby offsetting the effect of inflation on future investments in stocks and bonds. That would tax capital gains and ordinary income alike, which is what the tax reform of 1986 promised. And because capital gains are primarily earned by wealthy families, indexation would take some of the sting out of capping deductions.
There is, in short, no good case to be made for raising rates now. There are powerful reasons, including fairness and progressivity, for limiting deductions. If Congress and the Administration can resist distracting arguments over rate raises, the negotiators can achieve a grand compromise, one that would do credit to both parties. In this rare case, everyone can win.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Tax Would Hurt Electricity's Role in Reducing Global Warming

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''White House Gases'' (editorial, July 11) is on target in stating that ''sensible precautions'' can be taken now to address the global climate-change issue. But the editorial fails to mention a key component in the search for options to address this issue: electricity.
Electricity is moving our country toward greater energy efficiency and consequently is reducing energy-related emissions. From 1983 to 1989, overall energy demand increased 9 percent, while electricity use grew more than 50 percent. A study conducted for Edison Electric Institute found that electrification in the transportation and industrial sectors can reduce carbon dioxide emissions significantly. In fact, electric applications can decrease CO#2 emissions in industrial processes and in the transportation sector by 17 percent and 8 percent, respectively. 
In addition, electric utilities are spending more than $1 billion annually on energy-efficiency programs. Demand-side management programs have resulted in an estimated deferral of 21,000 megawatts of new capacity (42 medium-size power plants), and will result in deferring a total of 45,000 megawatts by the year 2000. Energy-efficiency gains can also be achieved when generating electricity. These efficiencies are achieved not only through new technologies like clean coal plants, but also through retooling existing plants.
But energy taxes could dramatically change the efficiency story. These taxes could add $12 billion per year to the already high price tag footed by electricity consumers for environmental protection. There is no fairness in a tax that would hit low-income households the hardest, affect heavily industrialized states disproportionately, and severely hamper our economic competitiveness in world markets.
As a country we must continue to press for energy efficiency in the residential, industrial, commercial and transportation sectors. The environmental benefits of an energy tax, however, are questionable. As we grapple with options to address future environmental concerns, we should not be adding taxes that will keep electricity from being part of the solution.
 
THOMAS R. KUHN, President
Edison Electric Institute
 Washington, July 16, 1990

HEADLINE: Pact Reached To Save Water In New York

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
New York City, threatened with a state ban on all new building in a third of Manhattan and parts of Brooklyn and Queens because sewage treatment in those areas is inadequate, has agreed to enforce far-reaching water conservation measures.
Under the agreement, details of which are being negotiated, the city would be obligated to accelerate conservation measures like installing water meters and detecting groundwater leaks into storm sewers in the areas served by the Newtown Creek sewage treatment plant in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, the city's largest.
In the next few years, the water conservation measures would be extended to neighborhoods served by the city's 13 other sewage treatment plants, said Thomas C. Jorling, the state's Commissioner of Environmental Conservation. It would be the first time the city has legally committed itself to enforce widespread water conservation. 
Under the agreement, the measures will begin immediately in the area served by the Newtown Creek plant.
 
Cost Not Clear
It was not clear yesterday what the program would cost. The city was already planning to spend more than $300 million over the next 10 years to install water meters in all five boroughs.
The city acted because it faced a ban on new sewer hookups, which amounted to a ban on all new building, in the area served by the plant - the northern half of Brooklyn, bits of Queens, and all of Manhattan below below 14th Street on the West Side and below 72d on the East Side.
The state threatened the ban, which was due to go into effect a week from today, because the Newtown Creek plant has been accepting more sewage and waste water than allowed under its state permit, and has passed inadequately treated waste into local waterways. There are 1.1 million residents in the area served by the plant.
If homes and offices cut down their use of water, and leaks of groundwater from water mains are kept out of the storm sewers, less waste water enters the 23-year-old plant, which puts less strain on its equipment and allows it to treat sewage more thoroughly. The plant had been designed to accommodate 310 million gallons a day, but has been routinely exceeding that amount.
The threatened ban on sewer hookups had deeply worried city officials and the real-estate community. The city is already suffering an economic slump, and the ban could have disrupted planning for future developments. The state only recently lifted a 30-month moratorium on sewer hookups in 26 municipalities in Westchester County.
The agreement was disclosed yesterday by Mr. Jorling and Albert F. Appleton, the city's Commissioner of Environmental Protection. It has been worked out in the last month, and the two sides hope to complete it by the end of the week.
Also, the city has committed itself to accelerating a program for pressing industry to cut down on toxic discharges through the sewer system, Mr. Jorling said. The city has long been obligated to carry out such a program under the Federal Clean Water Act, but progress has been slow.
The city will also be obliged to reduce the amount of heavy metals like copper and lead that originate with city water pipes and are carried into sewage treatment plants. The plants are not equipped to removed toxic metals from waste water and as a result, release them into the city's rivers, where they are carried in the water and absorbed in bottom sediments.
If the city failed to comply with the agreement, it would face a ban on new sewer hookups in eight months, Mr. Jorling said.
Mr. Jorling and Mr. Appleton would not discuss specific provisions of the agreement because they were still being negotiated. But Mr. Jorling insisted that the pact would force the city to take actions that it had not contemplated doing.
 
Sensitive to Appearances
That is a sensitive point because state officials do not want to be seen as having backed down from a sewer hookup ban, which is a powerful instrument, in the face of city pressure. Instead, Mr. Jorling said the threat of the ban pressured city officials into agreeing to binding commitments.
In the past, environmental groups have criticized the state for letting the city get away with environmental violations. Katherine Kennedy, a lawyer with the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group, said it was difficult to evaluate the accord without seeing specific provisions.
But she said her organization and others had long pressed for enforceable citywide water conservation goals. In the long term, an agreement that specified such goals would be beneficial, she said.
Ms. Kennedy added, however, that in the short term, the Newtown Creek plant would still continue to operate over capacity and pollute the East River.
 
Plant Expansion Planned
Ms. Kennedy put the average flow at Newtown Creek for the 12 months between April 1989 and March 1990 at more than 326 million gallons a day, 16 million over the design capacity. The chief engineer for the city's Department of Environmental Protection, Joseph T. Miller, also estimated the flow in the 320-million-gallon range. The plant serves 1.1 million people.
The city is already planning a $1.2 billion, 50-million-gallon expansion of Newtown Creek that will take 10 years. The plant's treatment process will also be upgraded to comply with Federal pollution requirements.

HEADLINE: New York City Still Growing, Studies Assert

BYLINE: By THOMAS MORGAN

 BODY:
Economists, demographers and city planners say the population of New York City has continued to grow and is now larger than ever - 8 million - an assertion that challenges official estimates, demographic trends and conventional wisdom.
The figure, reached most recently in a new study by a New York University economist, is larger than estimates by the Census Bureau and highlights a long-running dispute between the Federal agency and urban officials. New York and other cities have contended that the Census has undercounted their populations, costing them Federal aid and seats in Congress.
The 8 million figure for New York exceeds the Government's estimate by about 700,000 people, more than the population of Boston, for example.
Researchers have also found that by the end of the 1980's New York City had not only grown but had become younger. The average age of its population had dropped partly because of the second-largest wave of immigration to the city in this century. The influx - chiefly from Asia, the Caribbean and South and Central America - has consisted of large numbers of children and young adults who have begun to change New York, much as the larger migration of Italians, Poles, Jews, Russians and Greeks did at the turn of the century. 
 
Wide Implications
Census Bureau figures for the 1980's do not show this growth in population. But statisticians and demographers in New York City's Department of Planning as well as economists who have conducted their own studies have said that the bureau's estimates for New York City are too low.
This view is supported by a study that is to be released soon by the Urban Research Center at the Robert F. Wagner School of Public Service at N.Y.U. The study uses the 1980 Census count for New York City as a base and then projects population growth to 1987 by using information about births, deaths, enrollments in public and private schools, Social Security recipients and various other demographic indicators.
The New York University study and others achieving similar results have striking implications for city planners, who must determine how to allocate precious city resources to serve a much younger, child-bearing population. New York City public school officials, who have started an extensive school rebuilding plan, estimate that next fall's student enrollment will be 946,438, the highest in a decade.
The N.Y.U. study, by Emmanuel Tobier, an economics professor at the Urban Research Center and a former chief economist for the Regional Plan Association, highlights population increases among immigrants as well as among teen-agers and young adults in the major racial and cultural groups.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said last week that if the conclusions of Mr. Tobier and other economists are correct, the undercount would have ''serious repercussions'' for the city. Mr. Tobier's study says the Census Bureau's 1988 estimate of the city's population fell short of the actual number by 700,000; if so, New York City residents would be entitled to significant additional representation in Congress and in the State Legislature and more money in state and Federal revenue-sharing grants.
 
Counting Is Difficult
Counting people in large cities, particularly those with many immigrants, has always been difficult for demographers. But several university economists who specialize in demographics, economists at the Regional Plan Association and demographers in the city's Planning Department say that the city's population is closer to 8 million than the 7,353,000 estimated by the Census Bureau in 1988.
Demographers say census figures show that the city's population hovered around 7.8 million people from 1950 to 1970, despite a large migration out of the city and a nationwide population shift from inner cities to the suburbs. In keeping New York's numbers relatively stable, immigrants made the difference, demographers say.
''In view of the possible difficulty in establishing the 1990 census, somebody ought be be ready with credible numbers to question the Census,'' Mr. Tobier said.
Mr. Tobier said he based his numbers on largely the same demographic variables employed by the Census Bureau but used different and more accurate mathematical formulas to interpret the data. Demographers say the methods he used are not unusual.
Mr. Tobier said the Census Bureau estimated that the city grew by 3.5 percent between 1980 to 1987, from 7,071,000 to 7,317,000. His projection found a growth rate of 10 percent during that period. That includes a 28 percent growth in the birth rate between 1980 and 1989, compared with a rate of 11 percent nationwide.
 
A Populous 15-to-44 Group
The fastest growing category, according to the N.Y.U. study, was that of 15- to 44-year-olds, the prime working and child-bearing group. Their numbers rose by 20 percent from 1980 to 1987. Young people in this group make up about 50 percent of the city's white, black and Hispanic residents. About 63 percent of New Yorkers of Asian background are also in this age group.
''The widespread image that the city is in the midst of a population downturn is not supported by the evidence of Tobier's study,'' said Mitchell Moss, director of the Urban Research Center .
Not everyone agrees with Mr. Tobier or the other researchers who have made similar projections.
Samuel H. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, relies on Census estimates for his projections of the region's labor force and unemployment. He said he has not seen statistics suggesting that the city's population is as large as Mr. Tobier and others say. #100,000 Immigrants a Year Those who have concluded that the population is growing have attributed the phenomenon to immigration. Regina B. Armstrong, an economist and consultant for the Regional Plan Association, said she estimates that 35 percent of the city population is foreign-born. ''All the growth comes from new arrivals, and there are more arrivals than there is net growth in the population,'' she said.
City demographers say that during the 1980's nearly 100,000 immigrants came to the city each year and that most of them stayed.
The studies show that New York City is more crowded than ever, and the effects can be seen in greater traffic congestion, a growing demand for low-cost housing and the doubling-up among low-income families.
Roy Metcalf, a spokesman for the city's Housing Authority, said that in 1989 more than 22,000 first-time applicants for public housing gave a home address indicating that they already lived in public housing, by doubling up with other families. He said almost 40,000 families are doubled-up in Housing Authority projects.
 
'Something Is Happening'
Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said automobile registrations in New York City increased by 24 percent between 1980 and 1988. But the Census Bureau reported that in the same period both the number of households and the population grew by only about 4 percent.
''Clearly something is happening,'' Ms. Scanlon said. ''The household figures come from the Census study, and I presume that either more people are driving, or the Census numbers are wrong.''
A population undercount can have profound implications for New York City's government and residents.
''The 1980 undercount has cost New York City one Congressional seat and as much as $900 million in Federal and state financial aid over the past decade,'' said Victor Kovner, New York City's Corporation Counsel. New York was among several cities two years ago that unsuccessfully challenged the Census Bureau's 1980 count, contending that it undercounted minorities, immigrants and the homeless. Mr. Kovner said the city would mount another challenge if it believed that the 1990 Census results were too low.
City officials also use population data to assist in allocating money for schools, parks, housing and hospitals, among other beneficiaries.
 
Impact on Industry
An undercount can also effect industry. Businesses use census data to select locations for supermarkets, retail stores and manufacturing plants as well as to market new products.
''The smart marketer today is recognizing that it is very important to develop marketing programs that address the population as a set of distinct and quite separate market segments,'' said Jackie Silver, executive vice president and director of research and planning for Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide Inc., the Manhattan advertising agency.
''When we don't get accurate demographic information, marketers and communications experts are not getting the information needed to make the right decisions about how to spend their advertising and product development money,'' Ms. Silver said. ''Ethnic groups are very responsive to promotional programs which tie into products they use heavily. If that group is not represented properly, it's a very serious problem for us.''

HEADLINE: Unions Prepare Boycott Against The Daily News

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT

 BODY:
Labor leaders at The Daily News announced yesterday that they would organize an ''all-fronts boycott'' against the newspaper.
With contract talks stalled after six months of negotiations, officials of the newspaper's 10 unions said they had concluded that a boycott by advertisers and readers - or at least the imminent threat of one - could help force management into what they called a responsible stance at the bargaining table.
Contracts at the 71-year-old newspaper, owned by the Tribune Company of Chicago, expired March 30.
 
Strategy Isn't Disclosed
''We're going after The Daily News and the Tribune Company,'' said George McDonald, head of the Allied Printing Trades Council, the unions' umbrella group. ''They're the enemy.'' 
However, saying they did not wish to disclose their strategy, the unions' representatives declined to set an actual starting date for the boycott or to say how the unions would try to convince advertisers and readers to stop supporting the paper.
''I don't mean to be flip, but there are some things we'd like to keep to ourselves,'' said Samuel C. McKnight, a Detroit labor lawyer hired last month by The News's 10 unions. He helped plan a successful boycott of a Detroit television station on behalf of a technicians' union three years ago. His principal adversary was Robert Ballow, a Nashville lawyer who is now The News's chief tactician.
A spokesman for The News, John T. Sloan, promptly accused the unions of trying ''to kill the hand that feeds them'' and said The News had already moved to counter any boycott with a stepped-up campaign of upbeat 60-second radio messages featuring testimonials from longtime advertisers.
''Our primary mission at The News is to save and improve thousands of jobs, which will be severely jeopardized if the Allied's counterproductive tactics are attempted,'' Mr. Sloan said. ''We are confident that New Yorkers will overwhelmingly reject this unfortunate and misguided attempt to disrupt and harm the operations of their hometown newspaper.''
Mr. McDonald and Mr. McKnight said the boycott would be aimed at mobilizing The News's display advertisers, classified advertisers, newsstand readers and subscribers.
Asked whether the boycott might eventually be expanded to include other properties of the Tribune Company, Mr. McKnight replied, ''The truthful answer is: We're not going to say.''
The unions' announcement yesterday came less than a week after they began mailing thousands of ''informational letters'' to advertisers alerting them to the possibility that they would be asked to join a boycott.
''Because you support The Daily News with your advertising, you are directly involved in the bitter labor dispute that now exists at the paper,'' the letter said.
Officials of the financially ailing newspaper, who have been spending an estimated $4 million a month preparing for a strike, have tied new contracts to the unions' acceptance of a ''management rights'' provision, which would would give the paper free rein to set hours and working conditions.
 
Doubts Among Unions
The unions have called the demand unacceptable but have vowed not to play into management's hands by walking off the job, which would free the newspaper to fill their jobs with replacement workers. More than 40 potential replacement workers, mostly drivers, have been hired in the last month.
Not everyone connected with the unions was comfortable with the decision to announce a boycott.
At least one union adviser was said to have argued strenuously that a union-led boycott was not advisable now, saying that any action aimed at weakening the paper's already shaky economic base could play into the hands of its Chicago owners, whom the unions have accused of planning either to sell or to close The News.
Others have privately expressed concern that a boycott, or at least a badly timed one, could hurt the unions' cause by alienating advertisers and readers over the summer, a period of slack advertising.
 
'They Can Just Do It'
Labor officials say they remain convinced that management is embarked on a strategy aimed at somehow provoking a strike during the summer, when it could most easily weather the potential advertising losses.
But Mr. McKnight rejected the notion that the boycott would be counterproductive.
''You don't need an excuse to close a business,'' the 45-year-old lawyer said. ''They can just do it.''
A boycott, he said, ''will get the unions closer to contracts by giving the employer an incentive to help develop a constructive solution to our disagreements, one that includes respectable collective bargaining agreements.''
 
Awaiting Word From State
But Mr. Sloan rejected this reasoning, renewing accusations that The News has been victimized by featherbedding and what he called other institutionalized labor abuses. He also accused the unions of deliberate foot-dragging in the contract talks.
The unions' announcement came as both sides awaited word on whether state officials would move ahead on appointment of a fact-finding panel to look into the issues of the dispute.
Some officials close to the proceedings said yesterday that vehement opposition by The News - including a threat to go to Federal court to block any inquiry - might have stirred doubts among high-ranking state officials about the wisdom of the idea.
But city officials, including Eric J. Schmertz, the Labor Relations Commissioner, have strongly backed creation of a state board of inquiry, saying it could help prevent a major labor explosion at The News.
Under a rarely invoked state law, the state labor commissioner is authorized to appoint a board of inquiry if the chairman of the State Mediation Board certifies that efforts to reach a settlement have failed.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
On a Remote Soviet Island, Lessons in Capitalism

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 24

 BODY:
A Los Angeles business professor and a Soviet economist have announced that they are introducing the nuts and bolts of capitalism to the inhabitants of the remote Russian island of Sakhalin, north of Japan, in one of the latest free-market experiments in the Soviet Union.
The project, which will send American academics and business executives to help would-be entrepreneurs, is the creation of Valentin P. Fyodorov, who was elected head of the Sakhalin Island government in March.
Mr. Fyodorov, an economist who visited the United States two years ago as a guest of Loyola Marymount University in Los Angeles, enlisted the help of W. F. Kiesner, a professor of management and entrepreneurship at the school.
''Valentin's dream is to have a demonstration project on private enterprise and a market economy in a small and isolated area of the Soviet Union, where he can show Moscow that it can indeed work,'' said Mr. Kiesner, who has traveled to the Soviet Union five times in the last two years to lecture on American business practices. 
 
Import of Experiment
The Sakhalin experiment will be closely watched, he said in an interview after the announcement in late June, because there is great debate in the Soviet Union about the appropriate pace for revamping the Soviet economy without central planning.
Under the guidance of Mr. Kiesner, Loyola Marymount University will serve as a center for recruiting American professors and business leaders to serve as consultants to Sakhalin residents.
Mr. Fyodorov's plan differs from other private enterprise programs in the Soviet Union because it will have active official support, said Mr. Kiesner.
''The government in Sakhalin is now saying you can start any business you want, and they will encourage you and provide assistance,'' he said. ''They will cut the red tape and the tremendous bureaucratic opposition that entrepreneurs on the mainland face, which make it very, very difficult to actually start your own business.''
Sakhalin, the site of important Soviet military bases, made headlines in 1983 when a South Korean jetliner was shot down into the sea by a Soviet fighter after the jetliner flew over the southern end of the island.
The thin, 500-mile-long island is populated by 700,000 ethnic Russians, 95,000 members of indigenous tribes and 35,000 ethnic Koreans, who worked as laborers when Japan held the southern half of the island until 1945.
 
One-on-One Training
In addition to helping modify the island's timber, fishing and energy industries, Mr. Kiesner said he hoped to encourage enterpreneurs to open new small businesses on Sakhalin. One of the best ways to do this, he said, is to provide one-on-one training for all segments of the economy.
''The owner of a grocery store could go over there and improve and modify their ways of running food distribution and the grocery business,'' he said. ''In the same way, a dentist could show them the way you run a practice in the private enterprise system of medicine.''
If the island eventually aims to tap the export markets of the United States and Pacific Rim, for which it is geographically well suited, a major obstacle will be the Soviet ruble, which is nonconvertible.
''These problems seem insurmountable at this point, but I think in the next couple of years they can be solved,'' he said. Until then, exporters must develop ''countertrade'' plans, in the same way that Pepsico Inc. takes its profits from Soviet sales in the form of Russian vodka imports.
Another hurdle that American consultants may face is difficulty in teaching basic free-market concepts to Soviet business executives who have worked in a strict, centrally planned economy.
''The idea that the customer is always right might be hard to impart,'' Mr. Kiesner said. ''Up until now, their approach has been that you're awfully lucky if we sell you anything.''

LENGTH: 1514 words

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
English Theater Quick on Political Trigger

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
In the 1970's, during the heyday of the Joint Stock Company and other politically inclined theatrical organizations, English playwrights like Caryl Churchill, David Hare and Howard Brenton often reacted immediately to public issues. Faced with urgent political questions, the writers reached for their quill cudgels.
Except for the agitprop days of the Living Newspaper in the 1930's, playwrights in the United States have traditionally left such quick commentary in the hands of stand-up comics and monologuists. Although in the 1980's this kind of political theater was on the wane in London - possibly because theaters were worried about losing financial support - this summer in London there has been a reawakening of interest in what could be called Theater of the Moment.
As in previous years, the playwrights are led by Miss Churchill, whose new play, ''Mad Forest,'' is an insightful investigation of the revolution in Romania last December that toppled the regime of Nicolae Ceausescu and led to the execution of the Communist dictator and his wife. Simultaneously, the Royal Court Theater sponsored a six-week season of 15 issue-oriented dialogues, under the title ''May Days.'' 
Max Stafford-Clark, the company's artistic director, has explained the impetus for the dialogues: ''The swift course of events in Eastern Europe at the end of 1989 and the end of a decade of Thatcherism here in Britain prompted a wish for a kind of 'Royal Court Instant Response Unit,' able to give a theatrical platform to the immediate debate of political issues.''
The immediacy of the playwrights' response does not necessariy insure wide public attention. The Churchill play is performed on a small stage in the Embassy Theater in North London by students at the Central School of Speech and Drama - a long way from the customary venues of the author of such trans-Atlantic successes as ''Cloud Nine,'' ''Top Girls'' and ''Fen.'' The show is scheduled to conclude its run this weekend. The May Days series, which ended this month, played to embarrassingly small audiences, a fact that was variously attributed to a dearth of publicity, mixed notices and public apathy.
Nevertheless, the plays - in particular, ''Mad Forest'' and Doug Lucie's Royal Court one-act, ''Doing the Business'' - are provocative in the extreme.
Miss Churchill's play, commissioned by the Central School, is an incendiary piece of theater, which moves beyond reportage into a kind of historical analysis. As a play, it still has rough edges. Some scenes are either underdeveloped or overextended. But it has a visceral sense of events happening as the audience watches and a feeling of first-hand truthfulness.
Together with her director, Mark Wing-Davey, Ms. Churchill visited Bucharest in March, amassing information and images. Two months later, the playwright had finished writing the play and it was in production, without the delays found in the commercial and even the institutional theater.
Sitting on hard concrete blocks, theatergoers are uncomfortable witnesses to the Romanian revolution, as it detonates and then is eventually surrounded by questions. In the first act there are glimpses of the repressiveness of the Ceausescu regime and the economic and political deprivations suffered by Romanian citizens. The view is through the eyes of two families, one working class, one representing the intelligentsia - about to be united through marriage.
The second act offers a collage of snapshot reactions to the revolution. As in a mystery play, people with limited knowledge try to piece together what actually happened. In the third and most amorphous act, the playwright describes the seismic tremors that continue after the initial revolution. Especially in this final section, there are indications of Miss Churchill's more imaginative side, as she creates a sardonic encounter between a dapper Transylvanian vampire and a fleabitten dog, a stand-in for the bedeviled common man. Wisely, the playwright has refrained from sealing her play with a conclusion. Like the revolution itself, the play remains in progress.
The confused nature of the uprising, as Miss Churchill sees it, is reflected in the title. ''Mad Forest'' refers to the name of a forest outside Bucharest, considered to be ''impenetrable for the foreigner who did not know the paths.'' In other words, Miss Churchill believes one would have to be Romanian to understand the intricacies of the events of the last year, and even then the view might be obstructed. Guided by the playwright, we begin to understand the political and moral complexity. In one of many bitterly comic interludes, the play's Ceausescu explains why he is mightier than God. God created the sun, the moon, the stars and mankind ''out of chaos''; Ceausescu boasts, ''I created the chaos.''
The student actors are a closely allied ensemble, offering indications of their nascent theatrical talent. Similarly, there is a feeling of potential in the play - incomplete but far more evocative than the author's last effort (''Ice Cream,'' produced last season at the Public Theater in New York). With work, ''Mad Forest'' could become the Eastern European political equivalent of Miss Churchill's ''Fen,'' a play that far transcended its journalistic origins.
Coincidentally, at Miss Churchill's customary habitat, the Royal Court, there was the rotating repertory of one-act political dialogues, commissioned from a wide diversity of people, some of them playwrights, some of them public figures not previously involved in writing for the theater. The nonprofessional roster included one of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's advisers, a member of the Labor Party's shadow government, the Bishop of Durham and even a theater critic. Free to choose subjects, they focused on a diversity of contemporary issues.
The plays on one bill were ''The Wall-Dog,'' by Manfred Karge, a polemical conversation about German reunification; ''How Now Green Cow,'' a very funny assault on environmentalism by Julie Burchill, a newspaper columnist and pop novelist, and Mr. Lucie's ''Doing the Business,'' a comedy about the dangers inherent in private financing of the arts.
In the caustic Burchill comedy, a trendy woman (deftly played by Lesley Manville) committed to the self-indulgences of city life assails a liberal friend, who has retreated to the country and adopted a save-the-rain-forest missionary zeal. The author's anti-Green spokeswoman says, ''Nature is the biggest serial killer the world has ever seen.'' Theater of the Moment can, of course, derive from conservative as well as liberal hands.
The most incisive of the dialogues was ''Doing the Business.'' Mr. Lucie, the author of ''Progress'' and ''Fashion,'' is no latecomer in responding to public issues. But ''Doing the Business'' sets something of a record for a play hot off the presses. It was performed just as both England and the United States faced crises in financing of the arts. The crises outlasted the run of the play.
Those who are opposed to government support indicate that organizations and individual artists would be able to substitute private sponsorship for public support and this presumably would free them from restraints of censorship. With malevolent wit, Mr. Lucie concludes that the opposite is true. If anything, private financing, he says, will lead to more interference and a greater loss of artistic freedom.
The instruments for the author's debate are two former university classmates, a forward-looking theater director (Nick Dunning) and a fund raiser (Nicholas Woodeson) who brokers partnerships between art and business, something long in evidence in both countries. Mr. Woodeson, genial even as he is insidious, plays a diabolical dissembler who believes in ''creative funding'' - code words for censorship and sponsor control. In particular, the broker objects to two plays on the director's schedule, one by an Irishman (therefore, Mr. Woodeson concludes, he only writes ''Irish plays''), the other by a lesbian and dealing with child abuse. In the current English climate, the lesbian is more acceptable than the Irishman.
In order to guarantee jobs for members of his company, the director trims and rationalizes while trying to maintain his artistic conscience. Eager to please his own constituency, Mr. Woodeson dilutes the other's intentions through a series of guileful maneuvers, suggesting that he cast a famous ''alternative comedian'' in a leading role in a play to boost ticket sales. Art is sacrificed in the name of ''doing business'' and ''compromise is the language of progress.'' The sensibility is not too far removed from the crass commercialism of the movie executives in David Mamet's ''Speed-the-Plow.''
Mr. Lucie's short sharp satire has a particular resonance during a time when the National Endowment for the Arts is being subjected to heavy criticism. In this excoriating example of Theater of the Moment, audiences could be watching what may happen in the American arts if grants by the endowment are further restricted.

HEADLINE: Stalled Geneva Farm Talks Are Suspended for a Month

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 24

 BODY:
The United States and the European Community, failing to make progress at talks in Geneva in resolving a festering trade dispute over farm subsidies, suspended negotiations today for a month.
The delay raised worries among American officials and business executives about the prospects for a separate, broader effort, also under way in Geneva, to liberalize world trade. Nearly half of the 102 nations in those trade talks have indicated they will walk away from negotiations if Washington and Brussels cannot agree on measures to end protectionism in agricultural trade. They are working against a December deadline, when they are scheduled to present proposals to a ministerial meeting. 
The delay was also a setback for President Bush, who tried unsuccessfully to break the farm trade standoff in his conversations with heads of other major industrial countries in Houston earlier this month.
Administration officials voiced concern on the delay. ''Time has become our enemy,'' said the deputy United States trade representative, Julius L. Katz. ''The simple fact is that we are not as far advanced as we need to be at this time in the negotiations.''
But European Community officials expressed surprise that the Americans were disappointed. A senior European official in Washington, who asked not to be identified, said it was unrealistic to expect that a framework for agreement on agriculture could be reached so soon after the summit meeting.
''We still have four months to go,'' he said, ''and so no one should be terribly discouraged.''
William E. Brock 3d, who served as President Reagan's first trade chief, called for the renewed personal involvement of the industrial countries' leaders. ''It will now take an act of great political will for the round to become successful,'' he said. ''We just can't wait until the last minute to resolve this matter.''
Failure of the talks, many analysts believe, could result in protectionist trading blocks that could crimp global prosperity.
The Uruguay Round of talks, named after the site of the initial negotiating session at the Uruguayan beach resort of Punta del Este nearly four years ago, is currently meeting in Geneva under the aegis of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, an international trade organization.
The talks seek to cut billions of dollars of farm subsidies, ending distortions that curb farm exports; open trade in textiles, which ranks along with agriculture among the most protected industries, and expand international trading rules to cover services, investment and intellectual property rights.
With agriculture blocking progress in the other sectors, world leaders meeting recently in Houston agreed that a future pact on agricultural should contain assurances that participants would reduce ''not only internal support but also export subsidies and import protection in a related way.'' But the European Community has been loath to eliminate export subsidies, which give its farmers bigger markets abroad.
A Dutch civil servant, Aaart de Zeeuw, had prepared a document on freeing trade in agricultural products that had been discussed as a possible peace formula at the summit meeting.
But this week, when it came to making necessary concessions, neither side budged. As a senior American trade official put it, ''There was no sign that the basic differences have been bridged.''
The fallback plan, American officials said, is to begin a new process of trying to resolve differences after governments have reconsidered their positions between now and Aug. 27, when the agricultural trade talks are to resume.
Mr. Katz, the United States trade official, said, ''Those of us who want the Uruguay Round to succeed will have to assure that our negotiators return to Geneva at the end of August with the mandate and flexibility to make the policy-specific commitments necessary - in all the areas of negotiation.''
American officials said that blockages existed not just in agriculture, but in all the major negotiating sectors. ''It's clear the chemistry isn't there,'' said one senior American official who asked not to be identified.
Many outside experts warned that the delay could be costly for the Congressional approval process.
C. Michael Aho, director for economic studies at the Council on Foreign Relations, said it could mean that an agreement was ''inadequate from the U.S. viewpoint and the Administration will lose its constituency for winning Congressional backing.''
One indication of the domestic pressures against the Uruguay Round is the campaign of the textile industry to legislate restrictive quotas. These would reduce American trade negotiators' flexibility.
The Senate by 68 to 38 last week approved the quota bill, and the House is now expected to take up the legislation next week, just before the August recess. President Bush is virtually certain to veto the bill, and the veto is likely to be sustained.

LENGTH: 1070 words

HEADLINE: Few Heads Are Turned By Profits' Turnaround

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The selloff in the stock market on Monday, which many analysts attributed to weak profits, actually came at a time when company earnings seem to be rising again.
But the turnaround is hard to cheer about. Profits remain very weak, made so by the sluggish national economy. By one measure, they are nearly as low as they were in the 1982 recession. They are so weak, in fact, that a few disappointing earnings reports from blue-chip companies in the past week apparently helped touch off the 56.44-point decline in the Dow Jones industrial average. 
''There is no question that profits are turning around,'' said Kenneth Petrick, a Commerce Department economist who compiles profits data. ''The problem is that they are not turning around as quickly or in as big a way as some people apparently thought they would.''
By many measures, the profit turnaround came in the first quarter, and some forecasters say that once all the earnings reports are in for the March-to-June period, the overall earnings of the nation's tens of thousands of corporations will be found to have risen another notch.
Nevertheless, profits are not returning to anywhere near the level they reached in 1988 and in the first half of last year, before the economy began to weaken.
The average per share earnings of the Standard & Poor's 500, a cross-section of publicly traded companies, for example, was $6.74 a share and $6.48 a share in the first and second quarters of 1989, respectively. The average then plunged to $4.88 a share in the third quarter and $4.83 in the fourth. It finally moved back up, to $5.17 a share, in the first quarter.
DRI/McGraw-Hill, an economic consulting and data-gathering service, estimates that the S.& P. 500 companies earned an average of $5.54 a share in the just-ended second quarter. Other forecasters are also offering relatively optimistic estimates, among them the Conference Board, a business organization, and two Wall Street investment houses, the First Boston Corporation and Goldman, Sachs & Company.
A widely watched Commerce Department measure also suggests an upturn. Before-tax profits adjusted for inventory earnings and equipment investment, to simulate earnings from current production, fell for four quarters to an annual rate of $285.9 billion in last year's fourth quarter. That measure then turned up to $289.7 billion in the first quarter.
 
Troubling Factors
But two troublesome characteristics stand out in this incipient turnaround. One is that the profits of American corporations, rebounding or not, represent today only about 5.4 percent of the gross national product, the broadest measure of the nation's wealth.
In 1982, during the worst months of the last recession, corporate earnings before taxes fell to about 4.5 percent of G.N.P., the lowest since World War II. But within a few months, earnings jumped to 7 percent of G.N.P., and as the recovery proceeded, they stayed near that level until last year, when the economy weakened and earnings plunged to the current 5.4 percent.
The second characteristic is that some industries are doing far better than others - and few seem to be doing as well as many analysts had expected. ''They thought that the sharp dip in the second half of last year was a fluke caused by various one-time write-offs and profits would come back to where they were in last year's first half,'' said David Wyss, a senior economist at DRI.
That profits were not coming back to their 1989 levels apparently dawned on Wall Street last week. Although I.B.M. had reported fairly strong second-quarter earnings, others in the computer industry failed to live up to expectations, among them Texas Instruments Inc. and Apple Computer Inc.
Several of the nation's money center banks also reported earnings declines, hurt mostly by real estate loan problems, and then last Friday, the McDonald's Corporation dashed many hopes. Although the fast-food company, said that second-quarter net income had risen by 10 percent, compared with the figure a year earlier, some investors had expected this bellwether company in the consumer services sector to be among the leaders of a return to healthier profits.
 
Expectaions 'Out of Line'
''Consumer spending on service increased substantially in the second quarter, so why a service company like McDonald's didn't meet people's expectations, I'm not sure,'' said Robert Giordano, co-director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs. ''Maybe the expectations are too out of line with reality.''
Whatever the expectations, many consumer-products companies reported improved second-quarter earnings in recent weeks. Petroleum companies, some large regional banks, machinery manufacturers and food companies also said that profits were up in the quarter. Many others have said in recent weeks that earnings were down, among them construction and building supply companies, some electronics companies, auto companies, military contractors and appliance companies.
Several themes run through the explanations of why profits are weak, the main one being that few companies, in a sluggish economy, can raise prices. McDonald's, for example, blamed price discounting at its fast-food outlets for its difficulties, and many other retailers report consumer resistance to price increases.
But there have been other inroads into profits. One is interest payments on corporate debt, which now use up 5.2 cents of each dollar collected by nonfinancial corporations from the sale of their goods and services. As the debt burden rose, so did the repayment drain on earnings. It went from less than 4 cents in the mid-1980's to 5.2 cents in last year's third quarter and remained at that level through March of this year - perhaps because companies have borrowed less in recent months.
Unit labor costs have also taken their toll, rising to 67.3 cents of every dollar in the first quarter, from 67.1 cents in the fourth quarter of 1989, mostly because of the rising cost of benefits. But labor costs have risen more slowly over the last six months than they did last year, and that has helped to stabilize profits, which represented 7.1 cents of each dollar from current output in the first quarter, down only slightly from 7.2 cents in 1989's fourth quarter., ''There is no great exuberance in the earnings reports,'' said Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley, ''but no collapse either.''

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Sticky Traffic, Slick Fixes

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
FRESH from their triumphs in Eastern Europe, free-market economists are pushing market solutions for problems closer to home. Markets are being touted as the most efficient way to save wildlife, improve public education and reduce acid rain. Could they also be used to tame the scourge of America's city-sprawls: the rush-hour traffic jam?
Influential citizen groups in California think so. And in the last few weeks they have made cautious converts of the regional pollution and transportation authorities, whose leaders are scrounging for politically acceptable ways to contain traffic-related smog. The big question now is whether they can sell a fresh approach to a motoring public that takes the ''free'' in freeway very, very seriously. 
Under the gun from both state and Federal authorities to prevent deterioration in air quality, Southern California stitched together a pollution-control plan last year that included regulation of everything from aerosol deodorants to barbecue grills. To reduce anticipated car use by 40 percent in the year 2010, the planners talked of rules that would induce one-third of commuters to forsake their own vehicles for car pools, mass transit or home computer terminals. Just how that ambitious goal might be met, however, was left up in the air.
The quick and dirty way to get Californians to drive less would be to ration car use or parking or gasoline consumption - or all three. But that would be a regulatory nightmare, not very different than the one faced every day in a thousand ways by Soviet planners. Would those with extra-long commuting trips get extra ration coupons? How about families with more or less children than average? And who would enforce the rules, which are likely to be greeted with as much enthusiasm as root canal surgery?
The less painful and less intrusive alternative, argued a panel drawn from the Environmental Defense Fund, the libertarian Claremont Institute, business interests, auto clubs and a number of local governments, would be to ration road use by price. By coincidence the Bay Area Economic Forum, a committee of local governments with close ties to both business and environmental groups, came up with similar findings at virtually the same time. And with little public fanfare, the recommendations of both groups were embraced in principle by local regulators of air quality.
High on the lists are congestion or emission taxes - fees for consuming scarce road space and scarcer clean air. Collecting fees at toll booths, the Bay Area Economic Forum acknowledges, would itself add to congestion and pollution. But the region could borrow an idea from Singapore, where rush-hour use of critical arteries is regulated with windshield stickers. Anyone caught on the wrong road at the wrong time without a sticker (purchasable at convenience stores) would be in for a stiff fine.
A more expensive but technologically feasible variation on the system would use road sensors and in-car computers to measure travel. Motorists could then be billed monthly, according to flexible pricing formulas for time-of-day use and miles driven. Revenues could be used to subsidize mass transit.
The trouble with congestion taxes high enough to alter commuter behavior is that they would cost a lot of angry people a lot of money. Michael Cameron, an analyst for the Environmental Defense Fund in Oakland, believes that much the same results could be achieved with far less political hassle by giving everyone limited rights to commute by car, and then allowing those who need more (or merely want more) to buy rights from other motorists.
Car owners might, for example, be allowed to drive 200 miles a week on bottleneck roads at rush hour. Use would be measured with road sensors and on-board computers. Extra mileage allowances could be bought or sold from vending machines, the way modern mass transit systems now keep track of electronic fare cards. Prices might be recomputed frequently to balance changing supply and demand. Those who chose to trade in mileage allowances for cash would be paid by check, much the way tax refunds are paid today.
This may sound like a far too ambitious leap into the brave new world of managing cities by computer. But the technology, analysts argue, is no longer pie-in-the-sky. And once car-dependent commuters understand that the practical alternatives are poisonous air or bureaucratic controls on personal mobility, the brave new world may begin to look very good.
