HEADLINE: Greenspan Emphasizes Fight Against Inflation

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 24

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, provided little hope today to politicians who want to see interest rates lowered and bank regulations eased.
''We clearly have a sluggish economy,'' he told the House Banking Committee's Subcommittee on Domestic Monetry Policy. But he emphasized that the chances of a recession were ''low,'' that fighting inflation was his No. 1 priority and that the decision to lower a key interest rate two weeks ago was made solely to offset unusually tight credit policies by commercial banks.
More than in testimony to the Senate last week, Mr. Greenspan today stressed his desire to combat inflation. ''The inflation rate is higher currently than we would like,'' he said in answer to one question. ''It is very easy to accelerate from here.'' 
A Labor Department report today, in fact, showed that private industry wages, salaries and benefits had risen by 5.2 percent in the 12 months ended June 30, compared with a rise in the Consumer Price Index over the same period of 4.7 percent.
 
Good News for Workers
The report, which Mr. Greenspan was not asked to discuss, was good news for workers who saw their pay and benefits lag behind the rate of inflation for much of the 1980's. But compensation rose only by 4.5 percent in the previous 12 months, and economists said the rising cost to business recently was one reason why the inflation rate had accelerated this year.
Mr. Greenspan took issue with lawmakers who maintained that overzealous bank examiners had forced banks in their districts to restrict lending to creditworthy customers. Mainly what had happened, he said, was that lending practices had returned to normal after a decade of being dangerously lax.
This was the second stage of Mr. Greenspan's Congressional testimony on the state of the economy, testimony he is required by law to provide every six months to the Senate and the House. He presented today precisely the same statement he gave to the Senate Banking Committee last Wednesday and added little new in answer to questions.
 
Not Questioned on Stocks
Some experts on Wall Street attributed Monday's stock market slide to uncertainty about Mr. Greenspan's intentions on interest rates following his testimony last week. Although today's testimony was little different, the Dow Jones industrial average rose today by 17.82 points. Mr. Greenspan was not questioned directly about the market today.
At one point, Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, prefaced a question by suggesting that the Federal Reserve had lowered the Federal funds rate by a quarter of a percentage point two weeks ago as a signal to the budget negotiators from the White House and Congress that the central bank would cut interest rates if a deal was struck on reducing the budget deficit. The Federal funds rate is what banks charge each other on overnight loans.
 
Link to Talks Denied
Mr. Greenspan, who is normally extraordinarily patient with lawmakers, interrupted Mr. Leach and said rather sharply that the only reason the rate had been reduced was because banks had become unnecessarily tight in their lending practices and that the action had nothing to do with the budget talks.
Several legislators told Mr. Greenspan that business owners in their districts were complaining that they could not get loans for which they were qualified and had been told by their banks that the reason was that bank examiners were cracking down.
Mr. Greenspan said he agreed that some banks had become too tight in their lending practices, but he attributed this to caution that was a rebound from previous lax practices and denied that regulatory policy was the cause.

HEADLINE: Overseas Investment Down in U.S.

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Foreign investors shunned American stocks and Treasury securities in the first quarter of 1990, leaving the domestic markets with a net outflow of foreign investment in stocks and bonds for the first time since 1983.
Foreigners sold $3.3 billion more in stocks than they bought, according to figures released yesterday by the Securities Industry Association. In addition, foreigners had net sales of Treasury securities of $6.5 billion. 
At the same time, Americans cut back their purchases of foreign stocks in the first quarter as the Tokyo stock market plunged and other stock markets, while rising, were quite volatile.
David G. Strongin, the securities association's director of international finance, said the net sales by foreigners indicated it was getting harder for American markets to attract investment from abroad. ''The U.S. can't any longer count on an unending supply of foreign capital,'' he said. He said this could lead to higher interest rates and depress stock prices.
The decline in foreign buying in the United States is a reaction to the attractive opportunities in Europe because of the revolution in Eastern and Central Europe. For example, the West German stock market soared to new highs at the end of last year and again in the first quarter.
In addition, interest rates in West Germany and other European countries were rising, making their bond markets more attractive. And in the United States, the outlook for the stock market was not that positive during the first part of the year. The Dow Jones industrial average declined in the first three months.
The $3.3 billion of sales by foreigners in the first quarter followed net sales of $400 million in the last quarter of 1989.
Most investors selling American stocks were from Europe, where net sales totaled $1.3 billion in the last quarter of 1989 and $1.2 billion in the first quarter of this year.
The Japanese also sold stocks in the first quarter, resulting in net sales of $700 million. But the Japanese had been net buyers of $2 billion worth of American stocks in the last three months of 1989.
Americans cut their purchases of foreign stocks sharply. Net purchases totaled $355 million in the first quarter, down from $4 billion in the previous quarter.
The biggest net sales, $1.3 billion, were of Japanese stocks, which fell steeply from a record high on the last trading day of 1989. In addition, Americans were big sellers of French stocks in the first quarter, thereby missing part of the rally in the French market.
Most of the buying was done in the rest of Europe. In addition, Americans set a record for purchases in Australia - a total of $273 million, twice any previous quarter.

HEADLINE: Seger May Quit Fed's Board

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 24

 BODY:
President Bush may get a third chance to appoint a member of the Federal Reserve Board if Martha R. Seger resigns.
Ms. Seger, who is 58 years old, has been a governor on the seven-member board since 1984. She said in an interview published in The Wall Street Journal today that she might resign to care for her mother, who lives in Arizona and recently underwent hip surgery and suffered a stroke.
Ms. Seger, who has eight years remaining of her 14-year term, is the board's most outspoken advocate of an easy-money policy to keep economic growth vigorous. She is frequently at odds with other board members who favor higher interest rates to slow the economy and reduce inflation.
''I'll probably make a decision by the end of this year on whether or not I have to leave,'' she said in the interview. ''I'm going to play it by ear.''
Ms. Seger did not return several telephone messages seeking comment.
President Bush has already appointed David W. Mullins, a former Assistant Treasury Secretary, to fill one vacancy on the board. He is due to select a successor to Manuel H. Johnson, the Fed's vice chairman, who has announced that he plans to resign next month.

HEADLINE: Sallie Mae Shares Fall

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Shares of the Student Loan Marketing Association, were lower in heavy trading yesterday amid concern about the financial crisis at a key guarantor, analysts said.
Reassurances by the Secretary of Education helped to calm jitters only slightly after recent reports about trouble at the Higher Education Assistance Foundation, the nation's largest guarantor of college student loans. 
Shares were down $1.75, to $48.125, in New York Stock Exchange trading.
Secretary Lauro Cavazos earlier said the foundation-guaranteed loans would remain Government guaranteed. Mr. Cavazos said the foundation's problems do not threaten the national student loan program.
A Sallie Mae spokesman declined to comment on the stock drop.
 
Edward Caso, an analyst at
Goldman, Sachs & Company said Sallie Mae remained a high-quality financial institution. He continues to recommend the stock, noting that its recent losses have pushed it down to a level that makes it even more attractive.
Administration officials said today that they had scrapped the idea of turning over the troubled portfolio of the foundation.
The officials said the Department of Education was exploring other options, including the possibility of finding another agency to take over the Higher Education Assistance Foundation.

HEADLINE: Pepsico's Profits Climbed by 10.4% in the Second Quarter

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Pepsico Inc., the world's second-largest soft-drink company and the nation's No. 2 operator of fast-food restaurants, said that earnings in the second quarter ended June 16 rose 10.4 percent, to $292.5 million, or $1.10 a share, from $264.9 million a year earlier, or $1.00 a share.
Showing strength across all of its businesses, including the previously lackluster Kentucky Fried Chicken chain, Pepsico said second-quarter sales rose 17 percent, to $4.2 billion, from $3.59 billion in the period last year.
Earnings in domestic soft drinks were hurt by a $4.5 million charge to write off receivables because of the bankruptcy of the Circle K Corporation, a convenience-store chain. The Circle K problems also hurt Pepsi's snack-foods business, principally Frito-Lay, with a $4.6 million write-off. 
''But Pepsi's earnings are outstanding,'' said Roy D. Burry, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody. ''They look like $1.10 a share versus a buck, but in reality, it's $1.12 a share versus 94 cents because of all of those nonrecurring items.''
Soft drinks, one of the most profitable consumer products, is Pepsico's largest division, making up about 38 percent of the quarterly revenue. But unlike the Coca-Cola Company, the world leader in soft drinks, Pepsi gets most of its business from the United States, where volume growth has been slow compared with international markets. Pepsi reported a 4 percent volume growth domestically, Coca-Cola 3 percent.
In the United States, Pepsico posted a 10 percent profit rise on a 5 percent rise in sales of soft drinks. Pepsi, unlike Coca-Cola, sells most of its beverages in supermarkets, where sales are still relatively strong. Coca-Cola sells much of its beverages through fountain outlets in restaurants, where customer traffic has reached a plateau because of too many restaurants and a slowing economy.
Pepsi's domestic soft-drink revenue totaled $1.24 billion compared with $1.18 billion in the period a year earlier. Profit, hurt by the $4.5 million Circle K write-off, rose 10 percent, to $192.7 million from $175.8 million.
By contrast, in its international business, Pepsi posted a 29 percent profit rise on a 23 percent rise in sales. That excludes the effects of a $32.5 million credit in 1989 resulting from a decision to keep a Japanese bottler previously scheduled for sale.
International soft-drink revenue totaled $354.3 million, compared with a $289 million a year ago. International profits totaled $40.5 million, compared with $63.8 million.
Pepsi's restaurants, the second-largest operator of fast-food outlets after McDonald's, posted a 35 percent profit gain, to $137.6 million, on a sales gain of 22 percent, to $1.43 billion.

HEADLINE: U.S. Vehicle Sales Down 13.2% in Mid-July Period

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 24

 BODY:
The market for new autos softened in mid-July, as sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks fell 13.2 percent compared with unusually strong sales in the period last year.
Cars sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.9 million units, well off last year's pace of 7.7 million in mid-July, and below the selling rate of 7.4 million for the last 30 days. The annual selling rate for the last 60 days was 7.1 million.
But several analysts said that mid-July sales were slightly better than expected, and that car buyers were still active despite a rush by consumers to take advantage of cash rebates and financial incentives that were scheduled to end on July 9. After a strong initial 10-day selling period at the beginning of the month, the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company extended their rebate offers into the current period. 
 
'A Hard Act to Follow'
''We thought June was a hard act to follow,'' said Scott Merlis, an analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, ''but July is doing it so far.''
''Auto sales have been on a plateau since February, and it looks like July will be a slight improvement,'' said Ronald A. Glantz, an analyst for Dean Witter Securities in San Francisco. ''But I need to see one more month of improved sales before I call it a trend.''
The Big Three all reported sizable sales declines for the mid-July period, and the sales of the Nissan Motor Company, which also makes cars in the United States, also fell. Four other Japanese car companies with plants in the United States reported increased sales, although the gains posted by Toyota, Honda, Mazda and Mitsubishi were not as large as they have been in recent months.
Last year, many car companies offered huge rebates as they tried to clear bloated inventories to make room for new models. The discounts drew buyers, but hurt the industry by pulling many prospective customers out of the market for new models.
 
Role of Incentives
Inventories are much smaller this year and analysts do not expect the same kind of price slashing as the model year draws to an end. But some auto executives believe that consumers have come to expect big discounts in the summer, and they worry that sales will suffer without incentives.
''People are holding off,'' said Joel Pitcoff, manager of research and analysis at Ford. ''I think people have been conditioned to expect that the best deals in terms of incentives come at end of model year.''
The economic factors that often stimulate auto sales - lower interest rates and higher personal income -have not been evident lately. But some analysts have suggested that people who bought cars five and six years ago are returning to the market to replace their old cars.
Manufacturers and dealers have anxiously awaited the return of such replacement buyers, who have been out of the market for an unusual length of time. Previously, they returned to replace their vehicles in cycles of about 48 months, the usual length of their car loans. But to stimulate sales in the 1980's, manufacturers and dealers offered loan repayment terms lasting up to five years, which reduced the monthly payments but extended the replacement cycle.
''There are so many people out there paying down old loans that they haven't been buying new cars,'' said David Healy, an analyst for Barclays Bank in New York. ''I think we are just beginning to grow out of that.''
 
Higher Prices Ahead
As usual, buyers holding off for the new models will find they are substantially more expensive. On Monday, Ford announced to its dealers price increases on its 1991 models ranging from four-tenths of 1 percent on its Topaz models to 7.4 percent on its Taurus model. Prices on all Ford models rose an average of 3.2 percent, the company said.
For the mid-July period, Ford's car sales fell 24.6 percent, to 50,803 units, as sales of the company's Escort and Taurus models declined far below last year's levels. Light-truck sales dropped 13.2 percent, to 42,381 units.
G.M. sold 91,235 cars in mid-July, down 13.4 percent. The company's light-truck sales declined 10.4 percent, to 47,789 units.
The Chrysler Corporation's car sales declined 17.9 percent, to 20,052 units. Sales of Chrysler's light trucks, mini-vans and Jeeps also dropped 16.7 percent, to 25,295 units.

HEADLINE: 5 Years May Be Needed To Close Savings Cases

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 24

 BODY:
Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, criticized for his sluggish response to the savings and loan crisis, told a Senate panel today that the Justice Department will need at least five years to prosecute the most serious cases of fraud at 100 institutions on its priority list.
''I have settled on a ballpark figure of about five years of sustained effort,'' said Mr. Thornburgh, who testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee. ''By 1995, we should perhaps be winding down and transferring resources to other areas.'' 
Mr. Thornburgh's remarks today were his first public comments on how long it would take the department to make a significant impact on the huge backlog of investigations into criminal fraud that contributed to the nation's huge financial crisis.
He has been attacked by some Democrats in Congress for failing to move aggressively enough against savings and loan fraud, but he insisted today that the department was waging a ''relentless'' offensive against criminal wrongdoing in the industry.
 
Early Results
He said investigations of the 100 institutions selected by bank regulators, prosecutors and investigators had already produced results. To date, the department has indicted 51 people associated with these institutions and has convicted 39.
The successful prosecution of the 100 institutions would still leave more than 200 big savings and loans that are also considered likely targets for large-scale prosecution efforts. Investigative efforts against these institutions are also under way, but the priority cases will receive additional personnel and closer supervision by Justice Department officials in Washington.
Mr. Thornburgh acknowledged that the department's decision to concentrate efforts on large cases involving ''major rip-off artists who squandered billions of dollars'' would mean that many fraud cases involving small amounts might be turned over to local prosecutors, reduced to civil suits or in some cases never be prosecuted at all.
Mr. Thornburgh, whose testimony was cut short when the panel recessed for a vote on the Senate floor, did not deliver a portion of his prepared remarks commenting on legislation pending in Congress intended to enhance the department's prosecution efforts. In the undelivered part of his testimony, Mr. Thornburgh criticized a proposal in a bill pending before the House that would create a national commission on financial fraud.
 
Proposed Commission
The 12-member commission, with four members each appointed by the Administration, the House and the Senate, would be charged with investigating the roots of the crisis and would also be responsible for recommending solutions and new prosecution strategies.
''Apart from the constitutional problems brought about by the hybrid nature of the commission's membership, we think parallel investigations of S.&L. fraud, in which the same witnesses are sought and the same issues are investigated, raise dangers,'' he said in his prepared remarks. ''It would serve little benefit for a commission to track our activities.''
Mr. Thornburgh also criticized a proposal included in a House appropriations measure that would allow the Secret Service, an arm of the Treasury Department, to investigate financial fraud. The proposal has touched off a behind-the-scenes turf war with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which now has exclusive juridiction over investigations of savings and loan fraud.

Robson, center, and John Richmond referred to charts of statistics on savings and loan institutions yesterday before testifying at a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing. Mr. Richmond is a special counsel to the Deputy Attorney General for financial institution fraud. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Sears Reports a 29% Drop In Earnings for 2d Quarter

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 24

 BODY:
As it said it would several weeks ago, Sears, Roebuck & Company today reported disappointing second-quarter earnings, making already skeptical analysts even more concerned about the company's future.
Sears said earnings from continuing operations plunged 29 percent, to $237.9 million, or 69 cents a share, from $334.9 million, or 95 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier. Revenues rose 4.3 percent, essentially no more than inflation, to $13.9 billion from $13.3 billion. 
Part of Sears's earnings problems come from its Allstate Insurance Group, which suffered an unexpectedly large buildup in claims after the recent fires in Southern California. Allstate's income from continuing operations fell to $142.2 million from $199.8 million.
But analysts considered Allstate's big payouts a one-time event. They focused instead on Sears's core retailing operations, where, they said, the results appeared far more troubling.
 
New Retail Strategy
Analysts said Sears's new merchandising strategy, announced with much fanfare in early 1989, does not appear to be working. One leg of that strategy was to introduce name brands - everything from General Electric appliances to Pirelli tires -into Sears stores and thereby to increase revenues. In the three months ended June 30, however, store revenues rose only 2.1 percent, to $7.88 billion from $7.71 billion.
Another leg of the Sears strategy was to convert to everyday low pricing. This was supposed to lower costs by reducing the special promotions and advertising that stores must do and by lowering inventory costs. In fact, though, merchandising costs have continued to advance, rising 3.8 percent, to $7.7 billion from $7.4 billion, in the second quarter alone. Sears executives told analysts that much of the increase could be traced to higher training costs associated with remodeled home-improvement departments and to higher advertising expenses that came with the opening of new electronics and automotive departments.
''They were particularly hopeful about increased television sales,'' said L. Wayne Hood of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.
 
Unsuccessful Campaign
But the sales figures released today suggested that Sears's advertising was not particularly successful. Part of the problem may be that consumers over all are showing a skittishness about buying durable goods. But it may also be that there is little to distinguish Brand Central, Sears's remodeled electronics departments, from discount specialty stores like Silo or Circuit City, which offer more variety than Sears does.
The figures ''tell me that they did not get the sales lift they had hoped for,'' said Sidney Doolittle, an industry consultant. ''They spent all that money on advertising and the customers did not come in and buy.''

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Newspaper Company Profits Skid

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Times Mirror Company said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings dropped 44.7 percent from results a year ago that included a gain on a timberlands sale, while the Tribune Company said its profit fell 25 percent in the quarter.
Another large media company, Knight-Ridder Inc., said its net income skidded 64.8 percent for the second quarter from results last year that were inflated by gains on the sale of a newspaper and television stations.
The Washington Post Company said its quarterly earnings fell 7.6 percent, reflecting a weak advertising environment for newspapers and TV stations. 
 
Times Mirror
The publisher of The Los Angeles Times and six other newspapers said it earned $47 million, or 36 cents a share, in the second quarter, compared with $85 million, or 66 cents a share, a year earlier. The 1989 results included a gain of 11 cents a share on the sale of timberlands.
Revenue for the quarter rose 5.3 percent, to $906.6 million from $861.3 million.
Robert F. Erburu, chairman and chief executive, said weak economic conditions continued to adversely affect the company's newspaper and other advertising-driven businesses.
Times Mirror stock fell 12.5 cents, to $29.125 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Tribune Company
The Chicago-based Tribune Company said its earnings fell primarily because of operating losses at The Daily News in New York and a decline in newsprint operating profit.
The company said it earned $56.1 million, or 78 cents a share, in the three months ended June 30, compared with $75.3 million, or 98 cents a share, a year earlier.
Revenue for the quarter rose 2 percent, to $656.2 million from $643.1 million, a year earlier.
The company said its operating profit from newspaper publishing fell 33 percent, mainly because of losses at The Daily News that reflected economic weakness in the New York area and costs of contract negotiations with the paper's labor unions.
Operating profit from the newsprint group fell 83 percent, to $3.1 million, because of lower newsprint selling prices and the adverse impact of a stronger Canadian dollar.
Tribune stock fell 87.5 cents, to $40.25 a share on the Big Board.
 
Knight-Ridder
The Miami-based newspaper and business information services company said it earned $44.6 million, or 88 cents a share, in the quarter ended June 30, compared with $126.8 million, or $2.44 a share, a year earlier.
But the 1989 results were inflated because of gains on the sale of The Pasadena Star-News and television operations. Knight-Ridder said its net income rose 14.3 percent when compared with last year's earnings from ongoing operations.
Revenue was up 2.2 percent to $591.7 million, compared with $578.7 million a year earlier.
Its stock fell 25 cents on the New York Stock Exchange, to $47.75 a share.
 
Washington Post
The owner of The Washington Post newspaper and Newsweek magazine said it earned $55.9 million, or $4.60 a share, for the second quarter compared with $60.5 million, or $4.72 a share, a year earlier.
Second-quarter revenue edged up 1.4 percent, to $379.6 million, from $374.5 million a year earlier.
Newspaper division revenue was off 2 percent as ad volume fell 9 percent at The Washington Post. Newsweek revenue rose 6 percent, with one additional issue published in the second quarter this year.
Washington Post stock fell $3.50 on the Big Board, to $255 a share.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Fall Slightly

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell slightly and interest rates inched higher in light trading yesterday.
Dealers said that worries about how equity investors might react to Monday's steep slide in the stock market, as well as uncertainty about what the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, would say in Congressional testimony served to slow trading.
''There were a lot of good reasons to be on the sidelines,'' one government-bond trader said. ''But the market is pretty soft, and people are beginning to be concerned about upcoming supply.'' 
Today, traders will be asked to place bids on $11.5 billion of new two-year Treasury notes. And late yesterday, the Treasury said it would increase the size of its weekly auctions of three-month and six-month bills to a record $18.4 billion, from $18 billion.
Late yesterday, the notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.11 percent.
 
Inflation Gauge Rises
With one eye on the stock market and the other on Capitol Hill yesterday, market participants shrugged off the release of data showing a rise in labor costs. The Government's employment cost index, an important inflation measure, rose at a 5.2 percent annual rate in the second quarter.
''It was not a number that makes people confident that inflation will fall below 4 percent in the next 12 months,'' said Joseph R. Liro, a vice president and money market economist at S.G. Warburg Securities Inc.
Despite the employment-cost report and some tougher words on inflation from Mr. Greenspan in the second part of his semiannual testimony on monetary policy and the economy, Mr. Liro said that ''the expectation is that the Fed will have to ease policy again sometime in the fall, if not before. That helps short-term rates, but not bonds. The long end has problems with these inflation numbers.''
 
Remarks by Greenspan
In comments delivered to a House Banking subcommittee, Mr. Greenspan said the Fed was still intent on achieving its goal of pushing inflationary pressures close to zero ''within a few years.''
His remarks were in response to a series of questions from Representative Stephen Deal, a North Carolina Democrat, who is sponsoring legislation that would require the Fed to pursue a goal of zero inflation.
Mr. Greenspan's comments were clearly aimed at restoring the Fed's credibility as an inflation fighter in the financial markets. However, many traders said they were not impressed.
''The fact is that the Fed has eased the funds rate to 8 percent, and is more apt to ease credit conditions from here than it is to tighten,'' a trader said. 30-Year Bonds Drop By late yesterday, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 101 25/32, down 11/32, to yield 8.58 percent.
Treasury note prices also dipped, but by not as much.
In late trading, the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 1/4, down 9/32, to yield 8.52 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 18/32, down 7/32, to yield 8.47 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates, which dipped sharply Monday as stock prices fell, moved higher yesterday.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.56 percent late in the day, up 6 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by 2 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.43 percent. And one-year bills were offered at 7.35 percent late yesterday, up 4 basis points.
Aside from an offering of $1.1 billion worth of short-term tax anticipation notes by New York City, activity in the tax-exempt municipal bond market was slow, dealers said.
Participants in the municipal bond market said that prices of most widely quoted issues rose by about 1/8 point.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, prices of most issues dipped by about 1/8 point, dealers said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Weakens as Worries On Interest Rates Continue

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar weakened yesterday against key foreign currencies in worldwide trading.
Currency dealers said continued concerns about interest rates helped push the dollar lower. However, technical factors, along with reports of an Iraqi troop buildup along the Kuwaiti border, helped temper its fall, they added. The dollar is often seen as a safe haven in times of political turmoil. 
The markets were paying particular attention yesterday to testimony by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, before a House Banking subcommittee. He said a ''credible and enforceable'' budget deficit agreement could bring about lower interest rates in the financial markets. But he warned that the Fed would not move to accelerate a drop in rates unless it was assured that inflation was under control.
Lower interest rates tend to bring down the value of a currency.
In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar rose to a closing 148.70 Japanese yen, from 148.50 yen on Monday. It traded at 148.35 yen in London and at 148.40 yen in New York, up from 148.12 yen.
The dollar was mixed against the British pound compared with Monday. Sterling rose to $1.8250 from $1.8215 in London, and fell to $1.8140 from $1.8255 in New York.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday's levels, included: 1.62075 German marks, down from 1.62225; 1.3785 Swiss francs, down from 1.3815; 5.4365 French francs, down from 5.4410; 1.15655 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15545, and 1,186.00 Italian lire, down from 1,187.50.
In the precious metals market, gold prices ended lower after rising overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $367.90 a troy ounce, off $1.20 from late Monday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $367.25 an ounce, down 90 cents.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $368.25 an ounce, from $368.15 late Monday. In Zurich, gold rose to $368.35 an ounce from $367.75.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose by $6.97 to close at $369.25 an ounce.
Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $$4.811 a troy ounce, down 7.1 cents from late Monday. Silver rose in London to $4.85 an ounce from $4.90.

HEADLINE: A Pop(ulist) Quiz;
This man is:
 (a) A designer of Nixon's 'Southern strategy'
 (b) The Democrats' next Presidential candidate
 (c) Kevin Phillips
 (d) All of the above

BYLINE: By Eric Alterman; Eric Alterman, a senior fellow of the World Policy Institute, is writing a book about Washington pundits.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Move over, Mario. Take a hike, Teddy. Amscray, Albert. The Democratic Party has found a new standard-bearer. He's young and a master of the nine-second sound bite.
What's more, he seems to have developed a deep understanding of and compassion for exactly that group of voters the party needs most: middle-class working men and women. The guy's new book is a cinch to take the party into the White House next time around. There's just one problem: he's a conservative Republican. 
Kevin Phillips, author of ''The Politics of Rich and Poor,'' is riding one of the periodic waves that hits Washington whenever everyone agrees to pretend they have read the same book. (My former professor, Paul Kennedy, author of ''The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers,'' is now a millionaire owing to this phenomenon.) Known to Washington insiders as the diabolical political genius behind Richard Nixon's racially divisive ''Southern strategy'' in 1968, Mr. Phillips is enjoying a revival as the tribune of a racially inclusive economic populism. It is as if Niccolo Machiavelli had published a book on how to overthrow an unjust prince.
Mr. Phillips's book details the ravages inflicted upon honest working people during the Reagan years while fat cats yukked it up with their newly undertaxed incomes. This ''plutographic revolution,'' in Mr. Phillips's words, has led to ''so many Americans making so much money that the term 'millionaire' became meaningless.'' The rest of us saw our tax bites rise as our real income fell.
The author predicts a populist counter-revolution, if Democratic politicians are savvy enough to lead it. His tome quickly knocked George Will's out of the top slot of The Washington Post best-seller list, making its author a hot property on the talk show circuit. While the book has been favorably reviewed, none of its literary judges can hope to match the level of enthusiasm generated for it by the nation's top Democrats.
Governor Cuomo thinks ''every American should read this book.'' The House Democratic majority leader, Richard Gephardt, says, ''Mr. Phillips understands what the last 10 years have meant to working people.'' His colleague, Representative David Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin, a leading populist voice, wistfully notes that Mr. Phillips has written ''the kind of book you'd expect to be written by a Democrat.''
In fact, it has. Liberal Democratic economists have been making the same argument for years, while having trouble getting arrested.
In October 1986, a labor-funded think-tank, the Economic Policy Institute, issued a report showing that ''the real income of the average American household had been stag-nant for a decade.'' In early 1988, the liberal economists Bennett Harrison and Barry Bluestone published a book-length study establishing that ''for every affluent 'yuppie' in an expensive big-city condominium . . . there are many more people whose wages have been falling and whose families are finding it more and more difficult to make ends meet.''
The Harvard political scientist Robert Reich was whispering these phrases into Michael S. Dukakis's ear at virtually every campaign stop during the 1988 election. The candidate took the dimunitive Mr. Reich's advice only with regard to making ''short'' jokes.
During 1988, the media punditocracy deemed Representative Gephardt's campaign populism incredible owing to its utter lack of precedent in the candidate's career. The Rev. Jesse Jackson won millions of primary votes decrying the ''economic violence'' of the Reagan years, but party power brokers were so frightened by the Republican Party chairman Lee Atwater's new and improved version of Mr. Phillips's Southern strategy that they considered Mr. Jackson's success cause for alarm rather than encouragement.
Why, then, does the party suddenly seem open to ideas it has treated contemptuously for so long?
Part of the answer lies in Mr. Phillips's exquisite timing. As Americans face paying zillions of tax dollars for the fat cat orgy known as the savings and loan crisis, the blood pressure of the body politic rises precipitously. The fall of the Berlin Wall and the unmasking of the Soviet bogeyman have helped Americans assess the damage that the Reagan military build-up and soak-the-poor tax policies have inflicted on the country.
But more important is the complexion of the messenger. The original avatars of Democratic economic populism were exactly those elements of the party from which the hypercautious leadership sought to distance itself: organized labor, liberal activists and Mr. Jackson's ''Rainbow coalition.'' What the Democrats' belated embrace of Mr. Phillips's little-guy populist appeal illustrates is nothing so much as a party that is afraid of itself.
Back in 1981, Democratic strategists decided to compete with Reagan Republicans for corporate political-action committees and high-finance millionaires. As a result, when economic populism was presented by loyal members of the Democratic family, the party, like good Groucho Marxists, wanted nothing to do with anyone willing to be a member of it.
Excluding last year's capital gains fight, most Democrats have gingerly avoided raising the populist question of unfair taxation. They have refused to embrace Daniel Patrick Moynihan's initiative to reduce regressive Social Security taxes and they've disparaged Mr. Jackson's coalition-building efforts at every turn.
Above all, party leaders fear being accused by media pundits of waging ''class warfare.'' But the media do not elect Presidents, the American people do. And they are angry.
The only thing worse than fighting a class war in America is losing one without even fighting. Kevin Phillips has given the party a sword. Like the cowardly lion in the Wizard of Oz, all it needs now is a little courage.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kevin Phillips (D. Gordon for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 3 Detained Lawyers Released In Kenya but Not 3 Politicians

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 25

 BODY:
The Kenyan Government today released three lawyers detained without charges three weeks ago but kept in prison three politicians detained in the same crackdown on advocates of political pluralism.
Up to 10 other people, including former university lecturers and politicians, were detained two weeks ago and remain in jail.
The releases came as President Daniel arap Moi, an unrelenting opponent of a multiparty political system, seemed to be searching for a way to ease the political tensions inside the country and pressures from outside. 
Some Western donors, including the United States, have said aid money to Kenya will be in jeopardy unless detainees are released and movement is made toward opening up the one-party system. Congress has already frozen about $13 million of this year's aid allocation of $46 million to Kenya. #20 Killed in Riots Riots in Nairobi and rural centers over the detentions of the multiparty advocates killed 20 people, the Government has said. Church organizations say they believe the casualties were significantly higher.
Those released today were Gitobu Imanyara, editor in chief of The Nairobi Law Monthly, John Khaminwa and Mohammed Ibrahim, lawyers in private law firms in Nairobi.
Two former ministers in the Kenyan Government who have led the debate for a multiparty state, Kenneth Matiba and Charles Rubia, remain in detention. Raila Odinga, the son of Kenya's first Vice President, Oginga Odinga, was not released either.
One of the freed lawyers, Mr. Ibrahim, said he had been kept in isolation in the city jail after his arrest on July 5. In a telephone interview after his release, he said he was told on the night of his arrest that he had plotted with Mr. Matiba and Mr. Rubia to ''overthrow the Government and form another political party.''
''I was never involved in any such thing,'' he said. He had represented Mr. Rubia in a case involving the confiscation of the politician's passport, he said.
The United States Embassy, which has been outspoken in condemning the arrests, indicated it was pleased but not totally satisfied. ''We hope the cases of those remaining in custody can be resolved rapidly,'' the embassy said in a statement.
 
Moi Meets With Lawyer
In the first sign that Mr. Moi was seeking to ease tensions, he met on Tuesday with a prominent lawyer, Paul Muite, who had gone into hiding after the detentions three weeks ago. Mr. Muite represents the two leaders of the de facto opposition, Mr. Matiba and Mr. Rubia.
Mr. Muite told colleagues after the meeting with the President that Mr. Moi had told him there is ''no money in the country.'' This was apparently a reference to a serious shortage of foreign exchange in the last several months. Nearly one-third of Kenya's budget is made up of direct foreign aid, and cuts in that would have serious consequences in a weak economy.
Three days of rioting over the detentions in early July resulted in a slump in tourism, Kenya's largest foreign-exchange earner. The cancellation last week of the conference of the International Bar Association scheduled for September, on the grounds of the safety of its members and the political detentions, was another blow to tourism.

HEADLINE: Pessimism Over Budget Talks Grows

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
White House and Congressional negotiators worked separately to prepare deficit-cutting proposals today amid growing pessimism among many Democrats that an agreement on next year's Federal budget could be reached any time soon.
The negotiators are aiming for a combination of spending cuts and tax increases that would reduce the deficit in that budget by $50 billion, to about $120 billion, not counting the cost of the savings and loan bailout. They also hope to agree on steps that would produce a balanced budget by 1995, two years later than the target now set by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law.
But the proposals, which could be exchanged as early as Thursday, are expected to underscore sharp differences between Democrats and Republicans over how the spending cuts should be apportioned between military and domestic programs, and over the size and the nature of tax increases. 
 
'Some Final Conclusion'
''I don't expect that any of these packages that will come out in the next few days will be the ending point,'' Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, told reporters as he left a White House meeting with President Bush and other top Congressional leaders this morning. ''But they'll be specific ideas that could be moved over a period of time -and it doesn't have to be a long period of time - to some final conclusion.''
But Mr. Gephardt appeared to be far more optimistic than most of his Democratic colleagues. By the time Democratic negotiators had huddled for several hours on Capitol Hill to draft their plan, it was unclear whether they would even have one to offer.
''The only news coming out of this meeting is that Democrats have not agreed to a plan,'' said Senator Jim Sasser of Tennessee, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee. Mr. Sasser, in comments echoed by other Democratic negotiators, said his colleagues were hesitant to put forward an offer without knowing how serious a proposal would come from the Bush Administration and without some sense of whether the White House really wanted an agreement before the lawmakers leave town in August for a monthlong Congressional recess.
''My deep concern is that if you start and don't finish'' before the recess, ''you'll have every interest group out there pounding on us and the proposals,'' said Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee.
 
Opposition Is Aired
That fear appears to be well founded. Even as the Democratic negotiators were meeting - and while the White House budget director, Richard G. Darman, was reviewing the Administration's ideas with Mr. Bush - lobbying groups and lawmakers from both parties were lining up to declare their opposition to some of the tax increases likely to be included in the proposal of one side or the other.
For instance, members of New York's Congressional delegation called a news conference to make clear that they could not support a package that included restrictions on the Federal deduction for state and local income taxes, and to assert that a tax on securities transactions would be devastating to Wall Street, New York City and the American economy. The proposals are on a list of tax options that Mr. Darman and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady have discussed with Mr. Bentsen and Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the House Ways and Means Committee.
When the possibility of eliminating or reducing the deduction for state and local income taxes was first disclosed last week, budget negotiators described it as a step that would apply only to upper-income taxpayers. But exactly which taxpayers would be deemed upper income has not been defined, and in attacking the proposal today the New York delegation held out the specter that the negotiators might allow it to apply to millions of people who consider themselves middle class.
The delegation, citing figures provided by the Joint Committee on Taxation, said that more than half the nation's taxpayers who claim the deduction for state and local income taxes earn less than $50,000 a year and that 88 percent earn less than $100,000 a year.
 
'President on Notice'
''We want to put the President on notice that if this is included as part of the solution, we will find it impossible to support,'' Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Manhattan Democrat, said of the proposal.
Representative Raymond J. McGrath, a Long Island Republican, said he had written to the White House Chief of Staff, John H. Sununu, to urge that any such idea be rejected. ''I cannot vote for any budget agreement that further restricts the few tax benefits available to average families,'' he said.
New York's Democratic Senator, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, said restrictions on the deduction would have ''an altogether disproportionate impact on states that have chosen to get their revenues from a progressive tax.'' More than 40 percent of New York's revenue is derived from income taxes, and Mr. Moynihan said that other states that would be hard hit included California, Massachusetts and New Jersey.
New York's Republican Senator, Alfonse M. D'Amato. said: ''It's unconscionable to penalize taxpayers in communities who seek to provide a higher level of services to their citizens. The largest percentage of those taxes are paid to support education.''
Opponents of other tax changes that may be included in the deficit-reduction plans have also been gearing up their lobbying efforts. On Tuesday, the American Petroleum Institute and the National Association of Manufacturers held a news conference to warn of dire consequences for American businesses if lawmakers choose the broad-based energy tax that has been suggested by the Administration.
The Anheuser Busch Company has been running television commercials aimed at drumming up public opposition to increases in excise taxes on beer. A rise in excise taxes for all types of alcohol and for cigarettes are widely expected to be included in the Administration's and Democrats' proposals.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Federal Reserve's Chairman Blends Eye for Politics With Fiscal Skills

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
An admiring colleague says Alan Greenspan at his desk, his coat off, hunched in front of his computer screen and pouring over economic data, resembles an archeologist studying the latest find in hieroglyphics or a mathematician proving a theorem.
Nowadays, the Federal Reserve Board chairman is paying equally close attention to political information. And his success, even his survival, as the most influential economic policy maker in the Government may hinge as much on his keen eye for politics as it does on his mastery of unemployment rates, housing starts and price indexes.
His four-year term as chairman is up next year. His two immediate predecessors lost their posts because of differences with the White House over whether to accelerate or brake the national economy. Mr. Greenspan, now 64 years old, will not say publicly whether he wants to be reappointed. But this is the job for which he trained for his entire career, and few people doubt he wants to keep it. 
The chairman has close ties with the Republicans, having worked in several Presidential campaigns over the last quarter century, although he says his fascination is with public policy, not partisan politics.
 
Avoiding the 'Sharp Edges'
''Even during political campaigns I was uncomfortable with the sharp edges of partisan politics,'' he said recently. ''I have always thought, perhaps ingenuously, that it is important that protagonists seek to reconcile their differences.''
Nonetheless, rare for a Wall Street economist, he has many close friends in politics. Every couple of weeks he has lunch with one of them: Robert S. Strauss, the former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, who may have more connections in Washington than the White House switchboard.
''He never says anything about his business,'' Mr. Strauss said. ''But he picks me dry for everything I know about mine.''
Mr. Strauss continued: ''Alan Greenspan is a great listener, and he exposes himself to people who know what's going on in this town, who are moving around the town, and he knows how to digest that information. His political antenna is always up. He's very sensitive to what's taking place politically on the Hill, in the executive branch, in the media, and that's a tremendous strength for a person in his position.''
 
Many Political Connections
Mr. Greenspan regularly picks the minds of other political figures as well: Howard H. Baker Jr., the former Senate Republican leader and White House chief of staff; William E. Brock 3d, another former Senator from Tennessee, who was Republican national chairman and served in the Reagan Cabinet as the United States trade representative and later as Secretary of Labor; Robert Teeter, President Bush's poll taker; Felix G. Rohatyn, the New York investment banker, who is active in Democratic Party circles.
Mr. Greenspan plays golf with Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and tennis with Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. He has known Richard G. Darman, the budget director, since they worked together in the Ford Administration. And possibly most important, he has been close to Mr. Bush for years, although, by his own choice, he rarely sees the President one on one these days.
If Mr. Bush should decide not to reappoint Mr. Greenspan, he will be breaking a fundamental law of politics about rewarding one's friends. In 1980 he worked for Mr. Bush in the Republican primaries, and shifted his allegiance to Ronald Reagan only after Mr. Bush dropped out.
''There is an Administration in Washington with a lot of people who are friends of his,'' Mr. Rohatyn said. ''He has friends in Congress, too. So he comes to the table with a network of communications that is very helpful to him. Certainly Paul Volcker didn't come to the table with that, and I'm not sure anyone else in their position ever has.''
 
Pressure to Ease Credit
Mr. Volcker was not reappointed chairman of the Federal Reserve by Mr. Reagan in 1987. Mr. Greenspan was appointed instead, because the White House believed Mr. Volcker would keep too heavy a foot on the economic brakes in the 1988 election campaign. Under Mr. Greenspan, the Reserve raised interest rates steadily from March to July 1988, but did not do so again until December.
In the last few months Mr. Greenspan has been under constant pressure from the Administration to ease credit, but he has hardly relented.
He agrees that his political connections are an advantage as he tries to navigate the perilous political course. ''I know all the people,'' he said recently. ''I know the Democrats as well. I have a lot of friends on both sides of the aisle.''
For more than 30 years, Mr. Greenspan owned a highly successful economic consulting firm on Wall Street. Many of the nation's leading business executives were his clients, and he maintans contacts with them today.
But he has been involved in official Washington off and on since 1968, when he directed domestic policy research for the Nixon Presidential campaign. In 1970 he became a consultant to the Council of Economic Advisers, and from 1974 to 1977, with Gerald R. Ford in the White House, he was the Council's chairman.
 
Panel on Social Security
At the 1980 Republican National Convention Mr. Greenspan was a Ford-Reagan emissary when there was talk about Mr. Ford becoming Mr. Reagan's running mate.
In 1982 and 1983 he was chairman of a bipartisan commission on Social Security named by President Reagan and Congressional leaders that performed what seemed like a miracle at the time, forging a political compromise that put the retirement system on a sound economic footing.
In many respects Mr. Greenspan has relied as much on his personality over the years as on his skill as an economist. He has the unusual capacity to seem both confident and modest, to be outgoing in social situations and yet appear disarmingly shy.
At least in Washington, Mr. Greenspan, a bachelor whose regular companion is Andrea Mitchell, the Congressional correspondent for NBC News, seems to have no enemies.
Unlike some other economists who have been chairman of the Federal Reserve, including Mr. Volcker and Arthur F. Burns, who served in the Nixon Administration, Mr. Greenspan seems to have limitless patience. In his Congressional testimony he responds evenhandedly to questions mindless or astute.
While Mr. Greenspan is one of the few top officials besides Supreme Court Justices who almost always refuse to grant on-the-record interviews, he is willing to spend hours with reporters explaining the fine points of economics and his own views so long as he is not quoted.
 
Comity and Collegiality
''He never talks down to anybody, and you rarely meet someone who's so very able who's like that,'' said James T. Lynn, chairman of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, who was budget director in the Ford Administration when Mr. Greenspan was head of the Council of Economic Advisers.
On the Federal Reserve Board Mr. Greenspan has restored a comity and collegiality in discussion that was absent for much of Mr. Volcker's tenure. The votes on raising or lowering interest rates since he became chairman have been close to unanimous. Regularly, he has postponed actions until nearly all his colleagues were ready to move in the direction he wanted.
Some Administration officials and economists call this style indecisive rather than merely cautious, but Mr. Greenspan disagrees. ''You can lead an organization through persuasion or formal edict,'' he said the other day. ''I have never found the arbitrary use of authority to control an organization either effective or, for that matter, personally interesting. If you cannot persuade your colleagues of the correctness of your position, it is probably worthwhile to rethink your own.''
Wayne D. Angell, one of the swing votes on the board, said the chairman's greatest strength was his ability to judge people. ''He had a book on Wayne Angell very quickly,'' Mr. Angell said. ''He knew where I was and what I deemed important.''
 
A Maestro of Harmony
Mr. Angell suggested that perhaps Mr. Greenspan learned this talent at the Juilliard School of Music where, as a budding clarinetist and saxophonist, he studied for two years before switching to New York University to study economics.
''Maybe he learned the role of the conductor,'' Mr. Angell said. ''It's almost as if he provides cues to people. There's a flow to the discussion, a flow to the debate, and he will guide it like an orchestra conductor in the direction he wants it to go in.''
Mr. Greenspan's political skills are rarely so much on display as when he goes before Congress, as he did this week and last. He bobbed and weaved, telling lawmakers who asked him about prospects for an economic downturn that he, too, feared the economy was too sluggish, and telling those more concerned about inflation that he still considered fighting inflation his No. 1 priority.
On the one hand, he sympathized with people who find it hard to get loans. On the other, he said he did not observe a ''credit crunch.''
After two days of testimony, no one, not the financial markets and least of all the politicians, could be sure what his real intentions are about raising or lowering interest rates.
Toward the end of his House hearing Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat, realized that it was hopeless to try to pin the chairman down. ''You're getting very, very good,'' Mr. Schumer told him, ''at the art of walking all those little tightropes.''

HEADLINE: Massachusetts Lawmakers Balk at Budget and Re-examine Taxes

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, July 25

 BODY:
Rebelling against the latest attempt to resolve the state's budget crisis, Massachusetts legislators refused to approve a $13.7 billion budget and moved to repeal central elements of a $1.8 billion tax increase that was signed into law last week.
On Tuesday legislators had been expected to pass a budget for the fiscal year 1991, which began July 1. Instead the House proposed another increase in the income tax because, despite last week's increase, the proposed budget remained at least $300 million short of projected revenue. 
State officials said today that Governor Michael S. Dukakis, who has been calling for new taxes since last January, had agreed on Tuesday to reopen debate on the tax revisions because of the Legislature's paralysis on the budget.
To break the stalemate, legislative leaders met today to discuss the possibility of repealing major parts of the tax law, which included the largest increase in the state's history. The new law raised income and gasoline taxes, while extending the sales tax to 594 services that had not been taxed before, like legal and accounting transactions. Business executives have particularly objected to the sales tax expansion, arguing that it would only worsen the state's economic slump.
 
Even Higher Income Taxes
With the support of the Governor, House members proposed to repeal most of the service taxes covered under the new law, with a revenue loss of $174 million. The House proposal would more than compensate for the loss by increasing the income tax rate.
Under the law signed last week, the flat tax on earned income rose to 5.95 percent, from 5.75 percent. Today's House proposal would raise it further, to 6.25 percent this year and 6.5 percent in 1991. Massachusetts income taxes are already among the highest in the country.
After a decade of spectacular economic growth, the state's politicians are struggling to manage as recession has spread in New England. With rising unemployment and slower wage growth, tax collections in Massachusetts fell 3.3 percent last year, the first decrease since 1975.
But political leaders have consistently failed to agree on how to balance the budget. Massachusetts finished the 1990 fiscal year with a $1.2 billion deficit, but has yet to issue bonds to pay for it because of the political stalemate.
In June, Standard and Poor's, the credit-rating agency, warned that the state's rating would fall if the disarray continues. The rating is already the lowest of any state in the country, and one notch away from junk bond status.

HEADLINE: Nicaragua's Economic Slide Led to Strike

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Sandinista Democrats Please Stand Up'' (editorial, July 14), charging that ''If the Sandinistas think their influence in Nicaragua's army, police and unions entitles them to force the elected Government of President Violeta Chamorro to share power, they don't understand what democratic politics is all about,'' shows lack of understanding of Nicaragua and democratic politics.
The Nicaraguan general strike of the last few weeks was a popular reaction against worsening economic conditions since Mrs. Chamorro's installation and her attempts to initiate economic and social policies favoring the wealthy classes over the poor. Many of the poor, made miserable, not by Sandinista ''failed economic policies,'' but by 10 years of United States military and economic aggression, had voted for Mrs. Chamorro in the hope of relief. Disappointed, they acted. Not surprisingly, the Sandinistas, who do understand what democratic politics are about, supported them and made political capital from doing so. 
Chastened, the Chamorro Government - a deeply divided coalition put together with United States money for last year's election - has had to recognize reality. It will have to cease its efforts to govern by extraconstitutional decree and resort, as you recommend, to the National Assembly, where the Sandinistas hold the largest single bloc of seats as a result of that same election.
The Sandinista commitment to the democratic political process stands in contrast to that of many of their now-ruling political opponents. These resorted to a rule-or-ruin policy of noncooperation with either the provisional or elected Sandinista Governments of 1979 to 1990. They collaborated actively with the United States aggression that cost the lives of more than 30,000 of their fellow Nicaraguans and caused immeasurable economic destruction.
The Sandinistas, by their behavior in this strike, as during their years of rebellion against the dictatorship of Gen. Anastasio Somoza and while in power, have given a lesson in courage, commitment to principle and democracy.
 
DAVID MACMICHAEL
 Washington, July 14, 1990
The writer is a member of the Association of National Security Alumni.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Let 'Em Eat Cake

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
''In the war on poverty,'' Ronald Reagan often said, ''poverty won.'' That used to be just Reaganite overstatement; but under President Bush, poverty can hardly lose.
Earlier this month, Mr. Bush's Domestic Policy Council decided that he should embark on no new programs or strategies to reduce poverty in America. Instead, a White House official remarked jovially, the Administration would ''keep playing with the same toys. But let's paint them a little shinier.'' 
The council really wanted to help, another compassionate staff man said, but concluded that ''there were no obvious things we should be doing that we weren't doing that would work.''
Nothing obvious? When across the street from the White House the homeless are sleeping in Lafayette Square - and when in most American cities they're clogging the nighttime streets? When in the shadow of the Capitol dome, the poor rummage through garbage cans for something to eat?
Nothing they should be doing? When 32 million Americans are living in poverty? When 39 percent of them are children under 18, white, black and other?
Nothing that would work? When the life expectancy of black men in Harlem is lower than that of men in Bangladesh? When black family income in 1987 was only 56 percent of whites', the biggest gap since the 1960's?
Mr. Bush's council did have before it a few programs (mostly developed by outside experts, of course) that less responsible men might have considered worth trying - for instance, an expanded tax credit for the working poor. And since five million American women are supposed to receive child support payments, but only half of them ever receive the full amount, the council mercifully considered a national standard of child support, with Federal supplements to payments by absent parents.
But the outcome of such misplaced concern was foreordained. As an Administration official remarked: ''We realized we didn't have any cash. . . . It was fun to think about these things but for the time being we concluded that we don't want to do anything new, that we should just make things work better.''
Oh, what fun they must have had, indeed, before settling down patriotically to the grim reality of the bankruptcy and helplessness of Government in a nation barely able to afford $404,566 average annual family income for the richest 1 percent of the population in 1988.
The council did decide to shine up one of President Reagan's toys of that year, a reform he wisely designed to encourage welfare recipients to find jobs. The council did not say what jobs, nor specify other Reagan initiatives that might be polished - for instance, those that resulted in 19.7 percent of American children under 18 living in poverty in 1988.
Don't think the council was merely callous. Officials were well aware, they said, that a major ''investment in children'' would have a big payoff in the long run. The trouble was that such an investment - unlike, say, money spent on the Strategic Defense Initiative - was ''not likely to show an immediate reward.'' And though the family planning clinics that the council thought about proposing might well have reduced teen-age pregnancies, they would also ''cost money'' and might be seen as ''encouraging promiscuity.'' Not on George Bush's watch!
Perhaps among things to be made to ''work better'' are the farsighted Reagan-Bush policies that have led to astonishing changes in U.S. family income. Why tamper with a system that caused the average family income of the poorest 10 percent of Americans to fall 10.5 percent between 1977 and 1987, while the average family income of the wealthiest 1 percent rose 74.2 percent in the same years? Mr. Bush's Domestic Council knows a good thing when it sees it.
But no ''glitzy, splashy, high-profile'' new programs, like Lyndon Johnson's War on Poverty, need apply. After all, that high-profile approach only reduced the infant mortality rate by 33 percent between 1965 and 1975, and among blacks from 40.3 percent to 24.2 percent. Scarcely worth doing.
And where one in five Americans once had endured poverty, by 1980 all Johnson's glitzy efforts (many of them continued by Richard Nixon, Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter) had reduced that figure to only 1 in 15. Only 44 percent of poor households -less than half - had been raised above the poverty line by 1972.
Clearly, Mr. Bush and his men believe, another such victory and we are undone.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: OP-ED

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Risks to Cuomo If the Opposition Lacks Credibility

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Despite his self-confidence and his apparent lead in public opinion polls, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo arguably cannot afford to debate his Republican opponent, Pierre A. Rinfret.
It is not that the Governor has been given much reason so far to fear Mr. Rinfret. Rather, the only thing Mr. Cuomo may have to fear is himself. Mr. Rinfret might prove to be such a pushover that the Governor, by going on the offensive, would be branded as a bully.
The usual reasons for avoiding debates apply, too. No incumbent likes to give an underfinanced and unknown challenger more exposure than necessary. In this case, though, the more exposure Mr. Rinfret gets, some contend, the better the Governor might do in November. 
This would be bad for the New York Republican Party, which chose Mr. Rinfret after 19 other potential candidates were approached by party leaders but declined. One measure of Mr. Rinfret's growing self-confidence, or perhaps his gullibility, is his insistence that he was really higher on the list than 19th.
Mr. Rinfret's failure to mount a credible campaign could deny the Governor a grilling that would better prepare him for a Presidential campaign. It could deny the voters an overdue comparison between Mr. Cuomo's lofty oratory and his record, which has been more down to earth.
Mr. Rinfret, an economic consultant, is not New York's first gubernatorial candidate who is not a professional politician. The last to run was Lewis E. Lehrman, whom Mr. Cuomo narrowly defeated in 1982. The last to win was Nelson A. Rockefeller, who was first elected in 1958.
Mr. Rinfret's criticism of Mr. Cuomo's spending priorities faintly echoes the Democrats' criticism of Mr. Rockefeller.
What, Mr. Rinfret was asked in an interview, was the difference between the two Governors? ''Rockefeller was a Republican,'' Mr. Rinfret quipped.
When pressed as to which government functions he might shed to close projected budget gaps, he suggested only that registering of motor vehicles and testing of civil servants be spun off to private companies. He said existing departments could perform more efficiently, but he declined to recommend that the total state budget be cut.
Mr. Rinfret insisted that he was not being evasive. As evidence, he suggested that the same question be posed to the Governor. ''I'll bet you get the same answers,'' Mr. Rinfret said.
He prefers, if he is to be compared to other aspirants who appear to have come out of nowhere, to be considered in the same category as Ronald Reagan, who metamorphosed from ''a grade B movie actor,'' in Mr. Rinfret's words, to Governor of California, and Donald H. Souter, the New Hampshire judge who is President Bush's choice for the Supreme Court.
Mr. Rinfret is not the first inexperienced candidate to say that business and politics are largely interchangeable, which is consistent with his philosophy of trying to capitalize on a perceived liability.
But he acknowledged that the political arena may be more partisan than the private sector. Moreover, he has already learned that in politics and government there is more emotion, with more people looking over your shoulder and less attention to the future.
Last year, Rudolph W. Giuliani, another political neophyte, had several months to bone up on municipal government before he declared his candidacy for mayor of New York City. Mr. Rinfret's tutorial began only eight weeks ago after he had already been designated by the Republican State Committee.
It shows. He answers many questions vaguely. There are others to which he acknowledges, in what further distinguishes him from professional candidates, that he does not know the answer or has not yet made up his mind. Refreshingly, he is also unfettered by many traditional boundaries of campaign discourse. He was cautious enough, in complaining that offensive behavior had gone unchecked at an annual ethnic parade in New York City, not to say which one.
But Mr. Rinfret complained that when he questions the way government is run, ''everybody's got an answer as to why you can't ask a question.''
Mr. Rinfret hopes to pose those questions directly to Mr. Cuomo. If the Governor insists, Mr. Rinfret would agree to debates that also include the Conservative and Right to Life Party nominees, although he dismisses their candidacies as not viable.
''We're going to beat him,'' Mr. Rinfret said of Mr. Cuomo. ''Watch.''
Some surveys have hinted that Mr. Cuomo could be vulnerable to a challenge by a viable opponent. Whether he will have one by November is debatable.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk
