HEADLINE: For Dinkins, Ballroom's Fate Is Emotional and Sensitive Issue

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Blocks from the apartment where he raised his children, a somber hulk of a building, rich with history and once stained with blood, haunts Mayor David N. Dinkins these days. It embodies a hero of his past and his hopes for his old neighborhood's future, challenging him to balance the two.
Of course, that is not how Mr. Dinkins or most others saw it when New York City and Columbia University made plans to build a $25 million commercial biomedical laboratory on the site of the Audubon Theater and Ballroom in Washington Heights, where Malcolm X was assassinated in 1965. The building is across Broadway from the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, site of the Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons.
 
Focus of Controversy
But the ballroom has become the focus of a controversy that illuminates the special difficulties of a mayor who is a self-professed expert in the politics of conciliation and consensus, and it has been cited by disparate groups as a test of everything from his policy on development to his loyalty to his race. 
From the beginning, the new building was to include a memorial to the slain civil rights leader, whose reputation has risen since his death with some who were uneasy about him while he was alive. One early plan would have preserved the 1912 structure, which also happens to be where William Fox began building the empire that became 20th Century Fox. Columbia eventually deemed that idea too costly and moved to tear the old building down.
As Manhattan Borough President, Mr. Dinkins backed the plan, which had evoked no great outcry and was sponsored by Mayor Edward I. Koch.
 
A Storm of Criticism
But as he took office as Mayor, and the project moved closer to approval, Mr. Dinkins met a storm of criticism over the future of the Audubon, where once crowds danced to the music of Latin orchestras, where Mike Quill held early organizing meetings for the Transport Workers Union, a ballroom that has even been the site for boxing bouts.
Last month, the Dinkins administration agreed to preserve about 40 percent of the ballroom, including the stage where the Muslim leader was shot.
Now, a month before the city's Board of Estimate is to take final action on the project before the board is eliminated under the new City Charter, a debate pitting the city, Columbia and some of Mr. Dinkins's political supporters against each other is still raging. At one extreme are those who say preserving anything less than all of the ballroom would amount to desecration, while others say forcing more changes now could unravel the entire project.
''It's an issue of peculiar political sensitivity for this Mayor,'' said Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, Mr. Dinkins's Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development.
''The issue for us is how do we strike a compromise as it relates to architecture and to Malcolm,'' said another senior mayoral aide.
 
A Blurred Debate
In fact, the debate is blurred, with preservation groups and civil rights advocates in an unusual alliance in which each occasionally uses the arguments of the other to buttress its claims. The local community board and the local City Councilman, Stanley E. Michels, back the project, which would employ 500 construction workers and 300 permanent employees.
In the middle of the argument is Richard D. Emery, a Manhattan civil rights lawyer who represents the Sugar Hill Historical Society, which wants the building preserved. Mr. Emery brought the lawsuit that led the United States Supreme Court to declare the Board of Estimate's voting structure unconstitutional last year, and he is now in the position of lobbying the body he helped to doom.
Mr. Emery's clients back a proposal crafted under the aegis of the Municipal Art Society in late spring that would preserve the entire ballroom and the distinctive terra-cotta facade of the building on Broadway between West 165th and 166th Streets. But mayoral aides and Columbia officials say this option would be too costly and not practical at this stage.
 
'Just Ludicrous'
Charles A. Platt, an architect and former member of the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission who drafted the Art Society proposal, said the city's current plan to save a jutting portion of the ballroom building, and build the new laboratory around it to the north, was ''just ludicrous.''
''It's being mutilated rather than being saved,'' he said, adding that it would also be costly to shore up the old building while one piece was saved.
Michael Henry Adams, a preservation consultant who works for City Councilwoman C. Virginia Fields of neighboring Harlem, said her goal was to preserve enough of the Audubon to enable it to be designated a landmark. He said that the city's plan was ''laughable'' and that what would be left of the Audubon could not merit landmark designation.
''It's perhaps the most important African-American landmark in the city that isn't designated,'' he said. ''She absolutely believes it's worthy of designation and ought to be.''
Kent L. Barwick, a former chairman of the Landmarks Commission who is now president of the Art Society, said the commission's staff had discussed the building's importance in the early 1980's but never scheduled a hearing on it because city officials assured him that it would be preserved as part of any new development.
Driving the debate is the Board of Estimate's impending demise. Columbia, which began the project eight years ago, was eager to have it approved before the board went out of business. While Columbia has reached agreement in principle with the city on preserving part of the ballroom, and while city officials say they expect the university to contribute, it is still unsettled who will pay the extra costs involved, estimated at between $3 million and $5 million.
 
Money From Public Agencies
Public agencies are already contributing the bulk of the cost, with the city's Public Development Corporation committing $10 million, the State Urban Development Corporation, $8 million, and Columbia, $4.5 million in equity and $2.2 million in borrowing.
A pivotal figure is Mr. Dinkins's successor as Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger. She supports the plan's economic development goals, in which Columbia would lease space in the new six-story building to companies doing research in such fields as molecular biophysics, genetics, immunology and cancer.
But Ms. Messinger is also concerned about preservation and dissatisfied with the current compromise, and she does not want to contribute capital funds at her disposal to help finance it, as the city would like. She said she generally prefers the Art Society's alternative but is not ''slavishly wedded to it.''
Ms. Messinger also holds something of a bargaining chip since $8 million from the Urban Development Corporation is to be passed on from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. As Borough President, she has until Aug. 4 to exercise veto power over such plans.
But city officials and her own aides concede that Ms. Messinger hopes to avoid that possibility by crafting a new compromise.
''My feeling is it will get resolved,'' Ms. Hernandez-Pinero said. H. Bernhard Haeckel, director of project development for Columbia, said even obtaining detailed cost estimates for the Art Society proposal would take two more years of study. The society's proposal would also shift the new building to the southeast corner of the site, where Columbia hopes to build another building eventually.
 
'An Important Point'
''That is an important point because the enormous effort that is being put into this for this relatively small building of 100,000 square feet can only be justified, if and when that building proves to be successful, if there's a possibility to expand,'' Mr. Haeckel said.
Hanging over the dispute, some city officials acknowlegded, is lingering bitterness in Harlem over Columbia's unsuccessful attempt two decades ago to build a gymnasium in Morningside Park. But other officials said Columbia has tried to compromise this time, pledging to double an existing $250,000 Malcolm X scholarship as a living memorial and winning the wary support of Malcolm's widow, Dr. Betty Shabazz.
Mr. Dinkins himself has tried to stay above the fray lately, though he did exchange sharp words with a young woman and her friend who questioned him about the project after an appearance at Columbia in May.
''Remember you are an African,'' the woman said, prompting the Mayor to whirl and retort, ''Listen, I was black before you two were born!''
Last week he said the problem was finding a way to pay to save even part of the ballroom. But he said of Malcolm X, whose speeches he often quotes, ''I think it is important that generations to come understand the contributions that he made.''

HEADLINE: Chronicle

BYLINE: By ROBERT E. TOMASSON

 BODY:
Officials of the Koch administration continue their transition to the private sector. JAMES P. STUCKEY who, as president of the New York City Public Development Corporation from 1986 through 1989, managed a multibillion-dollar portfolio of city-sponsored commercial and industrial projects, will be the managing director of Gronich & Company, a real-estate brokerage and services organization in Manhattan. 
Mr. Stuckey was an early stalwart for EDWARD I. KOCH, starting just after Mr. Koch took office as mayor in 1978. At the age of 23, Mr. Stuckey was a personnel worker in the Office of Economic Development at $11,000 a year. He rose to head an agency with 200 employees at a salary of $110,000. He declined to divulge his salary at Gronich.

HEADLINE: June Orders For Durables Fell by 3.2%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
A large drop in demand for military goods like tanks and aircraft lowered orders for durable goods sharply in June in a new sign of economic weakness, the Commerce Department said today.
Orders for durable goods, which are designed to last at least three years, fell by 3.2 percent, or by about $4.1 billion, last month to a seasonally adjusted total of $124.7 billion, nearly wiping out a revised 4.2 percent gain in May orders.
 
Economists Caught Off Guard
The decline was a surprise for economists, who had predicted a slight pickup in orders of four-tenths of a percent. Durables orders are monitored closely because they can affect job opportunities and industrial production in the future. 
''This decline is worrisome, but I wouldn't make it into a recession without seeing a few more numbers,'' said Kathryn Kobe, an economist with Joel Popkin & Company, a Washington forecasting firm. ''
Military orders fell by 21 percent, to $7.99 billion in June, from $10.08 billion in May, after gaining 20 percent in May. That accounted for half of the overall drop in last month's orders, the department said.
The news helped spur a rally in bond prices because of the belief that the new sign of economic weakness would increase the chances for lower interest rates.
Jerry Jordan, the chief economist for the First Interstate Corporation in Los Angeles, said the durables report could have a positive effect by reinforcing the view that interest rates should come down.
The difficulty recently has been that easing rates by the Federal Reserve Board might appear that the central bank is giving up the fight to control inflation, Mr. Jordan noted.
 
Greenspan Reaffirms Stance
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, told Congress on Tuesday that the commitment to curb inflation remained strong and that recent moves to lower interest rates moderately did not mean a shift in policy.
Military orders are typically volatile because of the large dollar volume and long lead times required for completing production. But this sector has come under increased pressure with the reduction of international military tensions, leading to cutbacks in Federal spending plans.
The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, for example, intends to lay off as many as 17,000 employees, or 13 percent of its work force, by the end of the year because of military cuts.
A reduction in durables orders was recorded in nearly every primary category of goods last month, the Commerce Department said.
Transportation orders, which make up 8 percent of total orders, were down by 4.8 percent last month, after a 10.2 percent climb in May. That was a surprise because the Federal Reserve reported last week that industrial production rose by four-tenths of a percent in June after gaining six-tenths of a percent in May, as automobile production increased each month.
 
Drop Despite Boeing's Gains
Most of the decline in transportation orders, the department said, occurred because of lower aircraft orders, which was also unexpected because the Boeing Company, the Seattle-based airplane maker, has been receiving large orders.
Boeing received orders for 67 civilian aircraft in January, 22 in February, 2 in March, 23 in April, 73 in May and 32 in June.
But Boeing also said recently that it would cut 5,600 jobs this year because of a downturn in its military business.
Excluding transportation, durables orders still fell by 2.6 percent in June, after gaining 2.1 percent in May.
The exception was nonmilitary orders for capital goods, which gained three-tenths of a percent last month after falling by 1.4 percent in May.
Analysts said today that the rise reflected strong overseas demand for American-made machinery and other products, a bright spot for the economy that is expected to cut the nation's deficit on trade in goods and services despite weak economic conditions at home.

HEADLINE: Bankers Set to Extend Trump Loan Deadline

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Bankers are preparing to extend the deadline on the bridge loan that saved Donald J. Trump from bankruptcy as they continue to prepare the documentation for a permanent loan package, bankers involved in the deal said yesterday.
The extension is routine, simply allowing more time for the larger loan package to be completed.
The $20 million, 30-day bridge loan, which is set to expire today, was made to the developer last month to help him meet principal and interest payments on the high-yield ''junk bonds'' that financed one of his casinos. The bridge loan was made because paperwork for a larger loan package could not be completed by the deadline. Failure to make the payment could have thrown the developer into bankruptcy. 
The bridge loan is backed by an array of the personal properties of Mr. Trump, including his interest in the Trump Tower retail complex, his private plane, and residential units he owns in another New York condominium building, the Trump Parc. Earlier this month Mr. Trump announced that he had leased the Trump Tower retail space once occupied by Bonwit Teller to Galeries Lafayette, France's largest retailer.
 
Little Surprise
There was little surprise among the lawyers and bankers working to complete the voluminous documentation for the more complete rescue package that more time would be needed to put all the legal pieces in place. The larger package is a five-year loan arrangement that includes $65 million in new money and deferred payments on about $850 million of the developer's $2 billion of bank debt. The $20 million bridge loan will automatically be paid off once the deal is completed.
The loan package, which was hammered out over several weeks by some of the nation's largest banks, including Citicorp, Bankers Trust, Chase Manhattan and Manufacturers Hanover, is intended to encourage Mr. Trump to reduce his enormous debt burden by selling some assets. It is structured to reward Mr. Trump with interest-rate discounts if he sells the assets quickly.
While the vast majority of the foreign and domestic banks that own pieces of large Trump loans approved the long-term financing package last month, Dresdner Bank A.G., one of Germany's largest commercial banks, has refused. Bankers said yesterday that the loan package would go through without Dresdner's approval.
 
Search for a Financial Officer
Meanwhile, Mr. Trump is engaged in trying to find a chief financial officer who will help oversee the Trump Organization, the developer's main corporate vehicle. Bringing in such an officer was one condition of the loan package, but one banker involved in the negotiations said the search for a qualified financial executive willing to join the Trump Organization was an arduous one.
The banks are seeking a candidate with a traditional corporate background, and any candidate is subject to approval by both the bankers and Mr. Trump. The banker noted that because of the troubles of the Trump empire and the lack of perquisites like stock options at the Trump Organization, recruiting qualified executives was proving difficult.
Mr. Trump is also engaged in settlement negotiations with a Resorts International bondholders group that has filed a fraudulent conveyance suit against the developer. The Resorts bondholders charge that Mr. Trump's sale of Resorts to Merv Griffin in 1988 left the gambling and hotel company insolvent and that Mr. Trump did not pay enough for the Resorts assets he got as part of the same deal, including the then-unfinished Taj Mahal hotel and casino.

HEADLINE: Sun to Sell Its Computer Work Stations in Stores

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 25

 BODY:
Sun Microsystems Inc., in a direct challenge to personal computer manufacturers, announced today that it would sell its engineering work stations through computer retailers.
The move by Sun, which also introduced a new computer, is aimed at expanding the market for its machines beyond engineers and programmers to a broad range of office workers.
''This is Sun breaking out of the technical ghetto and beginning to walk down Main Street,'' said Mark D. Stahlman, computer analyst with Alex. Brown & Sons in New York. 
Also, the Tandy Corporation introduced a new home computer that comes with software for tasks like family financial planning, balancing a checkbook, storing recipes and organizing grocery lists. The move is expected to help Tandy head off a challenge from the International Business Machines Corporation, which re-entered the home computer business in June with the introduction of its PS/1 computers.
 
Retail Stores Named
Sun, based in Mountain View, Calif., said that selected dealers in three chains would begin selling its personal computers. The chains are Microage Inc. in Tempe, Ariz., Intelligent Electronics in Exton, Pa., and stores run by the Nynex Corporation in New York. The company said it hoped to have 200 dealers carrying its machines in a year.
The announcement is yet another sign of the blurring of the markets for work stations and personal computers. Work stations, which have been used primarily for science and engineering work, were once more powerful, more expensive and more difficult to use than personal computers. But they have been dropping in price below $10,000 and becoming easier to use while personal computers have become more powerful.
Sun until now has been selling its machines directly to customers, to other computer companies for resale or to specialized value-added resellers.
 
Machine With Color Images
Sun also introduced a new computer, the Sparcstation IPC, which will display color images. The machine, which can execute 15.8 million instructions a second, will sell for $9,000 without a disk drive and for $10,000 with a 207 megabyte hard disk.
Tandy's new computer, the 1000 RL, ranges in price from $750 for a machine with a floppy disk drive and monochrome monitor to $1,300 for the version with a hard disk drive and color monitor.
The machine replaces the 1000 HX, which was previously the low end of the Tandy 1000 line and sold for about $100 more. I.B.M.'s PS/1, by contrast, starts at $1,000 but has a built-in modem for communicating over telephone lines.
What is new in the 1000 RL, Tandy said, are the 24 built-in programs designed for home functions, including cataloguing collections and calculating interest rates and payments.

HEADLINE: USAir Loses $75 Million

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The parent of USAir said it lost $75 million in the most recent three-month period, attributing the drop to weakness in the nation's economy. America West Airlines said it registered second-quarter profits of more than $6 million, double its earnings from the comparable period last year. 
USAir Group Inc., based in Arlington, Va., said its quarterly loss was in contrast to profits of $101 million, or $2.29 a share, in the second quarter of 1989. Revenue for the quarter ended June 30 was $1.71 billion, down slightly from $1.73 billion a year earlier. USAir Group chairman, Edwin I. Colodny, said that industrywide domestic capacity was growing faster than traffic, and widespread promotional fare cuts on both coasts had reduced per-passenger yields.
America West posted second-quarter earnings of $6.14 million, or 29 cents a share, compared with $3.03 million, or 14 cents a share, during the second quarter of 1989. Revenue rose 37 percent, to $326 million from $239 million.
The results reflect a major improvement over the first quarter of the year, when the airline reported a net loss of $2.6 million.
Al Frei, senior vice president of finance, said much of the improvement was a result of a substantial drop in fuel costs.
Phoenix-based America West reported a 49.9 percent increase in passenger miles in the second quarter over the comparable period last year, Mr. Frei said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New President in Line To Be Southeast Chief

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
Douglas E. Ebert, who left the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in the spring after 22 years, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Miami-based Southeast Bank N.A. and is scheduled to become the bank's next chief executive.
Mr. Ebert, 44 years old, said yesterday of his appointment last week that he ''wanted to be in a position to be chief executive of a meaningful financial institution,'' and that was not how things were shaping up at Manufacturers Hanover.
In May, the New York bank reorganized its business into four major groups, and Mr. Ebert, who had wanted to head one of the groups, resigned when he was offered another job instead. 
At Southeast Bank, which has assets of $15.8 billion and 225 locations, Mr. Ebert replaces John E. Porta, who resigned in March. He will be working under Charles J. Zwick, 64, chairman and chief executive, who plans to retire in July 1993. ''It is the intent that I will be the successor,'' Mr. Ebert said. ''The reins will be passed over a period of time.''
Southeast Bank is not in the best of shape these days. It has suffered two quarterly losses this year and, although it expects improvement, still sees a loss for the full year. The Comptroller of the Currency has taken steps to strengthen the bank's procedures on real estate lending, credit review and establishing reserves.
''It's not a problem,'' Mr. Ebert said of the agreement with the Federal agency. ''It's a series of things they want us to do from a policy, procedural and monitoring point of view.'' He also said the bank would have no trouble meeting certain capital requirements sought by the Government by the end of the year.
Southeast Bank, Mr. Ebert said, ''has an extremely strong franchise built on a corporate and commercial business base.'' Florida's economy is strong, relative to what it has been in the last five years, he added, and most analysts expect Florida to continue its growth.
''This is not a New England, I can assure you of that,'' Mr. Ebert said.
Mr. Ebert, a graduate of Williams College, joined Manufacturers Hanover after college and worked in every major unit of the institution, from retail to international. In the last five years, he set up and ran Manufacturers Hanover's investment banking department.
Mr. Ebert said colleagues had told him that he would find a slower business pace in Miami than in New York. ''So far, I haven't found that at all,'' he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
Electronic Data Systems And G.M.A.C. in Profit Rise

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 25

 BODY:
The General Motors Acceptance Corporation and the Electronic Data Systems Corporation posted solid second-quarter earnings gains, but profits slipped 21.3 percent at the GM Hughes Electronics Corporation, which includes Hughes Aircraft and Delco Electronics.
Taken together, the General Motors Corporation's three non-automotive subsidiaries posted combined earnings of $616.4 million, approximately equal to last year's $614 million.
G.M.'s consolidated financial results will be announced on Thursday. 
 
GM Hughes
GM Hughes said today that second-quarter profit was $189 million on revenue of $3 billion, compared with profit of $240 million on revenue of $2.9 billion in the period last year. Profit attributable to G.M. class H stock, which represents a right to share in the dividend of the G.M. subsidiary, was 47 cents a share, compared with 60 cents last year.
For the six months, GM Hughes earned $372.3 million on revenue of $5.85 billion, compared with earnings of $450.4 million on revenue of $5.89 billion last year.
Robert J. Schultz, chairman of GM Hughes Electronics, said the increase in the unit's revenue came because of a 16 percent increase in the electronic content in G.M. vehicles and increased sales at three groups at Hughes Aircraft. Profit was hurt, he said, because overall North American vehicle production was down from last year, because of development costs for future spacecraft products and because the effective tax rate increased compared with last year, when several nonrecurring tax credits were claimed.
 
G.M.A.C.
General Motors Acceptance, the finance unit, earned $302 million for the period ended June 30, compared with $269 million for the period last year. For the six-month period, it earned $638 million, compared with $625 million last year.
The increase in profit from financing operations, which make up the majority of General Motors Acceptance's business, was mostly because of borrowing costs in the United States, the company said. The average interest rate on United States borrowings was 8.6 percent during the period, compared with 9.28 percent last year.
The company said it financed 541,000 new cars and trucks in the United States during the quarter, compared with 711,000 vehicles last year. Overseas, it financed 173,000 vehicles, compared with 192,000 last year.
 
E.D.S.
Electronic Data Systems said profit rose 19 percent in the quarter, to $125.3 million, on revenue of $1.46 billion, compared with profit of $104.9 million on revenue of $1.38 billion. Profit attributable to E.D.S. stock, which represents a right to share in the dividend of the G.M.-owned subsidiary, increased to 52 cents a share for the second quarter from 44 cents a share last year.
For the six months E.D.S. earned $235.1 million on $2.87 billion in revenue, compared with $204.9 million on revenue of $2.66 billion a year ago.
Electronic Data Systems noted two information processing agreements signed during the quarter. One was a 10-year agreement to handle all data processing and communications operations for the Westmoreland Coal Company. Another was a five-year contract to operate an information system for the Westar Transmission Company, a unit of the American Oil and Gas Corporation. E.D.S. did not disclose the value of the contracts.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields Down Only a Bit

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Yields on tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report continued to decline in the week ended yesterday. The declines, however, were not significant.
''We haven't as yet seen a significant decline in yields, perhaps because the bond market has yet to enthusiastically follow the Federal Reserve's lead in cutting interest rates,'' said Walter S. Frank, chief economist at Donoghue's. ''Should Washington come up with a feasible budget, we believe participants in the fixed-income market will become believers and then yields will decline further.'' 
Mr. Frank said he expected the yields on money market funds to decline before there is any major change in the interest rate structure in the fixed-income market.
 
Outlook for Tax-Exempt Sector
As for the tax-exempt sector, the yield outlook will also depend on what, if any, changes in the structure of personal income tax result from the budget negotiations now under way in Washington.
Meanwhile, the average number of days that managers of tax-exempt funds held securities in their portfolios was unchanged, at 51 days, in the latest week. But the assets of tax-exempt funds fell by $136 million, to $78.8 billion, with the average seven-day compounded yield down 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 5.21 percent, while the 30-day average yield fell 6 basis points, to 5.31 percent.
For investors in the 28 percent bracket the equivalent taxable seven-day compounded yield would be 7.24 percent, while it would be 7.78 percent for those in the 33 percent bracket.
Among tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's, the Strong Municipal Market Fund again topped the list, with a yield of 6.27 percent. The Strong fund is distributed by Strong/Corneliuson Capital Management Inc., Milwaukee.
 
Rise in Taxable Fund Assets
The assets of taxable funds increased by $2.4 billion, to a total of $384.8 billion. Those of institutional funds rose by $600 million, to $82.6 billion. The gains were again attributed to a widening of the yield spreads between certificates of deposit and money market funds.
The average number of days to maturity of taxable securities held in managers' portfolios was unchanged, at 44 days, in the latest week.
Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for a taxable money market fund dropped 7 basis points, to 7.88 percent, while the 30-day average slipped a basis point, to 7.94 percent.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 8.42, to 2,930.94; Investors Cautious

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stock prices continued to recover yesterday from Monday's huge selloff, but trading volume weakened and investors remained exceptionally cautious in an uncertain market.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 8.42 points to close at 2,930.94. With Tuesday's 17.82-point gain, it has now picked up almost half of Monday's 56-point loss.
Volume fell to 163.5 million shares, from 181.9 million the day before. Advances outpaced declines, 895 to 583, although 57 stocks set new lows. 
 
'Not Just a Malaise'
Remarking on the current attitude of investors, Hugh Johnson, head strategist for the First Albany Corporation, said, ''It's not just a malaise; it's an edginess, a lack of confidence, concern that we'll get blind-sided by some earnings disappointment or disappointment emerging from the current budget negotiations.''
Some traders said they had heard talk in Washington that members of Congress, who supposedly could leave town early for the summer recess, were being asked not to make nonrefundable plane reservations before Aug. 10.
Although the rumor does not appear to be widespread, traders who had heard it and others who were asked about it said it sounded plausible. They reasoned that if legislators were being asked to stay in Washington, a good explanation might be that strong progress was being made on a budget compromise - which would help both the stock and bond markets.
Part of the reason for the market selloff on Monday, traders said, was that sentiment had spread rapidly that negotiations on cutting the budget had bogged down and that nothing would happen until after the recess. Now that may change.
 
Effect of Durable-Goods Data
Mr. Johnson of First Albany said that while orders for durable goods fell 3.2 percent in June, or less than expected, the market barometer is so unpredictable and volatile that traders do not give it much credit. Even so, he said, it could have helped and, when combined with the ''reasonably successful'' auction of two-year Treasury notes, could account for the improvement in the bond market. That, he said, ''could explain why stocks did well.''
Other traders said that comments before the House Banking Committee on Tuesday by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, helped because he made it clear he wanted to control inflation.
Market performance, however, was mixed, with technology stocks advancing and energy stocks declining.
''Confidence has been shaken in earnings,'' Mr. Johnson said. ''Investors are extremely tentative, and that's reflected in the low volume.''
 
Oil Stocks Fall Slightly
Oil stocks, which jumped Tuesday in the wake of new tensions in the Middle East, fell slightly after swift peace talks between Iraq, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia were undertaken by President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. Of the three oil stocks among the Dow industrials, Chevron fell 1, to 77 3/4; Texaco fell 1/4, to 62 1/4, but had dropped to 61 7/8, and Exxon fell 3/8, to 49 5/8.
In the biggest drop among the Big Board's 10-most-active stocks, L.A. Gear, the athletic-shoe producer, fell 2 1/8, to 23, also hitting a new low of 21 7/8, after reporting a decline in second-quarter profits. Nike, a competitor, fell 1/4, to 88, but had fallen to 85 1/4.
Johnson & Johnson, which has reported a strong rise in profits, climbed 1 1/4 to 73 1/4.
On the Nasdaq, Cellular Communications, a cellular phone company, fell 2 1/4, to 33, on 2.8 million shares, after it agreed with Pacific Telesis to combine cellular interests in Ohio and Michigan. Dennis Leibowitz of the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation said the stock was now ''unattractive.''
Among the technology stocks on the Nasdaq, Microsoft rose 2, to 71 1/2; Novell rose 1 1/2, to 49 1/4; AST Research rose 2 1/4, to 22 5/8; Sun Microsystems rose 1 5/8, to 33 1/2, and Conner Peripherals rose 1 1/4, to 27 7/8.
Motorola rose 2 1/8, to 79 3/4; Compaq Computer rose 2, to 59 3/8, and I.B.M. remained unchanged, at 114 3/4.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bond Prices Are Higher

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices rose and long-term interest rates fell yesterday on evidence of further weakness in the economy and an indication that at least one key member of the Federal Reserve Board opposes the central bank's current stance on monetary policy.
A 3.2 percent decline in durable goods orders in June helped to push prices up initially. Most analysts had expected to learn that orders rose slightly last month.
Later in the day, bond prices moved higher again after a Fed governor, Wayne Angell, told an audience in Boston that any further easing of monetary policy would confuse world financial markets and cause long-term interest rates to rise. In his remarks, Mr. Angell seemed to suggest the Fed should remain more concerned about taming inflation than in using monetary policy as a tool to avoid recession. Over the last two weeks, market participants have become increasingly concerned that the Fed has shifted its priorities from dampening inflation to preventing a recession. 
 
Sale of New 2-Year Notes
The Fed governor's comments appeared on trading screens shortly after 1 P.M., when dealers placed bids on an $11.5 billion sale of new two-year notes. His remarks came scarcely 24 hours after Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, completed two days of extensive testimony to Congress that outlined the reasons why the Fed had moved to ease monetary policy earlier this month.
''The bottom line is that Angell was articulating a view that is his own, one that reflects a difference of opinion between himself and the consensus at the Fed,'' said Dana Johnson, chief money market economist at the First National Bank of Chicago.
''But at this point I think the Fed would agree that a further easing in policy would be unwise. It has to wait for the market to see more evidence of economic weakness or of a substantive reduction in the Federal budget deficit before it moves again.''
The durable goods numbers, although notoriously volatile on a monthly basis, did little to dispel the notion that conditions in the manufacturing sector remain very soft.
''The data leave new orders at the low end of the range they have been stuck in since late 1988,'' Robert T. McGee, senior vice president and economist at the Tokai Bank Ltd. said in a written commentary.
''The numbers confirm that the slight pickup in manufacturing this year is modest at best and unlikely to gather much additional momentum.''
The orders numbers, which were released during early morning trading, provided the backdrop for bidding at the two-year note auction.
 
Securities Demand Strong
Demand for the new securities was strong, and bids submitted produced an average yield of 8.07 percent, the lowest yield so far this year, and well under the 8.41 percent average yield at the last two-year note auction on June 26.
Despite Mr. Angell's remarks, which helped bond prices more than shorter-term securities, the two-year notes were trading on a when-issued basis late yesterday at the same price level at which they were auctioned earlier in the day.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 102 1/4 late yesterday, up 13/32, to yield 8.53 percent. Late Tuesday the benchmark issue was offered at a price to yield 8.58 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 5/8, up 9/32, to yield 8.47 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 26/32, up 5/32, to yield 8.28 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.54 percent, down two basis points, or hundredths of a point. But six-month bill rates rose by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 7.44 percent.
A number of new corporate debt issues were priced yesterday, including a $50 million 10-year note offering from Arvin Industries.
The 10 percent notes, which mature Aug. 1, 2000, were priced at $99.132, to yield 10.14 percent, 1.65 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing. The securities are noncallable for life.
Merrill Lynch Capital Markets acted as lead manager for the underwriting, which is rated Baa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was light, dealers said. Prices of most actively quoted intermediate- and long-term issues rose by about 1/4 point, while prices of short-term issues were largely unchanged.
Meanwhile, in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal securities, market participants said that prices of most issues rose by about 1/8 point.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mixed, With Gains Against Yen and Pound

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed yesterday in foreign exchange trading, rising against the Japanese yen and the British pound but losing ground against other key currencies.
Linda McLaughlin, a currency trader with Chemical New York Capital Markets Group, said the dollar's movement was largely affected by technical factors. She said the currency benefited indirectly from the yen's weakness against the German mark. 
Marketwide sentiment that the Bank of Japan will not be raising interest rates anytime soon has been putting pressure on the yen, while the mark has been supported by comparably higher interest rates in West Germany, traders said.
 
Effect of Tensions in Persian Gulf
The dollar has also been helped against the yen by jitters over rising tensions in the Persian Gulf between Iraq and Kuwait, which also lifted world oil prices. The situation has undermined some confidence in the Japanese economy, which is dependent on oil imports, traders said.
In Tokyo, where global trading begins, the dollar fell to a closing 149.13 Japanese yen, from 148.70 yen at Tuesday's close. It traded at 148.75 yen in London and at 148.80 yen in New York, up from 148.40 yen Tuesday.
The dollar was stronger against the British pound, which cost $1.8125 in London, down from $1.8250, and $1.8125 in New York, down from $1.8140.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.6170 German marks, down from 1.62075; 1.3715 Swiss francs, down fromm 1.3785; 5.4170 French francs, down from 5.4365; 1,183.625 Italian lire, down from 1,186.00, and 1.15175 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15655.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Tuesday's, included: 1.6170 German marks, down from 1.6185; 1.3715 Swiss francs, down from 1.3750; 5.4185 French francs, down from 5.4275; 1.8215 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8230; 1,183.62 Italian lire, down from 1,184.75, and 1.1518 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1557.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. FAVORS LIMIT ON TAX DEDUCTIONS FOR LOCAL LEVIES

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 26

 BODY:
The Bush Administration and senior Congressional Republicans have agreed on a budget proposal that would limit the amount of state and local income taxes that taxpayers could deduct on their Federal returns, Congressional officials said today.
The officials said that under the Republican proposal, this Federal deduction, which is now unlimited for all taxpayers who itemize deductions, would be capped at $10,000.
The effect would be higher Federal taxes for large numbers of upper-income Americans, particularly those paying high state or local income taxes.
 
Democrats Cautious
The deductibility provision was part of a larger White House package of deficit-cutting proposals whose elements were disclosed by officials on Capitol Hill. The Administration made no public comment. 
The new approach reflected an effort by President Bush's representatives in the budget negotiations with Congress to take the steam out of Democratic attempts to raise the Federal income tax rate for the most affluent taxpayers above the current level, 28 percent.
Democrats reacted cautiously to the Administration's idea, saying study would be needed to see whether it was truly aimed at the wealthy and would not place a burden on middle-income taxpayers. They also expressed concern that the proposal might have an unfair effect on residents of states like California and New York, where state taxes are relatively high. $3 Billion a Year Participants in the budget talks said the Administration estimated that its proposal would generate $3 billion a year for the Federal Treasury. In addition, they said, the larger Administration plan envisions an increase, long expected, in the Federal excise tax on wine, beer and spirits, a step that budget experts said would raise $7.2 billion.
Mr. Bush abandoned his 1988 campaign pledge of ''no new taxes'' last month. The two current proposals, taken together, are the first concrete steps signaling the President's willingness to raise taxes in an effort to reach a budget deal with Democrats.
 
Local Officials Angered
But the deductibility proposal seems certain to provoke a fight with state and local officials, many of whom view it as a threat to their ability to maintain revenues in the face of an increased burden on individual taxpayers.
Today several such officials -Democrats and Republicans from around the country, including Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York and New York City's Mayor, David N. Dinkins -were in Washington, where they held a news conference urging lawmakers involved in the negotiations to reject the idea.
Eliminating the deductibility of state and local taxes was discussed in negotiations leading to the overhaul of the Federal tax code in 1986. But although the deduction for state sales taxes was ended then, dropping the income-tax deduction was rejected because of fierce opposition from state and local officials like that shown today.
 
Impact on Taxpayers
Democratic budget negotiators said today that they had not had time to calculate the impact of the new Republican proposal on individual taxpayers.
Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the senior Republican on the Senate Finance Committee, said 94 percent of those who would be affected by the restriction earned more than $100,000 a year. But some Congressional budget experts said later that Senator Packwood had apparently been referring to the total income of working couples and not that of individuals.
Warren Shine, a partner in the accounting firm of Ernst & Young, calculated that under the proposal, a New York City couple who had combined adjusted gross income of $100,000 and whose tax bracket was 28 percent would have paid $65 more in Federal taxes last year. The proposal would have cost a single person in the same circumstances $163, Mr. Shine said.
 
The Aim of the Talks
The negotiators from the White House and Congress are looking for ways to cut $50 billion from a 1991 Federal budget deficit that is now estimated at almost $170 billion, not counting the cost of bailing out the savings and loan industry. Participants in the talks long ago ruled out a deeper cut, fearing that it might tip the economy into a recession and realizing that in any case, combined tax increases and budget cuts of such a magnitude were politically unachievable.
Lawmakers said the Administration's new budget proposal, which, as expected, also calls for deep spending cuts in Federal benefit programs other than Social Security, was presented to Republican negotiators on Wednesday night by the White House budget director, Richard G. Darman, and was agreed to by ''the bulk of the group.''
Mr. Darman had intended to put the full proposal to the Democratic negotiators today, but that move was delayed until Friday at the earliest because they were still working on proposals of their own.
''We're sorry to hear they are having difficulty, but we're ready any time,'' said John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff.
The Democratic negotiators, who met for several hours today after details of the Administration proposal began to seep out on Capitol Hill, said they now believed it would be impossible to conclude a budget agreement with the White House before Congress adjourns for a monthlong summer recess in early August. As a result, they said, they may not advance a competing proposal at all until early September.
Part of their concern is that if politically sensitive proposals for spending cuts and tax increases are made public before Congress leaves town, members will be subjected to enormous pressure from lobbying groups and constituents during the recess, perhaps causing the talks to collapse.
Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who heads the House Budget Committee, suggested that the negotiators might try to hold bargaining sessions during the recess in hopes of reaching a compromise before the rest of Congress returns to Washington.
Quite apart from the tax issues, the two sides remain divided over how to apportion spending cuts between the Pentagon and domestic programs. The Administration proposal, said officials familiar with it, would cut $16 billion from programs like Medicare, Medicaid, veterans benefits and farm subsidies, but would not touch Social Security.
The Administration would also cut nearly $7 billion from the Pentagon budget next year, about twice as much as President Bush proposed in the budget he sent Congress in January. Democratic negotiators, however, want the bulk of the spending cuts to come from the Pentagon rather than domestic programs and are looking to cut the military budget by at least $14 billion, while taking only $7 billion to $8 billion out of benefit programs.
 
The Deductibility Debate
Limits on the deduction for state and local income taxes would have a major impact on New York and other states that rely heavily on those taxes to finance a wide array of programs and services. New York's Congressional delegation has already mounted a lobbying campaign to block any changes in the Federal deduction, and by their presence today Governor Cuomo and Mayor Dinkins hoped to dramatize their view that the limitation would be devastating to the state.
They were joined at the news conference by officials from Indiana, Pennsylvania and Michigan, who also inveighed against the plan as an effort to solve the Federal deficit problem on the backs of local government.
Restricting the deduction would, for many taxpayers, effectively raise the cost of paying for state and local government. Opponents of the plan say that it would amount to ''double taxation'' because money that has been paid in local taxes would be taxed again by the Federal Government as income.
At the core of the objections is a concern that upper-income taxpayers in high-tax states or cities who can no longer deduct the full amount will flee over time to areas where taxes are lower. The result would be an erosion of the tax base on which states like New York, California, Massachusetts and New Jersey rely to finance operations.
Increases in alcohol taxes, another part of the Administration plan, are regarded in both parties as the least politically painful of tax increase options. Although Democrats tend to argue that such taxes are regressive, many lawmakers concede privately that the new health consciousness among consumers makes a rise in alcohol taxes more acceptable than it might otherwise be to the public.
Beer, wine and spirits are currently taxed at different rates, and industry sources familiar with the Administration proposal said the Administration was seeking to raise and adjust those rates so that all of them would be based on alcohol content. The increase would raise the current 16-cent Federal tax on a six-pack of beer to 81 cents, the current 3-cent tax on a 750-milliliter bottle of wine to 70 cents, and the current $1.98 tax on a 750-milliliter bottle of liquor to $2.54.
These changes would raise an estimated $7.2 billion in the next fiscal year, budget officials said. The taxes on beer and wine have not been increased since 1951. Taxes on distilled spirits, last raised in 1985, are now $12.50 per proof gallon.

HEADLINE: Castro Assails Spain for Standoff

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAVANA, July 26

 BODY:
In a speech marking the 37th anniversary of a guerrilla attack that began the Cuban revolution, President Fidel Castro bitterly criticized Spain today for the standoff involving refugees seeking asylum in its embassy here.
Mr. Castro described the recent flight of Cubans to European diplomatic missions here as ''the latest act of the U.S. against Cuba,'' and he accused Spain of acting as an accomplice to ''Yankee aggression.'' Eighteen Cubans have taken shelter in the Spanish Embassy and four have sought refuge at the Italian ambassador's residence. 
In a rhetorical challenge, Mr. Castro said he would be willing to set up offices so that ''progressive Europeans'' could receive Cuban emigres. If the United States is concerned about asylum seekers, he gibed, ''Let them send boats and visas.''
 
Laments Decline of Socialism
As for the $2.5 million aid program that Spain has suspended because of the dispute, the Cuban President said, ''We renounce it.''
With Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the former President of Nicaragua, and Julius Nyerere, the former Tanzanian President, as his guests of honor, Mr. Castro lamented the demise of socialism in much of the world.
He said that trade between Cuba and some of the countries that formerly were in the Eastern bloc ''has practically disappeared.''
Mr. Castro said that Moscow was ''making maximal efforts'' to help his country, but that even if the Soviet Union ''disintegrated or even disappeared,'' Cuba would ''continue to build socialism.''
Amid wide speculation about how Cuba will get by next year, when Soviet subsidies are expected to decline sharply, the President provided few details on his economic plans.
''If we must sacrifice on social projects, we must be ready to sacrifice them,'' he said. ''What we must not sacrifice is our development.''
Referring to the refugee crisis before Mr. Castro's speech, a Spanish diplomat, Fidel Sendagorta, said, ''We are awaiting events, trying to emphasize that tension should be reduced so that we can have serious discussions.''
Spain has refused to expel the Cubans, and Havana has said they should not be given refuge because they are not being sought by the Cuban authorities.

HEADLINE: OPEC Moves Closer to a Pact on Production

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, July 26

 BODY:
The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries moved closer today to an agreement that would set a ceiling on its 13 members' production of 22.5 million barrels a day and raise oil prices to at least $20 a barrel.
''We are going to have an agreement in this conference,'' said Issam Abdul-Rahim al-Chalabi, the Oil Minister of Iraq, whose tough position has significantly raised its stature as the new ''policeman of OPEC,'' as some delegates here put it.
Last week, Iraq warned Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates to stop cheating on OPEC quotas, and over the weekend moved troops to its border with Kuwait in a show of force.
Kuwait and the Emirates backed down, and reports circulating here today said that Iraq has pulled back some of the troops it had sent to the Kuwaiti border. Officials of the Kuwaiti and Emirates delegations seemed resigned today to accept their production quotas of 1.5 million barrels a day each. 
 
Irritation Over Quota Cheats
Kuwait and the Emirates had been producing about 1.9 million barrels a day and 2.1 million barrels a day, respectively, before the Iraqi warning first issued on July 17.
Many OPEC delegates said they were relieved that Iraq got its way without pushing its confrontation beyond the point of troop movements and tough oratory. Many OPEC members, including Saudi Arabia, a traditional ally of Kuwait and the Emirates, had expressed irritation with the chronic refusal of those two countries to abide by OPEC quotas.
The impact of their overproduction on prices cut into the revenues of all oil-exporting nations, including such non-OPEC countries as the Soviet Union, Egypt and Mexico.
The pricing and production accord, which is expected to be made final within two days, would reduce the amount of oil being pumped into world oil markets by about a million barrels.
 
'A New Minimum Price'
Despite the expectation among commodities traders that the OPEC agreement would eventually raise prices, trading today showed little effect. Saudi light crude oil, for example, sold for $15.85 a barrel, unchanged from Wednesday's price, while West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark American crude oil, dropped 8 cents a barrel, to $20.30.
''We will have a new minimum price,'' Sadek Boussena, Algeria's Oil Minister and the OPEC conference president, told reporters today. ''There are several positions but all of them are in favor of higher prices.''
A senior Iraqi official, who insisted on not being identified, said that the price range under discussion was ''a minimum of $20 and a maximum of $25 a barrel.''
Today, Iraq proposed that the so-called minimum reference price, in effect a target price, be raised to $25 a barrel immediately. The current reference price is $18.
 
Iran Offers a Compromise
Saudi Arabia, which is also in favor of higher oil prices, has argued that setting too high a price for oil may not be realistic given the current glut in the market, largely due to the sustained overproduction by Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates over the last few months. Saudi officials said they would favor a price a little lower than Iraq's proposal.
Iran, the other member of the troika that seems to be running the cartel nowadays, suggested a compromise, with a price of $20 a barrel coupled with a statement asserting OPEC's intention to push its prices upward over the next two years or so.
The Iranian proposal seemed most likely to be accepted, although some delegates said the price may be set a little higher at $21 or $22 a barrel to satisfy Iraq, Libya, Ecuador, and Nigeria, which are all backing higher prices.
Analysts said today that regardless of the price set, the cartel seems bent on a course for a steady but controlled rise in oil prices.
''There are not going to be any sudden shocks, but we all recognize that the price of oil today is far too low given inflation and the growing demand for OPEC oil worldwide,'' the Iraqi official said.
There was also a sense of confidence that OPEC's chronic inability to stick to its own agreements has been changed by the Iraqi military threat against any Arab oil producer who cheats.

HEADLINE: U.S. Weighs Sanctions on Iraq Over Baghdad's Oil-Dispute Tactics

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 26

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has started a wide-ranging review of American policy toward Iraq and will consider new economic sanctions and export controls as a result of Iraq's threats against two oil-producing neighbors on the Persian Gulf, Administration officials said today.
They said the State Department and the Pentagon were alarmed by the tactics of President Saddam Hussein, who this month threatened Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates with military action to force them to reduce oil production.
''What's gone on in the last several days has reaffirmed the need for a good, intensive look at Iraq,'' a State Department official said. ''We still think it's important to have a relationship - we need to be able to talk to Iraq - but at the same time there may be some specific areas where we'll want to be tougher with them.'' 
While the United States maintained official neutrality during the eight-year war between Iran and Iraq, its policy gradually tilted toward Iraq and, apparently in response, President Hussein moderated his behavior toward the United States and his Arab neighbors in the Persian Gulf.
 
Policy Review Quickened
Administration officials said their review of American-Iraqi relations began earlier this year as a result of evidence that Iraq was expanding its efforts to develop chemical and nuclear weapons.
The examination was stepped up last week, when President Hussein threatened military action against Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates if they continued to flout oil production quotas set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Officials said the review would continue even though tensions eased Wednesday when Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates apparently agreed in Geneva to a new production accord proposed by OPEC.
From 1979 to 1982, Iraq was on the State Department's official list of states that sponsor international terrorism, meaning that it faced trade sanctions at that time. Even today, there are some products that cannot be sold to Iraq, including chemicals that might be used to make nerve gas.
Reports that the State Department might seek new economic sanctions against Iraq have circulated on Capitol Hill this week, delighting lawmakers who in the past have criticized the Bush Administration for failing to act decisively to protest human-rights and military abuses by the Iraqi Government.
 
Limited U.S. Leverage
''Our policy in the past has been totally inexplicable,'' said Representative Howard L. Berman, a California Democrat. ''During Iraq's war with Iran, our Government agreed to look the other way at Iraq's support for terrorism, its involvement in weapons proliferation and even its use of nerve gas.''
''We can't afford to look the other way,'' he said, ''I think Saddam Hussein is now making the best case imaginable for why the United States must make a dramatic alteration in its policies.''
Administration officials warned today that the United States has only limited economic leverage over Iraq, and that additional sanctions would not have a dramatic effect on the Iraqi economy. There is only about $2 billion in annual trade between the United States and Iraq, most of it agricultural.
Late tonight the Senate debated a farm bill amendment that would restrict agricultural export credits to Iraq. But it postponed action until Friday, when the House is also expected to take up the farm bill.
Lawmakers have insisted that new sanctions would still have an important symbolic value. There was widespread indignation on Capitol Hill last month when the Bush Administration publicly urged lawmakers to resist growing sentiment to punish Iraq economically after President Hussein's recent threat to attack Israel with chemical weapons.
This month the Senate Banking Committee unanimously approved legislation that would deny agricultural credits to Iraq and would bar the sale of technology with potential military applications.
Haitham al-Najjar, first secretary of the Iraqi Embassy here, said in an interview that new sanctions ''would hurt Americans much more than Iraqis.'' ''It would hurt American farmers who are now getting the benefit of Iraqi imports, because Iraq could find many other markets to get what it needs,'' he continued.
He said, too, that Iraq considered its dispute with Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates over oil production to be an Arab issue. ''This is an Arab matter and will be settled as soon as possible,'' he said.
While President Hussein had moderated his policies during the war, when it ended he resumed actions that seemed intended to promote Iraqi domination of the region. In speeches and other comments in recent months, the Iraqi President has attacked the United States. Last week he accused the Bush Administration of conspiring with Kuwait to steal Iraqi oil reserves.
A State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, today reiterated the Bush Administration's condemnation of President Hussein's recent threats.

HEADLINE: Battle for Family Leave Will Be Fought in States

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
Groups that favor giving workers unpaid leave to care for newborn babies and ailing relatives are preparing to lobby individual states for legislation to do what a Federal bill vetoed by President Bush would have done.
Those who favor such legislation say some states delayed taking action while the Federal bill was making its way through Congress. The House sustained the veto on Wednesday.
''Most state legislatures are out of session now, but when they come back, this is going to be a big issue,'' said Donna Lenhoff, the legal director of the Women's Legal Defense Fund, a lobby that is mapping strategy for state legislation.
Fifteen states have adopted some form of job protection for workers who need time off for family purposes, and 30 other states have considered similar bills in the last year alone. 
Some of these measures are more generous, than the vetoed Family and Medical Leave Act, while others are less generous. The Federal legislation would have provided up to three months of unpaid leave for workers with new babies or those seeking to take care of immediate family members. It would have applied to employers with at least 50 people.
 
Government Intrusion Charged
Mr. Bush said he thought the measure would have been an unwarranted intrusion of government into business affairs.
Business groups argue that requiring employers to provide family leave might have the unintended effect of discouraging employers from hiring women of child-bearing age, as well as men with burdensome family obligations.
Some opponents also maintain that since the legislation generally mandates continued medical benefits -even though the leave itself is unpaid - employers would be burdened with substantial costs.
''We oppose mandates,'' said Christine Russell, a spokeswoman for the United States Chamber of Commerce. ''That's our reason: No. 1, No. 2 and No. 3. We haven't estimated how much it would cost because we don't know if it's a receptionist or an office maanger taking the leave, or if the business is going to use a temp or pay overtime. There are too many variables to estimate the cost.''
 
Battle Anticipated
Angela Jones, a spokeswoman for the National Federation of Indepedent Businesses, another group that opposed the Federal legislation, said she expected a fight in states that consider mandating family-leave provisions. She said that family-leave bills had already been introduced in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, and that similar bills were ''more than likely'' to be debated in others.
''If there is a push on the state level,'' she said, ''we will have to fight it on the state level.''
But labor groups, women's groups and advocates for the elderly have pushed for such legislation, noting that most other industrialized nations have long offered family leaves, with pay.
The laws already on the books range from Iowa's 1987 statute giving women up to eight weeks of pregnancy disability time to a Connecticut statute that went into effect July 1 giving men and women up to 12 weeks off to care for a newborn or newly adopted baby, a sick parent, spouse or child, or to recuperate from an illness of their own.
And just last Friday, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington signed the broadest family and medical leave law to date, requiring most employers in the District of Columbia, except the Federal Government, to provide up to four months of unpaid leave to workers who need time off to be with babies or ill family members.
 
Gay Partners Included
Several states, including New York, have legislation requiring leave for those who have a pregnancy-related disability. But they do not require that a job be held for them.
The Washington law is the first in the nation that defines family members to include gay partners or any others with whom the worker lives ''in the context of a committed relationship.'' The leave can be used to take care of a newborn, newly adopted baby or foster child, or an ill child, parent, relative or lover.
The current spate of family and medical-leave legislation comes in response to vastly changed demographics in the workplace. More than 70 percent of all American women 20 to 54 years old now work outside the home, making it far more difficult for them to provide traditional care.
 
Stories of Lost Jobs
For working men and women alike, the lack of a leave policy can create impossible binds. Indeed, the Women's Legal Defense Fund has compiled the stories of dozens of men and women from all walks of life who needed to be out of work temporarily in times of personal crisis - and lost their jobs because their employers did not offer adequate leave time.
Jim Censullo, for example, was working as a manager for a large New Hampshire video company in November 1989, when his wife, Kathy, gave birth to their second child. Two days later, the Censullos discovered that their new son's heart had only one working chamber, that he needed emergency surgery, and might die at any time.
Although Mr. Censullo had kept his office advised of the baby's condition, his supervisor called him at the hospital eight days later, demanding to know when he would return to work. Mr. Censullo said that, given his son's precarious hold on life, he could not say exactly when he would return. Later that day, with his 10-day old son facing an uncertain future, and enormous medical bills, Mr. Censullo received a mailgram telling him he was fired. He was invited back only after the story appeared in New England newspapers; he instead took a job elsewhere at an $11,000 annual pay cut. His son, Anthony, needs further surgery, and the family is struggling to make ends meet.
 
Most Workers Unprotected
Despite the proliferation of state leave legislation, most American workers still do not have the right to return to their jobs if they take substantial time off for family or medical reasons.
Indeed, while many states offer some job protection in such circumstances, only Connecticut, Maine and Wisconsin guarantee leave for employees who adopt children, need to care for a seriously ill child, spouse or parent, or have serious health problems themselves. A bill recently passed by the Illinois Legislature, but not yet signed by the Governor, would provide similar benefits.
Most of the other state laws are considerably narrower, although the coverage varies widely from state to state. The length of the leave varies, too, with most of the laws offering from six weeks to six months.
Many of the laws deal only with the right to take time off for pregnancy disability, but even those laws differ substantially. For example, Hawaii requires all employers to offer pregnancy disability leave, but Tennessee's law covers only those with at least 100 employees, and North Carolina's covers only state agencies.
''While many of the laws that have been on the books for a while are pregnancy disability laws applying only to women, the new laws now being considered tend to be gender-neutral, recognizing that men and women equally can have family or medical problems,'' Ms. Norton said.
 
Medical Leave Is Rare
The right to take extended time off for an employee's own medical problems is still relatively rare. In most states, even employees of long standing may lose their jobs when they develop a serious health problem.
The Women's Legal Defense Fund also cites the case of Florence McKeever, a Washington women who had spent 14 years as a housekeeper for a large apartment-management company when she broke a bone in her foot on March 20, 1988. Her doctor said she needed twelve weeks to recuperate, but she did not have that much sick leave. On May 23, Mrs. McKeever received a letter from her employer stating that her job was no longer available, and offering her a part-time job without the steady hours and without her previous benefits. Mrs. McKeever, then 56, found it difficult to find another job, and was forced to apply for unemployment benefits.
Under the new Washington legislation, Mrs. McKeever would not have lost her job. The new law, which still faces a review by the Congressional committees concerned with District affairs, would cover private employers with at least 50 workers and all city agencies. After three years, the coverage would be extended to firms with at least 20 employees.
To take advantage of the law, employees who have held their job for at least a year would be entitled to 16 weeks of family or medical leave every two years.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 8, 1990, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on July 27 about laws requiring businesses to grant leave for workers who need to care for ill family members or newborn babies referred incorrectly to the status of legislation in New Jersey. New Jersey's family-leave law, among the broadest in the nation, went into effect in May, giving employees at businesses with at least 100 workers the right to take up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave every two years to care for a new baby or an ill family member.

HEADLINE: Silber Taps Public's Anger to Run a Strong Race in Massachusetts

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, July 26

 BODY:
Despite waging an unusual, provocative campaign that has broken many of the rules of politics and offended some women, blacks and the elderly, John R. Silber is running more strongly than expected in the Massachusetts race for governor and could be in position to win the Democratic nomination in September.
''I'd say Silber is now the person to beat,'' said Tom Kiley, a political consultant in Boston who is not affiliated with any of the candidates.
If Dr. Silber, the 63-year-old president of Boston University, does win the Democratic primary election in September, it could put him in a commanding position to capture the governor's office in November in a state with a weak Republican Party, whose two candidates so far have turned in lackluster performances, Mr. Kiley said.
Mr. Kiley and others acknowledged that Dr. Silber could still undermine his chances in the September primary with more of the kind of candid comments that have become his trademark. 
 
Shakespeare Line Flops
In the past week alone, for example, Dr. Silber antagonized many elderly voters by proposing that medical care for the aged be rationed to save the state's deficit-ridden budget. After saying he would not let the state pay for a heart transplant for an 80-year-old, Dr. Silber added: ''I want to remind the voters of Massachusetts that Shakespeare was right when he said 'Ripeness is all.' When you've had a long life and you're ripe, then it's time to go.'' The citation was from ''King Lear.''
Similarly, Dr. Silber outraged some feminists when he said at a forum on women's issues last week that he would not appoint someone like Gloria Steinem to be a judge. ''I would want to make sure that the judge was not so taken up in a cause, either the cause of women or the cause of minorities, that that judge could not act fairly if a male came before that judge,'' Dr. Silber said.
But Dr. Silber, a native of Texas and a former dean of the University of Texas, seems to have turned his candor into a weapon, capturing the popular anger in Massachusetts over a faltering economy, an endless state budget crisis and rising taxes.
''I think because the voters are mad and because he is the meanest dude to come along in a long time, people have elevated John Silber into a status where he is judged by a different standard,'' Mr. Kiley said. ''He has tapped into their alienation, and if he wants to tip the whole thing over, that's fine.''
 
Grabbing the Headlines
Ralph Whitehead, a professor of journalism at the University of Massachusetts, said Dr. Silber had broken one of the standard rules of politics by ''making himself into the issue in the campaign.''
''Normally, that is dangerous,'' Mr. Whitehead said. ''But Silber has managed to use it to dominate the campaign,'' he said, and has largely obscured his Democratic opponents, Francis X. Bellotti, a former State Attorney General, and Lieut. Gov. Evelyn Murphy. The headlines each day in Boston's papers and the local television news are constantly devoted to what have come to be called ''Silber shockers.''
In the most recent poll on the gubernatorial contest, published by the Boston Globe on June 19, Dr. Silber and Mr. Bellotti were tied with 32 percent each, with Ms. Murphy at 27 percent. The margin of sampling error in the poll was plus or minus five percentage points. Although the poll showed the three candidates virtually tied, that represented a huge gain for Dr. Silber, who began the campaign last winter with well under a 10 percent rating.
Lieutenant Governor Murphy has depicted herself as the only liberal in the race, willing to raise taxes to resolve the state's budget crisis and press forward with the expensive cleanup of Boston Harbor. But she has been hurt by her close ties to the now widely disliked Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, who has been blamed for failing to halt the budget mess.
 
Not a Fresh Face
Mr. Bellotti has tried to claim the political center, appealing to traditional blue-collar Democratic voters. But he is 66 years old and has been burdened by his image as an old political warhorse - he first ran for Governor in 1963 - at a time of voter discontent with politicians.
Daniel Payne, another political consultant in Boston not connected to any of the candidates, said Dr. Silber might have injured himself by his comment on rationing medical care for the elderly. Some of Dr. Silber's earlier remarks, including one about the City of Lowell's becoming a welfare magnet for Cambodian refugees and his suggestion that welfare benefits be cut off for teen-age mothers who have a second child, were aimed at people who do not vote, Mr. Payne noted.
''But with the elderly, Silber put his tongue on the third rail of Massachusetts politics,'' Mr. Payne said. ''Silber finally picked on a group that can fight back.''
Nevertheless, Mr. Payne said, ''Silber sounds attractive to a lot of people because he hasn't learned the cautious vocabulary of politicians,'' adding, ''He is fresh and naturally different.''
 
A Hybrid of Sorts
Another of Dr. Silber's appeals is that he is a curious hybrid of liberal and conservative, as he illustrated in a televised debate last week. He once again stated his view that teen-age mothers who have a second child should be stripped of welfare benefits, but he also came out firmly against the death penalty and said he favored strict control on all types of guns.
''Silber is willing to take on the really tough issues,'' said John Cogswell, a retired treasurer of the New England Telephone Company in Boston. ''Too many politicians aren't willing to take on those issues. They're too willing to use platitudes.''
''The way Dr. Silber says things, his choice of analogies and flamboyant phrases, tends to get people to overreact,'' said Mr. Cogswell, who is a member of a special commission appointed by the Massachusetts Legislature to study a universal health care plan for the state. ''But it's part of a constructive dialogue, and he's getting people to think he might be able to change the aspects of government that appear out of control.''
In all the disputes over Dr. Silber, the two Republican candidates for governor, Steven Pierce, the House minority leader, and William F. Weld, a patrician former United States Attorney in Boston, have received far less notice. The Republicans, who make up only 13 percent of the state's registered voters, have not won the governor's office since 1970.
Mr. Pierce, a conservative who has made opposition to tax increases into an angry crusade, won the Republican state convention endorsement and appears well ahead of Mr. Weld.
But in a general election between Dr. Silber and Mr. Pierce, Mr. Kiley said, ''I think people will vote for the real thing,'' the really angry man, Dr. Silber.

GRAPHIC: Photo: John R. Silber, president of Boston University, who some say may be able to win the Democratic nomination for governor of Massachusetts in September. (Associated Press)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (98%); 

STATE: MASSACHUSETTS, USA (98%); 

CITY: BOSTON, MA, USA (94%);
