HEADLINE: A Cyprus Solution - Long Overdue

BYLINE: By Michael D. Barnes; Michael D. Barnes, a lawyer and ex-Representative, lobbies on behalf of Greek-American organizations that support Greek Cypriots.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A ranking United Nations official familiar with the U.N.-sponsored negotiations on Cyprus's future recently told me that, in his view, of all the world's intractable problems the Cyprus situation is one that is clearly solvable. He said that progress depended on outside pressure on Turkey, especially by the U.S., to remove its troops from the island nation, and on insuring that the Greek and Turkish Governments fully participate in any agreement on Cyprus's future political structure.
With all the dramatic changes taking place in the world, the time is ripe for strong U.S. steps to end the Turkish military's longstanding occupation of the island. 
Just over 16 years ago, 40,000 Turkish troops invaded and occupied the northern third of Cyprus. Thousands of Greek Cypriots were forced to flee to the south, leaving behind homes, friends and family.
The island continues to be separated, divided by the so-called green line, an artificial border that is patrolled 24 hours a day, just as the Berlin Wall divided Germany from 1961 until 1989. To this day, 35,000 troops and 65,000 colonists from Turkey remain in northern Cyprus.
The U.S. should play a central role in resolving this conflict. We are the only country with sufficient leverage to force Turkey to re-examine its military presence in Cyprus. For the last 10 years, the Turkish Government has received billions of dollars of U.S. military assistance; last year alone, we sent $500 million in foreign aid.
This level of military aid can no longer be justified as protecting U.S. interests from Soviet expansionism.
It is particularly ironic that one of the most significant effects of our aid is that it enables Turkey to continue financing its occupation of Cyprus.
If a primary goal of our foreign aid program is to promote freedom and self-determination, we are partly frustrating that goal.
For more than a decade and a half, the U.N. has tried to further negotiations by encouraging increased dialogue between the Greek and Turkish Cypriots. This approach has not worked.
The Turkish Cypriot leader Rauf Denktash, who controls the so-called Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus, has no incentive to compromise. As long as he enjoys the military and political support of Ankara, Cyprus will continue to be divided, even though Turkey is the only country that considers the Denktash government legitimate.
In order to play a constructive role in breaking the impasse, the U.S. should place the following conditions on any future military and economic aid to Turkey: Its troops and colonists must be removed from Cyprus; Ankara must rescind its recognition of an independent state in northern Cyprus, and significant progress must be made toward establishing a constitutional democracy based on majority rule, the rule of law and the protection of minority rights.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Municipal Services Shrinking in Suburbs

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL

 BODY:
Cities and towns across the New York metropolitan region are reducing services, sometimes drastically, under pressure from the slowing economy, declining state aid and a populace tired of ever-rising property taxes.
Many communities say they are struggling to keep essential services intact. In affluent towns where essentials are not yet the issue, what is being lost are the extras -cultural events, recreation programs, even door-to-door garbage collection - that helped define the communities and attract many of their residents.
''People expect their tax dollar to pay for more than police, fire and education,'' said Kevin T. Maloney, a spokesman for the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities. ''There's a sense that if you can't go to the library at night, or there are cuts in senior citizens' programs, some people will see this as real quality-of-life issues.'' 
In Windsor, Conn., a suburb of Hartford where taxpayers cut $4 million from the budget this spring, a library branch is closing, some street lights have been turned off and the school system is eliminating 33 jobs.
Savings also show up in scores of smaller ways. In Long Beach, L.I., members of all-star sports teams are receiving commemorative certificates instead of trophies this year. In Middletown, N.J., residents discarding old refrigerators and sofas now must take them to the dump, instead of having them picked up.
As communities re-examine the level of services they can provide, officials say they are caught between two opposing forces. On the one hand, there is a decline in revenue. Federal revenue sharing ended several years ago; state aid has slowed or decreased, and as the economy worsens, towns are encountering slower growth in their tax bases and more people failing to pay property taxes.
On the other hand, residents increasingly oppose large increases in property-tax rates, even as towns must rely on property taxes to finance a growing portion of their budgets.
''The tax burden has merely shifted to the municipal level,'' said Toni Anderson, the finance director of Windsor. ''The Federal Government cut out all its support, and the state government is in the process of cutting out its support while leaving in its mandates. We're the ones who are last in line.''
''It's going to be bad next year,'' said Richard P. Devine, the commissioner of finance for New Rochelle, a city of 72,000 in Westchester County. ''It's either that the tax rate is intolerably high, or we're going to do away with equipment and services that have always been there.''
 
'Room to Scale Back'
Mr. Devine said New Rochelle is affluent and can absorb more budget cuts. ''We have a lot of robust services here, and there is room to scale back some,'' he said.
Yet he said the city is facing the worst of both worlds in its 1991 budget: a tax increase of more than 10 percent, plus the elimination of some services that many residents take for granted.
Red Bank, a town of 12,000 in Monmouth County., N.J., is an example of a town that offers few extras to begin with.
''We really don't have that much leeway to reduce services,'' said Michael Arnone, a dentist who is the town's mayor. ''There aren't really a lot of things you can cut back on. So we cope in the only way we can cope, and that is by raising taxes.''
Because of cuts in state assistance, including general revenue sharing and money for health programs, Red Bank had to raise an additional $1.4 million this year to meet a shortfall in its $7.9 million 1990 budget. The owner of a house valued at $140,000 will see a $500 increase in property taxes, Dr. Arnone said.
Some towns are seeing alarmingly high numbers of people who are not paying their property taxes. Milford, Conn., collected about $1 million in taxes less than it expected in the current tax levy, because only 96.8 percent of the people paid, said Ruth M. Levine, the city's finance director. The town had anticipated 97.5 percent.
''In a budget that is 75 percent funded by property taxes, it's a problem,'' she said.
While many residents said that they do not want taxes raised any more, many also do not want services cut. In Windsor, where school budget cuts eliminated some extracurricular programs and intramural sports and 33 full-time employees, some parents are furious.
''The cuts were a knee-jerk reaction by a certain segment of the town,'' said John L. Reizian, who belongs to a group concerned about the effect of the budget cuts on education.
In New York State, revenue sharing for municipalities has been reduced for next year, but the decrease is being offset by a saving in the money the cities and towns are required to contribute to employee retirement funds. As a result, local government officials say, New York's municipalities are not in as much trouble as those in Connecticut and New Jersey.
 
'Remaining Status Quo'
In Islip, L.I., the Supervisor, Frank R. Jones, said the downturn in financing is being felt in relatively small ways so far. Over the last two years, the town has cut $50,000 from its programs for the aging. In the last year, the price of a meal for elderly people in the town nutrition program was raised to $1.50 from $1.00.
''In general, the programs we would normally expand and improve are remaining status quo, which means we are really falling behind,'' Mr. Jones said. ''We are spending more than we did just to keep the services.''
In New Jersey, cuts in state aid include the state's general revenue sharing program. It was reduced from $50 million to $20 million last year; it was eliminated altogether this year. In addition, the Legislature recently enacted tax increases and a new school-financing system that are intended to provide relief to a majority of the state's towns and cities, but are likely to raise property taxes sharply in many.
Jon R. Moran, senior legislative analyst for the New Jersey League of Municipalities, said that most towns and cities in the state were making cuts in their capital programs, postponing roadwork and other repairs.
In Newtown, N.J., a town of 8,000, taxes were raised an average of $550 a homeowner this year, said Camille Furgieule, the town manager. Still, the town had to reduce hours and cut several positions from its 65-person municipal staff. For the first time, the town will charge for its summer program for children. And the fall clean-up program in which residents could leave bulk trash for the town to pick up has been eliminated.
''The economy isn't as active as it has been, and it has a snowballing effect - it comes down to services in the municipality,'' Mrs. Furgieule said. Even with the cuts and tax increase, she said, for the first time Newton will have to borrow money against taxes it expects to receive in August and November to pay expenses through September.
In Connecticut, municipalities have seen a steady slowing in the growth of their tax bases - the growth was 3.1 percent last year, below the inflation rate - and in state aid. State aid grew 3.6 percent last year, the lowest rise in nine years, said Mr. Maloney of the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities. As a result, property tax increases this year averaged 8.2 percent.
The decline in state aid to West Hartford suggest what is happening around Connecticut. The suburb of 61,000 lost hundreds of thousands of dollars in state aid for non-educational services to private schools; it must pay those costs itself. It lost about $400,000 for special education. Altogether, it lost more than $1 million.
As a result, said Andrew F. Urban, the city's director of financial services, all-day kindergarten has been eliminated except in three schools with needy children; the hours at the public swimming pools and parks have been cut; plans to buy new equipment for the police and fire departments have been postponed, and the summer arts-and-crafts program has been dropped.
The small garbage ''scooters'' used to collect trash no longer go up driveways for door-to-door service, and next year the scooters, a symbol of West Hartford's high level of services, will be eliminated altogether.
Not many people like these budget cuts. And because property taxes are going up everywhere anyway, it is unclear whether residents feel that they are getting any benefit from this year's budgets at all.
''The citizens are not happy,'' Mrs. Furgiuele of Newton, N.J., said. ''They'll come in to my office and they'll sit there and I'll give them the facts. But they don't want to hear the facts. They just want you to fix the bottom line, and you can't do that.''

HEADLINE: State Enters Labor Dispute At Daily New

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT

 BODY:
Calling the labor dispute at The Daily News an explosive situation that could harm the regional economy, New York State's Labor Commissioner announced yesterday that he had appointed a fact-finding panel to help the two sides reach an accord on new contracts.
Hours later, a spokesman for The News denounced the decision as ''an unnecessary intrusion on a private labor matter,'' and hinted that management might try to use the state's entry into the smoldering dispute to impose new working conditions on its 10 unions without further bargaining.
The action by the Labor Commissioner, Thomas F. Hartnett, came shortly after Hezekiah Brown, chairman of the State Mediation Board, certified that despite more than 100 negotiating sessions over six months, efforts toward a voluntary settlement have not been successful. Can You Say 'Impasse'? Mr. Brown and other state officials have generally avoided using the term ''impasse,'' which has a specific application under Federal labor law. Under Federal statutes, management has the right to declare an impasse and impose new working conditions if it concludes that talks are stalling despite good-faith bargaining. 
But The News's spokesman, John T. Sloan, said that management considered Mr. Brown's assessment to be ''a certification by the unions that the talks have reached an impasse.''
Mr. Sloan declined to say whether The News was itself declaring an impasse, and when - or if - management might move to force the issue against the unions.
Mr. Sloan said the only statement he was prepared to make is that, ''We are not going to post conditions this weekend.''
State officials have repeatedly stressed in recent weeks that the creation of a board of inquiry, allowed under a statute that has been used only nine times in 49 years, does not involve the declaration of an impasse, but merely a finding that settlement efforts so far have proved unsuccessful.
The Commissioner's decision, which he said was backed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, was hailed by union leaders as well as by Mayor David N. Dinkins, who said a board of inquiry ''is a sensible way to help resolve this dispute.''
Commissioner Hartnett said he would not be surprised if the panel, composed of three professional labor arbitrators, would ask The News and its unions to observe a cooling-off period during its 60-day inquiry period. Such a step, if honored by both sides, could eliminate the possibility of a strike or lockout before the end of the summer.
But the board has no legal authority to compel actions by either side, although it has broad power to subpoena witnesses and gather evidence as part of its inquiry.
 
Six Disputed Areas
Labor leaders have asserted that the financially troubled paper, owned by the Tribune Company of Chicago, has been maneuvering to try to break the unions by provoking a strike by declaring an impasse and hiring replacement workers.
Mr. Hartnett, flanked by Mr. Brown at a midafternoon news conference at Labor Department headquarters in lower Manhattan, said he had directed the panel to begin work ''as soon as possible,'' concentrating on six important areas of the dispute.
Foremost among these are The News's insistence on a ''management rights'' provision that would allow it to make sweeping reductions in staffing and other changes without prior bargaining with the unions; the issue of what staffing levels are appropriate, and whether ''the denial of management's overall proposals'' would lead to ''the inevitable shutdown of The Daily News.''
Mr. Sloan dismissed the board of inquiry as ''a blatant intrusion on the collective bargaining process'' and ''a diversionary tactic'' by the unions, whose members have been working without contracts since March 30.
 
'A Fresh Look'
But Mr. Hartnett said he had been persuaded that management and the unions could benefit from ''a fresh look at the issues'' by a team of impartial professionals.
''I believe a board of inquiry may be one of the only tools at our disposal to help avoid a strike and secure the future of The Daily News and its employees,'' Mr. Hartnett said. ''I can't imagine why anyone would oppose this.''
The panel members, all appointed by the Labor Commissioner, are the chairman, Martin F. Scheinman of Manhasset, L.I., a lawyer who has seved as an arbitrator in over 1,750 labor disputes around the country; Fred L. Denson of Webster, N.Y., also an lawyer-arbitrator, and Thomas F. Carey of Jericho, L.I., a professor emeritus of collective bargaining at the City College of New York.
On Monday, Mr. Sloan said that The News was prepared to try to block any inquiry by appealing to State Attorney General Robert Abrams, the National Labor Relations Board and, if necessary, the Federal courts.
Yesterday, the spokesman, complaining that the publisher of The News, James Hoge, had been informed of the creation of the board of inquiry only 20 minutes before it was announced to reporters, said management would have to study Mr. Hartnett's decision before deciding on its next step.
Mr. Scheinman, reached by telephone, added: ''Obviously we hope that management are going to be full participants. We see our role not as intruders but as assisters.''
Mr. Hartnett's announcement came two days after the Allied Printing Trades Council, the unions' umbrella group, announced plans to persuade advertisers and readers to begin boycotting The News. On Wednesday, the Tribune Company reported that quarterly operating profits from its newspaper division had plunged $27.1 million ''primarily due to operating losses at The Daily News.''

HEADLINE: Rinfret Urges Freeze On Spending by State

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

 BODY:
In a broad presentation of his fiscal policies if elected New York's governor, Pierre A. Rinfret says he would balance the state budget by freezing spending at its current level but would avoid sweeping cuts in state personnel and programs.
The 66-year-old Republican candidate spelled out his positions in an interview with The New York Times, the most extensive in the two months since he emerged from political obscurity to become a candidate for governor.
 
Colorful Language
The interview, conducted on Tuesday, reinforced Mr. Rinfret's image as an unorthodox politician. For example, to help solve the protracted problems in public housing, he said he favored selling housing units to tenants. who would receive a state subsidy for the purchase. At another point he disagreed with many party regulars by saying he would support Medicaid financing of abortions and having universal health insurance at the national level. 
In the interview, Mr. Rinfret frequently resorted to colorful language not often used by candidates. At one point, he described Ronald Reagan as ''a great B movie actor;'' at another, he said he favored a marketplace in Harlem because ''they like being out in the open.'' Still later, saying that remarks he had made criticizing The Times were misunderstood, he added, ''I was fooling around, like a moron.''
On another question, whether he would address New York City's contention that the state was shortchanging it on education aid, Mr. Rinfret said: ''You want the rest of the state to kill me? They feel this city is ripping them off.''
Detailing his fiscal solutions, he said that if elected, he would impose a spending freeze and try to have private industry take over some of the smaller functions the state is now performing, like Civil Service testing, registering motor vehicles and overseeing the semiautonomous Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
In addition, the candidate, who is an economic forecaster, said he expected an upturn in the state economy that would produce enough revenue for the state to ''grow out'' of its budget difficulties. He also predicted ''a real bonanza'' in 1992 as the Bush adminstration ''gooses'' the economy in anticipation of the Presidential election.
Mr. Rinfret, who often responded frankly by saying he did not know the answer to a question, conceded that he was still learning about government and politics as well as the unwelcome discipline of ''sound bites'' as he tries to topple one of the leading Democrats in the country, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
The state's fiscal problems dominated the one-hour-and-40-minute interview as Mr. Rinfret proposed solutions that were at least unorthodox for a Republican and sometimes seemed inconsistent and contradictory.
Along with a spending freeze, he called for restoring the income tax cut deferred this year by Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature. But he acknowledged a gap of at least $2 billion in next year's budget because of one-time revenues in the current budget. He added that he could not provide all the details of his budget-balancing plans until after the election, when, if elected, he could study the budget more closely.
Asked about what cuts he would make in the budget to close the gap, he balked. ''I don't want to cut the budget,'' he said. ''I'm having trouble with the word 'cuts.' I'm terrified that you're going to say that I was talking about cutting the budget.''
 
'Pork Barrel' Spending
But he did talk about one politically sensitive cut - legislators' member items, money they can allocate to various groups in their districts. He called it ''pork barrel'' spending, costing $120 million annually, that he would veto.
He talked of improving efficiency in government, saying it could save 5 percent of the budget, but did not specify how. He said Medicaid costs could be cut by $400,000 by encouraging people to use clinics rather than hospitals.
He said New York has far more state workers per its population than any other state and yet he demurred at calling for layoffs or the elimination of programs. ''I don't believe in throwing people out of work,'' he said.
Of the bistate Port Authority, he said, ''I'd offer it to Florio.'' Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey shares responsibility for the agency with Governor Cuomo. Mr. Rinfret said that if the authority were sold to private interests as a cost-saving measure, he would insist on a toll freeze for 10 years.
 
'No Different'
He expressed confidence that he could convince New York voters that ''political experience is no different than economic experience.''
The candidate, seated across a table from three Times reporters, appeared relaxed in the interview. By his side was his campaign manager, Assemblyman John Faso of Kinderhook.
The candidate's exuberance sometimes gave way to annoyance as he challenged the basis of a question and denied some statements attributed to him by reporters and politicians. ''I'm shocked by the amount of material that is made up about me,'' he said. He declined to be more specific.
On other matters, he said he would put a college campus in Harlem as well as an open-air market to encourage neighborhood development.
He said he favored the death penalty but opposed Mr. Cuomo's alternative of life without parole because ''a new governor gets in and decides that 20 years is enough'' and gets the law amended.
Mr. Rinfret departed from many New York Republicans in supporting legalized abortion and from virtually all of them in supporting Medicaid financing of abortions for poor women. But he was more of a mainstream Republican in supporting a bill requiring parental consent for abortions for women under 18.
Of universal health insurance, he said, ''I'd like to see it nationally.'' But he opposed such a program at the state level because it would become a ''magnet'' for the sick from other states.
In opposing a state moratorium on Adirondack Preserve private development, he said, ''In simple form, it's creating an elitist environment.''
 
'That's News to Me'
Confronting questions about his credibility, he steadfastly maintained that he had not tried to persuade Herbert London, now the Conservative Party candidate for governor, to be his lieutenant-governor running mate, that he had not sought the Conservative endorsement in a meeting with its leader, Michael Long, and had not told Republican leaders, as they have said, that he was willing to spend $500,000 of his own money for the campaign.
''That's news to me,'' he said of the London offer. Of the meeting with Mr. Long, he said, ''On my word of honor, I never sought his party's nomination.''
As for the money commitment, Mr. Rinfret was emphatic. ''May the Lord strike me dead; I never promised $500,000,'' he said. Asked about the $540,000 he has contributed to his campaign, he replied, ''Everybody said I was going to do it, so I said what the hell, I might as well do it.''
Was that commitment a major factor in his selection? ''My answer is very simple,'' Mr. Rinfret said. ''It smacks of buying and I ain't going to buy nothing.''

HEADLINE: Starrett City Withdraws Proposal To Offer Apartments to Soviet Jews

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
The owners of the Starrett City housing complex in southeast Brooklyn yesterday withdrew a plan to make apartments available to Soviet Jewish emigres.
The proposal was criticized by housing advocates as an attempt to evade a ruling by the United States Supreme Court that the complex had used racial quotas to discriminate against black and Hispanic families on its waiting list.
Harvey Rudman, the president and chief operating officer of Starrett City Associates, said yesterday that the company had dropped its inquiry to the Department of Justice about whether the emigre plan would violate a consent decree that Starrett had signed in May 1989. 
The company signed the decree after a November 1988 Court decision outlawed quotas at Starrett that favored whites over minority families.
 
'Viewed as Divisive'
A Starrett spokeswoman, Devorah L. Fong, said the emigre plan was dropped after City Council members and representatives of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins ''expressed concern that it might be viewed as divisive.''
''We didn't want to contribute to the mounting tensions in the city,'' she said.
The plan became known this week, after Starrett officials acknowledged it in response to questions from The New York Times.
The complex - which opened in 1974 and whose motto is ''Where harmony is a way of life'' - has 46 buildings with nearly 6,000 apartments. About 55 percent of its residents are white, and its waiting list includes about 8,000 families.
Ms. Fong said the inquiry was not meant to create a certain ethnic mix but as a way to increase Starrett's ''economic diversity.''
The idea, which developed after Mr. Rudman was approached by organizations representing Soviet emigres, was to provide housing assistance of up to $2,000 over two years. ''But it was never a formal proposal,'' Ms. Fong said. ''It was just an inquiry as to whether this kind of thing would be permissible.''
Critics said the plan was meant to increase Starrett's white population to enhance market value if the owners converted the complex to a cooperative, as would be possible after 1994. They also charged that hundreds of apartments were held vacant for higher-income people who could pay market rates.
Ms. Fong said that apartments were not being held vacant, that 95 percent of Starrett's newest residents are black, and that the idea would not have allowed Soviet emigres to circumvent the waiting list.

HEADLINE: Man Tells of Stealing 13 Buses, Police Say

 BODY:
A 25-year-old from Queens who was arrested on Wednesday in the theft of a bus for a joy ride has confessed to taking 13 of the 22 buses that have been stolen in the last year, the transit police said yesterday.
The suspect, Darius McCollum of 107-35 Fern Place in Jamaica, told officers of the surface-crime unit, which has been investigating the thefts, that he stole 13 buses from Transit Authority depots, a spokesman for the transit police, Albert O'Leary, said. 
Officers who interviewed Mr. McCollum, who drives trucks in the winter and is now unemployed, described him as a ''bus buff'' who is familiar with bus jargon and operations, as well as the procedures of the unit that tracked him. He told one officer what duty the officer had been assigned to years ago.
Mr. McCollum was wearing a bus driver's uniform when he was seized driving a stolen bus. Officer Michael Minero said, ''It's clear from the way he talks that he's been around bus drivers for some time.''
The officers said Mr. McCollum apparently stole the buses ''for the fun of it and usually parked them near depots, so they could be recovered.''

HEADLINE: On Stage

BYLINE: By Enid Nemy

 BODY:

Short Stories in Song
''Heart's Desire'' had a developmental workout at Purchase, N.Y., for three weeks in January, and it's having another at one of the small theaters at Vassar College beginning Sunday. Even at this early stage, said Glen Roven, who conceived the musical, the film rights have been optioned by the producers Peter Guber and Jon Peters. In the fall there will be a production at the Cleveland Playhouse, and if everything works out as planned, a $3.5 million production of the show will be on Broadway in February.
Mr. Roven, who began his theatrical career as a rehearsal pianist while still in college, said the show was inspired by the power and the current popularity of short stories, and the thought that it would be interesting to transfer this idea to musical theater. He began by asking four writers to work on individual segments of a theme, taking in ''people's relationships and how to cope in these difficult times,'' using a different age group, from the teens to the 40's, in each segment. The individual but thematically related episodes were written first as short stories and then adapted for the stage by Stuart Dybek, Beverly Lowry, Armistead Maupin and Treva Silverman. The settings are Chicago, Texas, San Francisco and New York. 
The show, which will star Peter Gallagher and Alyson Reed, will be directed by Jack Hofsiss. A. Joseph Tandet, Michael Frazier and Mary Nelon are producing. Mr. Roven has written the music and lyrics.
 
Proposing Through Playbill
Christine Catti and Michael Schwendemann have known each other for five years, ever since they were at Queens College. Earlier this month, they went to see ''Aspects of Love.'' As Miss Catti was leafing through the Playbill before the show began, she saw her friend's name at the bottom of a letter. ''Wow,'' she said, ''what's this?'' Mr. Schwendemann, who knew what was there, replied, ''Read it, you dope.''
This is what she read: ''Dear Playbill: I am interested in spending the rest of my life with Christine Catti, production assistant at the Roundabout Theater Company, but I don't know if she will accept this proposal from a currently unemployed actor such as myself. What do you think?''
Playbill, which apparently had never had a marriage proposal in its letters column, said she should accept.
Miss Catti said she was ''totally shocked and amazed'' at the letter, but she pulled herself together enough to accept. Mr. Schwendemann then extracted a ring from his pocket and put it on her finger. ''And after that, I was supposed to watch the show!'' Miss Catti said.
Mr. Schwendemann is no longer unemployed. He now has a part in ''Social Security,'' opening in Port Jefferson, L.I., next month. The wedding is scheduled to take place in the fall of 1991 because, Miss Catti said, ''we have to afford it.''
 
Bless This Musical
It could be a first, but in theater one never knows. At noon today, ''Shogun,'' the James Clavell musical scheduled to open in November, will be blessed at a Shinto ceremony to be conducted by Haruki Kadokawa, who, in addition to being one of the musical's producers and a film producer and director in Japan, is also a High Shinto priest. Mr. Kadokawa will be assisted by four other Shinto priests who traveled to New York City from Japan, with ceremonial garments, especially for the blessing. The ceremony, incidentally, is not only for the musical, but also for the cast, creators, production staff and theater - the Marquis - where the show will be performed.
 
Sinise on Celebrity
''This business is so difficult; it's like, who is the flavor of the day?'' said Gary Sinise, who plays Tom Joad in the Steppenwolf Theater Company's production of ''The Grapes of Wrath.'' ''Television and Hollywood have done that; it's all about the moment and not the long haul.''
As for himself, said Mr. Sinise, a founder of Steppenwolf who has worked in motion pictures, on television and on stage, ''momentary celebrity is not that interesting.''
''Longevity is the important thing,'' he said. ''I see having a very long career and doing a lot of different things: acting, directing and even writing.''
Mr. Sinise, who as an adolescent was ''a very bad, mixed-up kid with a lot of problems,'' said his life turned around when he tried out for a high-school production of ''West Side Story.''
''Me and a bunch of other rotten kids went to audition,'' he said. ''We thought that beating up the kids on stage would be a lot of fun.'' He was amazed, he said, when the drama teacher, Barbara Patterson, ''cast the bunch of us.'' He credits Miss Patterson and Jeff Perry, a co-founder of Steppenwolf and a fellow cast member in ''The Grapes of Wrath,'' with introducing him to a ''whole new world and turning my life around.''
''It's a gypsy life, but that's the way it is being an actor,'' he said, ''changing face to be another person and changing locale. But you're fortunate to be working enough to be a gypsy.''
 
Improvements for the Lortel
Work began this month on a $250,000 renovation of the Lucille Lortel Theater, the original home (when it was called Theater de Lys) of shows like ''The Threepenny Opera,'' ''Brecht on Brecht'' and ''Cloud 9.'' Among the improvements, expected to be completed by early September, will be new seating, new air conditioning and facilities for the handicapped, including a chair lift to the mezzanine. Cattle Call? Not Quite. So maybe you'll never make it to Broadway, but if your dog is a terrier, there's a possibility that he or she will. A canine open audition is coming up Aug. 14 for the role of Asta, the dog that is almost as memorable as William Powell and Myrna Loy in the ''Thin Man'' movies. ''Nick and Nora,'' the stage show based on the characters in the novel by Dashiell Hammett, is scheduled to open on Broadway in February with Barry Bostwick and Joanna Gleason playing the Charleses. Roseland, 239 West 52d Street, is the place to go. Information: 768-3826.

HEADLINE: New Faces: Adrienne Shelly and Robert Burke;
2 Performers Who've Lived Their Roles

BYLINE: By KAREN SCHOEMER

 BODY:
Although 24-year-old Adrienne Shelly and 29-year-old Robert Burke are making their screen debuts in Hal Hartley's film ''The Unbelievable Truth,'' both actors seem to have known their characters inside out before even reading the script.
When Ms. Shelly was a teen-ager, she made a deal with her parents. She agreed to go to college and earn a sensible degree in something other than theater so that she would have something to fall back on if her acting career did not work out. But midway through her junior year as a communications major, Ms. Shelly lost patience with student life and asked her parents to let her out of the bargain. She moved to Manhattan, found a small apartment in Chelsea and began working in the theater. 
Like Audry, the character she plays in Mr. Hartley's critically acclaimed film, Ms. Shelly realized that deals can be a hindrance instead of help in achieving goals. Audry is a disaffected, hardhearted high-school senior who arranges elaborate deals with her father to combat the ennui she feels in her sleepy hometown on Long Island. She is convinced that the world is going to end, so she agrees to attend Harvard only if her father donates money to a coalition for nuclear disarmament. When a fast-talking fashion photographer boasts that he can make Audry a wealthy model, her father renegotiates the college deal out of greed. Then Audry falls for Josh (Mr. Burke), a black-garbed stranger with a shadowy past, who is returning home after several years in prison.
 
Cynical yet Vulnerable
''Josh is the only person in the whole film who doesn't let Audry get away with her behavior, and I think that's what attracts her to him,'' Ms. Shelly said in a recent interview at a Manhattan coffee shop. ''The way I see it is that love can put an end to this bureaucracy people go through in their relationships. But it can't blind you to the fact that maybe there are bombs, there are problems and the ozone layer is depleting.''
Ms. Shelly, who like Audry grew up on Long Island, lends her character the brash, overconfident grandeur of a cynical teen-ager yet reveals a stark vulnerability as the film progresses. In a long confrontation scene with Josh, Audry confesses her feelings without knowing she has a giant smear of lipstick across her cheek. ''That's my favorite scene in the movie,'' Ms. Shelly said with a laugh. ''It's very like me to have something like that happen.''
Although Ms. Shelly has been offered other film work, she said she chose ''The Unbelievable Truth'' as her feature debut partly out of empathy with Audry's sense of displacement. ''I did a lot of acting when I was a child,'' she said. ''I was very shy - the kind of kid who ran into a corner and cried on parents' visiting day.''
While growing up, she attended several performing-arts camps, then moved into professional stock theater when she was 15. Between her work on ''The Unbelievable Truth'' and a starring role in Mr. Hartley's second film, ''Trust'' (to be released next year), she founded her own theater company, Missing Children, whose premiere production will open next month at the Perry Street Theater in the West Village. ''Theater represents to me this phenomenon in juxtaposition to real life, where there are all these imposed guidelines,'' she said. ''Ever since I was little, it never seemed fair that I had to live by these rules. Why did I have to go to sleep just because it was dark? I never liked those guidelines. In theater you don't have to live by them.''
 
Acting and Life
Mr. Burke shares Ms. Shelly's disrespect for doing things the conventional way. Although he said he has appeared in ''thousands of performances'' throughout high school and college and was regarded as one of the most promising actors in his class at the State University College at Purchase, N.Y., he left acting for several years after graduating from college. His departure was partly motivated by the death of his father, to whom he was very close. ''I was meeting people and they were, like, 'He's so brooding; he's so angry,' '' he said. ''And I was angry. I was sad.'' But Mr. Burke was also disenchanted with the pressures and personal economics of professional acting. ''I just always wanted to take my time with this whole nonsense,'' he said recently. ''I saw other people slamming themselves against a wall. I respect them for their tenacity and resilience, but I'm not in the big rush.''
He taught in an experimental education program for three and a half years, then took up carpentry. The break from acting helped him, he said. ''It got rid of the acting voice and the acting speech. It gave me a life and life experiences.''
A first-generation Irish-American who grew up in Manhattan and on Long Island, Mr. Burke had nearly given up on the idea of returning to acting when he received a call from Mr. Hartley about the role of Josh. ''I knew the character would give me the debt, and now he's returning to the only place he knows. He's a character who has been rehabilitated. Josh doesn't blow up. He doesn't have any catharsis. He won't get angry because perhaps he'll skip right to rage.''
In the film, every move Mr. Burke makes is cautious, restrained, contained by the stigma of being an ex-convict. Even when he doesn't move a muscle, his face is thoughtful, grim. ''The interiority of the character -there is that interiority in me,'' he said. ''It was easy in one respect to play that part after taking years off of acting. It was like a little self-imposed exile. And Josh coming out of prison and everything - I say sometimes that my exile was completely transferable to the charcter.''
''I'm a lot more cautious now, a lot quieter,'' he said. ''I didn't want Josh to be sentimental. I wanted him to be above that. There is a transcending quality in the acceptance of someone's life.''

HEADLINE: TV Weekend;
Skip the Pen, Forget the Paper; Just Send Videos

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

 BODY:
CBS is having a promising run with original programming this summer. At 10 P.M. on Thursdays, the network is doing very nicely indeed with ''Northern Exposure,'' a show about a doctor from New York who moves to Alaska. And at 9:30 P.M. on Fridays, there is ''Wish You Were Here,'' the second episode of which can be seen this evening.
''Wish You Were Here'' was developed by Those Guys International, a new outfit of three men in their early 30's. Robert Altman and Steve Bawol, who grew up together in Greenwich, Conn., produced the 1988 syndicated series ''The Street.'' Taped with hand-held videocams, its 40 half-hour episodes told slice-of-life stories about police officers in Newark. Skip Lane, who grew up in Greenwich Village, was their agent at the William Morris Agency and set up the 1988 project. 
For ''Wish You Were Here,'' the three men are almost entirely sticking with videocam technology, using the Sony Hi-8-millimeter format for taping with local actors on locations that include New York, France, Hungary, Spain and Morocco. The economic angle is obvious. Episodes are brought in for about half the normal cost of a prime-time network series. More to the point, however, ''Wish You Were Here'' adds up to fresh, offbeat and imaginative television.
Our hero is Donny Cogswell, and he is played by Lew Schneider, a comedian who not only looks but also acts like Tom Hanks. With perfect timing, Donny decides to leave the rat race of Wall Street. He is more interested in his new video camera, which he sees as the perfect instrument for capturing ''all my special moments.'' His boss is not far off the mark when he says Donny's problem is attitude. It seems to be unfocused. Donny cheerfully agrees, and decides to travel around the world, sending back videotapes as postcards. Voila, the concept!
Last week, Donny wound up in Paris after leaving the choice of destination up to an airline clerk. ''If I choose, something terrible will happen,'' Donny said. ''They'll serve lasagna.'' On the banks of the Seine, Donny interviewed surly flower vendors and passionately kissing lovers, all in an effort to win back his former girlfriend in New York, who was watching the video postcard while trying to tell her new boyfriend not to be jealous. (''Is that Tom Hanks?'' asked the beau. ''What's he do to his hair?'') The plot mechanics can be as dizzying as the characters.
For the show tonight, Donny has sent a video to his family ''somewhere near Cleveland.'' The tape chronicles his visit to Hungary, birthplace of his crusty Grandpa Ziggy (Sandor Szabo). Celebrating Grandpa's birthday, the family sits watching the tape with understandable trepidation. Grandpa is furious with Donny for quitting his job. Donny begins the tape by fondly recalling how he loved listening to Grandpa's millions of stories about growing up poor, or was it, Donny suddenly wonders, the same story told a million times.
Leaving Budapest, Donny heads for Grandpa's village, thrilled at the prospect of exploring his roots. (''Just call me Kunta Cogswell,'' he narrates.) Along the way, however, he runs into inexplicable hostility whenever he mentions the family name. One man throws him out of his car, driving off with the puzzling advice: ''Don't vorry. Be heppy.'' When the many misunderstandings are finally resolved, Donny and Grandpa will, of course, discover how much alike they really are.
''Wish You Were Here'' is somewhat messy and not entirely convincing. The camera work is too professional to have been recorded entirely by an amateur, no matter how enthusiastic. But the combination of travelogue and sitcom has a goofy charm of its own. And it certainly is original.

At 9:30 tonight on CBS.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1, Column 4; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1436 words

HEADLINE: Japanese Lessor Thrives Under Loose Regulation

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
In the staid world of Japanese finance, the Orix Corporation is like a jazz musician. It can improvise across the spectrum of financial markets more freely than securities houses and insurance companies here because, as a leasing company, it operates under a separate and more liberal regulatory system.
As a result, the vibrant mix of businesses the company has assembled is providing some of the first clear notes of something Japan says it wants but still fears - a deregulated financial system.
Orix, which until two years ago was known as Oriental Leasing and is Japan's largest leasing company, has been more aggressive than most in experimenting with its regulatory freedom. It owns a professional baseball team, trades securities, and recently bought a fleet of commercial aircraft from bankrupt Braniff Airlines Inc. Such expansion is taking Orix increasingly into the United States. 
''We've been fortunate that when we see an opportunity, we can try it,'' said Yoshihiko Miyauchi, Orix's chief executive, a gregarious man who holds a master's degree in business from the University of Washington. ''But beyond that wall,'' he added, referring to regulated financial businesses, ''it's hard to even breathe.''
While banks and securities brokers are overseen by the strict bureaucrats of the Ministry of Finance, leasing companies like Orix, whose traditional role was financing purchases of equipment for industrial concerns, report to the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. The trade ministry has generally permitted leasing companies to wander across the financial spectrum with few constraints.
These regulatory inequalities have drawn much attention recently, as the move toward financial liberalization has become bogged down in bickering between banks and securities companies over the extent to which each should be allowed in the other's businesses.
In the meantime, Orix continues to pursue a bewildering number of businesses, although not with the approval of all. Moody's Investors Service, the financial rating agency, lowered Orix's debt rating in April.
''This is about the most complicated financial company to follow in Japan,'' said James Russell, an analyst here with Merrill Lynch & Company. ''What you learn from them really doesn't apply to anyone else.''
Orix trades financial futures and sells shares in commodity funds to individuals; it finances merchant ships and operates its own fleet; it is a leader in computer leasing, consumer finance and mortgage lending; it operates Budget Rent A Car in Japan, owns a small Japanese securities company and runs a London merchant bank.
 
Surprising Move in Jets
In a move that surprised many here, Orix paid $62 million last month to Braniff for the right to acquire 74 Airbus Industrie jets. It was the first time a Japanese financial concern had taken the risk not just of financing aircraft but of owning them outright. Mr. Miyauchi said that the jets would be sold or leased to airlines.
It was the sort of bold move for which Orix is known. ''What Orix has achieved has generally been by taking a lot of chances that others won't,'' said Roger Gough, an analyst here with Baring Securities.
But Orix's push into so many different fields has not been without substantial risks and criticism. For instance, the company was stuck with a $10 million debt from the bankrupt Drexel Burnham Lambert, most of which it has written off, and a $5 million loan to the wobbly Trump Organization in New York.
Those are decidedly modest sums for a company with total operating assets of 4.13 trillion yen, or about $28 billion. In the fiscal year that ended March 31, Orix also reported net income of 19.3 billion yen, or $130 million at current exchange rates. Too Far Afield? But as Stuart Matthews, an analyst here with Barclays deZoete Wedd, a British securities firm, commented, ''The big worry is that they are too aggressive, that they move too far afield.''
Mr. Miyauchi insists that such concerns will not slow him down. The company already has a sizable presence in the United States and is likely to become better known there. Late last year, it acquired the Commercial Alliance Leasing Company, a basic-equipment lessor, from the First Interstate Bank. It also owns 30 percent of the Commodities Corporation in Princeton, N.J., and 39 percent of Rubloff Inc., a big Chicago real estate concern.
Orix has also been shopping for more than a year for a Wall Street securities firm. ''We have tried to acquire several investment banks in the past but we stopped the negotiations because of price,'' said Sachio Hata, senior managing director and head of Orix's international operations. ''But we haven't given up.''
 
A Simple Strategy
One of the key criticisms of the company is that its disparate parts do not seem bound together by a coherent vision. Mr. Miyauchi acknowledged that Orix had followed a strategy of simply moving from each of its core businesses into related fields without much long-term planning.
''After you do that for a while, you find that what is happening at the right hand has nothing to do with the left hand,'' he said. ''But we feel these are businesses we know.''
The company contends that it has a basic conceptual framework. As explained by Mr. Hata, the aim is to become more like a traditional British merchant bank, acting as both an investor and an arranger of complex deals, collecting fees for its work. It is trying to become a giant financial intermediary, putting together borrowers and lenders from around the world.
Orix is diversifying, Mr. Hata added, to create a broader base of contacts and customers. ''Information is a very valuable asset for us,'' he said. ''That is the main asset we want to develop.''
Orix is also seeking new opportunities to sell portions of its investments to generate fee income. For a long time, it has syndicated portions of its large commercial loans and leases, and more recently has been doing the same with real estate developments in the United States, selling partnership interests to Japanese investors and keeping a piece of the financing for its own portfolio.
 
Clear Sign of Worries
The clearest sign of the worries this approach has created was the Moody's downgrading in April of Orix's debt rating to Baa2, from A3. Moody's cited three reasons for its shift: concern that the steep upswing in Japanese interest rates over the last year had increased Orix's costs faster than the company's ability to pass on those costs to customers; the heavy lendings to the Japanese real estate sector, which has boomed over the last five years but which some believe may be in for a fall, and the company's relatively weak capital base. Orix has 189.7 billion yen, or about $1.28 billion, in shareholder equity - equal to 4.6 percent of its operating assets.
Mr. Miyauchi insisted that the concerns were overblown. He maintained that Orix had locked in long-term borrowings at relatively low fixed rates and that it started this process before interest rates spurted upward.
As of March 31, Orix's long-term borrowings of 2.33 trillion yen were greater than the short-term debt of 1.886 trillion yen. That is a reversal from the year earlier, when riskier short-term debt outweighed long-term debt by 1.73 trillion yen to 1.2 trillion yen.
''You can't earn any profits without risk,'' Mr. Hata said. ''My personal feeling is that we are always walking towards the edge of a cliff and that we must have the skill not to go over.''
 
Close Call in Ships
Orix has extricated itself from deep trouble before. It dived heavily into ship financing in the 1970's and early 1980's and struggled to stay viable during the shipping industry depression that started in 1982.
Orix's profits, however, continued to grow, if slowly, because of a diverse earnings base. Mr. Miyauchi said it was not until two years ago that the company began to turn a profit from some of its older ships.
Orix's sudden interest in baseball is an example of how the company has grown. A couple of years ago it began to move into consumer financing and mortgage lending. However, its name was little known to the public. Mr. Miyauchi said that upon learning that a baseball team was for sale, a rare event in Japan, he jumped at the opportunity as a way to gain better name recognition even though the club, now called the Orix Braves, loses money.
''These opportunities do not come up very often in Japan,'' Mr. Miyauchi said. ''When we heard about it, we decided it made sense for us. You have to be willing to do that in our business.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Orix's opportunistic management is led by Yoshihiko Miyauchi, left, president and chief executive, and Sachio Hata, senior managing director and head of international operations, at headquarters in Tokyo. (Associated Press for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Earnings Plunge at G.M., Ford

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 26

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company yesterday reported sharply lower second-quarter profits. Both auto makers cited difficult market conditions in North America, and both were hit by economic disruption in Brazil that virtually stopped vehicle production there.
The results from the nation's two biggest auto makers, however, were in line with forecasts of analysts, who have noted falling United States production and the high cost of rebates and other incentives.
On the New York Stock Exchange, G.M. shares slipped 37.5 cents, to $47.25, and Ford also fell 37.5 cents, closing at $41.875. 
 
Costly Incentives
Scott Merlis, an analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, said, ''Earnings were depressed but not as depressed as they could have been, considering that factory production was at recessionary levels and incentives were at a record high levels.''
Auto makers calculate revenue and profit on the basis of factory sales to dealers, not retail sales to consumers. G.M.'s non-automotive subsidiaries reported profits of $616.4 million, about equal to those in the period last year. The Chrysler Corporation, which analysts also expect to report lower earnings, said it would release financial results on Tuesday.
G.M. said profit for the second quarter was $900 million, or $1.32 a share, down 38 percent from $1.45 billion, or $2.23 a share, in the period last year. Revenues were $33.9 billion, up slightly from $33.5 billion in the 1989 quarter. The six-month profit was $1.61 billion, or $2.34 a share, on revenue of $64.1 billion, compared with a profit of $3 billion, or $4.60 a share, on revenue of $66.8 billion in the first half of last year.
 
Hurt by Brazil
In a statement, G.M. said, ''Second-quarter earnings reflected the adverse impact of higher sales incentives on G.M.'s North American automotive operations.'' But the company added that overseas profits, excluding results from Brazil, were at a record level.
The economic overhaul in Brazil in the first half of the year resulted in a temporary closing of the banks and the stoppage of most manufacturing. G.M. and Ford make and sell far fewer vehicles in South America than in North America, but the complete shutdown of operations had a significant negative impact both auto makers' income. Both companies said Brazilian vehicle production has resumed in the third quarter and is beginning to approach normal levels.
G.M., the nation's No. 1 auto maker, produced more than 1.5 million cars and trucks in North America in the quarter, a drop of 3.1 percent from the period last year. Overseas production rose to 630,000, from 622,000, during the quarter, an increase of 1.3 percent.
For the last year auto makers have faced relatively soft demand for vehicles in North America, forcing them to cut production. But they have also had to prop up sales with discounts, which they refer to as incentives. G.M. declined to say how much it spent in incentives during the quarter, but a spokesman said the amount was roughly equal to a figure made public by Ford: $1,050 for every car and truck sold. Ford said the average second-quarter incentive compared with an average incentive of about $1,000 during the first quarter and $600 during the second quarter of last year.
 
Ford
Ford said second-quarter profit was $770.7 million, or $1.67 a share, off 45 percent from $1.41 billion, or $3 a share, in the 1989 period. Revenues for the quarter were up 3.9 percent, to $26.9 billion, from $25.9 billion. Six-month profit was $1.28 billion, or $2.77 a share, on revenue of $50.5 billion, compared with $3.04 billion, or $6.45 a share, on revenue of $51.8 billion last year.
Ford's vehicle production in the United States for the quarter was 975,000, a 7.6 percent decline from 1.1 million a year ago. Elsewhere, Ford's factory production was 711,000, down 6.3 percent from a year ago.
Ford had other problems overseas during the quarter: labor stoppages in Britain and Belgium.
The No. 2 United States auto maker's capital spending increased by $83 million during the period, to $1.7 billion. David N. McCammon, Ford's treasurer, said corporate borrowings have been heavier partly because of heavier outlays for product development and other capital projects. Mr. McCammon said Ford's debt to equity ratio had risen to 27 percent in the latest period, from 17 percent in the first quarter and 10 percent in the period last year.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Who Is No. 1? It's Hard to Say

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
WHICH country has the strongest economy in the world?
The question has assumed growing importance at a time when economic strength is perceived as the cardinal component in national power and when the industrial world may be dividing into three regions centered on the United States, Japan and a united Germany. Finding an answer involves complex issues of concept and measurement.
As measured by gross domestic product - the total volume of goods and services produced by a nation, within its borders - the United States still has the largest economy by far. United States G.D.P. in 1989 was $5.17 trillion, compared with Japan's $2.82 trillion and a united Germany's $1.5 trillion, at current exchange rates between the dollar, the yen and the mark. 
But much of the difference is attributed to population size. With the American population nearly twice as large as Japan's and more than three times Germany's, America's per capita gross domestic product was $20,766 last year, less than Japan's $22,855 but ahead of united Germany's $19,230. These comparisons are misleading, however, because they are measured at current exchange rates, which have swung widely and are a poor indicator of the real value of money spent in one's own country. For instance, Japan is expensive for Americans earning dollars and the United States is cheap for Japanese earning yen.
To correct this distortion, three University of Pennsylvania economists - Irving Kravis, Robert Summers and Alan Heston - have developed measures of international output and income based not on exchange rates but on so-called purchasing power parities, which are conversion rates that equalize price levels among countries.
The Kravis-Summers-Heston data, prepared for the United Nations International Comparison Project, which compares income and output of various countries, show that Japan's per capita domestic product was only 75 percent as large as that of the United States in 1987, on a purchasing power basis. Commenting on that large gap, Herbert Stein, a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, says, ''There is already so much paranoia about Japan in the United States that it seems to me important to get this comparison right.''
But measures of economic strength should be dynamic, and Japan has been steadily narrowing the gap with the United States. From 1980 through 1989, Japan's real gross domestic product, measured in purchasing power parities, grew at an average annual rate of 4.2 percent, compared with the United States' 2.6 percent. If those disparate growth rates continue, Japan's per capita gross domestic product in the year 2000 would equal 95 percent of that in the United States, and Japan would pass the United States by the year 2004.
In an article, ''Capital Investment: Key to Competitiveness and Growth,'' in the current Brookings Review, Ralph Landau of Stanford University examines the reasons why productivity has been lagging in the United States. He finds a high correlation between national growth rates of capital per worker and labor productivity. Japan had a growth rate of capital per worker of more than 8 percent and a growth rate of labor productivity of nearly 5 percent from 1964 through 1985, while United States gross capital per worker rose less than 2 percent a year and labor productivity less than 1 percent a year.
The Council on Competitiveness, a group of economists, executives and union officials, reports that in absolute terms Japan has overtaken the United States, with investment in new factories and equipment at $549 billion in 1989, compared with $513 billion by the United States.
Without basic changes in United States policy, Professor Landau concludes, ''The high cost of capital, greater uncertainty, inadequate savings and investment, increasing reliance on foreign capital in an open world capital market, and short time horizons by corporate managers and public policy makers will continue to gnaw away at the American standard of living.''
Further concern on that score emerges from the 1990 Human Development Report of the United Nations. A Human Development Index prepared by a group of economists ranks 130 nations according to life expectancy at birth, adult literacy and real gross domestic product per capita, measured on a purchasing power parities basis. The United States was 17th on the list - tied with Austria and Ireland - with a life expectancy at birth of 76 years, an adult literacy rate of 96 percent and a per capita G.D.P. of $17,615. The index rated Japan first, with life expectancy of 78 years, adult literacy of 100 percent and per capita G.D.P. of $13,135.
The low United States savings rate and chronic budget and trade deficits inhibit the strength of the United States in dealing with foreign and domestic problems and issues, compared with Germany and Japan. This may be no cause for paranoia but it certainly calls for a lot of soul searching.

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 10.15 Points, To 2,920.79

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stock prices weakened yesterday in sluggish trading, with investors continuing to show nervousness over disappointing earnings.
Tobacco stocks were hit especially hard in the wake of a landmark court ruling in New Jersey.
Last week the Dow Jones industrial average twice stood within a quarter point of 3,000, but the blue-chip index closed yesterday at 2,920.79, down 10.15 and nearly 80 points away from that supposedly magic mark of 3,000.
Volume slowed to 155 million shares, from 163.5 million the day before. Declines outnumbered advances, 778 to 701, and, in a sign that suggested further weakness, 72 stocks set new lows. 
''Corporate earnings are still a factor,'' Kenneth P. Ducey, senior vice president of S. G. Warburg & Company, said of yesterday's downturn. ''And a lot of people are focusing on the G.N.P. numbers'' due out today. ''They feel the economy is slowing down more than anticipated.''
A report by a Prudential-Bache analyst, Melissa R. Brown, showed that of 410 companies surveyed, 18.5 percent reported stronger-than-expected profits but 24.6 percent reported weaker-than-expected earnings. Moreover, she said, she expected that as earnings continued to come in they ''will probably stay skewed toward disappointments.''
 
Over-The-Counter Trading
In over-the-counter trading, low earnings or forecasts of weak profits sank Wholesale Club 5 5/8, to 18 1/2, and Microsoft 2 3/4, to 68 3/4. On the Big Board, weak earnings news toppled Raychem 1 7/8, to 26 3/8; Delta Air Lines 1 1/2, to 65 7/8; Compaq Computer 1 1/2, to 57 7/8, and Goodyear Tire 7/8, to 27 1/4. UAL rose 3 1/4, to 163 after a rise in second-quarter profits.
Tobacco stocks tumbled in the wake of a suit against the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, American Brands and the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation in which the Supreme Court of New Jersey, in a landmark decision, ruled that warnings on cigarette packages do not protect manufacturers from liability suits. The ruling will almost certainly be appealed to the United States Supreme Court.
American Brands, which makes Pall Mall, Tareyton and Lucky Strikes, fell 3 3/8, to 66 1/4. Philip Morris, which produces Marlboro, Benson & Hedges and other makes, fell 1 3/4, to 47 1/4, and Loews, whose Lorillard unit makes Kent, Newport and other brands, fell 2 1/4, to 105 1/2.
Value Line, the investment survey, said in a report on Loews that despite increasing risks, ''it will be years before tobacco profits are permanently impaired.'' Even so, tobacco is so important to Philip Morris that 3.2 million shares changed hands yesterday, making it the second-most-active stock on the Big Board.
 
RJR Nabisco Refinancing
The New Jersey ruling also shook investors interested in RJR Nabisco's huge new refinancing, which coincidentally came to market yesterday. Of particular concern was the position long-term bank lenders would take towards the surprise court finding.
Litigation also hit Eli Lilly, the drug company, which produces the antidepressant Prozac, the company's best seller. Lilly fell 4 3/8, to 79 5/8, in heavy trading after three widows sued Lilly and others in Kentucky on charges that a printer who had used the drug killed their husbands in a shooting rampage that took nine lives. The stock fell sharply a week ago after a New York woman charged that the drug made her attempt suicide.
As it has almost regularly, program trading played a big role in shaping the market's movements. Birinyi Associates, which tracks such activity, said that the net impact of four selling programs and two buying programs was to lop nearly 19 points of the Dow. One nine-minute series of selling programs around 3:15 pushed the Dow down 11 points alone, it said.
With the Dow industrials down only 10.15, changes among the 30 stocks were small. Except for the 1 3/4 drop in Philip Morris, I.B.M., which fell 1 5/8, to 113 1/8, was the only decline of a point or more. DuPont rose 1 1/2, to 40 7/8, after joining with Merck in a 50-50 deal that will open Merck's foreign markets to DuPont and give Merck access to DuPont's drug technology.
Among the Nasdaq technology stocks, Novell fell 1 3/8, to 47 7/8 and Lotus Development fell 1 1/4, to 21 3/4. On the Big Board, Motorola rose 1, to 80 3/4 and Compaq Computer fell 1 1/2, to 57 7/8. On the Amex, Amdahl fell 1 1/4, to 15 1/2.
The S. & P. 500 fell 1.18, to 355.91; the Nasdaq composite fell 0.02, to 445.43 and the Amex market value index fell 0.62, to 356.33.

HEADLINE: Goodyear, Citing Costs, Reports Loss

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the world's second-largest tire producer, yesterday reported a second-quarter loss of $9.4 million, reflecting costs associated with belt-tightening and reorganization.
The company took a $21.4 million charge against second-quarter earnings, a result of a realignment of operations in North America, the laying off of 1,100 workers and closing of a plant in Massachusetts.
Goodyear, based in Akron, Ohio, announced last month that it would take a charge against earnings because of competitive pressures in the tire industry and the reorganizaiton. Goodyear's last quarterly loss was in the first period of 1986, primarily because of a write-off. 
 
Realignment of Offices
In the second quarter of last year, Goodyear reported net income of $27.1 million, or 47 cents a share. Sales for the second quarter of this year were $2.87 billion, up from $2.81 billion in the period last year.
The company said the layoffs would come from the ranks of its 50,000 North American workers. Goodyear said last month that it would realign its operations in North America into 28 regional offices reporting directly to headquarters in Akron, rather than the previous structure, under which 43 district offices reported to five regional divisions, which in turn reported to headquarters.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Goodyear shares were down 87.5 cents yesterday, closing at $27.25.
Tom H. Barrett, Goodyear's chairman, said that the results were affected by ''severe price competition in North America and Europe in both tires and general products,'' as well as higher costs, a prolonged strike at the company's plants in Turkey and the impact of economic revision in Brazil.
 
Auto Output Cited
Goodyear, the second-largest tire company after Groupe Michelin of France, has been burdened in recent years by sluggishness in North American automobile production, higher operating expenses and losses related to its All-American Pipeline, which runs from California to Texas.Brazil, where Goodyear has production operations, has also contributed to company problems.
The company said that its operating income in its tires and related products segment fell 46.1 percent, to $108.9 million in the quarter.

HEADLINE: Profits Off 26% At Whirlpool

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BENTON HARBOR, Mich., July 26

 BODY:
The Whirlpool Corporation said today that its second-quarter profit tumbled 26 percent despite a 4.3 percent increase in revenue. The company cited economic troubles affecting its Brazilian operations. 
The manufacturer of major home appliances said its net income sagged to $37 million, or 54 cents a share, for the three months ended June 30, compared with $50 million, or 72 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1989.
Revenue rose to $1.71 billion, from $1.64 billion in the 1989 period.
Whirlpool said that if the results of its Brazilian appliance-making and marketing affiliates were excluded, net earnings for the quarter would have been up 18 percent.
David R. Whitwam, the company's chairman, said results in North America were strong, because of higher shipments, effective material cost controls, productivity improvement and aggressive marketing efforts.
Shares of Whirlpool rose 37.5 cents today, to $28, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Notes and Bonds Little Changed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in sluggish trading yesterday, as dealers watched the progress of budget negotiations in Washington and waited for a preliminary report this morning on how much the economy grew in the second quarter.
Although participants in the budget talks were far from upbeat in their assessment, traders said that many credit market participants were assuming that the outlines of a compromise package that would cut the deficit by $50 billion would be agreed upon before early next month, when Congress adjourns for its summer recess.
''The Street is long securities and seem likely to stay that way on the bet that we will have a budget deal by the time Congress goes on vacation,'' one government bond trader said.
But private analysts said that the pessimistic comments coming from Washington were closer to the mark, even though there were indications late yesterday that Congress might delay its Aug. 3 recess by a week or more to come up with a budget package. 
''It is clear that some people are ready to buy bonds if Congress comes up with an agreement, but it seems very unlikely that will happen by early August,'' said Louis v.B. Crandall, chief economist at R.H. Wrightson & Associates Inc., an economic consulting firm.
 
Second Quarter Economic Data
The release this morning of second-quarter economic data, which will be accompanied by three years worth of revised numbers on the gross national product, was another reason to be cautious yesterday, dealers said.
In advance of the report, most economists are estimating that the economy expanded at an inflation-adjusted annual rate of around 1.5 percent in the second quarter, slightly below the 1.9 percent rate recorded during the first three months of the year.
Yesterday dealers also had to contend with the Treasury's monthly auction of one-year bills.
The $10.5 billion issue attracted bids that produced an average yield of 7.34 percent, the lowest since the one-year bill sale in January, and well below the average 7.52 percent yield at the last one-year bill sale on June 28.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, bills, notes and bonds traded in very narrow ranges throughout the session.
By late in the day, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 102 9/32, unchanged on the day, to yield 8.53 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at a price of 102 19/32, down 1/32, to yield 8.42 percent. And the 8 percent two-year notes that were auctioned on Wednesday were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 8.08 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates rose slightly.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.56 percent, up two basis points, or hundreths of a point. Six-month bill rates rose by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 7.45 percent.
 
Corporated Bond Market
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the BankAmerica Corporation offered $100 million of ten-year subordinated notes.
The 9.70 percent notes, which mature Aug. 1, 2000, were priced at $99.502 to yield 9.78 percent, 1.30 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
Merrill Lynch Capital Markets acted as lead manager for the underwriting, which is rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In addition, the Ohio Power Company offered $50 million worth of 30-year bonds at competitive bid.
A bid from a group led by Lehman Brothers won the securities, which were reoffered to investors with a 9 7/8 percent coupon priced at $100, 1.33 percentage points over the prevailing yield on Treasury's 8 3/4 percent bonds of 2020.
The securities, which are nonrefundable for five years, are rated A-2 by Moody's and A-1 by Standard & Poor's.
A ruling by a New Jersey court, which refused to apply changes to the state's liability law that retroactively protect tobacco companies, pushed the price of RJR Nabisco bonds down sharply in the high-yield ''junk bond'' market.
After the ruling, prices of the company's payment-in-kind bonds fell by two points or more.
The impact on outstanding issues of the Philip Morris Companies, an investment-grade corporate issuer, was more modest.
Late yesterday, the company's 8 3/4 percent securities of 1996 were offered at a price to yield about 9.30 percent. Before the ruling was announced, the bonds were trading at a price to yield 9.25 percent.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported late yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply fell during the week ended July 16.
The report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Against Yen As Gold Ends Mostly Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen but finished mixed against most other primary currencies in seesaw trading yesterday.
Gold prices ended mostly lower. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $369.30 an ounce, down $2.70 from late Wednesday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $368.80 an ounce, $2.20 lower. 
The dollar rose initially in Tokyo when traders began selling yen, which lost ground across the board. Analysts said investors remained concerned about recent swings in the Tokyo stock market, as well as the uncertainty over whether the Bank of Japan will move to raise interest rates.
Higher interest rates in Japan would tend to support the yen by making yen-denominated investments more attractive.
Bob Morrissey, the senior trader at the Bank of Boston in New York, said rumors circulated that the United States Federal Reserve Board had entered the market to sell dollars and buy yen to stem the dollar's rise. But the rumors were not confirmed.
Trading was active. The dollar finished mixed in Europe and moved higher when dealings shifted to the United States. But profit taking late in the American session left the dollar lower against all currencies but the yen at the close.
Mr. Morrissey said some position-squaring occurred before today's release of the United States' second-quarter data on the gross national product. The figures might provide an impetus for the Fed to trim interest rates to stimulate the economy.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose by 0.98 yen, to a closing of 150.11 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 150.10 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 150.35 yen, up from a close of 149.83 yen on Wednesday. On Wednesday, the dollar had climbed by nearly a yen and a half, trading late in the afternoon at 148.80 yen before ending the day at 149.83, up from 148.40 on Tuesday.
In London, the pound rose to $1.8133, from $1.8125 late Wednesday. In New York, it cost $1.8145 to buy a pound, more expensive than Wednesday's $1.8120.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late Wednesday, included: 1.6230 West German marks, down from 1.6245; 1.3773 Swiss francs, down from 1.3800; 5.4360 French francs, down from 5.4445; 1,187.50 Italian lire, down from 1,188.75, and 1.1527 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1536.
Also in London, gold fell to a late bid of $368.65 an ounce, from $373.25 late Wednesday. In Zurich, it fell to a closing bid of $368.50 an ounce, from $372.50 late Wednesday. Gold rose $2.11 in Hong Kong to close at $369.94 an ounce.
On the Comex in New York, silver finished mixed.
