LENGTH: 1395 words

HEADLINE: OPEC IN AGREEMENT TO RAISE OIL PRICE BY CUTTING OUTPUT

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, July 27

 BODY:
The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries reached an accord today calling for higher oil prices. This time Iraq, which has emerged as a powerful enforcer, will try to make the increase take hold.
If OPEC members do go along by limiting production, the agreement will raise energy costs modestly for American consumers, bankers said.
On numerous occasions over the last decade OPEC has tried to set price and production targets for its members, but the efforts have usually faltered because of a lack of discipline. But oil analysts see today's agreement as a credible one. 
 
Tough Talk From Iraq
This is primarily because Iraq has clearly threatened to use force against those who weaken the accord by overproducing - a threat directed mainly at the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait, which together have been exceeding their quotas by about a million barrels a day. And Saudi Arabia, by far the largest producer in OPEC, appears to be content to have Iraq play this role.
Many nations dislike Iraq's overall aggressiveness. In Washington today, the House and the Senate defied the Bush Administration and voted to impose economic sanctions on Iraq, citing what lawmakers viewed as human rights violations and bellicose policies. [Page 5.] Today's accord in Geneva calls for a target price of $21 a barrel until the end of the year, up from $18 now, and fixes OPEC's production ceiling for all 13 members at 22.5 million barrels a day.
 
Former Enemies Cooperate
The agreement is a triumph for Iraq and Iran. After fighting a bitter war from 1980 to 1988, both desperately need greater revenues and can obtain them only through oil exports. Western nations, which consider them to have extremist policies, refuse to lend them money.
The oil ministers of Saudi Arabia, Iraq and Iran said in interviews that they were confident the agreement is solidly based on a new political alliance that brings together OPEC's three major producers and power brokers.
OPEC's new strength, though, could last only as long as that political alliance holds. Any of the three nations is capable of scuttling it.
But today officials of those nations were optimistic. ''I think you may call it a historic accord,'' Hisham M. Nazer, Saudi Arabia's oil minister, said in an interview here. ''I feel very confident it will achieve its objectives.''
Oil analysts agreed. Bahman Karbassiou, a Vienna-based oil consultant and former OPEC official, said, ''This is probably the only time in the past seven years that you are going to see very strict adherence by all OPEC members to their assigned quotas.''
The United States has become increasingly dependent on foreign oil in the last five years. Through April, the nation imported an average of 8.3 million barrels a day, with more than half that purchased from OPEC. In 1985, imports amounted to 5.1 million barrels a day, with OPEC contributing more than a third.
 
The Biggest Suppliers
The largest OPEC supplier is Saudi Arabia, which sold an average of 1.3 million barrels a day to the United States in the four months through April. Government policy bans Iranian oil imports. After Saudi Arabia, the leading OPEC suppliers to the United States are Venezuela, at 980,000 barrels, and Nigeria, at 923,000.
Among non-OPEC producers, Canada is the largest exporter to the United States, at 900,000 barrels a day, followed by Mexico, at 698,000.
Edwin Rothschild, director of the Citizen/Labor Energy Coalition, an energy research group, said gasoline prices could rise 2 or 3 cents a gallon if OPEC nations honor the accord.
George F. Friesen, oil analyst at Deutsche Bank Capital in New York, said oil prices were likely to soften in coming months, with West Texas Intermediate, the American benchmark, declining to as low as $17 a barrel because worldwide inventories remain high. But he said prices should rebound to about $21 a barrel by the end of the year.
In trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange today, the September contract for West Texas Intermediate settled with a loss of 26 cents, to $20.04 for a 42-gallon barrel.
 
Coordinated Pressure
Senior OPEC officials said it became clear early in these talks, which started about two weeks ago, that Iran and Iraq were coordinating their pressure on the rest of OPEC, with the willing cooperation of Saudi Arabia, OPEC's production giant.
It is evident, however, that Iraq's threat to use force was the prime factor that shook OPEC into action and remains the principal deterrent to further infractions of discipline.
When this conference began on Thursday, Iraq came pounding on the OPEC table, demanding three things:
* Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates must stop flouting their quotas and weakening prices by dumping too much oil in world markets.
* OPEC must embark on a course to raise oil prices in general.
* The organization's future course should be largely charted by its three biggest producers: Saudi Arabia, Iraq and Iran.
The Iraqis achieved all of their objectives with the tacit - but energetic - cooperation of Iran.
For its part, Saudi Arabia realized its principal objective: a gradual rise in prices only in response to genuine market demand, so as not to repeat the shocks dealt to the world economy in the 70's and 80's when OPEC kept on pushing prices up without regard to the ability of consumers to absorb the increases.
''We will not repeat the mistakes of the past,'' said Gholam Reza Aghazadeh, Iran's oil minister, in an interview. ''The price rise will be gradual.'' Asked if he was sure that production quotas would be adhered to this time, Mr. Aghazadeh said, ''This time I am 100 percent sure''.
 
Original Target Is Lowered
Iraq, which had insisted on a $25 price, abandoned that demand in return for having achieved most of its other objectives, OPEC officials said.
Senior OPEC officials, who asked not to be identified, said that Iraq's demand for a $25 price was deliberately balanced by Iran's suggesting $20, with the two squeezing the others to come up with a number in between.
OPEC's target price refers to a hypothetical barrel that represents a mix of grades from different oilfields.
As it happened, Saudi Arabia joined the power play by working into the agreement a stipulation that prices would rise only if studies proved that the increases could be absorbed by consumers without pushing them toward alternative energy sources.
 
A Million-Barrel Reduction
The accord removes about a million barrels a day of OPEC oil from world markets, easing the pressure in a glutted market.
The impact of the accord will not be clear until September, since many oil companies have been stocking oil and may now decide to use their stocks before buying new OPEC oil. [Flying from Washington to his vacation home in Maine, President Bush said there is ''not a thing'' he could do about the OPEC price decision. He said market forces will determine oil prices, not the Geneva agreement.] Oil analysts said that even if prices rose to $21, European and Japanese consumers would not feel the impact because of the steep fall in the dollar's value this year against major currencies. But American consumers may see their energy bills climbing, although not by much.
''The Europeans and the Japanese will shrug their shoulders, with the dollar having lost 10 percent of its value since the start of the year,'' said Christian Weyer, a banker and oil economist with Banque Indosuez.
 
Iranian Leader's Comments
In a speech today, Iran's President strongly supported Iraq's denunciation of quota violators. President Hashemi Rafsanjani said in Teheran that ''two or three countries in the Persian Gulf have committed a great treason due to their dependence on the West,'' in an obvious reference to the Emirates and Kuwait. Iraq has used similar language in denouncing the two countries, accusing them of carrying out American dicatates.
Oil economists said the price increase was balanced by the fact that inflation in the last 10 years has greatly reduced the real value of oil to exporters by diminishing the purchasing power of the dollars they get for their exports.
''In real terms, the price of oil now is the lowest it has been since 1972,'' said Jack Wilkinson, a senior oil economist at the Sun Company in Philadelphia who was here to observe the OPEC meeting.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 5, Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 890 words

HEADLINE: Congress Backs Curbs Against Iraq

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
The House and the Senate defied the Bush Administration today and voted to impose economic sanctions on Iraq, citing what lawmakers viewed as the human rights violations and increasingly bellicose policies of President Saddam Hussein's Government.
The Senate took the stronger action, voting 80 to 16 to cut off $700 million in United States loan guarantees that the Baghdad Government uses to purchase American wheat, rice, lumber and cattle as well as commercial goods like tires and machinery.
''We shall not give to the Iraqis the kind of special treatment you reserve for friends, for allies,'' said Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, who drafted the measure approved by the Senate. ''We've waited for Hussein to take a more humane course and it has not been done. He is a butcher, a torturer, a manipulator.'' 
The House, by a vote of 234 to 175, first approved a similar measure restricting loan guarantees to Iraq. But, after the pleas of representatives from rural districts, the House voted 208 to 191 to allow the Secretary of Agriculture to waive the sanctions if he determines they cause more harm to American farmers than they do to the Hussein Government.
 
Criticized by Texan
Senator Phil Gramm, a Texas Democrat who opposed the bill, said that the proposal was ''like responding to a bully by pulling out a gun, putting it to your head and saying if you keep threatening me I'll shoot myself.''
While conceding that the elimination of loan guarantees would harm farmers in her state, Senator Nancy Kassebaum, a Kansas Republican, countered that some principles go beyond economic interests.
''There comes a time when we have to stand up and be counted,'' she said. ''I can't believe any farmer in this nation would want to send his products, under subsidized sales, to a country that has used chemical weapons and a country that has tortured and executed its children.''
In recent days Mr. Hussein had threatened to use military force against members of OPEC he felt had been exceeding their production quotas and thereby keeping the price low. He massed troops on the border with Kuwait, creating a crisis atmosphere, which has yet to dissipate fully.
 
Bush Favors Guarantees
The Bush Administration had opposed the ending of the loan guarantees, arguing that it would harm American farmers, worsen the country's trade deficit, and not hurt the Iraqis, who could purchase agricultural products from countries like France and Taiwan.
A State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, said today that the Administration did not believe that proposals like Mr. D'Amato's would help ''in achieving the goals we want to achieve in our relationship with Iraq.''
Mr. Boucher said that as a result of a review of Iraq trade relations being conducted by the Administration in recent months, the Commerce Department is developing new regulations that will tighten controls on exports of some items, like industrial equipment, that could be used for the production of nuclear or chemical weapons.
Although there are many restrictions already in place, the new rules would clamp down more firmly because of special concerns about proliferation of nonconventional weapons.
 
Agricultural Credits Reviewed
The Administration's review is also examining whether agricultural credits should be restricted, he said, but the Agriculture Department has not reached any conclusions in that regard. The review had been in progress before the sudden heightening of tensions between Iraq and Kuwait in the last two weeks, and has been intensified since then.
The sanctions recommended by Congress would not take effect until final enactment of the farm bill, which was passed by the Senate today but awaits further action by the House. The two chambers would then have to reconcile their differences before sending the measure to President Bush for his signature.
The Congressional votes to impose sanctions came on the same day the 13-member Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed at their meeting in Geneva to raise the target price for oil to $21 a barrel, from $18 a barrel. The OPEC oil ministers also agreed to limit production to 22.5 million barrels a day, slightly higher than the current ceiling on output, but lower than what the members of the cartel have been actually producing.
 
Lobbying by Iraq
Iraq had been strongly lobbying for the price increase, which comes at a time of a continued glut of crude oil on the world market. That glut had kept oil prices depressed, severely hindering Iraq's ability to repay its foreign debt, estimated to be between $70 billion and $100 billion.
Abdul Rahman Jamil, press attache of the Iraqi Embassy in Washington, could not be reached for comment on the Congressional action. Telephone calls to a number where embassy staff said Mr. Jamil could be reached went unanswered.
Today's votes in Congress represent another step in the worsening relations between Washington and Baghdad that had begun to warm in the 1980's. While Iraq was engaged in war with Iran, Washington developed a decided tilt toward Baghdad, several experts on Iraq say.
During the war with Iran, Washington restored diplomatic relations with Baghdad, which also enjoyed closer relations with Kuwait, as Kuwait heavily financed Iraq's weapons purchases.

HEADLINE: Baker Hints at Direct Contact With Phnom Penh

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 27

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that Washington might further modify its Indochina policy by opening direct diplomatic contacts with the Communist Government of Cambodia.
His suggestion that the United States might drop its 11-year isolation of Phnom Penh came as part of a blunt retort to the steady criticism of recent American policies on Indochina and refugees. Several governments represented here at the meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean, have attacked the United States policy.
During the previous three days, several Southeast Asian foreign ministers said the Bush Administration's withdrawal of diplomatic support for a Cambodian guerrilla coalition including the Communist Khmer Rouge would only encourage the Khmer Rouge to step up efforts on the battlefield. The United States policy change included the opening of talks with Vietnam on Cambodia. 
Indonesia and Singapore have been particularly harsh in their comments. The other Asean nations -the Philippines, Malaysia, Thailand and Brunei - have generally followed suit.
 
'Dialogue of Death' Condemned
Mr. Baker responded to the criticism today by saying, ''Continued support for the coalition at the United Nations is only providing the Khmer Rouge diplomatic cover for its military maneuvers.'' He added that other nations must show ''no tolerance for the Khmer Rouge's dialogue of death.''
The Khmer Rouge are responsible for the killing or starvation of at least one million people from 1975 to 1979. They were overthrown in January 1979 after the Vietnamese invaded in December 1978. The Vietnamese later installed Hun Sen, a Khmer Rouge defector, as Prime Minister.
Mr. Baker suggested that international diplomatic efforts between the Hun Sen Government and the guerrilla coalition to settle the 11-year Cambodian conflict could be wasted by ''a failure to recognize the steady, threatening movement'' of the Khmer Rouge, who are gaining in a rainy season offensive.
Further reverses on the battlefield can be averted, he said, only by stepping up diplomatic exchanges with China, the Soviet Union and Vietnam to set up an interim government and United Nations-supervised elections.
Mr. Baker said that to ''advance our election goals, we are also considering contacts with the Phnom Penh regime.''
 
First Such Statement by Baker
While lower-level State Department officials had previously suggested that the Administration was considering a move to improve relations with Cambodia, this was the first time that Mr. Baker had publicly brought up the possibility.
State Department officials who favor further modifications of Cambodia policy say that if Mr. Baker can overcome Asean concerns here, he could increase efforts to improve relations with Phnom Penh and Hanoi and eventually cut all military aid to the two non-Communist rebel groups aligned with the Khmer Rouge. Such a realignment, these officials say, has been blocked so far by the National Security Council.
In his 20-minute address to the Southeast Asian foreign ministers, Mr. Baker also tried to narrow differences on how to deal with the continuing emigration of Vietnamese refugees.
The Southeast Asian nations urged in a communique this week that the United States agree to their proposal for involuntary return of boat people who leave Vietnam for economic rather than political reasons. Otherwise, they warn, they may have to stop accepting thousands of people who land on their shores every year.
The United States, which cooperates with Southeast Asian countries in dealing with refugee resettlement, has argued that no one should be forced to return to a country as repressive as Vietnam.
 
U.N. Compromise Urged
Mr. Baker reiterated that position, but he asked that the Southeast Asian group join the United States in accepting a compromise proposal offered by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.
That proposal designates a new category of refugees - ''those who do not object.'' Such people are to be convinced through screening and counseling that a voluntary return to Vietnam is preferable to living for years in a wretched refugee camp with little hope of finding permanent resettlement.
The Asean delegates appeared unwilling to criticize Mr. Baker directly, but they did not seem impressed with his speech either.
''We're not interested in finger-pointing,'' said Datuk A. Kamil Jaafar, Secretary General of the Malaysian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, ''but we can't understand the choices the United States has made recently.'' He was particularly critical of Mr. Baker's position on the Vietnamese refugees, saying they were no different from the Haitians, Mexicans and Central Americans that the United States has forcibly returned to their homes.

HEADLINE: Social Security Panel Opposes Moynihan Plan

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
A bipartisan Federal advisory panel said today that it opposed Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut Social Security payroll taxes.
The New York Democrat stirred a political storm here earlier this year with his proposal, which seeks to reduce the growing surplus in the Social Security trust fund. Mr. Moynihan says the trust fund surplus masks the true size of the Federal budget deficit and has been used for Government costs unrelated to Social Security.
But the Advisory Council on Social Security, a 13-member panel appointed in June 1989 by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, said the surplus should be allowed to continue growing because it would be needed when members of the baby boom generation retire. The generation is commonly defined as Americans born from 1946 to 1964. 
The panel said Mr. Moynihan's proposal for ''pay-as-you-go'' financing of Social Security was unwise because it would require steep increases in payroll taxes in the years from 2010 to 2030, when people in the baby boom generation retire.
 
Moynihan Undeterred
Mr. Moynihan introduced his proposal as a bill in January and plans to offer it again within two weeks as an amendment to a separate bill raising the Federal debt ceiling.
The council's report appears to reduce the likelihood that Congress will approve a Social Security tax cut. Nevertheless, Mr. Moynihan said in an interview tonight that he fully intended to press for approval of his proposal.
He took comfort from the fact that two council members representing organized labor supported his proposal. The two, Karen M. Ignagni of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and John J. Sweeney, president of the Service Employees International Union, issued a separate statement recommending a return to the pay-as-you-go method of financing Social Security.
The 13-member advisory panel is headed by a former Reagan Administration official, Deborah Steelman, who worked at the Office of Management and Budget. It includes liberal Democrats like Robert M. Ball, who was Commissioner of Social Security from 1962 to 1973, as well as business executives like Philip Briggs, vice chairman of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, and Paul H. O'Neill, chairman of the Aluminum Company of America.
 
Increasing Productivity
The Social Security tax paid by both employer and employee is currently 6.2 percent of the first $51,300 of earnings. Mr. Moynihan's proposal would reduce the rate to 5.1 percent for the years 1991 through 2011, then would gradually increase it to 8.1 percent in 2045.
Senator Moynihan said the payroll tax was regressive, hitting poor people harder than the well-off, and he asserted that a tax cut was justified because ''Social Security trust fund reserves have been growing at a much faster pace than anticipated: a billion dollars a week.'' At the end of 1989, the trust fund had assets of $163 billion, representing 64 percent of outlays projected for 1990.
In its report today to Dr. Sullivan, the advisory council recommended that ''no action now be taken to reduce revenues'' to the Social Security trust fund. It said the growing surplus provides ''an opportunity to increase national saving, which can enhance the future productive capacity of the economy.''
 
'Blue Smoke and Mirrors'
The panel said Congress should eliminate the Federal budget deficit to enhance prospects for ''a strong economy when the large baby boom generation retires.'' It said Social Security should be removed from the calculation of deficit reduction targets under a budget-balancing law adopted in 1985.
The law takes account of the Social Security surplus when computing the overall budget deficit. As a result, the deficit seems smaller than it would otherwise be.
The Comptroller General of the United States, Charles A. Bowsher, has said, ''The use of growing Social Security surpluses to mask the deficit in Federal operations amounts to blue smoke and mirrors.'' He says the deficit is larger today than in 1985 if trust funds are excluded from the calculations.
The advisory council said that ''Social Security is projected to have enough income to meet benefit payments for about the next 50 years.'' The panel said the amount in the trust fund would peak at $9 trillion in the year 2027 and would be depleted 16 years later if Congress took no action.

HEADLINE: Republicans Demand a Budget From Democrats

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
Congressional Republicans, angry that a White House budget proposal calling for higher taxes has become public without a companion proposal from Democrats, demanded today that the Democrats produce one before Congress adjourns for its August recess.
''The President has taken his hit on revenue's being part of the discussion, then we come up with some options, it's all over the press and we haven't seen anything from the other side,'' said Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House minority leader. ''We're at the point where it's absolutely essential that our Democratic colleagues ante up. We've got to see something up here on the table from the other side before we break.'' 
But the Democrats appeared in no hurry to oblige, saying that while there were press reports of an Administration proposal, no such plan had ever been formally presented at the negotiating table. Despite pledges that Congressional negotiators would try to work through part of the recess, it was clear from both sides that there would be no budget deal before September at the earliest.
Senator Jim Sasser, a Tennessee Democrat who heads the Senate Budget Committee, said he felt no obligation to put forward a proposal until the Democrats actually saw the Administration's plan.
 
Limit on Tax Deductions
The Administration proposal, agreed to with some reluctance by Republican Congressional leaders on Wednesday night, would raise Federal excise taxes on beer, wine and liquor and limit deductions for state and local income taxes to $10,000. The proposal is part of a plan to cut $50 billion from a 1991 budget deficit that is now estimated at nearly $170 billion, not counting the cost of the savings and loan bailout, Republicans say the limit would primarily affect wealthier taxpayers, an approach they hope will derail Democratic efforts to raise the Federal income tax rate for the most affluent taxpayers above the current level, 28 percent.
The proposal also calls for $23 billion in spending cuts - $7 billion from military programs and $16 billion from programs like Medicaid, Medicare, farm subsidies, veterans' benefits and Federal retirement benefits. Social Security would not be affected.
 
G.O.P. in Awkward Straits
Many of the benefit cuts were suggested by President Bush in the budget he sent to Congress in January, a budget that was rejected by House Republicans at that time as politically impossible. Most of the Republican negotiators were prepared to accept the new version of the Administration's plan as a bargaining tool, but its premature disclosure has clearly left them in awkward political straits.
''I'm very frustrated and discouraged,'' said Senator Phil Gramm, a Texas Republican who is part of the budget negotiating group. ''The only person who's shown any political courage or sacrifice in this is George Bush.''
Mr. Bush met with senior Congressional leaders of both parties before leaving for a weekend at his summer home in Kennebunkport, Me. He told reporters on Air Force One that White House and Congressional negotiators had narrowed some of their differences, but that the progress had not been dramatic. He turned aside any questions on details of the Administration proposal, saying only that he was ''not locked locked in to any specific proposal.''
Democratic strategists said that while proposals for limiting deductions for the wealthy would theoretically accomplish the same thing as raising the top income tax rate for the most affluent taxpayers, the rate increase remained the most economically efficient and politically achievable approach.

HEADLINE: Religion Notes

BYLINE: By Ari L. Goldman

 BODY:
On Praying for a Son There are few things that connoisseurs of antiquity enjoy more than a modern discovery that confirms the wisdom of the past. So, in recent weeks several students of the Talmud, the authoritative body of Jewish law completed in the sixth century, took pleasure in a report in the journal Nature about the discovery of a gene that determines maleness. The gene, the researchers report, begins its work in the seventh week of pregnancy, somewhere from the 43d to the 49th day.
The Talmudists cited page 60a in the tractate B'rachot in which the ancient rabbis question whether it is worthwhile for the husband of a pregnant woman to pray for a son. The rabbis determine that such prayers are worthwhile up to the 40th day of pregnancy, but after that point the supplication is a ''vain prayer'' since the sex is already determined. 
The modern Talmudists were not fazed by the fact that they differed from the modern scientists by a few days. ''The scientists came pretty close to the truth,'' said Yanke Shulman, who teaches an early-morning class in the Talmud in Brooklyn before commuting to his job as a systems analyst in Manhattan.
 
A Fight on Parking Rules
John Bozzella knew he was fighting a losing battle. Even his Irish Catholic mother was against him. But he fought the good fight and lost.
Mr. Bozzella is New York City's chief lobbyist in Albany, and it was his assignment to try to stop the Legislature and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo from approving a bill that would add Holy Thursday and Orthodox Holy Thursday to the roster of religious holidays when alternate -side parking rules are suspended.
Holy Thursday, three days before Easter, marks the last supper of Jesus and His disciples. In the Orthodox calendar it often falls on a different day.
The lobbyist had a host of arguments against Holy Thursday. He argued from logistics (it would disrupt traffic), economics (about $100,000 would be lost in parking fines) and theology (Holy Thursday is not, he said, a day when Catholics are obligated to attend Mass).
In addition, Mr. Bozzella warned that approval would encourage Muslims, Buddhists and others to renew their requests for parking exemptions on their holy days. ''As a result, the number of days on which alternate side of the street parking is suspended will grow significantly,'' he wrote in a memorandum in opposition to the bill.
The bill breezed through the Senate and the Assembly, and was signed by Governor Cuomo on July 17.
''I never really thought I could stop this bill,'' Mr. Bozzella said afterward. ''I guess it was just impossible for a legislator to vote against Holy Thursday.''
In addition to the the Holy Thursday observances, the alternate-side regulations are waived on these days: Christmas, Yom Kippur, Rosh ha-Shanah, Good Friday and Orthodox Good Friday, Ascension Thursday, the first two days of Succoth, Shimini Atzareth, the Feast of the Assumption, the Feast of All Saints, Simchat Torah, Shabuoth, the Feast of the Immaculate Conception and the first two and last two days of Passover.
 
Excommunication Issue
Three Roman Catholics in Corpus Christi, Tex., were warned by the head of the local diocese in recent months that they risked excommunication because of their work in abortion clinics. Two of them, a clinic director and a doctor, eventually received formal decrees of excommunication, but the third, Elva Bustamante, the director of a second clinic, has yet to get the final word from Bishop Rene H. Gracida.
Earlier this month Mrs. Bustamante took a step that her two excommunicated colleagues did not. She responded to the Bishop's warning with a pointed defense of her position.
''As a Catholic,'' Mrs. Bustamante wrote in a letter dated July 17, ''I take your warning very seriously, and have prayed, studied and reflected on my work at New Women's Clinic. I have concluded that you are incorrect in applying this penalty to me.''
In his letter of March 12 Bishop Gracida wrote, ''Your cooperation in procuring abortions is a sin against God and humanity and against the laws of the Roman Catholic Church.'' He said that under the canons of the church Mrs. Bustamante had excommunicated herself and that once he formalized this in a written decree, she would be officially barred from the sacraments of the church and from Christian burial.
Mrs. Bustamante argued with the Bishop's application of church laws. She wrote that automatic excommunication did not apply to her, but only to the woman involved in the abortion ''and those who directly participate in a specific, successful abortion procedure,'' such as the operating physician.
''After my prayer and reflection, I genuinely do not believe I am guilty of any sin in the work I do,'' she added. ''In order to be excommunicated I must willfully and culpably sin. I make no claims to perfection, but in this instance my actions are neither sinful nor undertaken in an attitude of defiance. I am simply following my conscience. I ask you to respect my conscience, even though you may disagree with it.''
Bishop Gracida's office had no immediate comment, but Mrs. Bustamante's letter clearly did not give the Bishop what he had asked. ''My hope,'' he had written in his warning, ''is that you will see the evil of this practice and return to reconciliation with God and Father and the Roman Catholic Church.''
 
Dueling Poll Results
By a margin of nearly 2 to 1, churchgoers in the San Francisco Bay area oppose hiring homosexuals as clergy, a recent survey in The San Francisco Chronicle says.
In a random telephone poll of 600 residents conducted in March, 50 percent of those who attend church once a week or more were opposed to hiring homosexuals as clergy, while 28 percent were in favor. The results had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
But when both churchgoers and nonchurchgoers were asked, the results were significantly different. Forty-eight percent said they were in favor and 29 percent said they were opposed.
In analyzing the results Mark Baldassare, director of polls for The Chronicle, said: ''Regular churchgoers, who represent 30 percent of bay area residents, have the greatest influence over church policy. There is a solid core of people who will continue to resist efforts to ordain homosexuals.''

HEADLINE: Groups in Northeast Protest Plan to Cap Deductions for Taxes

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 27

 BODY:
Predicting devastating consequences for state and local governments throughout the Northeast, school boards, business groups and municipal officials in New York and neighboring states began a spontaneous protest today against a Bush Administration proposal to restrict the deductions for state and local taxes on Federal income-tax returns.
The proposal, whose details were disclosed on Thursday in Washington, would impose a disproportionately heavy burden on residents of New York and other high-tax Northeastern states, experts said. Residents of those states are most likely to be affected by the restrictions.
''This appears to be another way to take more New York taxes and send them to other places,'' the director of the New York State School Boards Association, Lou Grumet, said. ''What it means is that if you educate your children substantially, like we do in New York, if you pay a lot for your schools, you're now going to pay even higher taxes. It's like putting a sin tax on education.'' 
Most Northeastern states rely heavily on property taxes to finance their public schools.
 
Cap at $10,000
Under the restrictions proposed by the Bush Administration and senior Congressional Republicans on Thursday, the amount of state and local taxes that could be deducted on Federal returns would be capped at $10,000.
Many officials argue that the cap would lead to ''double taxation,'' because some of the money that has been paid to states and localities would be taxed again by the Federal Government as income.
If adopted, the limits would not directly affect state and local revenues. But because higher taxes would, for many taxpayers, no longer be deductible, the resistance to new local taxes would inevitably increase.
''It's going to make it much more difficult for high-tax states to raise taxes in the future,'' Ronald Alt, a senior researcher at the Federation of Tax Administrators in Washington, said. ''And this comes at a time when many states are already experiencing financial trouble.''
Figures compiled by the federation show that in New York the average Federal deduction for state and local taxes is the highest of any state, totaling $5,435. In Massachusetts, the average deduction is $4,099. In Maine it is $4,208. In New Jersey the figure is $3,598, and in Connecticut, which has no state income tax, the average deduction for taxes is $3,056. The national average is $3,207.
Only taxpayers who itemize deductions can take one for the taxes.
There are no reliable figures on how many taxpayers in each state take deductions of more than $10,000. The New York City Budget Director, Philip Michael, estimated that as much as one-third of the estimated $3 billion that the cap on deductions would generate for the Federal Government would come from New York State taxpayers.
 
'All the More Onerous'
''It would be very damaging to our economic development and to our retention of upper-middle-class residents,'' Mr. Michael said. ''It would make the tax burden here all the more onerous, and it's already thought to be quite steep.''
In Washington, Republican officials like Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon called the proposed cap a ''tax on the rich'' and said it would largely affect taxpayers with family incomes of more than $100,000.
Officials in the New York metropolitan region conceded that the emphasis on affluent taxpayers would make the limits more difficult to object to politically. But they disputed the contention that the restrictions would only affect the wealthy, saying those hardest hit would be citizens paying the most in property taxes, and not necessarily those with the highest incomes.
''They would have a significant impact on middle-income people who make $40,000 or $50,000,'' the County Executive of Bergen County, N.J., William McDowell, said. ''They unquestionably would hurt our ability to raise money for local programs.''
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said the Federal Government should simply raise the income-tax rates for the richest Americans ''several points.''
 
Issue of Regional Strains
Across the Northeast politicians voiced resentment about the proposal, saying it would force hard-pressed state and local governments to pick up another part of the Federal deficit. ''Traditionally the Federal Government did not interfere with our sources of revenue,'' Mayor Joe Dadonna of Allentown, Pa., said. ''Now they're even interfering with that.''
Because the Northeast is apt to be so hard hit by any limit on deductibility and the Southwest and other low-tax regions would remain relatively unaffected, the issue raises many of the regional strains that characterize American politics. In New York and neighboring states the restrictions could add yet another disincentive to doing business in the area.
''It simply would make New York less competitive,'' the president of the New York City Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Ron Schelp, said.
Even when the talk of limiting the deductibility of the taxes was little more than rumor, opposition to the idea was intense. On Wednesday members of the New York Congressional delegation, both Republicans and Democrats, met to denounce the plan. On Thursday, Mr. Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins, together with union leaders and municipal officials from as far away as Indiana and Michigan, held a news conference in Washington to pledge their opposition to the proposal.
A proposal to eliminate the deductibility of local taxes was defeated in 1986 by a broad coalition of unions, school groups and local officials.
Today several politicians predicted that a cap would be the first step toward ending deductibility entirely.
''It's the foot in the door,'' Suffolk County Executive Patrick G. Halpin said. ''Their real agenda is to eliminate deductibility.''

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Status of India's Women Offers Hope and Despair

BYLINE: By Vidya Dehejia; Vidya Dehejia is an associate professor of art history at Columbia University. Her latest book, ''Antal and Her Path of Love: Poems of a Woman Saint From South India,'' is to be published next month by SUNY Press.

 BODY:

May You Be the Mother of a Hundred Sons
A Journey Among the Women of India
By Elisabeth Bumiller
Illustrated. 306 pages. Random House.
$19.95.
A believer in the Indian concept of rebirth would surmise that Elisabeth Bumiller had indeed been an Indian woman in her previous birth, so deep is her empathy with India and so pervasive the humanity that emerges from her book on India's women. Yet she never glosses over harsh realities; she makes no excuses for the disheartening events she reports. 
Her title, ''May You Be the Mother of a Hundred Sons,'' is well chosen. Ms. Bumiller eventually came to regard this blessing, conferred on Hindu women at the time of their wedding, as a curse and the cause of much that is wrong with the status of India's women. In a series of essays with eye-catching yet accurate titles (''Wedding First, Love Later: Arranged Marriages Among the Educated Classes''), she explores various aspects of women's lives in India. This is a profoundly moving book, one that plunges the reader into despair and yet gives glimpses of hope.
The attempt to give an overall picture of the 400 million women of India is a formidable undertaking. Over half the book is concerned with issues that affect women of the middle class, a term used in India to describe the top 10 percent of the population, 80 million people. The remaining essays concern the 75 percent who live in the villages; Ms. Bumiller spent time in an Indian village as the guest of a farmer's wife.
India is a country of paradoxes, and nowhere is this more apparent than in the status of women. India has no trouble conceiving of the divine as feminine; men and women, wealthy and poor, worship powerful goddesses like Durga and Kali. Yet this same India has caught the attention of the West with its infamous ''bride burnings'' or ''dowry deaths.'' The two extremes coexist. In Indira Gandhi, India had a woman as the leader of the nation, and today women account for 10 percent of the Indian Parliament (compared with 5 percent in the United States Congress). But as Ms. Bumiller writes, ''For every woman who sits in Parliament or has done a Ph.D. or goes to the Supreme Court to argue a case, you have thousands in the villages who don't even know about their basic rights and that they are equal citizens.''
From ancient times and for a multitude of reasons, Indian women have never had equality with men. Certainly one reason for the oppression was the paramount importance placed on preserving caste distinctions and lineage purity. Women have been glorified in Indian literature and in sculpture and painting, but the reality seems to have been otherwise.
In modern times, the complacency that arose from having a woman in the highest office of the land was shattered by the 1974 Government report on the status of India's women. The report, ''Toward Equality,'' revealed that in many ways conditions for women had actually regressed since independence. It was the catalyst for an Indian women's movement, which, like the feminist movement in the United States, was founded by the elite. Few Indian women, however, would call themselves feminists, a label regarded with suspicion. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, the first woman to be President of the United Nations General Assembly, would deny being a feminist, yet she was intensely aware of equal rights. Asked by a reporter after her election to describe the sari she was wearing, she promptly countered, ''Did you ask my predecessor to describe his suit?''
Ms. Bumiller's insightful study of arranged marriages illustrates her problems in coming to terms with the Indian woman's easy acceptance of such a system. She ultimately rationalizes that modern arranged marriages are, in fact, not much unlike America's dating services. Her essay ''Flames: A Bride Burning and a Sati'' includes potentially explosive material: Statistics indicate that the annual number of dowry deaths is higher than the deaths from terrorist activity in the Punjab. Ms. Bumiller suggests that the consumer boom of the last two decades, spurring the greed for economic status symbols, is in large measure at the root of the problem. Investigating female infanticide in ''No More Little Girls,'' she views the practice ''not as the act of monsters in a barbarian society but as the last resort of impoverished, uneducated women driven to do what they thought was best for themselves and their families.''
The essay entitled ''Indira Is India, and India Is Indira'' raises the question why Mrs. Gandhi largely ignored those of her own sex. Ms. Bumiller says the Prime Minister made no special effort to promote other women and comments that she ''transcended sexual categories''; but she never tries to answer the question.
The final essay, on the failure of population control in India, lays the blame largely on the debased status of women and a family's overwhelming desire for sons. The only success story is in the southern state of Kerala, where 70 percent of women are literate (three times the national average); they have a partnership role in marriage and a voice in deciding the number of children they will bear. Overpopulation aggravates every major problem India faces, and Ms. Bumiller concludes that the status of women must be improved because ''the future of India'' depends on it. Advance Publicationsd(Random House)

HEADLINE: Diversionary Tactic on S.& L.'s

 BODY:
Several members of Congress propose creating a nonpartisan commission to dig out the full story of the savings and loan scandal. They make it sound like a serious attempt to rise above politics. It smells more like a refuge for politicians. 
Special commissions can serve useful purposes. The Rogers commission on the Challenger shuttle explosion in 1986, for example, conducted a highly professional, technical investigation into a subject of widest interest. The Warren commission, headed by a Chief Justice with impeccable credentials, helped calm the nation after the assassination of President Kennedy. The Greenspan commission on Social Security reform brokered a deal between warring Democrats and Republicans in 1983 that arguably saved the system.
But none of those special needs exist in the S.& L. scandal. The public is certainly entitled to the complete truth about what and who caused this historic bust. And it would be useful to pull all the facts together in one place. But the proposed commission would also be authorized to second-guess the Administration's current efforts to untangle the mess, adding yet another layer to an already top-heavy structure of administrators and investigators. It would also be useful to uncover all the meddling and conniving by key members of Congress and the Reagan Administration. But many of those players are gone from Washington already; it seems much more likely that a commission would only provide cover for sitting politicians who are embarrassed by their negligence, if not complicity. Representatives and senators could duck the issue during this fall's re-election campaign by saying ''we've appointed a commission.''
When it came time for the commission to report, how boldly would it confront the roles that Congress and the Administration played? And would its charter permit comment on the political system that elects and appoints irresponsible officials? A recommendation to curb political contributions would be welcome from any quarter, but that's not the kind of advice Congress is looking for.
The causes of the savings and loan scandal are no mystery - high interest rates, careless deregulation, lax and possibly corrupt Federal supervision and, in the industry, incompetence, greed and outright looting. Who needs a commission to confirm that? Only politicians who want to appear to be doing something.

HEADLINE: Letter: On Ecology;
Brazil's Small Share of the Greenhouse

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Preaching to Brazil From Hawaii'' (editorial, July 24) gives credence to the ill-founded rumors that ''Brazil is the world's third-largest creator of greenhouse gases, after the United States and the Soviet Union.'' Such rumors originated in a recent report from the World Resources Institute. Its figures regarding Brazil are plainly wrong. 
Recent data obtained by the Space Research Institute of Brazil, independently confirmed by NASA studies, indicate that:
* Deforestation in the Amazon has been progressing at a near-constant rate since 1974 and not exponentially as predicted by the World Bank.
* Average rate of deforestation from 1978 to 1989 is 21,800 square kilometers a year (2.2 million hectares). This rate of deforestation is four times less than the numbers used by the World Resources Institute report.
* Total deforested area until 1989 was 394,000 square kilometers (93,000 early this century).
* Deforestation in Rondonia and Para has declined considerably.
* The contribution of deforestation in the Amazon to carbon dioxide emissions is estimated as 0.25 gigatons per year, about 3.7 percent (not 10.5 percent) of all CO#2 emissions.
The Brazilian Government recognizes that the deforestation rate of Amazon forest is still too high, and is trying successfully to curtail it. The subsidies, tax incentives and special credits conducive to forest destruction have been stopped. However, millions of people live there who burn parts of the forest to convert it into subsistence agriculture land.
Relocation of populations might be a future way to attract such people to other areas of the country, but Brazilians don't want to use the same argument used by some developed countries that such actions are not cost-effective. They are already acting, and a reforestation project in denuded areas in Carajas has been started.
These efforts alone will not ''stabilize greenhouse gas emissions,'' as recommended by the Group of Seven in Houston. Deforestation in the Amazon contributes less than 4 percent to worldwide CO#2 emissions. Industrialized countries need to act too, e.g., by reducing fossil-fuel burning, which is responsible for some 60 percent of all CO#2 emissions. Only a concerted effort of industrialized and developing countries in this matter will lead to a solution.
 
JOSE GOLDEMBERG
Secty. for Science and Technology
 Brasilia, July 24, 1990

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
Soviet Alternatives

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

DATELINE: LENINGRAD

 BODY:
This is the Soviet Union's second city and none too pleased about it. People claim that Leningrad, with a population of some five million, sends 80 billion rubles a year to Moscow, and gets 20 billion back. The center deliberately puts Leningrad down and holds it back, they say, and they are just as aggrieved as people in minority Soviet republics.
For two centuries this city was Russia's capital, founded on Baltic marshland by Peter the Great to open his country to Europe and force reforms and modernization. Lined with canals and lavish old palaces, it used to be called the Venice of the North, and it has a lively, defiant spirit. 
But the mood is bleak now. Everything gets worse and worse, people tell you on the street, and they see no better prospects. They don't believe perestroika will work. They are angry and frustrated.
Still, there are current heroes, three of them. First is the new Mayor, Anatoly Sobchak; then Boris Yeltsin, the new president of the Russian Republic, and Gavriil Popov, the new Mayor of Moscow. All three recently quit the Communist Party. The only good words I heard about Mikhail Gorbachev in a week here were from delegates to the Dartmouth Conference, a Soviet-American discussion group founded 30 years ago and sponsored by the Kettering Foundation.
Like the neighboring Baltic republics, Leningrad wants to make its own plans. There are to be negotiations with Estonia, where food supplies are considerably better, and there is a fuzzy project for a free economic zone to attract foreign investment. Mayor Sobchak talks about rivaling some of Spain's tourist income, and indeed, the old parts of the city and the birch-groved countryside are superb.
But the city also contains a disproportionate share of what's wrong with the country. Eighty percent of its industry produces for the military, and one in every four workers is employed by these industries. ''Even in the cold war we didn't need all that,'' said Aleksandr Fursenko, vice chairman of the local branch of the Academy of Sciences. Local demand is trying to block further construction of a huge dam in the Gulf of Finland across the mouth of the Neva. It was a flood control measure, but it has already built up pollution to the point where swimming is forbidden. As happened in Budapest with protests against a Danube dam, ecology is channeling a whole spectrum of grass-roots disgust into a political force.
There are already several hundred citizens' associations, not coalesced into any effective parties but providing a base for ferment. Leningrad is a prime example of momentum for fundamental change in the Soviet Union coming no longer from the top and the center but from the bottom up, from the regions and the provinces.
Asked who's to blame for what he called the intolerable, hopeless state of affairs, a young man who works in the port said it was the Communists and the Jews. ''Well, I don't know, maybe it's not the Jews' fault, but they make the good deals.''
He was lounging on the street at midday, reading one of the new independent papers, clearly well informed. ''There are three things I like in life,'' he volunteered. ''My ex-wife, whom I divorced, beer and cigarettes.'' He asked for a cigarette, and said, ''I'd be willing to work 12 or 14 hours a day for a normal living, but it's impossible. It humiliates me to beg for a cigarette.''
He wasn't like the idle, disaffected young on American streets. He spoke with contempt of dishonest people and his own lack of direction, and he was articulate. But he saw nothing he could do to make things better.
Mayor Sobchak is one of the scarce optimists. He is a blue-eyed, 51-year-old law professor, brimming with energy and convictions about changing the system. Unknown until he ran for the Supreme Soviet, he is a product of TV, through which his bold and forceful oratory made a huge impact.
He only joined the Communist Party in 1988, because then the only possibility for change was from the inside. He said he had quit because it was the way to speed the development of a multiparty system. He plans to appeal abroad for a fund for the revival of Petersburg-Leningrad (the city was formerly St. Petersburg), which he assures will again be as sparkling as a fresh American city.
He represents the new alternatives opening up to President Gorbachev's leadership - dispersed but very popular, finished with the ideas of gradual change and of clinging to the center. Despite the power game in Moscow, legitimacy is shifting ground.

HEADLINE: New York City Schools Face $62.3 Million Budget Cut

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
New York City school officials announced plans yesterday to cut $62.3 million in planned spending for the coming school year, a figure that they said is likely to reduce the teaching force in some places and further tighten the central bureaucracy by as many as 350 positions.
The cuts, which they said were the largest since the city's fiscal crisis ended around 1981, will mean more crowded classrooms in some schools and a variety of smaller cutbacks.
These, officials said, will include reductions in intramural sports in junior high schools, new fingerprinting fees for aspiring teachers, elimination of a summer camp program, fewer cars for bureaucrats and less use of consultants.
''It's all going to be difficult and it's all going to be painful,'' said Stanley S. Litow, the Deputy Chancellor for Operations as he briefed reporters before informing the 32 local school districts of the cuts that they will have to absorb. 
Yesterday's numbers were the first specific figures offered since the economically embattled city government told the Board of Education that it would have to achieve cuts of $89.4 million to reach a budget for the year that began July 1 of $6.49 billion. School officials managed to make up a portion of that sum by persuading state officials to take on financing of certain programs. Last year's budget was about the same, $6.49 billion, and Mr. Fernandez requested $6.87 billion for this year to cover increases such contractural costs as salaries and to account for inflation.
The city's budget of $28 billion, adopted earlier this month, called for more than $800 million in new or higher taxes and cutbacks for most city services. Other agencies are also in the process of pinpointing their cuts.
Mr. Litow could not say how many school jobs would be eliminated because districts and principals would have to decide where to cut. Of the total reduction, $26.8 million was identified as cuts in instructional expenses - $6.8 million for the high schools run by the central board and $20 million for the elementary and junior high schools run by the local boards.
That works out to roughly one starting teacher's salary for each of the city's 984 schools, but districts could decide to cut paraprofessionals, guidance counselors or secretaries instead, or they could reduce spending for books, supplies and programs.
A district of average size would have to cut about $625,000.
''It will mean hundreds of fewer positions,'' said Robin Willner, the board's executive director for strategic planning. Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers, expressed doubt yesterday that experienced teachers would be laid off.
Rather, she said, administrators are likely to leave unfilled the jobs of teachers who retired or quit in June. The board had planned to hire 5,000 new teachers for September. Ms. Feldman said that any cuts in teaching positions would affect that group rather than returning teachers.
''I don't see widespread layoffs,'' she said.
Other cuts announced yesterday will mean as many as 350 fewer workers at the board's headquarters centered at 110 Livingston Street. The board has already lost more than 400 positions since Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez took office Jan. 1 and is now down to a staff of 4,500.
 
'Less Service'
The city's superintendents examined the new figures yesterday afternoon and many could not predict what shape their cuts would take.
''The clear thing is that we're going to provide less service to children for the next year,'' said Anthony Alvarado, superintendent of District 2, in Manhattan.
Mr. Alvarado's district has a budget of $55 million, and 90 percent of that is for salaries. ''Some of it will have to come from personnel,'' he said.
The superintendent of District 11, in the Bronx, Frank Arricale 2d, said he would probably have to eliminate ''teacher trainers'' assigned to each of his 31 schools. These are experienced teachers who help both novice and veteran teachers improve their instructional and disciplinary skills. Most, he said, would return to the classroom and fill some of the more than 90 teaching vacancies that the district expects in September. But the loss would hurt, he said.
 
A $140 Million Problem
School officials said yesterday that poorer districts that more readily qualify for Federal funds would find it easier to make up the cutbacks than districts that are relatively well off..
Mr. Litow said that even accounting for inflation the magnitude of the cuts were similar to those in the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's, when, he said, 14,000 teachers lost their jobs. But nothing like that epidemic of layoffs is on the horizon, he said, because officials have had far more time to plan and have been willing to take cuts of $15.8 million in the central bureaucracy's budget. During the fiscal crisis, he said, no central board jobs were cut.
The scope of the problem that school officials had to wrestle with this year, Mr. Litow said, was actually $140 million, the combined result of an underestimate of teacher salaries and an overestimate in student population. But the city restored $32 million, and the state agreed to finance the city's Project Giant Step program for 4-year-olds and to pick up several other costs.
Of the $15.8 million in administrative cuts at the central board, $2.5 million will come through savings achieved by the State Legislature's abolition of the Board of Examiners effective Dec. 31; $1.5 million in savings for consultants; $500,000 in reductions of official cars; $3 million in supplies, and $5.6 million in job cuts through both attrition and layoffs.
For the first time in several years, the vast majority of teaching candidates will have to pay $104 in fingerprinting and other application fees in addition to new charges of roughly $40 for drug testing. The fingerprinting fees had been waived in an effort to encourage applicants for a system that is short of teachers.
The board will also pare money for several centrally financed programs, including eliminating a $400,000 program for student ''diplomats'' who visit other cities and canceling a new program that would have provided $1.1 million for the identification of teaching prospects in college.

HEADLINE: Eastern L.I. Spots a Dreaded Foe: The Brown Tide Surfaces Again

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAMPTON BAYS, L.I. July 27

 BODY:
After a two-year absence, a mysterious algal bloom that devastated the bay scallop industry in eastern Long Island has reappeared.
Suffolk County officials this week reported high concentrations of the algae, a species of microscopic plankton, in Shinnecock and Moriches Bay on the South Shore and in West Neck Bay at Shelter Island.
The algae is measured in cells per millileter and turns the water brown when concentrations reach 200,000 - thus its popular name, brown tide. The latest reading, on July 12, showed a count of 800,000 in western Shinnecock Bay. 
But concentrations elsewhere have been smaller, and unlike five years ago, when the algae blanketed the open water and cell counts reached 2 million, the problem this summer appears far less pervasive.
 
Facing the Unknown
The large Peconic Bay system, for example, which separates the North and South Forks, has been largely free of the brown tide. Officials believe the outbreak will remain spotty across the East End of Long Island and have seen signs of its decline. Even a modest scallop harvest is expected at the end of the summer.
But though less severe this year, the problem has nevertheless refocused attention on the search for answers to one of the biggest environmental threats in eastern Long Island, where the open water plays such an important recreational and economic role.
In addition, the rise and fall of brown tide here has implications for much of the East Coast, where sheltered bays behind barrier beach islands are the typical geography.
Despite substantial study in the last five years, no one still knows why the brown tide developed in 1985, why it receded the last two summers and why it has now made a comeback.
''We don't have an answer to the brown tide, but we do have clues,'' said Elizabeth Cosper, a professor at the State University of New York at Stony Brook who is researching the phenomenon. She spoke at a conference here today to discuss early results of a two-year study of brown tide.
The return of the algae this year is particularly disconcerting because much money has been spent to revive bay scalloping. But so far the blooms have spared reseeded scalloping areas.
The algae crippled the scallop and shellfish industries in the summers of 1985, 1986 and 1987. In the worst year, 1985, scallop harvests plummeted in value from an annual total of $1.5 million before the brown tide appeared to $1,000. Many other fish and shellfish populations suffered.
Scientists were astounded by the size of the 1986 bloom. It covered the Peconic Bay system, from Flanders Bay on the west to Gardiners Island on the east. And it extended south to the Shinnecock, Moriches and Great South Bays.
''I have never seen a bloom that widespread and composed of one single organism,'' said Dr. Bob Nuzzi, chief of the Bureau of Marine Resources of the Suffolk County Department of Health Services. In 1985, brown tide also swept across Narragansett Bay in Rhode Island and Barnegat Bay in southern New Jersey.
 
Reseeded Areas Safe, So Far
The problem is less serious this year. In the one part of the Peconic Bay system that has been tainted by the algae - the small West Neck Bay at Shelter Island - concentrations rose to nearly 600,000 cells per milliliter in early July. But the number has since fallen to 7,000, Dr. Nuzzi said today. In eastern Moriches Bay, concentrations were recorded at 360,000 last Tuesday.
Speakers at today's conference said it was a good sign that concentrations had declined dramatically in some areas and that the outbreaks were limited geographically.
''While I'm concerned about where concentrations are getting high, I'm buoyed by the fact the brown tide hasn't hit the reseeded areas'' for scallops, Dr. Nuzzi said.
Four years of work by Long Island's baymen have been involved in the reseeding. After 1985 there was ''really little hope for the future,'' said Chris Smith, a Cornell Cooperative Extension agent who has helped the baymen reintroduce scallops.
 
Indigestible Menace
Scallops are hurt by brown tides because they apparently cannot digest this plankton species, Aureococcus anophagefferens. In addition, eel grass, a habitat for scallop larvae, can be devastated when the surface is covered by brown tide and no light can penetrate for photosynthesis.
As a result of reseeding, millions of tiny scallops rest at the bottom of Great Peconic Bay, not a lot by normal standards but far more than anyone could have hoped several years ago, Mr. Smith said. A limited scallop harvest is possible this September and commercial-size harvests in coming years.
This assumes the brown tide remains quiescent. Results of the two-year brown-tide study, led by the Suffolk County Health Department, are expected in the fall and may offer conclusions about causes of the algae blooms and how they can be avoided.
 
Thriving in Stagnant Bays
So far, research points to a combination of circumstances that foster brown tide. An increase in water salinity brought on by drought may be a precondition; this occurred during the last three blooms. Also, bays that are blocked from ocean currents and thus rarely flushed may be particularly vulnerable. Flanders Bay is one of these.
The nutrients can come from many sources: effluent from sewage treatment plants or duck farms; fertilizer from farms, homes and golf courses, and other stormwater runoff. Nutrients in acid rain might also be a factor.
The study is expected to discuss ways to control such nutrients and prevent them from fouling the waters.
Peconic Bay is ''one of the most pristine estuaries in the Northeast,'' said Patrick G. Halpin, the Suffolk County Executive. ''The test for us is whether the next generation will be able to say the same thing.''

HEADLINE: St. Vincent's Discovers a Financial Cure

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
A week after Margaret Broughal was brought by ambulance to St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan, her left side immobilized by a stroke, physical therapists began helping her exercise her weakened body.
This early intervention was intended to speed Mrs. Broughal's recovery and make room for other patients. It was a small step in a campaign by the 141-year-old hospital to salvage its faltering financial standing.
When hospitals in New York State have been complaining of rising financial losses and lobbying for increased payments from state regulators, St. Vincent's has turned in its best financial performance in years: a $4.8 million profit.
Its success is due in part to shorter hospital stays, which allow St. Vincent's to treat more patients using fewer beds. 
This success also raises the question, state health officials say, of whether better management at the state's 260 hospitals could have better controlled costs when they were seeking financial relief.
If Gov. Mario M. Cuomo signs reimbursement legislation now on his desk, hospitals will receive $1 billion more in 1991 than they will this year in payments from patients covered by private insurance or Medicaid. The increase, totaling 13 percent, would be paid through taxes and higher health insurance premiums.
At St. Vincent's an unexpected $11.5 million loss in 1988 stunned the hospital staff and convinced it to try new remedies.
Chastened by the deficit, trustees, administrators and doctors at the hospital, on West 11th Street in Greenwich Village, set about systematically cutting costs and increasing revenues, mainly by reducing the number of days that patients like Mrs. Broughal spend in the hospital.
They ended the year with a $4.8 million gain, and doctors there say there is no evidence that patient care suffered as a result.
After coming close to bankruptcy in 1980, St. Vincent's had managed to just about break even each successive year, losing about $4 million a year from operating expenses, but making most of it up through contributions and income from its endowment.
Then in 1988 the losses rose. The hospital could not hire enough staff nurses and spent $6 million on per diem nurses. Supplies were more than $1 million over budget. The hospital spent more than its reimbursments for treating AIDS patients and for increasingly complicated and expensive cardiac surgery.
 
From 'Crisis,' A Cost Savings
 ''Sometimes a crisis can lead to a good ending,'' said Roger G. Weaving, the hospital's chief financial officer. ''The physicians said, 'Hey, we really got a problem here.' ''
St. Vincent's improved financial performance came as other hospitals reported increased losses.
The latest State Health Department figures show losses of $83 million in New York City in 1989, even after $151 million in income from endowments and charitable contributions were included. In 1988 the hospitals reported $34 million in losses.
While 19 hospitals reported some losses, large losses at a few hospitals accounted for much of the total. Of every $10 in hospital losses in New York City last year, $4 was attributed to Presbyterian Hospital in upper Manhattan.
The hospital attributed much of its $33 million loss to the cost of opening a new hospital pavilion in Washington Heights and the cost of running outpatient clinics.
Ronald B. Dreskin, vice president for finance at Presbyterian, said the hospital, which just hired its third chief executive officer in two years, has been reorganizing its management with an eye toward cutting costs. But he said cost controls are difficult when the medical staff also serves as a teaching staff.
''It is hard to run a hospital as a business,'' Mr. Dreskin said, ''but it is that much harder when you have 600 residents running around whose function is to learn.''
New York Hospital in Manhattan showed a $4 million loss. But that was a sharp improvement over the $20 million loss reported the year before. Dr. David B. Skinner, the hospital's president, attributed the change to tightened management.
Dr. Skinner said his institution reduced the average length of patient stays and serves the same number of patients as it did several years ago, while temporarily closing 60 beds.
At St. Vincent's the sudden crisis in 1988 stirred the trustees, who commissioned a consultant to review the hospital's finances, and propelled the medical staff to focus on longstanding problems.
The consultant, Price Waterhouse, confirmed what Mr. Weaving said he had been saying all along: The hospital had to reduce the average length of stay for patients, which was high even for hospitals in New York City. For every tenth-of-a-day reduction in the average length of stay, Price Waterhouse said, the hospital could save $1 million.
To convince the medical staff, the hospital circulated graphs comparing average lengths of stay at St. Vincent's with those at leading institutions in New York and across the country. Dr. Lawrence N. King, the medical director, quietly wrote to the 40 doctors whose patients had the longest stays.
The hospital also tried to reduce the number of patients waiting for nursing-home beds, which have been in short supply in New York for years. It offered financial guarantees to nursing homes that agreed to accept patients before applications for Medicaid payments were completed.
Since nonemergency patients sometimes waited several days for CAT scans, the hospital intalled a second CAT scan system.
Nowhere is the campaign to improve performance at St. Vincent's more evident, hospital officials say, than in neurology service, where Mrs. Broughal was a patient.
Dr. Joseph C. Masdeu, the neurology chief and Mrs. Broughal's doctor, has transformed the service since he arrived in 1985 - when its residency program was on probation by an accrediting agency.
The department won back full accreditation and stepped up the pace of its operations. It cut the average length of stay to 9.5 days in 1989 from 19.6 in 1984. As a result, it is able to treat one-third more patients using one-third fewer beds.
Dr. Masdeu said that neurologists are now trained to schedule a series of diagnostic tests as soon as patients are admitted, rather than ordering them one at a time as results come in. Planning for discharge begins, he said, almost as soon as patients arrive.
 
A Brisk Pace Toward Recovery
 For Mrs. Broughal, who is 58 years old and schedules booths at conventions for the American Bible Society, this meant a brisk schedule almost from the time she woke up one morning earlier this month and found that she could not get out of bed.
Soon after her condition was stabilized with medicine, a specialist in rehabilitation medicine visited her and began planning her move to the rehabilitation ward, which took place a week later.
''These physical terrorists put me on a mat and shove me around,'' she said with a laugh.
In the past, Dr. Masdeu said, patients did not begin physical therapy until they had regained more strength, but the earlier intervention is now thought to be helpful.
And, he noted that the sooner a patient can be moved from the neurology service to the rehabilitation service, the greater the savings to the hospital. Hospitals are paid a fixed fee for each stroke victim they treat, but can bill by the day for each day of recovery in the rehabilitation unit.
Soon after Mrs. Broughal arrived at the ward, social workers arranged for help to care for her husband, who is 76 and was incapacitated by a stroke some years ago. They also began preparing for her return home.
In the bed next to Mrs. Broughal, Pam Anzelone of Union, N.J., was receiving anti-inflammatory medication through an intravenous tube. Mrs. Anzelone sought help after she began having double vision and problems with her balance.
After administering a series of tests, doctors diagnosed her condition as multiple sclerosis. But except for two days when she was hospitalized while medicine was administered, Mrs. Anzelone was treated as an outpatient. In the past, Dr. Masdeu said, she would have likely been hospitalized during the testing.
As a result of the hospital's efforts, the average stay for acute-care patients was cut to 8.8 days in 1989 from 9.7 days in 1988. This made it possible for the hospital to admit more patients, for a savings of $9 million.
Costs were also carefully controlled and a new state system of computing payments for AIDS cases was begun. As nursing salaries rose, the hospital was able to recruit more full-time nurses and save money on payments to temporaries.
For the first time in years, the hospital broke even on direct operating revenue and showed a $4.8 million gain when contributions and endowment income were added. At the same time, said Dr. King, the medical director, the hospital's quality reviews reported no increase in patient problems, despite the shorter stays.
 
Bill Criticized By Insurers
 While some health experts raise the question of whether some hospitals are releasing patients before they ready, Dr. King said, ''We are not pushing things to the limits.''
''The difference between the length of stay in New York City and the rest of the country is enormous,'' he said. ''We are merely getting down to the national levels.''
The reimbursement bill on Governor Cuomo's desk would provide $420 million in increased payments to hospitals. Other adjustments already included in state law - for inflation and contruction costs - would bring the total to more than $1 billion.
Insurance companies, business groups and some union officials say that the legislation will have a disastrous effect on private health insurance rates. They say it does not direct the money to the hospitals and services that need it most.
But hospital officials say the large increase is justified because the system has been systematically starved of cash during the last decade and hospitals have been forced to defer maintenance and trim several thousand employees.
''We are as strung out as any hospital system in the country,'' said Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, which represents private hospitals. ''We are as lean as can be. Now is the time to reinvest wisely.''
J. Rock Tonkel, who was recently appointed as the first lay president of St. Vincent's Hospital, which is operated by the Archdiocese of New York and the Sisters of Charity of St. Vincent de Paul of New York, said that even with its recent profitability the hospital is not awash in money and needs a higher reimbursement rate as much as the next hospital.
''If you look at the reimbursement,'' he said, ''there is no way this or any other hospital is able to get the cash flow it needs to replace its equipment.''
