HEADLINE: U.N. Sees AIDS Toll Surging Among Women and Infants

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

 BODY:
At least three million women and children will die of AIDS in the 1990's, more than six times the number in the 1980's, the World Health Organization said in a report being published today.
In addition, several million children who are not infected with the AIDS virus are destined to become orphans in the 1990's after the deaths of their parents from AIDS, said the report in The Lancet, a leading medical journal published in London.
In New York and other major cities of the Americas, Western Europe and sub-Saharan Africa, AIDS is now the leading cause of death for women from 20 to 40 years old, the report said. In these cities, AIDS could raise the deaths among infants and children by up to 30 percent, said the author, Dr. James Chin, who heads the forecasting unit of the health organization's global AIDS program. 
 
Infections of Heterosexuals Rise
Until now, Dr. Chin said, ''the social, economic, and demographic impacts on women and children have been largely neglected.'' The major reason for the neglect was that during the 1980's most AIDS cases were in young and middle-aged men, Dr. Chin said.
But as the AIDS infections among homosexual and bisexual men have slowed in most areas of the world, there has been a slow but steady increase in HIV infections among heterosexual populations, especially in Latin America and the Caribbean.
Dr. Chin's report did not give figures for men. Another official of the Geneva-based health organization, Dr. David Heyman, said in a telephone interview that an even greater number of men were expected to die of AIDS in the 1990's.
The data from the Lancet article and specific numbers about deaths in men and other details are to be released at a meeting on AIDS in Asia next week in Canberra, Australia, said Marjory Dam, a spokeswoman for W. H. O. in Washington. However, the Lancet report appeared earlier than expected and her office at the Pan American Health Organization had not received the new data from the AIDS program in Geneva, Ms. Dam said.
 
African and Caribbean Impact
Tom Netter, a spokesman for W. H. O. in Geneva, said the projection of three million deaths of women and children was one million higher than earlier estimates from W. H. O. Mr. Netter said the W. H. O. had revised upward, to 8 million to 10 million, earlier estimates of the number of people infected with the AIDS virus in the world. The previous figures were 6 million to 8 million, Mr. Netter said.
The estimates for the 1990's are based on more precise evaluations of surveys and health statistics by W.H.O., which is a unit of the United Nations. Dr. Chin said the new projections should be viewed as very conservative.
The chief impact is in sub-Saharan Africa and some parts of the Caribbean. Up to 40 percent of women from 30 to 34 years old were found to be infected with the AIDS virus in some central African cities, the report said.
 
'Death Within a Year'
The proportion of pregnant women infected with the AIDS virus ranges from 10 to 20 percent in several central African cities, Dr. Chin said, and over the next five years most African countries below the Sahara can expect surging death rates in children under the age of 5 and adults in the 20-to-49-year age group from the viral disease.
AIDS could become the leading killer in the most severely affected sub-Saharan African cities in the next few years, the report said.
''As for most AIDS patients in Africa, the diagnosis of the disease in women and children in this continent will be followed by death within a year unless substantial improvements can be achieved with newer treatments,'' Dr. Chin wrote.
By the end of 1992, about four million infants will have been born to women who are infected with the AIDS virus, the report said. The AIDS virus is also called HIV, for human immunodeficiency virus. Nearly a million of the babies will themselves be HIV-infected, Dr. Chin said.
''Results from several HIV infection/AIDS models suggest that during the next few decades, life expectancy at birth in many sub-Saharan African cities may fall by about six years. Infant and child mortality could be as much as 30 percent greater than would otherwise have been expected,'' the study said.

HEADLINE: 'Junk Bond' Deal Joined By Investor

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HONG KONG, July 27

 BODY:
A Hong Kong businessman, Li Ka-shing, plans to spend $150 million for a half-interest in an investment group that has agreed to buy $3 billion in ''junk bonds'' from the troubled Columbia Savings and Loan Association in California, it was announced today.
Cheung Kong Ltd. and Hutchison Whampoa Ltd., two leading Hong Kong companies controlled by Mr. Li, along with a third company he controls privately, said they would buy half of a partnership assembled by the Gordon Investment Corporation, a merchant bank based in New York and Toronto.
The partnership, Gordon America L.P., said earlier this week that it had agreed to pay $300 million down for the portfolio of Columbia junk bonds and preferred stock along with a note for the remaining $2.7 billion at a 10.5 percent interest rate. 
 
A Troubled Savings and Loan
Regulatory changes in last year's savings industry bailout legislation forced Columbia to write down the value of its junk bonds by $1 billion, and it needs to improve its capital position if it hopes to escape being seized by regulators. Columbia is based in Beverly Hills, Calif.
Richard Li, the managing director of Hutchison's corporate fund management committee and the son of Li Ka-shing, said the purchase was part of the group's efforts to diversify its investments beyond Hong Kong.
''We look at this investment as a window into corporate America and into further investment opportunities,'' he said.
While the announcement of Li Ka-shing's involvement in the acquisition of Columbia's portfolio was disclosed only today, Mr. Li and Gordon had struck their deal before the sale was announced on Wednesday. In fact, Mr. Li and Gordon have a longstanding relationship. Mr. Li's Hutchison Whampoa Ltd. is an investment partner in Gordon Investment.
Li Ka-shing's investment career has been built largely on real estate, not stocks and bonds, but the move fits a strategy he discussed in a newspaper interview in November in which he said he wanted to reduce his exposure in Hong Kong, where 90 percent of his assets are based.
 
Changes Coming in 1997
Many people in Hong Kong are afraid that China will break its promise to maintain the economic and political system for 50 years after Beijing takes control of Hong Kong in 1997.
Numerous Hong Kong-based companies are moving assets abroad. The huge trading house Jardine Matheson has moved its base to Bermuda, while other companies have bought property in the United States, Canada and Australia.
In 1987, Mr. Li's business empire purchased a 43 percent stake in Husky Oil Ltd., Canada's largest oil and gas company.
In the Columbia deal, Cheung Kong, a real-estate giant, and Hutchison, a big trading house, will each own 20 percent of Gordon America L.P. A company owned by Mr. Li's family will hold 10 percent, with the remainder held by Gordon Investment.
Under the terms of the Gordon-Columbia deal, Gordon America agreed to pay $3 billion for the junk bonds, but with 90 percent financing on a non-recourse basis. That means the partnership could drop the portfolio if its losses exceeded 10 percent and Columbia would have to take it back.

HEADLINE: Prices of Treasury Securities Climb

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of all Treasury securities climbed and yields fell yesterday amid new signs that the economy is closer to a recession than data had previously indicated.
Several analysts suggested that the new evidence of economic slippage might be enough to persuade the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates.
The latest indication of weakness was reported by the Commerce Department, which said that the second-quarter gross national product grew at an annual rate of only 1.2 percent, compared with 1.7 percent in the first quarter. The department also revised downward the growth rates for the first quarter of this year, the fourth quarter of last year and the annual figure for 1989. 
 
Drop for Sales Component
Perhaps more important, the data showed that the ''real final sales'' component for the latest quarter registered its first decline since the recession year of 1982. Real final sales are the change in total G.N.P. minus the change in inventories.
While the report benefited the bond market, which thrives on negative economic news, it eroded the value of the dollar against all major foreign currencies. Any sign of economic weakness usually benefits investors in Treasury and other fixed-income securities because it tends to lessen inflation pressures and suggests interest rates may decline to help stimulate economic growth.
''The trend in the G.N.P. data tells us to expect a recession by the fourth quarter,'' said Philip Braverman, senior vice president and chief economist at the DKB Securities Corporation, the domestic arm of the giant Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Tokyo. ''The Federal Reserve's soft-landing scenario is turning into a crash landing. The Fed will now have to ease credit and ease aggressively.''
The Fed took steps exactly two weeks ago that lowered interest rates, a day after the central bank's chairman, Alan Greenspan, suggested lower rates might be needed to stimulate the economy and alleviate a tightening of credit by major banks. But since then Mr. Greenspan has indicated he did not see an immediate need for further easing.
Mr. Braverman stressed that the decline in real final sales was of particular concern. ''The G.N.P. report said second-quarter real final sales were down 1.5 percent,'' he said. ''But they would have been down 2.2 percent if the sales of crops to the Government were taken out. By comparison, real final sales were up 3.8 percent in the first quarter.''
Robert H. Chandross, chief economist at Lloyds Bank, said, ''The real final sales factor galvanized the fixed-income market.'' He added, ''Normally, the Fed does not immediately respond to G.N.P. data, but it will have to because the revised data for the previous two quarters and all of 1989 do not look good.''
One of the few positive aspects of the latest G.N.P. data is that they are expected to attract greater participation at the Treasury's next refunding auctions, the terms of which will be announced Wednesday. Mr. Chandross said the quarterly refunding auctions the next week are expected to consist of $11 billion of 3-year notes, $10.25 billion of 10-year notes and $10.25 billion of 30-year bonds.
In late trading, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue maturing in 2020, were offered at 102 31/32, up 22/32, as the yield fell to 8.47 percent, from 8.53 percent Thursday and a week earlier.
The long notes, the 8 7/8's of the year 2000, added 14/32, at 103 1/32, for a yield of 8.41 percent, down from 8.47 percent a week earlier. By comparison, the yield on 10-year Japanese bonds soared to 7.56 percent from 7.38 percent, while the yield on the 10-year West German bonds dropped to 8.13 percent from 8.39 percent.
Among other representative Treasury issues in the secondary market, the new 8 percent notes of 1992 rose 5/32, to 100, for a yield of 8 percent; the new 8.5's of 1997 added 11/32, at 100 14/32, to yield 8.35 percent.
 
Bill Discount Rates Ease
Dealers said a continuing flight to quality from the stock market caused discount rates on Treasury bills to ease. The rate on the 90-day bills fell four basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.54 percent; six-month bills declined five basis points, at 7.42 percent, and the one-year bills lost six basis points, at 7.28 percent.
The key Federal funds rate that banks charge each other for temporary loans traded at 8 percent virtually all day.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Plummets as Traders Expect Interest Rates to Fall

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply yesterday as traders, with evidence of a further weakening in the economy, grew convinced that the Federal Reserve would push United States interest rates lower.
Gold prices slipped despite the weakened dollar.
The dollar was hit hard by a Commerce Department report that the gross national product grew at an annual rate of just 1.2 percent in the second quarter. 
The G.N.P., which measures the country's total output of goods and services, was supported solely by a big buildup in business inventories. Other important components of the economy, including consumer spending, business investment and housing construction, declined.
The poor showing followed a meager 1.7 percent increase in the first quarter and an even more paltry advance of three-tenths of a percent in the final quarter of 1989.
''The overwhelming majority of the market believes we're in a recession; it's heard too many things to suggest otherwise,'' said Robert Ryan, chief foreign exchange dealer with Bank of New York.
The financial markets believe that with the economy continuing to slump, the Fed will have to let interest rates fall to help stimulate growth. But such a move would come at the expense of the dollar. Currencies are supported by higher interest rates, so a drop in United States yields makes the dollar less competitive.
That was evident yesterday as the British pound surged more than 2 cents against the dollar. Sterling rose to $1.8375 in New York from late Thursday's $1.8145. In London earlier, the British pound rose to $1.8350 from $1.8133.
It was also down against the West German currency, falling to 1.6120 marks, from 1.6230 late Thursday.
Against the Japanese currency, the dollar fell more than a yen, to 149.10 yen in New York, from 150.35 late Thursday. In Tokyo earlier, the dollar rose 0.64 yen to a closing 150.75 yen and it was quoted in London at 149.70 yen.
Other dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's prices, included: 1.3620 Swiss francs, down from 1.3773; 5.3990 French francs, down from 5.4360; 1,180.00 Italian lire, down from 1,187.50, and 1.15195 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15265.
Gold often benefits from a decline in the dollar, but technical factors carried it lower yesterday.
Gold fell $1.50 on the Commodity Exchange in New York to $367.80 an ounce. The Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $367.30, down $1.50 from Thursday.
Silver prices also declined. Silver slipped 1.9 cents, to $4.831 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange, and it fell in London to a late bid of $4.80 an ounce, from $4.85 late Thursday.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Speaker-Shopping in New York's Bazaar

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
If visitors from outer space landed in midtown Manhattan, they could conclude from shop windows that the object of life on earth was to consume stereo cassette players, compact disk players, video cameras, television sets, radios, telephones, calculators, fax machines, hand-held computers and other electronic gadgets nestled among signs saying ''Sale!'' and ''Discount!''
The concentration of stores, some of which advertise nationally through newspapers and catalogues, has made New York the nation's capital for electronics sales. But how good is it for consumers?
 
A Good Price Is Hard to Find
 Experts say you would have to be from Mars to take the stores at face value. ''The customer has a very difficult time nailing down 'What should I pay for it?' '' said Louise Boundas, the editor of the trade magazine Stereo Review.
At another trade publication, This Week in Consumer Electronics, Bob Gerson, the editor, said, ''There's no way I know of that the average guy can work this out.'' 
Even when he goes shopping for himself, Mr. Gerson said, he cannot determine what adds up to a good price for many products.
''Price'' is a relative concept in New York, harkening back to economists' definition of fair price: what a willing buyer will pay and a willing seller will accept. Electronic products are sold all over the United States, of course, in stores and through catalogues, but generally not at competitive prices.
Several New York stores have become national retailers through catalogue sales and large advertisements in major newspapers, complete with toll-free numbers for taking orders. Visitors from around the country and around the world come to New York to shop for these products.
They find a market that is nothing if not confusing. Consider, for example, shopping for a pair of speakers designed to operate from a portable cassette or CD player, without amplifier, in lieu of headphones.
The Sony SRS-55 model speaker - 7 inches high, 5 inches deep and 3 inches wide, is suitable for a desktop, a dresser or other places where full-size stereo equipment is not practical. Most stores have the SRS-55.
At Camera Electronics, in Herald Square, the salesman first asks a customer how many speakers he wants - apparently intending to sell them individually. ''One pair,'' the customer says. ''One hundred and twenty dollars,'' the salesman says. But, the customer says, at 47th Street Photo the catalogue lists them for $69.95. The customer turns to leave; the salesman says with a shrug, ''O.K., give me $69.''
In that immediate area, Camera Barn wants $79, and Sixth Avenue Electronics wants $89. At the Wiz, the price is $99.99 and the salesman does not offer to beat or equal another store's price.
At Tower Camera and Video, which opened a few weeks ago on the corner of 43d Street and Broadway, near the heart of the Times Square tourist district, the sticker says $259.95 but a salesman says $109.
 
The Best, Only the Best!
Just down the street at USA Electronics, the salesman says $75, but when a shopper resists, he says, ''What's your best price?'' Pursuing the shopper toward the door, the salesman exclaims, ''I'll give you the best price, I'll give you the best price!''
At Grand Central Camera, on Lexington Avenue at 44th Street, a salesman asks a price-shopper, ''Why don't you want the better one?'' and points to a different brand. When the customer insists on the Sony, the salesman says $65. The customer turns to leave, saying he wants to do more shopping. ''How about $49.95?'' asks the salesman, and the two agree. The salesman writes out the sales slip and adds the tax. But a clerk sent to the stockroom announces that there are none left: the salesman pushes his other models.
On Canal Street, Uncle Steve Inc. is selling the SRS-55 for $59, cash only. A salesman there offered a shopper an AC adapter for $18 but the shopper bought one at a shop next door for $5.
There are other ways. A consumer with a computer and a modem can shop through the General Electric Information Services Company and order merchandise by credit card. The SRS-55 is $79.95. And there are catalogues.
What should electronic goods really cost? a shopper might ask. ''All we do is set the list price,'' said Shari Haber, a spokeswoman for the Sony Corporation of America. In this case, it's $99.95. ''It's up to the store what they sell it for,'' she said. By law, manufacturers cannot dictate sales prices. Ms. Haber said Sony's recommendations were generally followed only when a product was brand-new, in demand and hard to find.
''It's like a third-world economy, a flea market,'' said Mark Green, the New York City Consumer Protection Commissioner. A week ago his office revoked the license of one of the larger electronics shops, Camera World and Sound. It is illegal, said Mr. Green, to offer merchandise for sale without a price tag. ''If there is no tag and someone walks in speaking a foreign language, they may pay $450 for a $150 pair of binoculars,'' he said.
Mr. Green added that it is also illegal to charge more than the manufacturer's suggested price without telling the customer. That may be one reason list prices are kept high. ''You cannot disparage an advertised sale item in order to bait and switch the consumer to a more expensive item,'' he said - the charge against Camera World.
But charging what the traffic will bear is accepted practice. ''The reason there are so many electronics stores in midtown is that there are so many gullible tourists in midtown,'' he said. ''If a store grossly overcharges, you might find someone from Pennsylvania or Poland who will gobble it up.''
It sounds like the old joke: Why did God create tourists? Because somebody has to pay full retail price. Mr. Gerson, whose trade journal is known by its acronym, Twice, says that stores like Radio Shack often get a higher price, ''but when a customer walks into Radio Shack and walks out with a receiver, he knows the price he paid for it is the price of a Radio Shack receiver.''
At another store, he said, ''You don't know the price of, say, a Technics receiver, or whether it's this year's model or last year's model or next year's model.'' Some national chains, he said, can stay in business because customers are confident that while they are not getting a bargain, they are not being taken.
Comparison shopping is probably the only key to a reasonably priced purchase. Katie Hafner, an author, now recounts with chagrin the electronic database wristwatch with the $198 price tag that the salesman at a store on Fifth Avenue sold her for $98, along with a $169 camera. The salesman even threw in some free film.
Later Ms. Hafner saw the watch for $25 and the camera for $69. ''I will never be able to face another electronics store without burning with shame,'' she said.
 
FERRETING OUT A FAIR PRICE
How do you buy electronic equipment at a fair price?
First, try to settle on the make and model by talking to people who have bought something you like. That done, check a reputable independent source, like Consumer Reports, and then be prepared to shop hard.
Here are some things to remember. On items that should sell for under $100, it is not unusual for the first price quoted to be double what the retailer will settle for.
The dollar amount on a price tag means nothing in many stores. A letter or number code on the price instantly tells the salesman what the actual price is.
Larger electronics products, like television sets or videocassette recorders, generally have a markup of about 28 percent, said Bob Gerson, editor of This Week in Consumer Electronics. Smaller ''accessory'' items, like independently powered speakers, usually have list prices that may be double the wholesale cost, or more.
When you decide, make sure the box is sealed, the model number on the item matches the one on the box and the device is new. Otherwise, in a world of rapidly changing products, you may get this year's wrapper and last year's model.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Window at Bryant Imports, 42d Street near Avenue of the Americas. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times); one item at issue, with disparity in prices. (Bill Aller/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bush Will Let Japanese Buy Hercules Unit

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, July 27

 BODY:
President Bush said today that he would not block the sale of Semi-Gas Systems Inc. to a Japanese bidder even though the California company has a central role in the semiconductor industry's effort to overtake its Japanese rivals. Semi-Gas Systems is a primary supplier of gas distribution and control systems to American chip makers.
Under terms first disclosed in April, Nippon Sanso of Japan intends to acquire Semi-Gas Systems for $23 million from Hercules Inc., a large chemical producer in Wilmington, Del. Hercules acquired Semi-Gas three years ago for an investment of about $5 million, industry officials said. 
Officials at Sematech, the Government-industry alliance to bolster the nation's chip-making technology, renewed their threats to cancel its contract with Semi-Gas after the decision was announced from Mr. Bush's summer home in Kennebunkport, Me.
''If the acquisition goes through, we would more than likely remove Semi-Gas as a supplier to the consortium,'' Peter H. Mills, Sematech's senior vice president and chief administrative officer, said in an interview.
''They have been an intimate partner to Sematech almost since we began two years ago,'' he added. ''They have an intimate knowledge of our fabrication facility. You couldn't choose a better way to do industrial espionage.''
The Semi-Gas purchase also has opposition in Congress. Representative Mel Levine, the California Democrat, said after the President's decision today that the endorsement of Nippon Sanso's bid was ''an unconscionable abandonment'' of the President's responsibilities on national security.
''Does the President care who controls American's strategic industries and our economic future?'' Mr. Levine asked. ''Mr. Bush has sold off a critical piece of American's economic pie to the Japanese without blinking an eye.''
 
National Security Issue
President Bush is authorized by Congress to block the purchases of American companies by foreign buyers in any case where issues of national security are raised. The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, headed by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, had recommended approval of Nippon Sanso's bid for Semi-Gas Systems.
An Administration official said Sematech secrets would be protected from use by Nippon Sanso under a confidentiality pact Nippon Sanso has said it will accept. He added that Nippon Sanso had agreed to sell to American chip makers a different gas-purifying system preferred by many Japanese chip makers because of it reduces defects in the chip-making process. Setback for Sematech Removing Semi-Gas equipment would be a major setback for Sematech, which has been pressing to improve the technology and equipment for producing computer chips with increasingly narrow circuit widths by next year. Mr. Mills said replacing Semi-Gas with another domestic supplier would force a shut down of Sematech's research laboratory for at least six months.
Sematech's annual budget is about $230 million, with $100 million contributed by taxpayers and the balance from 14 companies in the domestic chip-making and computer industry, including the International Business Machines Corporation, the Intel Corporation, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Motorola Inc. It was formed in 1988, with headquarters in Austin, Tex.
 
Alliance on Course
Before his death last month, Robert N. Noyce, Sematech's president and chief executive, said the alliance was on course to reclaim the lead from their Japanese rivals by the mid-1990's.
Semi-Gas controls 46 percent of the market for gas distribition and control technology for the chip-making industry in the United States. Its purchase by Nippon Sanso, a major supplier of similar equipment in Japan, must still pass antitrust reviews by the Justice Department.
The prospect of another Japanese purchase of an American supplier to domestic chip makers was scuttled earlier this year after angry protests by some members of Congress. Japan's Nikon considered bidding for a unit of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation that produces photolithography equipment, but never made a formal offer. The Perkin-Elmer unit was later acquired by the Silicon Valley Group, in San Jose, Calif.
''We found that there is no credible evidence'' that Nippon Sanso's acquisition of Semi-Gas Systems would threaten national security or the nation's chip-making industry, said an Administration official familiar with the Semi-Gas analysis by the Brady panel.

HEADLINE: G.N.P. Rate Up Just 1.2% In 2d Period

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
PUB-DATE: July 31, 1990
In its latest figures on the health of the American economy, the Commerce Department reported yesterday that the United States was much closer to a recession than Government statistics had recognized until now.
The new figures showed that the gross national product, measuring the total value of the nation's goods and services, grew by a very weak 1.2 percent annual rate in the second quarter. That was about half-a-percentage point or so below the forecasts.
The dollar tumbled and Treasury securities rose sharply in price and yields fell, the usual reaction to news that a recession may be more likely because interest rates move lower in recessions. [Pages 32 and 37.] Closer to Recession Still, the slow economic growth during the April-to-June period was not a great surprise, given that economists refer constantly to the economy as sluggish. The big surprise came in the Commerce Department's annual revision of earlier G.N.P. figures. Instead of a slowdown that seemed to have started last September, the department said the sluggishness actually began in March 1989, indicating that for more than a year the economy was moving closer to a recession than many economists realized. 
''The basic story is that the economy had a lot less momentum than we thought because income was less than we thought and for that reason people aren't spending as much as we thought they were,'' said David Wyss, senior economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, an economic consulting service.
 
Revised Downward
Until yesterday, Government data showed the G.N.P to be growing at a healthy annual rate of 2.6 percent in last year's second quarter and 3 percent in the third period. The revised G.N.P. numbers for these two quarters, however, were 1.6 percent and 1.7 percent, respectively. Similar revisions for last year's fourth quarter reduced growth to a meager three-tenths of one percent from the previously reported 1.1 percent. The first quarter of 1990 was reduced to 1.7 percent from 1.9 percent.
A recession is formally defined as two consecutive quarters of contraction in the G.N.P.
The Bush Administration put the best face on the numbers. Michael Darby, the Commerce Department's Under Secretary for Economic Affairs, said the best way to look at the G.N.P. numbers was to average the first and second quarter, rather than think of the first quarter as 1.7 percent growth and the second as 1.2 percent. He described the average, an annual rate of 1.5 percent in the first half, as modest.
Mr. Darby also insisted at a news conference yesterday that despite the latest numbers, the G.N.P. would still grow by 2.2 percent in 1990, with most of the catch-up growth coming in the fourth quarter. If the goal is not met, the budget deficit is likely to be higher than the current estimates. That is because sluggish economic growth usually reduces tax revenue and raises outlays for unemployment insurance and other programs.
 
Many Sectors Off
The sluggishness in the second quarter appeared in many sectors. Net exports declined from the first quarter. So did business investment, consumer spending and personal income. Only Government purchases rose. As a result, final sales - the broadest measure of demand for American goods and services - fell by an annual rate of 1.5 percent in the second quarter, after having risen by 3.8 percent in the first quarter.
Personal consumption, in fact, fell by three-tenths of a percent, at an annual rate, in the second quarter, and by eight-tenths of a percent in last year's fourth quarter, according to the revised figures. That is still well above the 2.2 percent decline in the fourth quarter of 1981, in the opening months of the last recession, which lasted a year and was the most severe since World War II.
Personal income, on the other hand, is not falling as quickly as spending. Income from all sources dropped five-tenths of a percent, adjusted for inflation, after having risen by 2.5 percent at an annual rate in the first quarter. About one-third of the drop was in Federal subsidies paid to farmers. Wages, commissions and fees paid to stockbrokers and others in financial services also declined from first-quarter levels, the Commerce Department said.
Some economists, among them Richard Rahn, chief economist at the United States Chamber of Commerce, urged the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates. The central bank has been reducing rates in spread-out steps since March 1989, but many economists consider mortgage and consumer lending rates of 10 percent or more as still too high to encourage purchases on credit that would stimulate the economy.
 
Fear of Inflation
Out of concern that the inflation rate might rise, the Federal Reserve is often reluctant to reduce interest rates and thus encourage too much demand and upward pressure on prices. But the new G.N.P. data showed that the fixed-weight price index, a broad measure of inflation, had declined in the second quarter to an annual rate of 3.9 percent from 6.6 percent in the first period.
What growth there was in the second quarter came from a buildup in inventories, mostly in the warehouses of wholesalers and retailers, but not manufacturers. Recessions have frequently begun in the past when businesses, concerned about their unsold stockpiles of goods, canceled factory orders en masse, resulting in widespread layoffs. Government data indicate that so far these cancellations have not occurred.
The G.N.P. figures seemed to indicate a sharp rise in auto inventories. But Mr. Donahoe noted that this was not the case. Auto inventories actually declined in the second quarter, but by a much smaller amount than in the first quarter, and G.N.P. accounting makes this seem like a buildup in auto inventories. The major buildup, however, was in retailing and machinery, the later probably a reflection of the decline in capital spending and the drop in net exports.

HEADLINE: Trinidad Rebels Threaten to Kill Premier and 11 Other Hostages

BYLINE: By Reuters

DATELINE: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, July 28

 BODY:
Representatives of the Government of Trinidad and Tobago were negotiating tonight with Muslim coup plotters who said they had wired the Prime Minister and 11 other hostages with explosives and would blow them up if loyal forces tried to free them.
The Government-controlled radio reported progress in the negotiations, although details were sketchy. The Caribbean News Agency quoted a police official as saying that the rebels had requested safe passage to Libya, which the Trinidad Government says is backing the group.
A Roman Catholic Church official, Archbishop Anthony Pantin, said earlier that the leader of the Muslim group, which has been holding Prime Minister Arthur N. R. Robinson and members of his Cabinet in the Parliament since Friday evening, had told him that the hostages would die if any attempts were made to storm the building to free them. 
 
Threat by Rebel Leader
''He said he has them wired up and will fire them,'' the Archbishop said after meeting with the rebel leader, Abu Bakr.
Archbishop Pantin termed the situation ''very grim'' and said Mr. Abu Bakr and his group appeared to be losing patience with the standoff.
But the Government radio announcer said later that the Archbishop and another church official had headed to the national television station, which was occupied by the rebels, in the expectation of a breakthrough.
About 22 people were reported killed in scattered fighting in the capital of this two-island nation [In Washington, the White House expressed support for Mr. Robinson's Government. A Bush Administration official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that ''the possibility exists to dispatch a team for an advisory role'' but that there were ''no plans for military activity'' to aid the Trinidad Government.] Earlier today, Government troops surrounded the Parliament building, where the rebel organization, Jamaat al-Muslimeen, started its coup attempt. The group's name is Arabic for Group of Muslims.
Witnesses said that looters ran through the streets, parts of the capital were ablaze and that sporadic firing was going on between forces loyal to the Government and supporters of the Muslim group. The international airport was closed shortly after the start of the coup attempt.
The Caribbean News Agency reported that hospital officials had said about 22 people, including several police officers, had been killed in gunfights between the two sides since the the coup attempt began.
 
Many Victims in Hospitals
The state-run radio said there were ''lots of wounded'' and appealed for doctors and nurses to go to hospitals to cope with the influx of victims.
Mr. Abu Bakr (whose name is pronounced AH-boo BAH-kuhr) said in a morning television broadcast that he had overthrown Mr. Robinson's Government and that charges were to be brought against the Prime Minister and members of his Cabinet.
At least three people were reported to have been killed when the rebel group stormed into Parliament while lawmakers were in session about 6 P.M. Friday and seized 20 officials. No officials are known to have been hurt.
The rebels, whom the Government estimates to number between 250 and 500, were armed with AK-47 rifles. They were holding their captives in the ornate parliamentary chamber and had also taken up barricaded positions on the street outside.
The Acting President of Trinidad, Emanuel Carter, declared in a radio broadcast early today that the Government was in control. His statement came well before Archbishop Patin's first meeting with Ali Bakr and his report that the hostages had been wired with explosives.
 
President Vacationing Overseas
Mr. Carter, filling in while President Noor Hassanali is on vacation in Britain, declared a state of emergency and an indefinite curfew.
The rebel group released 8 of the 20 captives before dawn today after mediation by an Anglican priest. Those freed included two Government ministers.
A spokesman for Deputy Prime Minister Winston Dookeran described the situation early today as ''a mass kidnapping.''
''We are victims at this time of extremists, particularly backed by Libya and other international hoodlums,'' Mr. Dookeran's spokesman said in an appeal for international help.
Emeka Anyaoku, the Secretary General of the British Commonwealth, which lists Trinidad and Tobago among its 50 members, condemned the coup attempt, telling the British Broadcasting Corporation, ''There is no way the region as a whole and the Commonwealth in general can accept a situation where democracy can be turned over in that way.''
The police headquarters in Port of Spain, set on fire early in the coup attempt, was destroyed. At dawn, many fires were visible for miles under towering plumes of black smoke. Gunfire sounded sporadically in the streets of the capital, a city of 60,000. [The State Department described the Muslim rebels as a ''fringe extremist group with no popular support.'' The department's statement said that the group had direct ties to Libya and that some members had been trained there. Americans in Trinidad were asked to stay indoors, and travelers were warned against heading there.] Television Station Seized Mr. Abu Bakr seized control of Trinidad's state-run television station at about 6:30 P.M. on Friday. He went on television several times during the night with statements that railed against the Government.
When the group seized Parliament, Steve Maurice, chief of security for the Prime Minister, tried to shield Mr. Robinson from the rebels with his body but was forced at gunpoint to move away, a newspaper report said. Mr. Robinson and 19 other ministers and officials were ordered to lie on the floor, and were later taken to another room inside the building.
Mr. Abu Bakr, a former policeman in his mid-40's who founded the rebel organization about six years ago, said in an early-morning broadcast that the Government was responsible for a wave of corruption, rape, incest, robbery and drugs sweeping the country.
Trinidad and Tobago, an oil-producing republic off Venezuela, has been hit hard by a fall in the price of oil, and unemployment has reached 20 percent. Mr. Robinson has imposed unpopular austerity measures to halt economic decline.
Mr. Robinson, whose full name is Arthur Napoleon Raymond Robinson and who is 63 years old, came to power in a landslide victory on Dec. 16, 1986, ending 30 years of rule by the People's National Movement. Mr. Robinson pledged that in his five-year term he would restore growth to the economy and end racial divisions.

HEADLINE: A Tax Debate Revived

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 28

 BODY:
The Bush Administration opened old political wounds this week when it proposed to limit the amount of state and local income taxes that taxpayers could deduct on their Federal returns.
The proposal raised anew the question of the best way to make the wealthy pay more taxes. It stirred once again conflict between states with high income taxes and those that rely on sales taxes. And it led governors and mayors to complain that this Administration, like the previous one, would inhibit their ability to raise money at the very time they were being required to shoulder a greater share of the burden of dealing with social problems.
Today, it is still unclear whether the Administration intends to push for enactment of the plan or whether it was made as a bargaining chip to emphasize that there were ways to raise taxes on many high-income taxpayers without increasing tax rates. 
 
Bush Not 'Locked In'
On his way to Maine for the weekend, President Bush told reporters he was not ''locked in to any specific proposal.''
The brunt of the new tax proposal would be felt in states like New York, Massachusetts and California, where state and often city income taxes are steep.
These are the states with the most ambitious social programs and state services. Although there are exceptions, as a rule the states with the highest income taxes tend to be Democratic strongholds.
Residents of states like Texas, Florida and Connecticut who pay little if any income tax would not be affected by the plan. Many lawmakers from such states argue that since sales taxes, from which they derive most of their revenue, are no longer deductible, it is only fair to drop the deduction for income taxes.
 
Plan Outlined Privately
One important lawmaker who might be expected to take that position is Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, a Democrat and chairman of the Finance Committee. But Senator Bentsen may still be interested in running on a national ticket and may therefore be reluctant to alienate residents of large states with high taxes that would be important to him politically.
The plan was outlined by Richard G. Darman, the budget director, at a private meeting with Republican leaders Wednesday evening. No full description has been made public, but officials familiar with the proposal said on Thursday that it would place a $10,000 limit on the amount of state and local income taxes that could be deducted by a married couple from their Federal income taxes. The officials said they were not sure how single taxpayers would be affected, but presumably the limit would be somewhat lower. The deductibility of property taxes would not be affected.
Deductions are subtracted from total income before taxes are calculated. For example, a taxpayer who earns $50,000 and has deductions of $15,000 has a taxable income of $35,000.
 
Effects in New York
Nicholas A. Nesi, a tax partner in the New York headquarters of BDO Seidman, the accounting firm, calculated that a $10,000 ceiling would affect couples in New York City with incomes above $107,000. Elsewhere in the state where there is no local income tax, it takes a higher income before the state tax by itself reaches $10,000. Those affected in such areas would be couples with incomes above about $145,000. The top tax rate is 7.875 percent in New York State, and the top city rate is an additional 3.5 percent.
Mr. Nesi figured that a couple living outside New York City and earning $150,000 would owe about $1,600 more in Federal taxes each year if the plan became law.
In New Jersey, the top tax rate has just been increased to 7 percent from 3.5 percent, effective next January.
Congressional statisticians estimate that if the new rule were to go into effect next January, it would raise less than $3 billion in the 1991 fiscal, which begins Oct. 1. But over the following four years, it would raise about $7 billion a year, a sizable downpayment toward reducing the Federal deficit.
Mr. Darman is familiar with the political pitfalls of such a proposal. He was Deputy Treasury Secretary and the chief tax negotiator in 1985, when Ronald Reagan proposed abolishing all deductions for state and local taxes.
 
Reagan Proposal Was Disputed
It was one of the most hotly disputed parts of the Reagan tax plan, and it threatened to wreck the Reagan plan until it was watered down. In the end, Congress agreed to eliminate deductions for state and local sales taxes, but income and property taxes were left fully deductible.
The Reagan proposal on state and local tax deductions was part of an overall plan to reduce tax rates and eliminate tax breaks. The Bush proposal, in contrast, is intended to raise revenue as a step toward lowering the Federal deficit.
In putting forth the plan this week, the Bush Administration may have made a political miscalculation. Mr. Darman apparently intended for it to become public simultaneously with a Democratic tax offer.
But when word of the proposal leaked out Thursday morning. Democrats decided to withhold their offer and let the Republicans take the political heat on taxes for a change.
From the Administration's perspective, the most attractive feature of the new proposal is that the taxpayers affected would be mostly the well-heeled. Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the top Republican on the Finance Committee, said that 97.4 percent of those affected would have annual incomes of more than $100,000 and that 86 percent would have incomes above $200,000.
 
States and Localities Benefit
That allows the Administration to oppose the Democrats' favorite tax change, which is to raise the top rate paid by the highest-income taxpayers to 33 percent from 28 percent, and still rebut Democratic arguments that the Administration supports only those taxes that spare the rich. Many high-income taxpayers below the level of the wealthiest are now paying a marginal rate - that is, the rate paid on the last dollars earned - of 33 percent, although no taxpayers pay a rate of 33 percent on their entire income.
Politicians in states like New York say they are able to keep their taxes high in part because residents can deduct the cost from their Federal taxes. In effect, the Federal Government reimburses taxpayers for a portion of their state and local taxes.
Mayor David N. Dinkins was one of several politicians from New York State and City who came to Washington to work against the plan even before it became public. Mr. Dinkins said at a news conference that he had balanced the city's budget by raising local taxes and added, ''one of the reasons we did so is because of the deductibility of those taxes.''
Some executives fear that if individual income taxes are not deductible, states will shift the tax burden to businesses, a step they say would stifle economic growth.
In the past, Mr. Darman has vigorously advocated eliminating the deductibility of local property taxes. He has argued that it is not fair for residents of one community with high taxes to deduct the money that goes for fancy schools and parks, while residents of another community with lower taxes and services cannot deduct what they pay for private schools or clubs.
But the issue has not come up this year, apparently for two reasons. First, much property tax money is used for schools, and President Bush does not want to be seen as working against better education. Second, one of the states hardest hit by the abolition of the property tax deduction would be New Hampshire, which has no sales or income tax. John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, is the former Governor of New Hampshire.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard G. Darman, the budget director, has been working on a plan that would tax upper income brackets more heavily. (Associated Press) (pg. 22)

HEADLINE: Transit Agency's Plan: Tokens Outside Subway

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Tired of waiting in long lines in the subway to buy tokens?
Rather wait at your bank? Your check-cashing outlet? Or your museum?
Transit officials are experimenting with ways to trim the long lines in subway stations, but they say they are having little success because most riders are not aware how many off-site places to buy tokens there are.
They plan to conduct a publicity campaign to tell the public about the experiment. 
Transit officials are also negotiating with fast-food restaurants like McDonald's and consumer-products companies to give discounts and free products to riders who buy tokens in bulk. Under one such plan, buyers of packages of 10 tokens would use the plastic wrapper as a coupon to obtain a discount or a free product, like fries at McDonald's.
 
Where to Buy Tokens
There are 410 businesses and public agencies in New York City that sell tokens for the Transit Authority. These include 80 Manufacturers Hanover branches, 40 Chemical Bank offices, 9 Bank of New York branches, the Whitney Museum, the Museum of Modern Art, and some Thriftway and Rite Check Cashing outlets.
In addition, about 230 employers in New York City buy tokens directly from the transit agency and make them available to their employees. These employers include messenger services; credit unions; brokerage houses like Shearson Lehman Hutton, Goldman, Sachs & Company and Bear, Stearns & Company; large companies like Colgate-Palmolive, and large accounting firms like Arthur Young.
''Selling tokens allows banks and check-cashing centers to provide their customers with another value-added service,'' said Michael Alvich, the Transit Authority's director of corporate services, who is recruiting businesses to participate in the program. ''For retailers, it gets more people in the store browsing and looking at their merchandise.''
''On the corporate side, many businesses do it as an employee benefit, and it also cuts down on people being late because they missed the train while waiting to buy tokens,'' he said.
 
Token-Vending Machines
About 42 million tokens, or 4 percent of all tokens, are sold through businesses and public agencies each year.
The Transit Authority also plans to increase the number of token-vending machines in subway stations. There are now three such machines in the Parsons Boulevard station in Queens, four in Grand Central Terminal, two at Lexington Avenue and 86th Street, two at 72d and Broadway, and three in Penn Station. The agency plans to place groups of five or six machines at stations in the future.
The token-vending machines accept $10 bills and dispense eight tokens and change or $5 bills and dispense four tokens and change.
Mr. Alvich said the response to the new vending machines was outstanding, with some machines running out of tokens and change faster than the agency could fill them.
 
'D Minus' for the Agency's Effort
Still, some transit-agency critics say the Transit Authority has not done enough to reduce the wait to buy tokens. ''I'd give their efforts to relieve token booth lines a D minus,'' said Gene Russianoff, a spokesman for the Straphangers Campaign, an advocacy group for New York subway riders.
''The Transit Authority is behind its stated goals for off-site sales of tokens and there is absolutely no advertising or information to let people know that they can buy tokens at other places aside from token booths,'' he said.
Mr. Alvich said the number of businesses selling subway tokens was much lower than expected because of the low commission that the Transit Authority offered. Currently, the agency offers a 1 percent commission to businesses that buy 100,000 to 399,000 tokens, a 1.5 percent commission for 400,000 to 799,000 tokens and a 2 percent commission for 800,000 or more tokens.
Mr. Alvich expects the number of sellers to grow quickly under a plan by the agency to offer a higher commission to independent token sellers.
 
Tokens on the Newsstands
''Our objective is to come up with a program that both lowers the number of tokens that needs to be purchased to qualify for a commission and raises the commission, while making it economically feasible for the agency,'' he said.
Although the Transit Authority has no agreements with newsstands, bodegas and candy stores to sell tokens, Mr. Alvich said many of these businesses sold tokens on their own accord and accepted tokens for payment.
Lines at token booths have grown longer since the Transit Authority raised the subway and bus fare to $1.15 from $1 on Jan. 1, increasing the number of coins that token booth clerks must handle. Waits of 10 minutes at rush hour are not uncommon at some subway-station token booths.
Over all, subway and bus riders can reduce the amount of time they wait at token booths by buying tokens in bulk at their home stations instead of purchasing a few tokens at a time at busy stations, transit officials said.
To obtain information on off-site places to buy tokens, riders can call the Transit Authority travel information bureau at 718-330-1234, which is open 24 hours a day, seven days a week, or the transit consumer-service department at 718-330-3322, which is open Monday through Friday, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Making subway tokens available in vending machines like those at Penn Station, above, is one of the steps the New York City Transit Authority is taking to shorten lines at token booths. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Testimony Begins in Lawsuit Over Effort to Aid Contras

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MIAMI, July 28

 BODY:
Testimony has begun in the Federal trial of a civil suit pitting Eugene Hasenfus, the only survivor of a plane crash that helped to expose the Iran-contra affair, against Richard V. Secord, a leading figure in the scandal.
Mr. Hasenfus, a cargo handler, filed the Federal lawsuit in 1988 along with the family of the plane's co-pilot, Wallace B. Sawyer Jr., who was among three people killed in the Sandinista rocket attack on the rebel supply plane in Nicaragua. They seek a preliminary estimate of $3.4 million in damages, including expenses caused by the crash and lost income.
The downing of the C-123 cargo plane on Oct. 5, 1986, led to the discovery of an extensive United States contra supply operation that was based in El Salvador and financed by the profits from the American sale of arms to Iran. 
After the crash, President Ronald Reagan denied that there was any Government connection to the flight. But Mr. Hasenfus, and documents in the wreckage of the plane, linked the crew to Government involvement.
The suit by Mr. Hasenfus and Mr. Sawyer's family is not only against Mr. Secord, a retired Air Force general, but also against Southern Air Transport, a Miami-based company that was owned by the Central Intelligence Agency until 1973. It alleges that they misled the crew and negligently used aircraft without adequate safety equipment.
Mr. Secord and Southern Air deny they were legally responsible for Mr. Hasenfus and Mr. Sawyer. They also contend that the two men knew the risks they were taking in ferrying supplies to rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government.
Mr. Hasenfus managed to parachute out of the plane after it was hit. He was captured, convicted of terrorism and sentenced to 30 years in prison. The Sandinista Government released him after he served three months, and he is now a construction worker in Marinette, Wis.
 
Contract for Services
Mr. Hasenfus, 49 years old, testified Thursday that he worked for the C.I.A.-owned airline Air America in the Vietnam War. When hostilities in Central America heated up in July 1986, he said, he was contacted by William B. Cooper, with whom he used to work in Southeast Asia, and was offered a job similar to the work they had done there. Mr. Cooper was flying the plane that was shot down in Nicaragua.
After talking to Mr. Cooper, Mr. Hasenfus said, he was taken to the Southern Air headquarters at Miami International Airport, where he signed a contract with Corporate Air Services. He said, however, he understood that Corporate Air was a front for Southern Air, which was paying his expenses.
Mr. Hasenfus said the crews complained that there was no safety equipment like parachutes or survival gear in the plane, and that the navigation radios did not work properly. But he said he accepted the defects, thinking that the supply operation was a patriotic, shoestring effort to fight communists in Central America.
Only when the Iran-contra affair became public, he said, did he become aware that Oliver L. North, Mr. Secord and Southern Air were running the supply effort as a profit-making enterprise.
 
Effort to Conceal Operation
Richard Gadd, who helped Mr. North, Mr. Secord and Southern Air set up the supply operation, said in written testimony on Friday that the use of Corporate Air and other companies was designed to hide who was behind the supply effort.
Southern Air continued to do contract work for the United States Government even after he was no longer owned by the C.I.A., Mr. Gadd said.
Mr. Gadd and the president of Southern Air, William Langton, decided that the effort ''should be treated as a clandestine or covert activity (so the) media could not attempt to trace it back to the owners and the United States Government,'' the deposition said.
Mr. Gadd said Mr. Secord directed the money and made policy decisions in the enterprise, a major point for Mr. Hasenfus, who is trying to prove that Mr. Secord, an officer in Corporate Air, was his real employer.
 
Name on Tax Returns
On cross-examination, the lawyer for Southern Air, Robert Beckman, focused on the role of Corporate Air, forcing Mr. Hasenfus to show that his pay drafts, tax returns and unemployment compensation claim all reflected that company's name, not Southern Air.
Mr. Beckman also sought to show that Mr. Hasenfus had violated a secrecy agreement he signed with Corporate Air. Mr. Hasenfus said the case ''was already blown by Congress'' when he later sold the rights to his story for $10,000 to CBS. The account has never been made public, he said.
Mr. Secord's lawyers have said their client never had any legal relationship with Mr. Hasenfus and Mr. Sawyer, and indeed had never met them.
Mr. Secord pleaded guilty on Nov. 8, 1989, to lying to Congressional investigators when he said he was not aware of any money that went to Mr. North's benefit from the maze of companies he used in the Iran-contra affair. He was sentenced to two years' probation.

HEADLINE: Omaha Grand Jury Sees Hoax in Lurid Tales

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ROBBINS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 28

 BODY:
Lurid reports of child sex abuse, drug trafficking, pornography and political intrigue that have held Omaha enthralled for nearly two years were a ''carefully crafted hoax,'' a county grand jury in Nebraska has concluded. But two other inquiries are continuing, and the Nebraska State Senator who heads one of them has raised questions about the grand jury's conclusions.
The report this week said the hoax, involving allegations against some of Omaha's more prominent citizens, was ''scripted by a person or persons with considerable knowledge of the people and institutions of Omaha.'' 
The grand jury did not identify those suspected of engineering the hoax. But it did indict two witnesses who it said had given perjured accounts in the tangled case, involving a failed credit union formed to help the poor that was headed by a nationally prominent Republican.
 
'A Strange Document'
State and Federal inquiries into some of the same matters are continuing, and the Nebraska Senator who heads the state's investigation, Loran Schmit, labeled the grand jury's report ''a strange document.''
''That is the kindest thing I can say about it,'' he said.
An Assistant United States Attorney, Thomas Talken, who heads the Federal inquiry, said it would continue to examine some of the same matters studied by the county panel.
The rumors about child sex abuse, drug trafficking and other offenses began to circulate in late 1988 shortly after the failure of the Franklin Community Federal Credit Union, which was headed by Lawrence E. King Jr., a former vice chairman of the National Black Republican Council, an affiliate of the Republican Party, who has entertained generously at Republican national conventions. He has been indicted on charges of embezzling money from the credit union, which closed in November 1988, but a Federal magistrate has ruled that he is not mentally competent to stand trial at this time.
The rumors gained further attention last year after a former State Senator, John De Camp, wrote a memorandum naming five prominent individuals as ''central figures'' in the state's investigation.
The grand jury exonerated the five, saying, ''We found no credible evidence of child sexual abuse, interstate transportaion of minors, drug trafficking or participation in a pornography ring.''
The grand jury quoted Shakespeare's King Henry IV: ''Rumor is a pipe, blown by surmises, jealousies, conjectures and of so easy and so plain a stop that the blunt monster with uncounted heads, the still discordant wavering multitudes, can play upon it.''
 
'Rumor and Innuendo'
Though it made no formal accusation, the grand jury said it suspected that a state investigator looking into the sexual allegations had been duped by a executive who had been dismissed by Boys Town, the home for troubled young people in Omaha. It said the unemployed executive, identified as Michael Casey, might have ''fueled the fire of rumor and innuendo'' because of personal grudges.
Among the rumors swirling around the affair was one that Mr. King had abused young people from Boys Town. At least some of the five prominent people named by Mr. De Camp had either supported the cause of Mr. King's credit union or attended some of the lavish parties he frequently gave.
The two witnesses who were charged with perjury were a young man and a young woman who had said they were victims of abuse when they were teen-agers. They were indicted after two other witnesses, who had supported their accounts, recanted. The two who were indicted are now serving jail terms for unrelated offenses. They were identified as Alisha Owen, 21 years old, and Paul A. Bonacci, 22.

HEADLINE: Revisions Sought in U.S. Food-Aid Program

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 28

 BODY:
Each year the United States sends so much grain to Egypt that the farmers feed loaves of bread to their cows.
In Indonesia, officials appealed to the United States Ambassador to stop the shipment of 70,000 tons of American grain that would have put their farmers out of business.
And every year, tons of food rots on foreign docks because aid shipments are sent without regard to local harvesting and milling schedules.
Frustrated over waste and mismanagement in the $1.5 billion Food for Peace program, lawmakers, commodity and private aid groups are trying to push through Congress the most sweeping changes in 25 years in the humanitarian food program. 
The versions of the bill that have been approved by the House Foreign Affairs Committee and the Senate Agriculture Committee would reorganize the bureaucracy that distributes the food and would allocate more money to grants, rather than loans.
American aid officials say what began as a well-intentioned foreign-aid effort to distribute surplus grain has been stymied by mismanagement and political interests. Bureaucratic infighting and agency turf battles paralyze food delivery, they say. And because food is used as a foreign-policy weapon, they say, it is channeled away from the neediest countries to the politically important ones.
''The present Food for Peace program has so many bureaucratic and political players that it usually serves the political ends before it works to end hunger,'' said Representative Tony P. Hall, Democrat of Ohio, who heads the House Select Committee on Hunger.
''What we are trying to do is to streamline the decision-making process and basically, if possible, take as much politics out of it as we can,'' Mr. Hall said. He is working with Senators on a bipartisan bill that would reorganize the bureaucracy of five agencies that administer the program.
''It's used as a slush fund of the State Department to meet political requirements around the world,'' said Owen Cylke, former acting director of Food for Peace, who retired last year.
According to Congressional testimony, a third of American food aid goes to countries that do not have food shortages. Morocco, which has one of the highest per capita calorie rates, received $70 million in food aid last year, while Angola, a country where there is severe malnutrition, received less than $3 million.
The United States has provided covert support to rebels fighting the Angolan Government.
Mr. Cylke said the program lends the world's poorest nations the money to buy American grain and processed foods, which worsens their debt crisis. Meanwhile, countries that are relatively well off receive gifts of food.
Those leading the revision efforts say most of the problems stem from wrangling among the five agencies involved: the Agency for International Development, the Office of Management and Budget and the Departments of State, Agriculture and Treasury.
 
Expertise Seen as Lacking
Each agency must agree to every aid package, said a staff member on the House Select Committee on Hunger. And except for A.I.D., not one of the agencies has the expertise or manpower in the field, he said.
Under the Senate legislation, co-written by chairman Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont and the ranking Republican member, Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, the Agency for International Development would have sole authority to make food gifts to the least-developed countries. Grants would be allocated according to per capita income, caloric intake and the mortality rate among children under 5 years of age.
The Department of Agriculture would be responsible for the credit-sales program, which provides low-interest loans to countries that are poor but not facing starvation.
The President would also have a $100 million discretionary fund to assist newly emerging democracies.
The bill was approved by a unanimous vote in the House Foreign Affairs Committee on July 11. It moves next to the the House floor as part of the 1990 Farm Bill. Debate by the House and the Senate is expected in late summer.

HEADLINE: Kenyan Human-Rights Lawyer Urges Economic Sanctions by U.S.

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
A prominent Kenyan human rights lawyer has called on the United States to press for democratic changes in Kenya by imposing economic sanctions similar to those in effect against South Africa.
The lawyer, Gibson Kamau Kuria, who took refuge in the United States Embassy in Nairobi during a political crackdown three weeks ago, has come to this country to pursue his quest for multiparty democracy in Kenya.
Mr. Kuria said the United States should use its foreign policy to encourage the emergence of democracy in Kenya and other African countries.
''From my understanding of the situation in Kenya and much of Africa, the dictators are not going to respond to reason,'' he said. ''Therefore the United States and other Western governments should impose the kind of economic sanctions which forced South Africa to take the first steps toward democracy.'' 
Mr. Kuria specifically urged Washington to suspend next year's $53 million aid program to Kenya ''until fundamental democratic changes are introduced.'' Congress recently suspended about $13 million of this year's $45 million allocation to Kenya.
He also called on American tourists to postpone visits to Kenya, saying their presence and money ''props up the oppressive regime.'' Tourism is Kenya's leading source of foreign exchange.
A recipient of the 1988 Robert F. Kennedy Human Rights Award, Mr. Kuria criticized Western nations for their apparent reluctance to intervene on human rights questions in Africa out of ''some kind of colonial guilt complex.''
He was even critical of Nelson Mandela, who in a recent visit with President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya said the West had no moral standing to press African countries to make democratic reforms. ''By playing to the white guilt complex, Mandela appeared to support dictators in general and Moi in particular,'' the lawyer said.
Mr. Kuria was interviewed on Thursday in the mid-Manhattan office of Africa Watch, a private human-rights monitoring organization that has reported serious rights violations in Kenya. He was accompanied by his law partner, Kiraitu Murungi, who also went into exile during the crackdown.
 
Plans to Study and Teach
Until government changes in Kenya enable him to return, Mr. Kuria plans to spend six months teaching and studying at Harvard and six months at Yale. ''I want to identify the reasons why Kenya's 1963 democratic Constitution permitted the emergence of a dictatorship and how human rights can be protected in a reformed constitution,'' he said.
Mr. Kuria, who has angered the Kenyan authorities by his attacks on the one-party system in The Nairobi Law Monthly, said the failure of one-party rule in Eastern Europe has accelerated the movement for political pluralism in Africa. Algeria, Somalia, Ethiopia, Benin, Gabon, Zaire, Angola and Tanzania have accepted the principle of pluralism, he said.
He said African nationalists in the 1960's had been fascinated with the Eastern European political model and had imported it, calling it African socialism. ''Proponents of the system have made great economic gains and will not give up their vested interests easily,'' he added.
He rejected the arguments of many African leaders that multiparty systems would fuel tribalism. Kenya has more than 40 tribes, he said, and any leader aspiring to power ''must appeal to interests beyond the tribe.''
He urged the Nairobi Government to free all political detainees, including the two former Cabinet ministers, Kenneth Matiba and Charles Rubia, who have led the campaign for multiparty democracy.
Mr. Kuria, a stocky 43-year-old, said he went into hiding after the arrest of the two ministers, who had been his clients. On July 7, when he learned that officers of the Special Branch security police were waiting for him at his office, at his home and at the courthouse, he decided to seek protection in the United States Embassy.
 
U.S. 'Most Understanding'
American officials, who have had their own problems with President Moi's Government recently, were ''most understanding,'' Mr. Kuria said. He said negotiations for his departure were rapid because both sides felt that a prolonged stay would ''heighten the strain in relations'' between the two countries. He arrived in this country with a United States travel document, good for one year, with humanitarian parole status.
Mr. Kuria has been active in human rights since 1982, when his law firm began defending dissidents. In that year, the Constitution was amended to make Kenya a one-party state and since then, he said, there has been a progressive erosion of the rule of law.
In 1987, he was detained for 10 months after he sued the Government on behalf of three political prisoners who he said had been tortured and illegally detained. He was released only after an international campaign on his behalf, but could not come to the United States to accept the Kennedy award because his passport had been confiscated.
In his latest feud with the authorities, Mr. Kuria contends that the Government rigged elections in the influential Law Society of Kenya.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gibson Kamau Kuria, a Kenyan human rights lawyer, wants the United States to impose economic sanctions to force Kenya to take steps toward democracy. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

LENGTH: 912 words

HEADLINE: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;
Across New York Bay, A Place With No Future

 BODY:
Standing in his workshop amid leather hides and metal hand tools, a man in a white linen shirt, worn blue work pants and hand-made shoes explains how he earns his daily bread: ''There are mostly farmers on Staten Island, not like the rich folks in Manhattan, so I make mostly farm shoes.'' He says he has never heard of refinements like left shoes and right shoes.
Of course he has, but scenes like that are frequent at Richmondtown Restoration, where 18th- and 19th-century life on Staten Island is recreated. It is a historic village with 30 buildings, some on their original sites, some transported to the village, and all are meant to preserve and display three centuries of Staten Island history. 
At Richmondtown Restoration, visitors wander through the village exploring the buildings (half are being restored and not yet open to the public) and are greeted by people in period costume describing how they live and work.
 
Petticoats to Queen Anne's Cake
A woman in petticoats shows the quilt and needlepoint she is working on. A tinsmith creates pitchers, plates, lamps, pails and other common 18th-century household items. A young man demonstrates the process of carding to spinning to reeling yarn, while another uses the heat of a fireplace and a reflective oven to make Queen Anne's cake.
The restoration is run jointly by the Staten Island Historical Society and New York City, and the society began the project in 1939. What became Richmondtown itself was established by the Dutch as Cocclestown, a farmers' center, in the 1690's. By the 1730's it was Staten Island's main village and political center, and the seat of the Richmond government until 1898. The Third County Courthouse, built in the Greek Revival style, houses the visitors' center. The oldest building on the site is Voorlezer's House, dated 1695, a Reformed Dutch Church elementary school, church and minister's home.
The County Clerk's and Surrogate's office now houses a historical museum offering exhibitions of Staten Island economic and social life from the first settlers till today. Special activities abound, like the 19th-century feast today for those who have reserved a place.
 
Meeting Farm Animals
On Wednesday afternoons in July and August, children 5 to 12 years of age can take part in the ''Little Folks Program'' with their parents. They'll learn how to make toys, churn butter and shuck corn, and meet farm animals from the Staten Island Zoo. The admission fee is $4 per child per session, or $14 for a four-part series. The adults are admitted free.
A Trades and Talents series, Saturdays and Sundays Aug. 4-19, presents candlemaking, shoemaking and dressmaking. Admission to the demonstrations is included in the entrance fee.
Visitors will find sandwiches and soft drinks sold on the restoration grounds, or they can use picnic tables near the visitors' parking area. A museum store sells quilts and tinware made by the Richmondtown craftspeople.
The restoration is open Monday through Friday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and on Saturday and Sunday from 1 to 5 P.M. Admission is $4 for adults, $2.50 for students and those in their 60's, children and young people 6 to 18 years of age. Children under 6 are admitted free. There are memberships available which provide free admission. For information and reservations call (718) 351-9414.
 
Getting There
For bus riders: After taking the Staten Island Ferry from lower Manhattan, take the S74 to Richmond Road and Court Place in the middle of the Restoration area. Up the hill is the Courthouse Visitors Center.
For motorists: Turn left out of the ferry terminal into Bay Street. Follow Bay Street about two miles, and make a right turn into Vanderbilt Avenue. At the fourth traffic light, bear left onto Richmond Road. After about five miles, turn left into St. Patrick's Place and follow the signs to the Richmond Restoration.
From the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge: Follow the New Jersey West Route to the Richmond Road/Clove Road Exit. Exit, proceed to the second light and turn left on St. Patrick Place. Follow the signs to the Richmond Restoration.
From the Bayonne Bridge: Exit at Goethals Bridge sign. Keep right and take the first exit, Richmond Avenue, and stay on it to Arthur Kill Road, where you turn left. At the fourth traffic light, turn right into Clarke Avenue and follow the signs to the Richmond Restoration.
From the Goethals Bridge: Take the Staten Island Expressway to Richmond Avenue, exit and turn left at stop sign, then right at light onto Richmond Avenue. Stay on it to Arthur Kill Road and at the fourth traffic light, turn right into Clarke Avenue and from there follow the signs to the Richmond Restoration.
From the Outerbridge Crossing: Take Richmond Parkway to the Richmond Ave. North exit. Turn right at the first light onto Arthur Kill Road, proceed to the fifth traffic light and turn right onto Clarke Ave. Follow signs to the Richmond Restoration.
 
AND SOMETHING EVER NEW
The 11th annual Richmond County Fair will be held at the restoration Sept. 1 and 2 from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M. The fair (which is not in the 19th-century tradition) draws than 20,000 people a year.
Special activities will include a judging of flowers and vegetables and a contest for baked goods, all brought by fairgoers. Entertainment will include a freckle contest, a dog race and a turtle race.
Admission is $5 for adults, $3 for those in their mid-60's and older, and $2 for children.
