HEADLINE: Campus Life: Michigan;
Opening in Poland: Observation Post For Researchers

DATELINE: ANN ARBOR, Mich.

 BODY:
While the recent upheavals in Eastern Europe have been watched with close attention here, most American academics are studying the transformations only from a distance. To help make first-hand observation easier, the Institute for Social Research at the University of Michigan is opening a branch office in Warsaw, in conjunction with the Polish Government and the University of Warsaw.
The project is the first such cooperative venture in the social and behavioral sciences between an American university and an Eastern European country, university officials said. 
 
Eastern European Base
''There have been collaborative ventures before, but this is unique in that it is the true joining of two institutions,'' said William Zimmerman, professor of political science at the University of Michigan and director of the institute's Internal Peace and Security Program.
The venture, to be called the Center for Social Research, will be housed on the University of Warsaw campus in a building donated by the Polish Ministry of National Education. The director of the Institute for Social Research, Robert B. Zajonc, said the center would be a base for studying social, political and economic change throughout Eastern Europe.
Other universities in Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia are expected to participate, Mr. Zimmerman said, adding that he was negotiating with the Institute of Sociological Research of the Academy of Sciences in Moscow regarding the possibility of the Soviet Union's joining in.
Samuel Barnes, a professor of political science at the University of Michigan, said that while in Budapest recently talking with Hungarian professors interested in the project, he also spoke with academics from Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and Poland about their desire to work with the center. Some Romanian scholars have also expressed interest in participating, he said.
Mr. Zimmerman said he expected about 15 scholars to initially work at the center, most of them Polish. Eventually, he said, an equal number of Polish and American social scientists could pursue research there.
Officials at the institute in Ann Arbor said they expected the Warsaw branch to open by October.
Mr. Zajonc, who left Poland in 1940, said he first discussed the idea of a social science center in March with a longtime friend, Janusz Grzelak, Poland's Deputy Minister of Education.
''Several factors came together to make this happen so quickly,'' Mr. Zajonc said. ''One, I was born in Poland. Two, I am director of I.S.R. and, three, I wanted to immediately exploit this unique opportunity to observe Poland as it actually changes.''
Several University of Michigan researchers already have projects in Poland, which will be continued under the new center's auspices. Among these are an analysis of intergenerational value shifts conducted by Prof. Ronald F. Inglehart, and a study of varying concepts of justice by a sociology professor, Duane F. Alwin.
Mr. Zimmerman said the development of entrepreneurial activity in Poland was a topic of particular interest, as well as the country's weak past environmental policies and pollution problems, and the Poles' response to new governmental institutions.
He added, ''Having our own office in Poland will expedite grant proposals and data analysis.'' Besides, he said, ''it is hard to conduct academic studies by fax machine.''

HEADLINE: POP VIEW;
When Black Feminism Faces The Music, and the Music Is Rap

BYLINE: By MICHELE WALLACE; Michele Wallace is the author of ''Black Macho and the Myth of the Superwoman'' (Verso). Her book ''Invisibility Blues: From Pop to Theory'' will be published this year.

 BODY:
Like many black feminists, I look on sexism in rap as a necessary evil. In a society plagued by poverty and illiteracy, where young black men are as likely to be in prison as in college, rap is a welcome articulation of the economic and social frustrations of black youth.
In response to disappointments faced by poor urban blacks negotiating their future, rap offers the release of creative expression and historical continuity: it draws on precedents as diverse as jazz, reggae, calypso, Afro-Cuban, African and heavy-metal, and its lyrics include rudimentary forms of political, economic and social analysis.
But with the failure of our urban public schools, rappers have taken education into their own hands; these are oral lessons (reading and writing being low priorities). And it should come as no surprise that the end result emphasizes innovations in style and rhythm over ethics and morality. Although there are exceptions, like raps advocating world peace (the W.I.S.E. Guyz's ''Time for Peace'') and opposing drug use (Ice-T's ''I'm Your Pusher''), rap lyrics can be brutal, raw and, where women are the subject, glaringly sexist. 
Given the genre's current crossover popularity and success in the marketplace, including television commercials, rap's impact on young people is growing. A large part of the appeal of pop culture is that it can offer symbolic resolutions to life's contradictions. But when it comes to gender, rap has not resolved a thing.
Though styles vary - from that of the X-rated Ice-T to the sybaritic Kwanee to the hyperpolitics of Public Enemy - what seems universal is how little male rappers respect sexual intimacy and how little regard they have for the humanity of the black woman. Witness the striking contrast within rap videos: for men, standard attire is baggy outsize pants; for women, spike heels and short skirts. Videos often feature the ostentatious and fetishistic display of women's bodies. In Kool Moe Dee's ''How Ya Like Me Now,'' women gyrate in tight leather with large revealing holes. In Digital Underground's video ''Doowutchyalike,'' set poolside at what looks like a fraternity house party, a rapper in a clown costume pretends to bite the backside of a woman in a bikini.
As Trisha Rose, a black feminist studying rap, puts it, ''Rap is basically a locker room with a beat.''
The recent banning of the sale of 2 Live Crew's album ''As Nasty as They Wanna Be'' by local governments in Florida and elsewhere has publicized rap's treatment of women as sex objects, but it also made a hit of a record that contains some of the bawdiest lyrics in rap. Though such sexual explicitness in lyrics is rare, the assumptions about women - that they manipulate men with their bodies - are typical.
In an era when the idea that women want to be raped should be obsolete, rap lyrics and videos presuppose that women always desire sex, whether they know it or not. In Bell Biv DeVoe's rap-influenced pop hit single ''Poison,'' for instance, a beautiful girl is considered poison because she does not respond affirmatively and automatically to a sexual proposition.
Bell Hooks, author of ''Yearning: Race, Gender, Cultural Politics'' (Southend, 1990), sees the roots of rap as a youth rebellion against all attempts to control black masculinity, both in the streets and in the home. ''That rap would be anti-domesticity and in the process anti-female should come as no surprise,'' Ms. Hooks says.
At present there is only a small platform for black women to address the problems of sexism in rap and in their community. Feminist criticism, like many other forms of social analysis, is widely considered part of a hostile white culture. For a black feminist to chastise misogyny in rap publicly would be viewed as divisive and counterproductive. There is a widespread perception in the black community that public criticism of black men constitutes collaborating with a racist society.
The charge is hardly new. Such a reaction greeted Ntozake Shange's play ''For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide When the Rainbow Is Enuf,'' my own essays, ''Black Macho and the Myth of the Superwoman,'' and Alice Walker's novel ''The Color Purple,'' all of which were perceived as critical of black men. After the release of the film version of ''The Color Purple,'' feminists were lambasted in the press for their supposed lack of support for black men; such critical analysis by black women has all but disappeared. In its place is ''A Black Man's Guide to the Black Woman,'' a vanity-press book by Shahrazad Ali, which has sold more than 80,000 copies by insisting that black women are neurotic, insecure and competitive with black men.
Though misogynist lyrics seem to represent the opposite of Ms. Ali's world view, these are, in fact, just two extremes on the same theme: Ms. Ali's prescription for what ails the black community is that women should not question men about their sexual philandering, and should be firmly slapped across the mouth when they do. Rap lyrics suggest just about the same: women should be silent and prone.
There are those who have wrongly advocated censorship of rap's more sexually explicit lyrics, and those who have excused the misogyny because of its basis in black oral traditions.
Rap is rooted not only in the blaxploitation films of the 60's but also in an equally sexist tradition of black comedy. In the use of four-letter words and explicit sexual references, both Richard Pryor and Eddie Murphy, who themselves drew upon the earlier examples of Redd Foxx, Pigmeat Markham and Moms Mabley, are conscious reference points for the 2 Live Crew. Black comedy, in turn, draws on an oral tradition in which black men trade ''toasts,'' stories in which dangerous bagmen and trickster figures like Stackolee and Dolomite sexually exploit women and promote violence among men. The popular rapper Ice Cube, in the album ''Amerikkka's Most Wanted,'' is Stackolee come to life. In ''The Nigga Ya Love to Hate,'' he projects an image of himself as a criminal as dangerous to women as to the straight white world.
Rap remains almost completely dominated by black males and this mind-set. Although women have been involved in rap since at least the mid-80's, record companies have only recently begun to promote them. And aswomen rapperslike Salt-n-Pepa, Monie Love, M. C. Lyte, L. A. Star and Queen Latifah slowly gain more visibility, rap's sexism may emerge as a subject for scrutiny. Indeed, the answer may lie with women, expressing in lyrics and videos the tensions between the sexes in the black community.
Today's women rappers range from a high ground that doesn't challenge male rap on its own level (Queen Latifah) to those who subscribe to the same sexual high jinks as male rappers (Oaktown's 3.5.7). M. C. Hammer launched Oaktown's 3.5.7., made up of his former backup dancers. These female rappers manifest the worst-case scenario: their skimpy, skintight leopard costumes in the video of ''Wild and Loose (We Like It)'' suggest an exotic animalistic sexuality. Their clothes fall to their ankles. They take bubble baths. Clearly, their bodies are more important than rapping. And in a field in which writing one's own rap is crucial, their lyrics are written by their former boss, M. C. Hammer.
Most women rappers constitute the middle ground: they talk of romance, narcissism and parties. On the other hand, Salt-n-Pepa on ''Shake Your Thang'' uses the structure of the 1969 Isley Brothers song ''It's Your Thing'' to insert a protofeminist rap response: ''Don't try to tell me how to party. It's my dance and it's my body.'' M. C. Lyte, in a dialogue with Positive K on ''I'm Not Havin' It,'' comes down hard on the notion that women can't say no and criticizes the shallowness of the male rap.
Queen Latifah introduces her video, ''Ladies First,'' performed with the English rapper Monie Love, with photographs of black political heroines like Winnie Mandela, Sojourner Truth, Harriet Tubman and Angela Davis. With a sound that resembles scat as much as rap, Queen Latifah chants ''Stereotypes they got to go'' against a backdrop of newsreel footage of the apartheid struggle in South Africa. The politically sophisticated Queen Latifah seems worlds apart from the adolescent, buffoonish sex orientation of most rap. In general, women rappers seem so much more grown up. Can they inspire a more beneficent attitude toward sex in rap? What won't subvert rap's sexism is the actions of men; what will is women speaking in their own voice, not just in artificial female ghettos, but with and to men.

HEADLINE: FILM;
Spike Lee and the 'Slavery' of the Blues

BYLINE: By SAMUEL G. FREEDMAN; Samuel G. Freedman, the author of ''Small Victories: The Real World of a Teacher, Her Students, and Their High School'' (Harper & Row), is writing a book about a black church in Brooklyn.

 BODY:
In one of the earliest sequences of ''Mo' Better Blues,'' Spike Lee's new film about jazz, the camera lingers almost lecherously over the womanly curves of a trumpet and saxophone. As simple as the shot seems at that moment, over the course of the movie it becomes a powerful and shifting metaphor, as Mr. Lee's concerns travel from romance to creativity to commerce and from satire to genuine tragedy.
At its most apparent level, ''Mo' Better Blues,'' opening Friday, is the story of a jazz musician so committed to his art that he drives away not one but two lovers. And from a haircut modeled on John Coltrane's to a style indebted to Miles Davis's, Bleek Gilliam (Denzel Washington) makes no secret of where his desire and devotion reside. ''I know what I want - my music,'' he puts it bluntly. ''Everything else is secondary.'' In its very creation as well as its plot, ''Mo' Better Blues'' amounts to a celebration of black talent by a director who has fostered and nurtured a great deal of it himself. But given Mr. Lee's characteristic astringence and social conscience, this is a celebration with a decidedly cautious subtext. Bleek seeks not simply musical expression but control over that expression and the livelihood it brings. His battles with bandmates, an ineffectual black manager and especially two cunning white club owners serve as a reminder that for much of America's history, its most brilliant black musicians have themselves been played like instruments by a predominantly white recording industry. 
''Musicians are low-priced slaves, whereas athletes and entertainers are high-priced slaves,'' Mr. Lee said in a recent interview in Brooklyn, his home and the setting for most of his films. ''It's their music, but it's not their nightclub, it's not their record company. They have an understanding only of the music, not of the business, so they get treated any old way. A lot of money can be made off black artists, and a lot of what racism is about is financial gain.''
Some black artists, like Count Basie, signed away publishing rights to compositions that ultimately earned millions of dollars in royalties. Some, like Bo Diddley and Big Joe Turner, found their signature sounds copied, slightly diluted, and finally repackaged as lucrative ''product'' for the rock-and-roll market. Mr. Lee saw the struggle embodied by his own father, Bill Lee, a bassist and composer in jazz, folk and classical settings.
''Even a musical genius like Bird would have to go out on tour without a band,'' Bill Lee wrote of Charlie Parker in an essay included with the published screenplay and production notes for ''Mo' Better Blues.'' ''Headliners had to pick up musicians in every city where they were booked. This cut down costs for their management and club owners. Ultimately it was a form of exploitation and disrespect. You couldn't perform at your best if you didn't know the cats you were playing with.''
Nor was Bill Lee himself immune from the fiscal gravity of jazz. An acoustic bass purist, he virtually lost his profession in the 1970's when the electric Fender became the instrument of choice in jazz ensembles, less for any musical reason than because its thumping tone suited the commercial sounds of jazz-rock fusion. It fell to his wife, Jacquelyn Shelton Lee, to take a teaching job to support their five children.
An early draft of ''Mo' Better Blues,'' in fact, contained a scene in which Bleek turns down a high-paying recording session with the singer Sade because he cannot accommodate his jazz classicism with her pop style. One scene that does appear in the finished film has Bleek Gilliam surveying the Japanese and German tourists in a nightclub and complaining: ''I'm sick and tired of playing for everybody but my own people. They don't come out. We don't support our own. If I had to rely on niggers to eat, I'd starve to death. Jazz is our music, but we don't support it. It's sad but true.''
''Everything I know about jazz, I got from my father,'' Spike Lee said. ''I saw his integrity, how he was not going to play just any kind of music, no matter how much money he could make.'' On the other hand, he went on, ''I couldn't agree with my father when he said, 'Money's not the question; I could have it or not have it.' An artist has to be a businessman today. Money means a lot. It equals power. If my films did not make the money they make, I couldn't make the demands I make. A studio knows I'll have final cut, I won't use John Williams for the soundtrack.''
For that matter, Mr. Lee said he had to resist pressures from CBS Records, which is releasing the soundtrack album of ''Mo' Better Blues,'' to mix a softened and sweetened version of the song ''Harlem Blues'' for mainstream radio airplay. The stakes have often been much larger. He publicly accused Columbia Pictures of promoting ''School Daze,'' his satire of a black college, only feebly, and the film became Columbia's largest-grossing release of 1988. He moved ''Do the Right Thing'' from Paramount to Universal rather than comply with demands that he change its climactic scenes of a racial killing and an ensuing riot. ''They wanted Sal and Mookie,'' he said of the Italian pizzeria owner and black delivery man who were the film's antagonists, ''to hug each other and sing 'We Are the World.' ''
The single-minded Bleek Gilliam, then, recalls Spike Lee and his peers in the jazz world like Wynton and Branford Marsalis as much he does Bill Lee and the earlier generations of jazz musicians. Bleek stands even farther apart from the jazz musicians portrayed in recent films written and directed by whites. Far from being the dependent, pathetic savants of Charlie Parker in Clint Eastwood's ''Bird'' and Dale Turner in Bertrand Tavernier's ''Round Midnight,'' Bleek shows that artistic creation derives from rigor and discipline. His sole flaw, albeit a pivotal one in the film's plot, is his allegiance to the childhood friend, played by Mr. Lee, who is his manager.
''You didn't see the genius of the musicians in 'Bird' and 'Round Midnight,' '' Mr. Lee said. ''Not the way you saw it in 'Amadeus,' much of a jerk as Mozart seemed to be. So I wanted to show a man who could make decisions, who had a family life, who wasn't a drug addict or an alcoholic. And I wanted to show these guys practicing. Wynton Marsalis practices six hours a day. It's not just a natural ability.''
Mr. Lee has brought a similar efficiency and craft to his own genre of film making. Within four years, he has released as many feature films, writing, directing and acting in each. And the first three - ''She's Gotta Have It,'' ''School Daze'' and ''Do the Right Thing'' - have not only won largely positive reviews but have reaped sizable profits. With a budget of $9.9 million, ''Mo' Better Blues'' represents Mr. Lee's most costly effort, but one well within Hollywood's bargain basement.
Besides economy and success, the films share an evolving ensemble on both sides of the camera. Mr. Lee is quick to dispute the idea that personal loyalty figures largely in his selection of cast and crew, even to the point of dropping the term ''tyrant'' and telling a pink-slip anecdote or two. Yet when he talks about the New York Knickerbockers 1970 championship team as the model of selflessness and stability, it is clear what a premium he places on those values.
Three of the supporting players in ''Mo' Better Blues'' - Giancarlo Esposito, Bill Nunn and Joie Lee - have appeared in Mr. Lee's earlier films and even a few of his student projects, first at Morehouse College in Atlanta and then in New York University's graduate program. Mr. Lee's co-producer, Monty Ross, first met him as a fellow freshman at Morehouse 15 years ago. Among the other crew members whom Mr. Lee calls the ''key cogs'' are Ernest Dickerson, the director of photography; Wynn Thomas, the production designer; Robi Reed, the casting director, and John Kilik, the line producer. ''Mo' Better Blues'' also provides a high-profile debut for Cynda Williams, who plays the aspiring jazz vocalist romantically involved with Bleek Gilliam.
''Spike's approach is to treat us like family, not employees,'' Mr. Ross said, ''and each of us is a professional because of this family. You get a chance to really expand on your craft with Spike. Even if you work on a Scorsese movie or a De Palma movie, you'll learn some things, but as a young black you'll work as a third or a fourth. Here, you'll be a first. You'll be in charge. You'll be responsible to Spike as a production head. Here, Ernest Dickerson is a director of photography. Without 40 Acres and a Mule,'' he said, referring to Mr. Lee's production company, he'd be hustling to be a camera operator.''
For actors, Mr. Lee has offered deep and varied roles. Bill Nunn, for instance, has gone in three films from a college jock in ''School Daze'' to the malevolent Radio Raheem in ''Do the Right Thing'' to the gentle bass player Bottom Hammer in ''Mo' Better Blues.'' Over those same three films, Mr. Esposito has successively donned the characters of fraternity nabob, streetcorner radical and affected pianist, with the latter role written specifically for him.
''What's good about working with people you've been with before,'' Mr. Esposito said, ''is that you have a camaraderie instead of a competition. In the real - or maybe it's unreal - world of film, actors are worried about how many lines they have, where they fit into the film. On Spike's films, we're concerned about the film as a whole.''
More than opportunity or even friendship binds Mr. Lee's longtime collaborators. Mr. Esposito recalls that when he first met Mr. Lee in the early 1980's, and the future director was cleaning films at a distributorship, ''You could see he had a vision.'' Joie Lee, tied to Mr. Lee as both actress and sister, used the adjective ''focused.'' That vision has been focused upon the abundant black life that exists between the Cosby show and the crack house, the sort of life that rarely merits headlines, much less feature films.
''The pride comes in retrospect,'' Joie Lee said. ''When you're making the film, you're living in the moment. But when I look back at the body of work, the thing is that Spike's not just making films; he's creating history. Besides breaking down the doors for black film makers and artists, he's shown the world a new perspective on black life. He's given stories and slices of life; he's addressed issues that have been unaddressed or ignored. The people on the street see themselves in these films.''
 
SUCCESS STORY
Last July, a 24-year-old restaurant hostess named Cynda Williams, a picture and resume tucked in her bag, walked into a Manhattan studio for her first feature film audition. Four weeks later, Robi Reed, the casting director of ''Mo' Better Blues,'' and the film maker Spike Lee watched Ms. Williams make her final effort as a candidate.
Welcoming the end of an exhausting month, she left the studio quickly and returned to her apartment. Just as she entered, the phone rang. Mr. Lee, sounding a little exasperated, urged her to come back to the studio. Denzel Washington met her at the door with what he called good news and bad news. The bad news, said Mr. Washington with a laugh, was that her feet were too big; the good news was that Ms. Williams had won the role of Clarke Bentancourt, an aspiring jazz singer from the Midwest.
Ms. Williams was raised on the South Side of Chicago, where, in school and church choirs, she established herself as a singer. Ten years ago, after her family moved to Muncie, Ind., she took an interest in acting. Encouraged by a drama teacher, she began playing roles like Nancy in ''Oliver'' and the title role of ''Evita.''
Next she earned a theater degree at Ball State University in Muncie, and also appeared in nightclubs before her graduation in 1988, when she moved to New York.
Now that her film career has been launched, she says, ''I want to have longevity. I don't want to just disappear.'' - Shawn von Schreiber

LENGTH: 1236 words

HEADLINE: RECORDINGS;
Manchester's Pop Music: Escapism Without Escape

BYLINE: By JON PARELES

 BODY:
Blobby light-show shapes flicker and wobble on a screen. Musicians, scruffy in blue jeans or gaudy in flower-patterned shirts, play their instruments and shamble around the stage. Onstage and off, people flail the air in hippie dances. But amid all the appearances of a festive 1960's revival, the lyrics (if any) are often grim, while the beat is likely to be pumped out by a drum machine.
Those are the contradictory signals coming out of the industrial city of Manchester, England, the center of a late-1980's British pop phenomenon. At a club called the Hacienda, opened in 1982 by Tony Wilson (whose company, Factory Records, brought Manchester's Joy Division and New Order to the world a decade ago), thousands of people turn out for all-night dance parties, known as ''raves,'' often fueled by the drug Ecstasy, an amphetamine variant. Disk jockeys, live bands and half-canned electronic hybrids keep people in motion amid the accouterments of a 1960's happening, from strobe lights to bell-bottom pants. ''Raves'' have spread across Britain and Europe. 
Some Manchester bands - particularly Stone Roses and Happy Mondays, which both released debut albums in the United States in 1989 - have become nationwide hit makers in the United Kingdom (so much so that Britain's hipper-than-thou music papers are starting to declare that the Manchester scene has peaked). The obvious next step is to export the music across the Atlantic.
American listeners can now sample Manchester bands on new recordings: 808 State's ''United State 90'' (Tommy Boy 1033; all three formats), A Guy Called Gerald's ''Automanikk'' (Columbia 46770; all three formats), Adamski's ''Liveandirect'' (MCA 6454; all three formats) and Inspiral Carpets' EP, ''Cool As'' (Mute/Rough Trade DUNG 9; all three formats), and album, ''Life'' (Cow/Mute British import DUNG 8; all three formats; with a planned fall release in the United States). There are also two recent releases by Happy Mondays, ''Hallelujah,'' an EP of four new songs and three remixes (Elektra 60945; CD and cassette only), and a 12-inch single, ''Step On'' (Elektra ED 5469).
When music arises from a small local scene, there's no guarantee that it will travel well, or that it will mean the same things elsewhere. Onstage in New York this month at the Sound Factory, Happy Mondays didn't translate: Shaun Ryder's flat, offhand vocals, Mark Day's watery guitar vamps, the pounding riffs of Paul Ryder on bass and Gaz Whelan (plus a machine) on drums, and the floppy-limbed, glassy-eyed dancing of Bez (a full-fledged band member) seem as alien to an American observer as they seem welcoming and homey to regular Manchester fans. The music is more sullen than celebratory. Manchester's music speaks to local conditions in a rainy, decaying factory city with a large blue-collar population. On ''Life,'' Inspiral Carpets, who revive the organ-driven garage rock of the Seeds, aim for working-class realism: ''He prays each night that his family's all right and he's got work.'' In ''Clap Your Hands'' on Happy Mondays' ''Hallelujah'' EP, Mr. Ryder sings about getting ''a small raise,'' while ''Hallelujah'' itself is a manifesto of lowered expectations: ''just here to raise your feet from the maze.'' ''Step On,'' based on John Kongos's 1970 song ''He's Gonna Step on You Again,'' twangs and chants a message of paranoia and oppression.
At the end of the 1970's, Manchester bands like the Fall, Throbbing Gristle and especially Joy Division developed music with a brutal, static beat and a sense of hopelessness; New Order, formed by members of Joy Division after the band's lead singer committed suicide, keeps its despair at a slightly ironic remove behind deadpan vocals and music that's both surging and sinister. New Order has found international popularity; there's no shortage of alienated, cultish listeners. Where basic punk black is the wardrobe for New Order and its followers, the new Manchester music arrives in an explosion of flower patterns and Day-Glo colors; its trappings evoke every hedonistic pop style from psychedelia to disco. The open drug use - ''marijuana keeps that smile upon my face,'' sings Shaun Ryder of Happy Mondays - is another kind of escapism (and one that might not migrate to the United States in the just-say-no era). While Stone Roses, who stand slightly apart from the rest of the Manchester bands, write concise folk-rock songs, the other groups depend on the trippy combination of a drone and an unstoppable beat, whether they rely on post-disco synthesizers (808 State, Adamski, A Guy Called Gerald) or guitar (Happy Mondays) or organ (Inspiral Carpets).
But the new Manchester music offers escapism without escape, a euphoria that comes to a bleak end on Monday morning. The psychedelia of the 60's was music of rebellious hope, convinced that a new world was in the making. Manchester's music arrived in the same costumes, but it can hope for nothing more than a few hours of forgetfulness. It's psychedelia turned dystopian; no wonder Happy Mondays' 1989 album is called ''Bummed.'' The rock bands sing depressive tidings, too pessimistic to hope that protest would do any good; the synthesizer bands' drum-machine beat is not simply propulsive but ominous, mechanical, relentless, even more so than the disco music of the late 1970's.
Inspiral Carpets are Manchester's truest 1960's revivalists. Their riffs are ground out on what sounds like a cheap 1960's-style combo organ; the drums are pounded by hand. Although the band members cite influences like Sonic Youth and rap music, a listener would never know it; the band re-creates the old-fashioned momentum of a garage band, as if it were playing songs the Seeds or Question Mark and the Mysterians never got around to recording. ''Cool As'' includes four short singles (''Out of Time'' is best) about romantic and existential frustration and a 16-minute workout on ''Planecrash'' that could have been recorded at the Fillmore.
A Guy Called Gerald, led by Gerald Simpson, and Adamski both crank out tapocketa-pocketa rhythm tracks that club disk jockeys will find useful. Adamski favors buzzing, pogo-stick keyboard riffs, while A Guy Called Gerald features a vocalist, Viv, who suggests a latter-day Donna Summer. She sings about being powerless - against the beat, against emotions, against undefined forces.
The clear standout among Manchester's electronic bands is the primarily instrumental 808 State. Most of its songs use the deep, piston rhythms of house music and top them with Manchester's most imaginative sonic vocabulary - not just electronic plinks and zingers, but cool pop-jazz melodies, exotic-sounding bells and flutes and layer upon layer of riffs and cross-rhythms, floating and stomping. Where the other bands dress psychedelic and play disco, 808 State combines them into an aural fantasy that can survive if it's removed from the dance floor.
Manchester bands are going to have to make their ways individually in the United States. There is no scene here to support them, since dance clubs concentrate on house and rap music, and working-class fans prefer more conventional rock. But the dedication of Manchester fans and the spread of their music show that even in hard times people will find reason to dance. Right now, from across the Atlantic, Manchester's music sounds peculiar; an American recession could make it sound prophetic.

HEADLINE: The Rocky Road to HDTV

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''The Lure of Digital Television'' (June 24) hinges on the idea that ''the technology could set the stage for the evolution of HDTV from passive television to an interactive medium.'' Indeed, technological innovation has been and will continue to be an essential element in the successful development of a widely used interactive medium. However, it is not technology but economics that has delayed the acceptance of interactive television and home data services.
Interactive television via analog cable television and interactive data via the telephone network were introduced more than a decade ago. Today, homeowners spend substantial sums for entertainment like movies and sports); but home banking, home ticketing and other such interactive services have never been financially successful. Unless technology provides people with valued services at a fair price, a more elegant and rugged digital delivery system will not alter consumer acceptance.
SIDNEY TOPOL,
 Fellow Kennedy School of Government
 Harvard University
 July 16, Cambridge, Mass.

HEADLINE: How Many Bosses Does It Take . . . To Mange One Worker?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I agree with Professor Richard Rosecrance that there are too many chiefs in American organizations and with his suggestion that Japanese companies are doing better than American companies because the percentage of managers is lower in Japan than in the United States.
One important point should be added to the discussion about American businesses. In America, the basic attitude toward work is negative. Most white- and blue-collar workers do not view work as pleasurable. Work is simply a means to obtain more toys to use in leisure time. In general, Japanese workers are extremely dedicated to their companies and find work more desirable than leisure time. In fact, some workers are so averse to taking vacations that companies must actually force them to take a week or two off from work.
In addition, the normal working day for a Japanese is 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. Some even work on Saturdays. American workers, however, have the 9-to-5 mindset. Those who are the exceptions reach the upper echelons of management in a short period of time.
Just consider the Leviathan task it would be to change the mindset and work week of the American worker. But that is what it would take to have a ''long-term economic resurgence.''
YUKO J. NAKANISHI
 July 15, Forest Hills, N.Y.

HEADLINE: The Networks' New Advertising Dance

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

 BODY:
Viewers of the new television series ''Northern Exposure'' on CBS Thursday evening could hardly miss the striking scenery and the quirky mooseburger meals depicted in the saga of a young New York doctor acclimating to a rugged Alaskan town.
Only a brand-name whiz, though, would have realized that half the parade of commercials - Crest, Downy, Head & Shoulders, Folgers, Pringle's Potato Chips, Tide, Oil of Olay, Pepto-Bismol - came from one source: the Procter & Gamble Company. That was no coincidence.
In a deal struck with CBS, Procter & Gamble had agreed to foot part of the production expenses and buy half the commercials in exchange for a minority ownership stake in the program. This unusual experiment is one of the latest signs of the partnerships being forged between advertisers and major networks, arrangements that vaguely harken back to the early ''Golden Age'' of television, when the advertising community was virtually indistinguishable from the networks. 
Clearly, the romance is back. After years of agitated relations in the marriage between the networks and advertisers, the beleaguered networks are increasingly courting makers of canned peas and of crackers by flashing inventive ways to make expensive network commercials worth more.
Beset by dwindling audiences and brutal competition, the networks have been transforming themselves from lackadaisical order bookers to panting salesmen. They are doing things like mall tours in connection with advertisers, special segments on regular shows keyed to themes of keen interest to sponsors and joint sweepstakes with retailers and fast-food chains doling out millions of dollars in prizes. In rare instances, they are agreeing to plant products in episodes of prime-time shows, and considering having stars of shows plug merchandise. Cognizant of the shifting sands, large sponsors are pushing the networks to accept more programs produced - or co-produced - by advertisers. Can the return of the ''Goodyear TV Playhouse'' be far behind?
 
Just Trying to Help
 ''We're trying to be advertiser friendly,'' said Larry Hoffner, executive vice president of network sales at NBC. ''We're trying to find out what advertisers wish to accomplish and trying to help them.''
Jerry Dominus, head of sales at CBS, added: ''We are finding extra ways for advertisers to get more out of their sponsorship than sending us a commercial and we run it, thank you very much.''
There are those who fret, however, that this enhanced cooperation bodes ill for programming, and may ultimately blur the lines between programs and commercials. ''The weakening of the networks will no doubt make them prey to more advertiser control of program content,'' said Michael Schudson, professor of communications and sociology at the University of California at San Diego.
Just how much the promotional efforts accomplish, particularly in winning lasting viewers for new series, is questionable as well. ''Last year was not the best year for new shows on network television,'' admitted John Miller, NBC's senior vice president of marketing, advertising and promotion. ''It really boils down to good shows.''
And how far the faltering networks will now go to revive the days of old will depend in part on how much power programming executives are willing to relinquish and how well sales forces are able to balance the needs of competing advertisers.
In television's infancy, power was heavily centered with advertisers, who supplied most of the shows and named many of them after themselves. But as television prospered, the networks took command of programming and adopted an almost cavalier attitude toward sponsors.
At this point, more ideas are being bandied about than actually implemented. ''Something is happening, but the habits and emotions are so well entrenched that it will take a while for a lot to happen,'' said Roy Bostock, chairman and chief executive of the D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles advertising agency.
Advertisers and their agencies are clearly eager for more to happen. Mr. Bostock, for example, preaches an exceedingly focused view of the core purpose of network television. ''I think the networks need to define their business as delivering audiences to advertisers,'' he said. ''That's how they generate their revenues. And the networks have generally not thought in that way. But they did think that way in the 1950's.''
 
A Bullish Sign
To be sure, this new era of cooperation may only go part of the way toward rescuing the networks. ''It's an anchor in the storm of continuing slipping audiences,'' said John Reidy, a media analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. He noted, however, that the three networks in their advance ''upfront'' sales for the 1990-91 season have achieved surprising price increases in the vicinity of 8 to 9 percent. ''So something that they're doing is contributing to a strong upfront market,'' he said.
The ways in which the networks are accommodating advertisers are taking myriad forms, with fresh derivations being constantly formulated.
Over the last two years, ABC has run a series of theme weeks on ''Good Morning America'' designed to attract new advertisers. During these weeks, the show incorporates a five-part series wedded to a single theme and then sells time to advertisers making products related to the theme.
In an added twist, during a recent parenting theme week, ABC promoted a phone number viewers could call for further information and to obtain coupon packages featuring the sponsors' products. ABC said the device has enabled it to lure a number of new advertisers, including Kodak, Chubb and Kimberly-Clark, and the network gets a premium of $25,000 from each sponsor.
On another front, ABC News has just begun creating videocassettes based on files in the sizable film archives - ''Royalty Around the World,'' ''Behind Kremlin Walls'' - it is trying to peddle to advertisers, who might hand them out as premiums or insert commercials in them and then sell them to customers. It said early interest has been substantial.
 
Geoffrey's Secret Word
 In return for Toys ''R'' Us doubling its spending on Saturday morning shows for the coming season, NBC structured a four-week promotion, ''Geoffrey's Secret Word Game,'' in which customers will be able to pick up game cards at Toys ''R'' Us and then need to watch an NBC show to listen for secret words.
In another unusual action, NBC signed a deal estimated to be worth more than $500 million in commercial time over three years with the General Motors Corporation, giving NBC a guaranteed level of revenue from the car maker and granting G.M. assurance of having commercial spots within shows it desires and a firmer fix on costs.
By buying a large quantity of ads on CBS sports programming, a small group of advertisers - including American Telephone and Telegraph, Visa, Nike and Sears - received places in a CBS promotional tour that began in April and is visiting shopping malls in 27 cities. In the fall, the network will stage a 50-campus college tour for Isuzu Motors and L'Oreal promoting ''The Young and the Restless'' soap opera.
Some of the new efforts are trespassing on long-forbidden territory. For Coca-Cola, CBS and the producer of the series ''TV 101'' agreed to the rare step of displaying a Coke machine in episodes of the show in return for Coke buying more than the normal amount of commercial time. As it happened, the series, Coke machine and all, failed. Such placements, although pervasive in movies, are tricky on television, because they outrage makers of competing products. ''Pepsi, for instance, wouldn't go in 'TV 101,' '' said Mr. Dominus of CBS. ''That's the downside of fooling around in this area.'' But almost anything is undoubtedly possible at the right price. The networks say they are becoming more open-minded about the notion of ''cast commercials,'' in which characters in series would perform pitches for a product during commercial breaks. One big hitch is what price to charge for such plugs, since the cast has to be compensated, too.
Cast commercials have been in disfavor in television for many years, though they were commonplace decades ago. Captain Kangeroo, for instance, used to promote Schwinn bicycles while he entertained children on his morning show.
''This hasn't happened in the medium for years,'' said Mr. Dominus. ''We've talked to some advertisers about it and it could be worked out. Yet it would probably involve a lot of investment.'' Many of these value-added techniques are aimed at recapturing promotion dollars. The bulk of the marketing budgets of most advertisers is spent on promotional activities - contests, discount coupons, direct mail and the like - rather than conventional advertising, and much of that promotion money has been siphoned out of television. Thus, the networks are trying to persuade advertisers that television can assist in these promotions.
Both CBS and NBC have linked themselves with major chains to push their new fall shows at the same time that the chains get network exposure. Last year, CBS ran a sweepstakes that was advertised through K Mart, and the promotion will be repeated this September. NBC, meanwhile, did a promotion last year with Sears that produced mixed results. For this September, it has signed up with McDonald's to do a ''McMillions on NBC'' campaign that will give away $35 million over 28 days in September and October.
In hope of developing additional customized arrangements for sponsors, Mr. Miller of NBC is finishing the organization of teams that will shortly fan out and call on the top 100 network advertisers to specify the portfolio of things the network can do for them.
 
Highly Motivated
Certainly, the networks have never appeared to be more open to change. Hobbled by a continuing loss of viewers to cable, the speedily-growing Fox Broadcasting Company, syndicated shows, independent stations and home video, the major networks have watched their share of audience tumble from some 90 percent in the late 1970's to around 65 percent last season.
Magnifying their woes was the startling report by the A. C. Nielsen Company that in recent months millions of people seem to have abandoned watching television altogether. The three major networks have since announced plans to alter the way they validate audience sizes to advertisers because of their lack of faith in the Nielsen numbers.
In recent years, advertising spending on the networks has hardly even kept up with economic growth. Last year, spending was off seven-tenths of 1 percent, according to Robert Coen, director of forecasting at the McCann-Erickson ad agency, and he projects an increase of just 5.5 percent in 1990, to $9.6 billion.
 
Long-Term Worries
Although all the networks were profitable last year, they have to worry in the long term about how to increase revenues while audiences shrink. ''The big question everyone is asking is, 'How can we be of mutual benefit to one another?' '' said Michael Moore, the media director at D'Arcy.
In many respects, though, the networks are still rookies in conceiving fresh marketing ideas. As Philip Guarascio, head of advertising at G.M., put it, ''Frankly, I think we're far more sophisticated than the networks in these things. And so they have to play catch-up.''
One of the more curious changes taking place - albeit a small factor in terms of total programming hours - is the slowly growing popularity of advertiser-generated shows. Although P.&G. has long produced daytime soap operas to peddle its suds - it currently does three - advertisers have had little say in the production end of prime-time programming.
For years, large advertisers like A.T.&T., G.M., Hallmark and General Foods, along with their agencies, have produced their own movies and specials and then bought the time to put them on prime-time schedules, usually through tough bargaining with the networks. Network programming people in particular have not been overly anxious to take them, though advertisers report that the networks are getting less chilly.
''This is still in its infancy in modern times,'' said Robert Cagliero, ABC's vice president of special program sales. ''But it has increased markedly in the last few years.''
As one sign of the increased interest, D'Arcy last week created a new position of director of broadcast programming to help develop ideas for programs for D'Arcy clients.
Like others, Mr. Miller of NBC acknowledged that the efforts to improve advertiser relations are still in their early stages. ''But the mood has changed,'' he said. ''We are making it clear that we are interested in talking to advertisers. We're regular people just like they are. They can pick up the phone and call us.''
 
DURING THE 'GOLDEN AGE'
In the ''Golden Age'' of television, during the 1950's, the relationship between advertisers and the networks was the very definition of cozy.
During this time, as Stephen Fox points out in his book, ''The Mirror Makers: A History of American Advertising and Its Creators,'' the ''lines were blurred between ad agencies and TV networks. Many top executives shuttled back and forth between the two, changing jobs but using the same skills and contacts.''
Most television programs were produced by agencies for a single sponsor. Fittingly, the shows routinely carried the names of the advertisers: ''Texaco Star Theater,'' ''Goodyear TV Playhouse,'' ''Kraft Television Theater.'' The sponsor took care of contents of programs, while the networks, which were essentially an assemblage of contractually connected television stations, furnished facilities and air time.
There was an insidious side to these arrangements. Nothing prevented the sponsor from blending plugs for its products into the shows. In certain instances, a show's principals recoiled from the interference they were subjected to.
Mr. Fox recounts the time scriptwriter Rod Serling was asked to change ''American'' and ''lucky'' to ''United States'' and ''fortunate'' because the cigarette company underwriting the show competed with American Tobacco's Lucky Strike. Mr. Serling capitulated but struck his name from the script.
 
ADVERTISERS OUT ON A LIMB
The costs and risks to advertisers of producing their own television movies and specials are high. Deals can be structured in many ways, often with a network as a partner. But if an advertiser produces a program on its own, it could easily spend $2.5 million to $5 million to complete a two-hour movie - then have to buy a two-hour time slot from a network, at a cost that can exceed $4 million.
Depending on the success of the program and what residual sales to syndication and foreign markets are made, the show could turn out to be cheaper than buying all the commercial time on a network show. But it could also be a lot more expensive. ''This is not a game for amateurs,'' said Philip Guarascio, head of advertising at the General Motors Corporation. ''It's not for the meek.''
Yet many expect the practice to grow further. ''The more crowded the world gets, the more appealing we feel programming is,'' said Marcella Rosen, executive vice president and managing director of media services at the Ayer advertising agency. ''In a cluttered world, this is a way to get noticed.''
While it may never come to pass that many regular series will again be made by advertisers, agency executives report that several large advertisers are intrigued by the thought of producing a series.
One, according to Louis Schultz, worldwide media director of the Lintas agency, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is working on a pilot for a series that may air in the winter. He would not identify the advertiser or the network, but said that the show might carry the advertiser's name.
Advertisers and agencies are also beginning to produce shows for European television, which is rapidly expanding and in dire need of programming. Lintas, for instance, does new versions of ''Wheel of Fortune'' and ''Jeopardy'' in Europe, and is bringing out a soap opera called ''Monte Carlo'' in the fall.

HEADLINE: New Accounting Proposal Create Nonprofit Anxiety

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
When a wealthy businessman said in 1986 he would donate $1.5 million to Princeton University, the school, as is usual for a nonprofit organization, decided not to show the revenues on its books until it had collected the money. It is a good thing, because the donor, Ivan F. Boesky, the Wall Street arbitrager, was subsequently arrested on insider trading charges, putting him in no position to follow through on his pledge.
But in an effort to hold nonprofit institutions to the same rigorous accounting standards that apply to for-profit corporations, the Financial Accounting Standards Board may force universities, hospitals and other charitable organizations to recognize most pledges as ''revenue'' as soon as a donor has made a commitment - in the same way that the board requires for-profit companies to handle credit-card sales, where the cash does not automatically change hands.
This is just one of the far-reaching new rules that the accounting board plans to propose in August and that is creating anxiety among nonprofit groups. The proposed rules will be released for public comment by the board before a final draft is issued in 1991. 
The rules would also require nonprofit organizations to account for as revenues certain assets that are now often not accounted for at all, from the donation of a priceless work of art to a museum, to the hard-to-value gifts of time made by volunteer workers.
''All gifts have value, and conceptually, they all should be recognized,'' said Ronald J. Bossio, the official in charge of the project at Fasbee, as the board is informally known.
While audited financial statements are the best proof to the public that their donations are well spent, many nonprofit groups are uneasy about the proposed standards. Putting a value on labor would increase their paperwork. Most are afraid that recognizing pledges will increase revenues, making them looking richer than they are, a turnoff to potential donors. Nonprofit organizations also worry that collection problems will put them in the awkward position of having to either shake down donors or suffer a write-off.
''If you press the guy, you may not get that pledge, and you'll certainly never get another one,'' said Richard T. Lawrence, the pastor of St. Vincent de Paul Church in Baltimore, explaining why many churches and schools prefer to keep mixed blessings like uncollected pledges off their books.
And accounting firms do not relish certifying the value that their nonprofit clients assign to volunteer labor. ''It's mind-blowing, and it's silly,'' said John K. McLaughlin, a partner with KPMG Peat Marwick.
The accounting board, an independent seven-member group in Norwalk, Conn., was created in 1973 to set policy for for-profit and nonprofit corporations in the private sector that auditors could use to determine whether to sign off on a client's financial statements. But four years ago, the board began reviewing the accounting practices that are peculiar to nonprofit organizations.
Fasbee believed that the nonprofit groups could do a better job of recognizing the impact of unaccounted-for contributions on their revenues and assets. Because nonprofit organizations do not have shareholders as do for-profit corporations, they do not invite the same regulatory scrutiny. Auditors privately say they are not as hard on the sloppy accounting of their nonprofit clients as they are on that of for-profit clients, where the risk of being sued by disgruntled investors is higher.
Theoretically, the new standards would make the financial statements of nonprofit organizations more uniform and therefore easier for donors like foundations, which typically review a group's financial position before making a contribution, to compare.
''In the nonprofit world, the accounting is not that good, and there is not the consistency of the business world,'' said Daniel Borochoff, an analyst with the National Charities Information Bureau in New York, which rates nonprofit groups on their financial reporting. ''In the business world, you have the Securities and Exchange Commission and investors who would sue if they got information that would lead them to make a poor investment decision. In the nonprofit world, there's not that much pressure on having good information that accurately portrays what is going on.''
Groups like hospitals and charities should be able to account for their pledges without too much trouble. They know from past fundraisers what their collection record is likely to be, and they can set up reserves to handle the losses they might suffer from an occasional bad debt.
But colleges, universities and churches, which attract large, infrequent donations from prominent individuals, have always been loathe to record mere pledges, lest they fall through.
''There are many cases where people, for a variety of reasons, can't make good on their pledges,'' said Richard R. Spies, Princeton's vice president for finance. ''It can be business reversals, family circumstances, even a change of heart. We try to get people to honor those commitments, but we don't take legal efforts to force them to make good on those pledges. That's true whether it's Ivan Boesky or anyone else.''
Many museums believe they would have special problems complying with the proposed rules and strongly oppose their adoption. They contend that valuing the millions of objects they have in their collections is an impossible task, one reason they have balked at carrying them on their books at all.
Hospitals, churches, schools and other charitable organizations are also troubled by the proposal that would require them to put a dollar value on volunteer labor and to include the number in revenues whenever the activity meets certain tests. Otherwise, the board intends to encourage, but not require, compliance.
Several officials at nonprofit organizations said they agreed with the board that this approach captures the economic realities they face. But they complained that the proposed new rules would create enormous paperwork by forcing them to keep track of hordes of volunteers who come and go, and whose value to the organization is hard to gauge.
How much, for instance, was Jimmy Carter's time worth when the former President volunteered his carpentry skills to building low-cost housing for New York City's poor? What is the value of time donated by an unpaid board member or director, a staple of the nonprofit world, when the individual generally fetches a large salary? What about the 80 million Americans who contribute an average of five hours a week on activities ranging from candy striping to envelope-stuffing to being a den mother?
Barry S. Weinstein, chief operating officer for the Children's Hospital Medical Center in Cincinnati, said that valuing all the ''surrogate grandparents'' who pitch in at his hospital would itself be a labor-intensive effort. ''The hospitals have a good cadre of finance people,'' he said. ''The question is, do you want to dedicate them to determining the value of volunteer employees or have them do something else that they're doing now?''
Though the ''contributions'' made by volunteers would indeed increase some organizations' revenues, they should have no impact on bottom lines, since the organizations would also recognize an offsetting expense to balance their books.
Nonetheless, some foundations fear that Fasbee may do more harm than good by giving nonprofit groups a choice of whether to value the volunteer labor they receive.
Here's the problem: Donors judge nonprofit organizations largely on how much of every dollar goes to worthwhile projects, as opposed to overhead. Thus, those organizations whose volunteers tend to work on projects that relate to the nonprofit organization's mission may be inclined to use volunteer labor to prop up their revenues. Doing so would make overhead appear smaller while inflating the amount apparently spent on program-related activities. But organizations whose volunteers stick to fundraising would simply opt out of the new rule because it would appear to increase their overhead in relation to their program expense.
Making the rules optional could create chaos rather than clarifying the relative financial positions of nonprofit groups. ''There's a potential for abuse,'' said Patrick J. Yogus, a vice president for the American Cancer Society. ''If any organization was not totally upfront, they could inflate what they're doing.''
His organization, for instance, has roughly 77,000 volunteers who are collecting information for a 10-year study on cancer prevention. Valuing their time at the same pay rate as say, census workers, Mr. Yogus said, could enable the society to put an additional $90 million in ''contributions'' on its books under revenues. The offsetting $90 million entry that would then be entered as ''research expense'' to balance the books, would make the society appear to be spending a higher proportion of its dollars on research than it is.
''To maintain credibility, we've backed away from doing that and maybe under these new standards, it will be seen as a legitimate thing we should be doing,'' said Mr. Yogus, who thinks that such information properly belongs in the footnotes, if anywhere.

HEADLINE: Circuit Breakers: Maybe They Work, Maybe They Don't

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
The embattled futures industry finally got a break last week, and it came in the guise of plummeting markets.
When the dust settled after the plunge on Monday, industry executives declared a victory for the Chicago Mercantile Exchange's self-imposed circuit breaker system.
Circuit breakers are mechanisms that temporarily halt trading in wildly swinging markets. On Monday, when contracts for the Standard & Poor's stock index futures fell 12 points - the equivalent of 100 points in the Dow Jones industrial average - the Mercantile Exchange's circuit breakers kicked in and were widely credited by traders and market watchers with stemming the drop in both the futures and stock markets.
An expert trader could not have timed it better. The next day, at scheduled hearings before the Senate Banking Committee, futures industry representatives were able to point proudly to this performance as evidence the regulatory system is functioning smoothly. 
When Senator John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania, suggested that the futures industry had done little to correct problems that exacerbated the 1987 market crash. Leo Melamed, chairman of the Mercantile Exchange's executive committee, put it succinctly: ''Circuit breakers are in place and they work very well.''
Added Ted Doukas, an executive with the Chicago Board of Trade, where circuit breakers were also triggered on Monday: ''We could keep our heads up high and say some very good things about how the markets responded.''
Despite all the talk of victory, experts remain divided over whether circuit breakers can claim credit for stemming the drop in the markets. Some even question whether such an effect is for the best. In fact, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission itself has criticized circuit breakers in the past.
Recently, however, this discussion has been overshadowed by the much louder political debate over who should have regulatory control over the futures exchanges. While circuit breakers are not a key issue in the turf war between the commodity futures commission and the Securities and Exchange Commission, they do play a role and were freshly examined last week amid this highly charged environment.
Hans R. Stoll, a professor of finance at Vanderbilt University, said it is not clear that circuit breakers perform as intended. Still, he said, if the public perception was that they helped, it would be useful ammunition for the futures industry. ''It reduces the political pressure to move authority from the C.F.T.C. to the S.E.C.,'' he said. In fact, the Administration's plan to do that has recently faltered. (See box.) Circuit breakers were introduced after the 1987 stock market crash in response to the public cry to ''do something.'' The chief intent of the mechanisms, which include trading halts and price limits, is to give traders a chance to gather their bearings in a wildly swinging market. Supporters say they are not meant to keep a market from dropping, only to help it drop in an orderly fashion.
Several studies on volatility, most recently a report issued in June by the New York Stock Exchange, have recommended circuit breakers, and the stock and futures exchanges have instituted a number of them over the last few years.
Circuit breakers are triggered by large price movements. On Monday, when the futures contract for the S.& P. 500-stock index fell 12 points at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, contracts were not allowed to trade at a lower level for 30 minutes.
At the New York Stock Exchange, if the Dow Jones industrial average dropped by 250 points, trading in all stocks would be halted for an hour. That has not happened since the rule went into effect on Oct. 20, 1988.
Proponents argue that trading halts reduce volatility by letting investors cool off and digest information. They also allow clearing operations to catch up with trading.
Critics charge that a halt interrupts a fluid market and prevents buyers and sellers from completing trades. Information that translates into price changes is slowed, merely delaying price swings. And big price drops, they say, can be beneficial by attracting bargain hunters. Halts delay or even prevent that from occurring.
There is also concern about a so-called magnet effect: when prices approach a circuit-breaker level, the drop accelerates in a rush to sell before the mechanism is triggered.
Mr. Stoll of Vanderbilt said it is not clear that the market's recovery on Monday had anything to do with circuit breakers. The Dow fell more than 100 points in little more than an hour before closing the day down 56.44. ''This time we were probably just lucky,'' he said.
If investors' perceptions have changed, causing stock prices to plummet, Mr. Stoll said, circuit breakers will ultimately do little to stop that decline. ''All they can do is stop people from trading, but it doesn't stop them from thinking.''
Other academics also question the philosophy of circuit breakers, while futures and stock markets have endorsed them and traders see them as basically benign. James H. Lorie, a professor of finance at the University of Chicago, said: ''If we attribute the rebound to the circuit breakers, I think we are making a mistake.''
''Even if circuit breakers worked, I think it would be counterproductive,'' Mr. Lorie said, since no one is helped by keeping the markets from gravitating to the correct level.
Indeed, a number of studies exist on the efficacy of circuit breakers, including ones by the commodity futures commission and the S.E.C. on the role of the trading halts in the crash last Oct. 13.
The futures commission report found that the circuit breakers did not reduce volatility. ''Instead,'' it said, ''there is some evidence that a binding circuit breaker in one market is associated with increased volatility in other unconstrained markets.'' Because circuit breakers are not triggered simultaneously in different markets, the commission contends, their activation increased volatility by transferring selling pressure to other markets.
The S.E.C. found, in contrast, that the imposition of the mercantile exchange's price limit for S.&P. futures coincided with a sharp reduction in program selling on the New York Stock Exchange and in the rate at which stock prices fell.
The chairman of the S.E.C., Richard Breeden, and the chairwoman of the futures commission, Wendy Gramm, exchanged bitter words over their interpretations of the Oct. 13 crash, both maneuvering to use the data to bolster their position over which agency should oversee futures.
The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, issued perhaps the final word last week in yet a third report, ordered by Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut and chairman of the Senate subcommittee on securities. The G.A.O. said the two agencies had used incomplete data to form conclusions that reflected their viewpoints. According to the G.A.O., ''Determining the soundness of these conclusions would require better data.''
But the battle over circuit breakers continues. On Wednesday, the S.E.C. approved a rule that could curtail program trading on days with broad market swings. The futures commission opposed it, saying it would decrease the linkage between markets and increase volatility.
''I find all this tinkering undesirable,'' Mr. Stoll said. ''You've got all these things that kick in at different points. Five years from now, we will say 'Gee, all these little rules are kind of silly. Let's get rid of them.' ''
 
REGULATORY PLAN IS UNRAVELING
Not too many months ago, the Bush Administration's bid to wrest regulatory control of much of the futures industry from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission seemed destined for success.
''I thought it was a done deal,'' said Daniel R. Siegel, a finance professor at the University of Washington.
Within the Administration, powerful backers of the plan shared that view. At the very least, the Securities and Exchange Commission would oversee stock-index futures, they said. ''Anything less than that is unacceptable,'' a senior Treasury official said in March. But now the Treasury is accepting less.
A compromise plan would give the Federal Reserve Board authority to set broad guidelines for margins for stock-index futures, which are now set by futures exchanges. Two powerful backers of the original plan, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady and Richard Breeden, chairman of the S.E.C., have argued that low margin requirements for futures make the market more volatile.
Why did the Administration's effort apparently fall short?
For one, the commodities industry's powerful political allies, like the farm lobby, rallied. ''It has been an intensely lobbied campaign,'' said Robert K. Wilmouth, head of the National Futures Association.
Futures officials argued that tampering with the system might add cost and inefficiency, driving business to London and Tokyo. Mr. Siegel of the University of Washington said the Administration had no compelling economic arguments.
Also, futures exchanges are getting less publicity about the Government's investigation of trading abuses. In the first case to come to trial, one defendant was acquitted and two were convicted on lesser charges. ''It seems that the F.B.I. sting operation kind of evaporated,'' Mr. Siegel said.
The Administration has been criticized by some backers of the original plan for not working hard enough for its passage. But a Treasury spokeswoman, Desiree Tucker-Sorini, said Secretary Brady has pushed hard for it.
 
CIRCUITS BREAKERS
 
Key automatic suspensions of trading designed to restore stability to the stock markets in the event of dramatic price moves.
 
NEW YORK STOCK EXCHANGE
 
All trading is halted for one hour if the Dow Jones industrial average falls 250 points during one day, and for an additional two hours if the average falls another 150 points on the same day.
 
CHICAGO MERCANTILE EXCHANGE
 
Trading on the S. & P. 500 stock index futures contract market is halted for two minutes if, in the first 10 minutes of trading, the market rises or drops five points from the previous day's close. During the day, trading is halted for 30 minutes if the market drops 12 points. After 2:30 P.M., the daily limit becomes 20 points. If the market drops 20 points, the market is halted for an hour. If the limit is reached after 1:30 P.M., trading is halted for the rest of the day.
 
PROGRAM TRADING
 
When trading on the S. & P. futures market in Chciago is halted, orders for program trades at the N.Y.S.E. are diverted into a separte computer file where buy and sell orders are paired off. After five minutes, trading is halted in a stock if a large imbalance between buy and sell orders exists.
 
Sources: Chicago Mercantile Exchange, New York Stock Exchange

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Where a Boom May Not Be a Boon

BYLINE: By BENJAMIN WEINER; Benjamin Weiner, president of Probe International in Stamford, Conn., specializes in assessing political risk for corporations.

 BODY:
Expanded American trade and investment in the Soviet Union might prolong President Gorbachev's political life, but a number of American executives are beginning to sense that it could prove more a disaster than a boon for the American companies involved.
Admittedly there appeared to be a rapport of sorts between Mr. Gorbachev and the corporate leaders who crowded into the meetings set up during his recent visit to the United States. The Soviet President displayed a skillful blend of blandishment and warning in his sales pitch to American executives, promoting a very tentative Chevron Corporation and Soviet drilling venture as having a potential in excess of $6 billion and cautioning his audiences that if they did not jump on the bandwagon now the opportunity might be lost forever. The Gorbachev pitch was well received by a number of businessmen who already have committed themselves to activities in the Soviet Union and by promoters who sense profits in playing the middleman. 
Yet despite the preaching and the willingness of American executives to shout amen, it appears few approached the baptismal font. Surprisingly, it was only the Chevron project and the International Business Machines Corporation's sale of personal computers that generated publicity.
If this is a reflection of caution on the part of American industry it is well advised, for business prospects in the Soviet Union are slim indeed.
The current political uncertainties in the Soviet Union not only signal social instability but they also could drastically affect the quality and size of the marketplace.
For example, a joint venture established in Vilnius, Lithuania, in 1988, might have been predicated on a domestic market potential of 290 million people. Today that domestic market has shrunk to three million. And if the project required extensive energy inputs it would now face uncertainty.
Given the potential for the disintegration of the Soviet empire, the projected Chevron drilling venture in the Tengiz oil field may start out in the friendly Soviet Union but end up in an independent and hostile Republic of Kazakhstan.
It is also difficult to accept the Gorbachev challenge to take a chance on the Soviet economy when he and his associates appear unwilling to do so themselves. The Kremlin's leaders have been tentative and contradictory in their commitment to the realistic but painful path toward a market economy. Most importantly, they have procrastinated on convertibility of the ruble, presumably since the immediate consequences of inflation and unemployment would be politically unpalatable. Yet a soft ruble severely limits the potentials for foreign investors and traders who then are forced to engage in the archaic acrobatics of countertrade and barter to repatriate profits.
The off-and-on-again trade agreement signed by Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev is not a panacea and in itself will not generate badly needed hard currency for the Soviet Union. The reality is that there are few Soviet products and services that can find significant markets in the United States, regardless of reduced tariff levels. Expanded caviar and vodka sales are hardly the answer, and it could be years before the Russians are in a position to market reliable and price-competitive industrial goods in this country.
Mr. Gorbachev and his advisers apparently are hoping that a surge of trade with the United States would smooth transformation toward a free market and could even jump-start the moribund economy. However, given the Soviet Union's festering sores of political conflict and economic stagnation, this may be the moment for caution on the part of the American business community.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris;
The Volatile Impact of Crude Oil

 BODY:
When words don't persuade, a gun can help.
Iraq's threat to take military action against competitors who undercut its prices for crude oil may or may not have aroused envy among businessmen who are forced to rely on other tactics. But it did send American warships scurrying to the Persian Gulf, and it breathed new life into the markets for crude oil and oil company shares. It also seemed to concentrate the attention of oil producers that had not been as determined to push up prices. 
On Wall Street, the oil stocks have replaced the growth stocks and the technology stocks as the market stars. Chevron and Texaco were featured prominently last week on the shrunken list of stocks making new highs, as hopes of rising profits drew investors who have been stunned by just how low profits seem to be in the rest of the economy. Exxon came within a whisker of hitting a 1990 high. It may be too strong to say, in a paraphrase of ''Engine Charlie'' Wilson, that what's good for Exxon is bad for America. But there is little doubt that, historically, what has been good for oil stocks has seldom been good for the entire stock market. Rising oil prices are paid by everyone, and while some parts of the economy benefit, the net effect is similar to that of a tax increase, draining money that would have gone to other uses. Oil price hikes helped to provoke recessions in the mid-1970's and early 80's.
One way to illustrate the counter-cyclicality of the oil stocks is to measure the Dow Jones industrial average against the three big oil companies in it. Since 1970, in quarters when the oil stocks bested the Dow in performance, the Dow has dropped an average of 1 percent. But when the oil shares lag, the Dow averages a gain of 5.5 percent.
As oil prices rise this time, it turns out the country has been skating even closer to recession than was thought. The Government went through its economic figures of the past three years, and now says that growth was much lower than previously reported. In the second quarter, it said, there were fewer final sales of goods and services than in the first. All of the meager 1.2 percent growth in the economy was due to rising inventories.
That second-quarter guess is subject to revision, and in the past the revisions have often been huge. But it added to the glum picture of an economy with profits lower than expected and renewed the confidence of the minority of economists who think a real recession may have already begun.
Monday's sell-off in the stock market reflected both economic fears and the fragility of the stock market itself. But those who blamed the fall on index arbitrage trading may want to reconsider. That trading normally hits the big stocks - the ones that dominate the stock indexes - the hardest. But small stocks were smacked as well last week. The Dow was down 62.62 points, or 2.1 percent, to 2,898.52,last week, but the fall in the Nasdaq composite was even worse, 2.8 percent. That index is off 5.5 percent for the past fortnight, the worst showing since late 1987.

HEADLINE: Currency;
Sinking Against the Mark

 BODY:
The dollar moved into new territory last week. First, it hit a two-and-a-half-year low against the German mark on Monday as the stock market plunged. Then it fell further on Friday as the report on the American gross national product for the second quarter showed a very sluggish economy, one held above water only by the build-up of inventories. The dollar closed on Friday in New York at 1.6115 against the mark. It has not been this low since Jan. 5, 1988, when it closed at a dismal 1.5880. (The dollar surged to a close of 1.6380 on Jan. 6, 1988, after central banks bought dollars to support it.) But against the yen, the dollar is still holding its own. Despite the stock plunge and the weak report on G.N.P., the dollar was up slightly on the week at 149.
