HEADLINE: A Reckoning for the Utility High Rollers

BYLINE: By LEAH BETH WARD; Leah Beth Ward, a reporter for the Albuquerque (N.M.) Journal in Santa Fe, has covered the utility industry for several years.

 BODY:
The utility industry has never been known as a haven for high rollers. But in late 1986, when Keith L. Turley agreed to buy a Phoenix savings and loan institution, he was only topping off a buying binge started six years earlier by four of the brashest utility companies in the country, all of them in the Southwest.
Mr. Turley headed the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation, whose main asset, the Arizona Public Service Company, is the state's largest public utility. In a deal many industry experts call the highest-stakes gamble ever by an electric utility, Mr. Turley paid $426 million for the Phoenix-based Merabank, roughly twice the savings unit's book value. After two years, Merabank collapsed, nearly taking Pinnacle West with it and ultimately costing the utility holding company an additional $450 million to dispose of it.
Pinnacle West was only the biggest of the brazen. By the early 1980's, the Public Service Company of New Mexico, the El Paso Electric Company and, to a lesser degree, the Tucson Electric Power Company had begun their own wild rides into diversification. 
Much like the savings and loan industry, which sought greater profits than its plain-Jane home mortgages could earn, these four companies strayed far afield from the business they knew best, hoping to cash in on the booming Southwestern economy and create profits beyond the reach of regulators.
''They were considered the go-go companies in the utility industry,'' said Dan Scotto, a utility analyst at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.
But as investors, ratepayers and regulators have learned, Southwestern-style utility diversification has been a painful failure. Indeed, the experience of Pinnacle West and the others - called ''the dismal four'' by Bert Kramer, a utility analyst at Paine Webber Inc. - is reinforcing what some in the industry had long suspected: Utilities, with their engineering-based corporate cultures and history of low risks and low returns, are asking for trouble when they venture into more volatile businesses.
Dismal just begins to describe the condition of the four battered companies, which lost more than $1.2 billion between 1987 and 1989 from investments related to diversification. The basic utility business has slowed, too, rendering total earnings anemic.
Mr. Turley and the heads of the other three companies during the go-go years have either resigned or retired. What they have left behind them is not a pretty sight:
The utilities have laid off several thousand employees, stopped paying dividends and seen their stock prices plummet. Debt has been downgraded to near-junk status and consumer groups worry that increased financing costs will be passed on to ratepayers. And at least two of the dismal four - Public Service of New Mexico and Pinnacle West - have become takeover targets.
Meanwhile, angry regulators have tightened their grip, contending that the companies reneged on promises to keep the utility business insulated from the risks of their other investments. Regulators are now talking about excluding some utilities from diversification by revoking exemptions from the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935, a Federal law passed to end financial speculation by utilities in the 1920's.
Analysts and other industry experts say the four utilities were hobbled by a combination of mismanagement, poor timing and a blind belief that growth in the already pumped-up Southwest would continue unabated. ''There was a uniform pattern of overoptimism, but the numbers really weren't there to justify it,'' said Jerry Jordan, senior vice president at First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles.
Barring actual takeovers, the four companies will do little more than limp along until 1995 or so, most analysts say, when demand for power is expected to grow again.
Nationally, most utilities have diversified cautiously, says Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm. Utility managers in the Northeast are among the most conservative, said Ed Tirello, an industry analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. ''It seems the farther west you go, the more game they get,'' he added.
They were plenty game in the Southwest in the late 1970's and early 80's. Cash was overflowing in many utility coffers in that period, the result of rate increases that kept pace with inflation. The pot grew as big utility construction projects wound down and depreciation helped cash flow.
But the utilities worried that regulators might snatch up the profits, and paying them all out in dividends would shrink the size of their companies, said James Dewey, a partner in Price Waterhouse's utility group. ''They needed some place to invest,'' he said.
So Pinnacle West, El Paso, Tucson and Public Service of New Mexico (known as PNM) all plunged into the increasingly feverish real estate market through development companies, limited partnerships and ownership of, or investments in, savings and loans.
For a short time, the aggressive diversification boosted earnings. But then came the severe downturn in real estate and the collapse of much of the savings and loan industry. To make matters worse, three of the four utilities - Pinnacle West's Arizona Public Service unit, PNM and El Paso - own part of the Palo Verde nuclear plant west of Phoenix. Once hailed as a prime example of prudent construction, Palo Verde has since had operating nightmares, causing extended shutdowns and forcing Arizona and El Paso to buy expensive replacement power.
Shareholders have showered PNM, Tucson Electric and Pinnacle West with lawsuits, alleging mismanagement, and El Paso is embroiled in litigation over the sale of some of its diversified investments.
Citing the pending litigation, the executives who made diversification decisions at the four troubled utilities declined through company spokesmen or their attorneys to be interviewed for this article.
But Richard Snell, the man who succeeded Mr. Turley as head of Pinnacle West in January, conceded that real estate euphoria may have gotten the best of the company in 1986. ''Acquisitions of consequence probably were made at the top of the market,'' said Mr. Snell, a longtime Pinnacle West board member who had opposed Mr. Turley's ambitious diversification plans.
Outsiders have broader explanations for the deep troubles at the four utilities. They never truly diversified, said Mr. Scotto, the Donaldson Lufkin analyst, because they put all their chips on the Southwestern economy. ''They really did not spread out their business risk,'' he said.
And the experience of the four utilities underscores the need to create a solid wall between regulated and unregulated businesses, said Bill Berry, chairman of the Richmond-based Dominion Resources Inc., considered one of the most successful diversified utilities. The non-utility operations, he said, must stand alone financially.
That was supposed to happen with the Southwestern utilities, but didn't, say state regulators. Instead, to varying degrees the utilities pledged the parent companies' credit to underwrite their nonregulated businesses, exposing the whole company to claims by lending banks. And only minimal reporting requirements were established when the utilities received permission to diversify, often leaving regulators to uncover abuses after the fact.
But Mr. Dewey of Price Waterhouse said the regulators underestimated the potential for trouble. ''I think they were naive about how diversification would work,'' he said.
In any event, while the scale is different, there are striking similarities between the excesses of these utilities and the savings and loan industry, said Mr. Jordan of First Interstate. In both cases, he said, normal business risk was improperly shifted. ''Whenever you combine a regulated business with an unregulated business, you in effect make consumers stockholders,'' Mr. Jordan said. ''It's consumers that become the risk bearers, and if management makes mistakes, consumers pay. That's not the way the system is supposed to work.''
In general, ratepayers are facing higher bills not because of diversification, the new chief executives at the utilities insist, but because the costs of doing business have gone up and some of the utilities have found themselves with excess capacity. And shareholders have suffered the most, they say, given that dividends have been suspended indefinitely and stock prices have fallen.
Annual shareholder meetings were particularly brutal for Pinnacle West and PNM this spring. Some investors even hanged an effigy of Jerry D. Geist, PNM's longtime chairman who retired last month.
PNM's stock got a boost earlier this month when a group headed by the company's former chief financial officer made an informal bid that the board is still studying. And Pinnacle West is being pursued by Pacificorp, the acquisitive Portland, Ore., utility holding company that is trying to gain a foothold in the Southwest. Each of its four bids so far has been rejected.
Takeover possibilities aside, the people now running the four utilities have their hands full trying to turn things around. They must sell greatly devalued non-utility assets, regain Wall Street's faith and operate within strict covenants imposed by lenders. And at the same time, they must deal with angry regulators.
Arizona regulators, for example, have asked Federal officials to revoke the legal underpinning for Pinnacle West's diversification. ''I want to make sure they can't go out and do these same silly things again,'' said Timothy Hogan, chief counsel to the Arizona Corporation Commission.
But all four utilities say they are now going back to the basics. In fact, some are pursuing plainness as zealously as they chased glamour. Said Roger Yohem, spokesman for Tucson Electric: ''We are on a fast track to becoming a pure utility company.''
 
BUYING SPREE, POOR TIMING
In the Southwest, the utility shopping spree began with real estate and the most aggressive buyers were the Public Service Company of New Mexico, known as PNM, and the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation.
A PNM investment subsidiary became one of the general partners in a regional land development company a decade ago. When the real estate market began to sour in 1987, the other investors wanted to liquidate the partnership but PNM blocked the move, saying the market would rebound.
In 1989, when the others threatened to sue, the investment subsidiary bought its partners out. But the sale came just months before the land company filed for bankruptcy with more than $300 million in debts, leaving the PNM unit with a controlling stake in a greatly devalued company.
In Phoenix, Pinnacle West, through its Suncor Development Company, spent $168 million buying commercial land in 1986. The same year, Pinnacle West's chairman at the time, Keith L. Turley, reportedly shook hands at a football game on a $221 million deal to buy 12,000 acres of mostly undeveloped land west of the city. Management believes that even though some of the purchases have lost value, others will turn out to be profitable.
But Pinnacle West's biggest wager, which led to its steepest losses, came in December 1986 when a predecessor holding company, called AZP Group, bought Merabank. Two years later, the savings and loan unit recorded a $209 million loss, nearly wiping out Pinnacle West's net income.
The company agreed to pump $450 million into Merabank this spring. In return, it was released from any further obligations by Federal regulators, who now control Merabank.

HEADLINE: All About/The Shuttles;
Clipped Wings Along the Northeast Corridor

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
It's Friday morning at La Guardia Airport and the shuttle business is even slower than usual. Richard F. Cozzi, wrapping up his first week as president of the Trump Shuttle, glances about anxiously, as if hunting for more passengers. A holiday that week has thinned the weekend rush; only a few people straggle into the Trumpterminal, ready to board a Trumpjet, sink into leather Trumpchairs and enjoy Trumpsnacks. At the other end of the airport, Pan Am's shuttle gates are equally desolate.
The Northeast shuttles, on the New York-Washington and New York-Boston routes, were long considered cash cows. Nearly all the passengers are business travelers, frequent fliers who don't flinch at high fares. And with a virtual lock on gates at the three airports - Washington's National, Boston's Logan, and New York's La Guardia - the chances are slim that a third airborne competitor can elbow in on Trump and Pan Am.
But these cows may be going dry. The Trump Shuttle is not yet profitable, the Pan Am shuttle only modestly so. Short flights, with the stress of frequent takeoffs and landings, require more jet maintenance. Airport landing fees at the three airports are among the nation's highest, and standby planes - needed because every passenger is guaranteed a seat with no reservations - are costly. And the shuttles are links, not spokes; they do not feed traffic into airline hubs. 
Then there are the slumping Northeast economy and the stronger competition from Amtrak (see box) Mr. Cozzi predicts that total shuttle ridership will fall from 4 million passengers in 1988 to 3.6 million this year, and blames the economy. Richard Copland, president of the New York Chapter of The American Society of Travel Agents, said businesses are trimming their travel budgets. ''Instead of making three trips, they might make two,'' he said.
Both shuttles have been for sale for months, without attracting buyers. ''The shuttle is a great business to be in if you're the only one operating it,'' said Ed Starkman, an analyst with Paine Weber. ''If there are two of them, it's tough.''
 
Pan Am vs. Trump
A Barely Noticeable Difference
Pan Am and Trump have their loyalists, but the two are so similar that passengers often decide which to fly according to when they arrive at the airport. Trump flies every hour, Pan Am on the half-hour. Jerry Gitner, chairman of Tribeca Aviation, a consulting and investment firm, calls them the ''Tweedledee and Tweedledum'' of the industry.
Eastern started shuttling in 1961, with propeller-driven Constellations and a $10 fare. It had virtually no competition until 1980, when New York Air, a division of the Texas Air Corporation, entered the market. Pan Am bought the New York Air shuttle in 1986 for $76 million. Eastern's shuttle was sold to Donald Trump in June 1989.
Despite the competition, fares continue to climb. Last December, Trump raised fares to $119 from $99, and Pan Am followed. The airlines say that fewer riders but higher revenues resulted.
Since many passengers find the two products nearly indistinguishable, the marketers have been assigned to create some distinctions, also known as frills. Both already let passengers choose from dozens of newspapers and magazines - everything from Business Month to Garbage: The Magazine of Waste Disposal shows up on board.
Pan Am recently began offering its own, condensed daily newspaper. The airline is also holding a special drawing, available to passengers and non-passengers alike, for a new Cadillac Allante.
Pan Am, but not Trump, offers discounts for major corporate customers. Trump gives coupons good for restaurants discounts, extra frequent flier miles or companion tickets if its flights are more than 15 minutes late for any reason. The airline has given away thousands of the coupons, but, Mr. Cozzi said, ''We have enough confidence that we're not going to lose our shirt.''
 
Trump's Cargo of Debt
Market Share, But Not Profits
By one measure, the Trump Shuttle has done fine. Its market share has grown from 12 percent when Eastern sold it, after employees went on strike, to 48 percent. Many passengers had switched to Pan Am, but Mr. Trump lured many back. ''He started with an airline that had no place to go but up,'' Mr. Copland said.
But the Trump Shuttle has not made any money, mainly because of the debt that came with the $365 million price. Many analysts believe Mr. Trump overpaid.
Earlier this year Mr. Trump talked of selling it, but Mr. Cozzi says that no sale is imminent. ''I am not a caretaker for the sale of this airline,'' he said. ''I wouldn't have taken this job if I were.''
Mr. Cozzi took over as shuttle president after Mr. Trump ousted Bruce R. Nobles earlier this month. Mr. Trump had said earlier that he was dissatisfied with the airline's management. Mr. Nobles and Mr. Trump reportedly disagreed on several issues, like the seat assignments that Mr. Nobles wanted to eliminate but Mr. Trump kept.
Even as Mr. Trump adds frills, he has cut back on flight schedules and employees. He has refurbished 12 of his Boeing 727's at a cost of $1 million each and plans to do the same for eight more. He has installed leather seats, GTE Airfones in every row and ''marble-look'' bathrooms, complete with florid T's rimming the sinks and automatic sensors to turn on the taps.
Since the business traveler spends an average of only 10 minutes in the terminal and 45 on board, some industry experts question whether such luxuries are appreciated. ''You don't need rugs on the floor for a 45-minute ride,'' said Mr. Copland.
In other respects, the Trump Shuttle is economizing. A hundred employees, a tenth of the staff, were laid off earlier this month and a concierge service, for hotel reservations and the like, was suspended. Trump also quit serving free coffee in the terminals, but resumed after customers complained. It also dropped six weekend flights, where low fares failed to attract many riders, and may eliminate more. ''It was just a good management decision to say we have to streamline,'' said Mr. Cozzi. ''The demand for the shuttle just isn't there on the weekends.''
But analysts ask how the airline can still claim to fly every hour on the hour. ''Passengers don't want to be looking at their watch as they drive out to the airport,'' said Mr. Starkman. Pan Am said it has no plans to eliminate any weekend flights.
In one respect the Trump Shuttle is doing better than expected: the axiom about there being no such thing as bad publicity seems to be holding true. Reports of Mr. Trump's financial and marital problems have shown no signs of chasing away passengers, analysts say. As one flier explained while boarding a recent Washington flight out of La Guardia, ''It doesn't bother me as long as he gets me where I'm going.''
Mr. Trump has said he expects the airline to fetch $500 million or $600 million. Industry analysts say $300 million. Continental Holdings, formerly Texas Air, might exercise its right to veto the Trump Shuttle's sale if the buyer is a major competitor.
 
A Needy Pan Am Parent
Sacrificing the Successful Offspring
If Pan Am has no slick wheeler-dealer as its namesake, neither does it have that wheeler-dealer's debts. Pan Am bought its shuttle for for only $76 million. Its frequent flyer program is more attractive than Trump's, and it has gained about 10 percentage points of the market since before the Eastern strike, to more than 50 percent.
Pan Am provides no profit figures for its shuttle, but Harris K. Herman, the shuttle's president, said that it has been earning money for the last 10 quarters. Analysts estimate that it earned $15 million last year.
And yet, the Pan Am Shuttle is for sale. The parent company is apparently desperate, with cash reserves that have dwindled to less than $60 million. Thomas G. Plaskett, the company's chairman, has said that Pan Am needs to merge with another airline to survive.
No formal bidders have emerged for either shuttle, but the Transportation Department might exclude any major airline that would gain an overwhelming advantage in the Northeast.
America West, a mid-size carrier which was interested in buying the Eastern Shuttle but couldn't obtain financing, is reportedly considering a bid for either shuttle. Most analysts estimate that either would bring $250 to $300 million, a profit for Pan Am and a loss for Trump. But travelers should not hope for a fare war, since the market would still be dominated by two companies. As Kevin Murphy, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, said, ''It's a legal duopoly.''
 
CAN AMTRAK COMPETE?
The two shuttles face little competition in the air, but Amtrak might give them cause to watch out below. The federally subsidized railroad carried 1.6 million passengers between New York and Washington in the year ended Sept. 30 - about a third of the number who flew. Its goal is to add 500,000 riders in 10 years.
To that end, Amtrak added three round trips between New York and Washington, for a total of four, last October. All are on sleek Metroliners that surpass 100 miles per hour. Coming next month: a test of conference cars in some trains.
Amtrak calls its express service the ''civilized shuttle.'' The trip takes two hours and 35 minutes - which, as Amtrak officials are quick to point out, might be less time than it takes to reach the airports and fly. Record-breaking flight delays at New York's airports give Amtrak another advantage. ''One of our best sales devices is a fog bank at La Guardia Airport or a snow bank at Washington's National Airport,'' said Clifford Black, an Amtrak spokesman.
Amtrak has been averaging about 75 passengers on the express trains - enough to cover its costs but not much more. A one-way Metroliner ticket, standard or express, costs $79, compared with $119 on the two shuttles.
But Amtrak has several disadvantages. Shuttle executives question Amtrak's ''downtown-to-downtown'' boast, saying that most passengers begin and end their trips in the suburbs. The railroad admits that it is considerably less competitive between New York and Boston, where serpentine tracks result in a four-and-a-half-hour trip, compared with a 45-minute flight.
Amtrak also has an image problem. As Mr. Black put it, ''To look and act and feel like an executive you have to fly, regardless of how unproductive it might be.'' And only the airlines have frequent-flier programs. But Amtrak is considering an airline tie-in, allowing frequent train riders to earn free flights.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard Cozzi, Trump Shuttle president, at La Guardia Airport in New York. The shuttle is not yet profitable (Barton Silverman/The New York Times); Harris K. Herman, president of the Pan Am Shuttle. (Pan Am)

HEADLINE: World Markets;
The Greek Market Takes Its Turn

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
In the months since the narrow victory last April of the conservative Government of Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis, the Athens stock market has soared. The tiny Greek market is up 200 percent for the year, and it is the leading performer by far this year in the group that analysts class as emerging stock markets.
Such performance puts Athens up there with other high flyers in Mexico, Thailand, Turkey and Taiwan. All have far outperformed the world's major stock markets in the last several years. Last year, the 19 emerging stock markets in the International Finance Corporation index outgrew Japan by almost 4-to-1 and the United States by just under 2-to-1. 
In September, Americans will be offered their first easy access to the Greek market. Alliance Capital is scheduled to launch the first closed-end country fund for the Greek market to be traded here. It will have a minimum of $60 million to invest. A major portion of that will go into state-owned companies as the Greek Government sells them to the public and into private companies that are not now traded on the exchange but are expected to go public in several years. Only about 25 percent of Greece's top 200 companies are now traded in Athens. In total, only 124 companies were listed on the exchange in June.
So should investors get on board? It will be a difficult decision, because there are some reasons to exercise caution.
For one thing, the steep climb in the Greek market has meant that price/earnings ratios are soaring. For another, the one-vote majority of Mr. Mitsotakis's Government gives a tentative air to the sweeping economic reforms Mr. Mitsotakis wants to take his country through and which account for some of the market's rise. Already, a radical group has protested the selling off of state-owned companies with a bombing incident in Athens. Greece also has high inflation, around 21 percent, and troublesome budget and trade deficits.
Antoine W. van Agtmael, who manages global investment funds through Emerging Markets Management in Washington, calls Greece a classic sell. ''I have been selling most of what I have,'' he said.
On the other hand, Greece has a leg up on many other developing countries because it is a member of the Euorpean Community and should be able to avail itself of some of the benefits of the economic union of 1992. And the high price/earnings ratios, now averaging 25, are based on 1988 earnings. Many analysts expect them to drop when compared with earnings for 1989 and projected earnings for 1990.
One reason for the sharp rise in stock prices is the shortage of stock to buy. Some of the new offerings to come to the market have been oversubscribed by up to 60-to-1. Nikitas A. Niarchos, the head of the stock exchange, said this stock shortage gives the market a floor. ''There may be a small fall in prices but not a big one,'' he said during a visit to New York last week.
Alexander E. Zagoreos, a global fund manager at Lazard Freres & Company in New York, made his bet in Greece early. Last June, at the time of the first, inconclusive, election, he said he saw price/earnings ratios down around 6 and thought much of the bad news in Greece was already in the price of the stocks. So he got in by buying a Greece fund that trades in London.
He did well, he said, but has now taken out all his profit because the market has moved so far and price/earnings ratios have risen to near their highest levels since the late 1970's. But he has left his original investment there.
''There is a good reason to take a hard look at the market,'' he said. ''But if underlying growth continues, the potential growth is so large you almost have to look past the price/earning ratios.''
''It is definitely not a sell,'' added Nicolas C. Bornozis of the CCF International Finance Corporation, a French firm in New York that is concentrating on the Greek market. He argues that the change in the government and, therefore, the economic climate in Greece is on a par with changes in such countries as Mexico and Brazil. ''But it is very hard to ask people to go in a buy now. You have to be very selective,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Business Diary

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
The Power of the Pencil at Eastern
 
For an airline to boast of correcting vital maintenance and repair problems is hardly the path to recovery. Who on Madison Avenue could craft a campaign around a message like this? But claims of ''full corrective action'' were the essence of Eastern Airlines' response to an indictment last Wednesday on 60 counts of ignoring upkeep and falsifying records - ''pencil whipping,'' as it was called. Nine managers, up to the level of a former vice president, were also charged. The airline, now under a court-appointed trustee, is laying plans to plead that $1.9 million in fines last year by the Federal Aviation Administration for faulty maintenance was penalty enough. Some analysts say the indictment nearly obliterates the airline's fading chances of emerging from bankruptcy proceedings. As Helane Becker, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Hutton, said, ''This game might be over.'' 
 
Meeting Low Expectations
 
Such is the state of the American auto industry that companies can win applause for getting by with much lower profits but no debacles. General Motors earned $900 million during the second quarter, down 38 percent, and Ford $771 million, down 45 percent, from the same period last year. Weak sales in North America and turmoil in Brazil were to blame. But analysts said the companies have cut costs and reduced inventories to a five-year low. ''The core operating profits came ahead of exzpectations,'' said Scott F. Merlis, an analyst at Morgan, Stanley, ''considering that they had the worst rebates and one of the lowest production levels we've seen in a while. It was not Armageddon.''
 
No Frigate Like a Profit
 
Poets have never written language as sweet as the clauses giving Paul B. Fireman a share of Reebok International's profits. Last year, zzhe made $14.6 million as chairman, more in salary and bonuses than any other American executive at a publicly owned company, according to Forbes magazine. A bit much, even for the man who endowed sweaty old sneakers with a perfumed image as the height of footwear fashion. Ah, but contracts, unlike other forms of literature, are not everlasting. A new contract to take effect in January limits Mr. Fireman to a $1 million base salary and a bonus of as much $1 million more, depending on profits.
 
More Sieve Than Shield?
 
Tobacco companies are finding that cigarette warning labels might make flimsy shields. The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that the warnings do not protect the companies against damage claims. Five Federal appeals courts have said otherwise, but higher courts might be reluctant to reverse a state decision. The ruling stemmed from a zwidow's lawsuit against three tobacco companies that made the brands her husband, who died of lung cancer, smoked.
 
In Brief
 
General Electric consented to pay $16.1 million for overcharging the United States Army for a battlefield computer system and $11.7 million to settle other allegations.
 
*
 
William Donaldson, a co-founder of the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette brokerage firm, is said to be the leading candidate for chairman of the New York Stock Exchange.
 
*
 
The Columbia Savings and Loan Association of Los Angeles agreed to sell $3-billion in ''junk bonds'' to Canadian investors.
 
Digital Takes a Dive
 
For the first time in 25 years as a public company, the Digital Equipment Corporation reported a quarterly loss. The company took a $400 million charge for retraining, pruning operations and reducing its staff by at least 5,000. Digital has rebounded before, from the days when the International Business Machines Company seemed invincible. Now Digital is beseiged by a host of smaller competitors whose personal computers and work stations often make its minicomputers look clunky and expensive. The company is counting on its first mainframe, and several other new productseasily linked into networks, to fuel its comeback. Despite a worse report than expected, Digital stock barely budged and analysts are modestly optimistic. ''DEC has clearly accepted the changes in the industry and they're trying to adapt,'' said George Elling, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. ''If we get any cooperation from the economy, DEC is positioned to improve.''
 
News From the 2d Quarter
 
Second-quarter earnings:
RJR Nabisco Holdings, a loss of $108 million compared with a loss of $319 million for the similar period last year. Higher sales, lower debt payments. Exxon, $1.1 billion, up from $140 million when the company was spending heavily last year to clean up the Alaskan oil spill. Time Warner, a loss of $189 million because of merger expenses and a slowdown in the magazine and book businesses. Morgan Stanley, $58 million, down 48 percent, and Salomon, $120 million, down 52 percent, as the investment business continues its slump.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Closing Down a Loophole
 
As the cost of paying back savings and loan depositors passes $500 billion, the Government seems about ready to impose new restrictions on deposit insurance. The Government now backs deposits of up to $100,000, but those who split their funds among many institutions have gained virtually unlimited coverage. And in practice, Federal authorities has made good on all deposits, whatever the size. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady suggested last Wednesday a $100,000 limit for individuals and businesses no matter how numerous their accounts. With some banks and credit unions looking weak, Mr. Brady wants to avoid another bailout.
 
The Inexorable Recession?
 
Growth in the gross national product slows and recession talk quickens. The G.N.P. rose at an annual rate of just 1.2 percent during the second quarter. And the estimate of last year's rate was reduced to 2.5 percent, the lowest since the 1982 recession. The Administration deftly played both sides, predicting stronger growth ahead but adding that the Federal Reserve should lower rates to be safe. Few economists foresee a rebound strong enough to fulfill the Administration's prediction of 2 percent growth this year. Next year might be worse still, said Lawrence Krohn, an economist at Shearson Lehman Hutton. ''I think there is an increasing risk of recession early in 1991,'' he said. ''It's really up to the Fed. If they don't ease, then they're going to be held responsible.''
 
Greasing the Wheels of War
 
Kuwait has 20,000 soldiers in all. Iraq had 100,000 troops massed along its border last week. Suddenly, the Kuwaitis and the United Arab Emirates saw the logic of cutting their oil output to help the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries raise prices. ''This is the first time in OPEC's 30-year history that a member country has used the threat of war,'' said David T. Mizrahi, editor of the Mideast Report. ''It took two armored brigades, plus 200 tanks plus 3,000 trucks to raise the price of oil from $17 a barrel to $20 in a matter of three days.'' OPEC agreed to a $21 target price on Friday.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
The Bolshoi Shops Till It Drops
 
The leaps! The pirouettes! The lifts! And after they finished shopping in New York, it was remarkable that members of the Bolshoi Ballet had enough energy left to continue their exertions on stage. The Moscow company, which ended its visit to New York last Sunday and opened in Washington on Tuesday, sprinted to the stores for goods scarce back home. Used to be that Bolshoi members would bring luggage filled with food cansso they could save their $25 daily allowance for videocassette recorders and computers. Now, on $50 a day, with many meals provided, they can really go wild. The first shipment home included 14 refrigerators.
 
Carats for Currency
 
The Soviet Union's latest guide along the capitalist road is, of all nations, South Africa. The Soviet Union is one of the world's major diamond exporters, and South Africa's De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd. runs the world's diamond cartel. For decades, political qualms kept the Soviet Union from publicly associating with De Beers, although there was probably some cooperation behind the scenes. But Soviet officials newly concerned about squeezing the most hard currency from every carat struck a deal last week to sell an estimated $5 billion of uncut diamonds through De Beers. To help pay some foreign debts, the Soviets will receive a $1 billion advance from the company, shipping their diamond stockpile to London to serve as collateral.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC & PRIVATE;
Justice and Mercy

BYLINE: By Anna Quindlen

 BODY:
Perhaps there comes a moment in the life of every woman when she yearns to telephone an 84-year-old man she has never met and ask, ''How could you do this to me?''
For me, that moment came last week.
I am taking the resignation of Justice Brennan personally. I have read all of some of his opinions, and bits of others, and I know where he dissented and where he pulled together a tenuous majority. And I keep remembering the speech in ''The Merchant of Venice'' about mercy seasoning justice. 
Over the years I have come to believe that someone who was in my corner, who touched my life from within one of those pale official tombs that line the streets of Washington, was a member of that mysterious body, the Supreme Court. ''The lightning rod for individual rights and individual freedom,'' Barbara Jordan called him on television. The man who once referred to the treatment of women as '' 'romantic paternalism' which, in practical effect, put women not on a pedestal, but in a cage.'' That's how I thought of him the morning after he called it quits. Not too shabby for an ordinary guy appointed by Ike.
He was a kinder, gentler Justice. One reason that that well-wrought phrase has become so potent is that it is so patently false. We have the sour disposition of a country with diminished expectations, a country whose people have been living through a depression both economic and spiritual.
It is a depression our government refuses to acknowledge, so the American people live with a sinking feeling that their sinking standard of living is a failure of the individual. ''I really don't feel like politicians have any connection to me personally,'' a college student told me. Our elections are as big, bright and empty as balloons.
Only one branch of our tripartite system is not governed at the highest levels by the ballot box, and that is the judiciary. No commercials with the flag rippling in the breeze, no slogans (''Blackmun - because it's your body''), no term of office. Nine private people spend their lives defining our own through cases. Behind those cases there are always human beings, who want to be spared loyalty oaths and censorship, who want to buy birth control devices and be admitted to good colleges. Justice Brennan seemed to pick the people out of the fact patterns, and to respond to their problems and their pain. Justice and mercy. Maybe that was not his job, but I'm glad he did it.
America is a country that seems forever either toddler or teen-ager, those two stages of human development characterized by conflict between autonomy and security. While some interpret this to mean we want neither to use the potty nor have a curfew, it's a tension that is one of our great strengths. Justice Brennan stressed both sides, the right to have government leave us alone in some cases and be our defender in others. The rights of the accused. Free, even objectionable speech. Affirmative action. The right to die, to do what we please in our bedrooms, to be protected from sex discrimination. The discussion of his retirement has centered on a single right, the right to a legal abortion, and that is sad because his vision was larger than that.
His detractors saw it as too large, a liberal agenda that made the Court into a legislator of public policy, not an interpreter of the Constitution. Judge Robert Bork, whose nomination to the high court was rejected by the Senate and who is still smarting from it, calls Justice Brennan ''imperialistic.'' Judge Bork is a fan of the framers, those increasingly popular guys who actually made up the Constitution, and whose intent has become a matter of great moment to some jurists. We have judges who talk about the framers as though they played squash with them regularly. It reminds you of the proprietary, slightly arrogant way in which born-again Christians talk about God. They know Him; you don't.
The only thing I know about the framers is that they were general kinds of guys. They didn't go on about the right to put fences around your farmland, or the right to pull your children out of school if the teacher taught sedition. They used broad terms. Life. Property. Liberty. They designed a document that wouldn't go out of fashion. Written by men whose wives couldn't vote and whose country permitted slavery, it has transcended their time.
Justice Brennan made it transcendent. His work is full of empathy, and that is an uncommon thing, not only in a judge, but in our society. We rarely take government personally, and so I was surprised to feel personally disenfranchised by his loss. I prize what Justice Louis Brandeis called ''the right to be let alone.'' I'm an individual. One of the best friends an individual ever had has left the arena, and we will all miss him, whether we know it yet or not.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Gas Tax Hike Could Help Us Kick Auto Habit

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''The Broad Benefits of a Gasoline Tax Hike'' by Charles H. Percy (Op-Ed, July 8) makes many good points; however, I believe there are other compelling arguments the former senator did not mention.
While a large gas tax will cause people to buy more fuel-efficient cars and possibly drive less, the indirect effects could produce far more good. When one looks at the Japanese economy, two things stand out: one is a fairly high saving rate, the other is a small proportion of automobile ownership. I believe they are related. 
In Japan, even the typical auto worker either rides a train or rides a bicycle to work. Despite Japan's high food and housing costs, the Japanese still manage to save a signficant part of their income. Certainly, one reason for that is that they are not spending $10,000 to purchase a car every three years. Nor are they spending $1,000 a year on insurance. And we haven't even mentioned maintenance.
It is a particular flaw in the American psyche that most Americans consider the purchase cost of a car an investment, like a house or stocks and bonds. The truth, of course, is that it is just money thrown away.
Since Americans, unlike the Japanese, now require two workers to support a household, we tend to have two or more cars per household. After taxes, most of the extra earnings go to that second car, rather than to enriching the family.
A significant boost in the gas tax, combined with the national trend to establish and expand city rail lines (for example, Los Angeles and San Diego) should have the macroeconomic effect of increasing our saving rate. The money not spent on cars, a significant portion of which goes overseas, will be available to spend on such things as personal computers and home appliances.
However, the macroeconomic effects will not only be at the consumer level. With fewer cars purchased, the money otherwise invested in auto production can be shifted to investment in domestic electronics, aerospace and housing. These shifts will strengthen the American economy. Though there will be economic dislocation in the auto industry, the positive effects of investment in 21st-century technologies will far outweigh the problems.
 
EUGENE R. GOBBY
 Allston, Mass., July 10, 1990

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Blacks, Jews and 'This Thing That Is Suffocating Us'

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS

 BODY:
A black California official's comment earlier this month that leading Hollywood film and television studios and executives are guilty of ''Jewish racism'' set off the latest troubled round in the sometimes strained history of relations between blacks and Jews in the United States.
Jewish leaders were outraged that the comments by the official, Legrand Clegg, were made at the annual convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and were not immediately repudiated by its executive director, Benjamin L. Hooks. Dr. Hooks later said he did not attack Mr. Clegg's remarks because ''racism does exist in Hollywood, but we disavow the existence of Jewish racism.''
While that may have pleased Jews, who are tired of debunking the myth that Hollywood is a monolithic Jewish enterprise, the issue lingers in the minds of many blacks as an example of what might be called the disavowal syndrome, the expectation that black spokesmen should immediately repudiate each and every black person whose comments are considered offensive to Jews, whether blacks view the comment as valid criticism or as ill-founded opinion. Blacks object to the treatment and doubt its effectiveness as a remedy. 
''Anytime any black person says anything that is taken to have a tinge of anti-Semitism, everyone is asked to publicly repudiate them,'' said Mary Frances Berry, professor of history at the University of Pennsylvania and a member of the United States Commission on Civil Rights. She added that there were blacks even wondering whether they would have to repudiate Nelson Mandela during his recent visit to the United States because of his statements in favor of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
Mr. Clegg, who is chief deputy city attorney in Compton, Calif., heads a group called the Coalition Against Black Exploitation, which attracted attention in 1985 when it protested the portrayal of blacks, particularly black men, in the movie ''The Color Purple.'' Because he was included in the N.A.A.C.P.'s program, along with more than a hundred other speakers, his remarks became a national test for Dr. Hooks: yield to pressure to repudiate the statements and risk the scorn of younger and more militant blacks, or risk a clash with long-time allies.
The relationship between blacks and Jews, an alliance forged at the turn of the century, has grown increasingly rancorous over such incidents.
In the early 1900's, blacks and Jews, whose histories have been laced with periods of exploitation and discrimination, cooperated in the founding of the N.A.A.C.P., and in the 1930's and 1940's, black and Jewish lawyers framed civil rights lawsuits across the South. These bonds held through the boycotts and protests of the 1950's and early 1960's, but by the late 60's, blacks became more assertive and determined to plot their own course. Differences among blacks and Jews over affirmative action, black support for the Palestinians, Israeli links with South Africa and a growing perception that prominent black organizations and their leaders were beholden to Jewish interests also drove a wedge into the coalition.
Many blacks have said they resented the repeated questions about Israel that reporters put to Mr. Mandela during his recent visit, because he had expressed support for Yasir Arafat and the Palestine Liberation Organization. They took the questioning as another sign of what is perceived to be undue Jewish influence over the news media.
''I think the black community was upset about Mandela and the fact that he had to prove himself to the Jewish community,'' said Dr. Alvin Poussaint, the Harvard psychiatrist. ''Blacks are troubled by what they see as Jews' hard line; that if you are for Palestinian rights, you are anti-Israel. If you slip or make a mistake, you're painted as though all your thoughts are anti-Semitic. That's what blacks objected to about Mandela's treatment.''
Jews saw it differently. They felt that Mr. Mandela, a man of high moral authority, was using a double standard in praising Mr. Arafat, Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya and Fidel Castro of Cuba solely because they supported the African National Congress, while ignoring their human rights records with the explanation that he didn't have time to look into the affairs of other countries and that it didn't concern him.
''I think a cause of real consternation and some of the anger shown by Jews was the knowledge that Mandela's best and only friends in South Africa were Jews who went out on a limb for him; people like Helen Suzman,'' a longtime member of Parliament and campaigner against apartheid, said Rabbi Joseph Glaser, executive vice president of the Central Conference of American Rabbis.
''There were cries of anger and pain that somebody who we've been so supportive of could turn on us.''
Despite such frictions, it is easy to exaggerate the tensions between blacks and Jews. While blacks may have become more openly critical of Jews, the two groups continue to work together, despite disagreements, on important issues, most recently the passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1990.
 
Turning to Old Allies
''There is no absence of participation on the part of Jews when it comes to assisting on things that are of substance to black Americans and vice versa,'' said Harry Belafonte, the entertainer and civil rights campaigner, who helped organized Mr. Mandela's American visit.
''When we began organizing the Mandela trip, we turned to some of our traditional allies who are not black, whites of various persuasions and Jews, for assistance and expertise,'' Mr. Belafonte said. ''When we looked around for money, there were a number of people of the Jewish faith who were quite responsive to us. A lot of what went on was very low profile.''
Some blacks argue that a long-smoldering resentment is now more frequently expressed because blacks have more political and economic power and feel less dependent on the goodwill of Jews and other white liberals for financial support - long a staple of the civil rights community. The statements about Hollywood come, for example, as black entertainers and entertainment executives are having enormous impact on the popular culture. Spike Lee, Arsenio Hall, Oprah Winfrey and Bill Cosby, to name a few, have awakened blacks to their own power within the industry.
 
Becoming More Outspoken
Many believe the ascension of blacks to more powerful positions has enabled - some say freed -them to be more outspoken on any number of issues.
''The evolution of blacks in American history has set the stage in the present moment so that we will continue to be much more outspoken on all these issues than we have been in the past,'' said the Rev. Benjamin F. Chavis, executive director of the United Church of Christ's Commission on Racial Justice. ''Ironic as that appears, there are some in the Jewish community who want us to go back to a kind of rhetorical captivity where we would think one thing and not say it. Now more than ever we say what we think, and that has caused some tension.''
What many are saying at social gatherings and in public meetings is that blacks have grown impatient with the disavowal syndrome. While blacks are not monolithic in thought or actions, many are frankly unwilling to ostracize members of the race because they offend the sensibilities of another group.
According to Robert L. Woodson, president of the Center for Neighborhood Enterprise, a community-action program in Washington, leaders of traditional black institutions are particularly frustrated by such situations, because they serve as opportunities to alienate further the blacks in the inner cities who see groups like the N.A.A.C.P. as bought and paid for by white interests. ''Anybody or anything that thumbs their nose at whites, or those defined as white people, we must be for,'' Mr. Woodson said in describing the feelings of others in the black community.
Some say this perception accounts, in part, for the popularity of Minister Louis Farrakhan of the Nation of Islam and the Rev. Al Sharpton of New York City. They are seen as men who speak their minds with no concern about consequences. Such speech can feel liberating, much like the lyrics of militant rap groups like Public Enemy. Moreover, many blacks who condemn the anti-Jewish remarks of such figures are hard-pressed to dismiss some of their positions about black life in America.
''When Farrakhan talks about black solidarity and economic independence, you can't dispute that,'' said Dr. Hooks. ''I would look like a fool.'' Some blacks also argue that while Jews seem to use Israel as a ''litmus test'' of black people's loyalty, they often do not acknowledge similar tests on issues of concern to blacks. It has not been forgotten that prominent Jewish figures have been visible opponents of affirmative action, for example.
''Blacks feel very strongly about affirmative action being our litmus test,'' said Ms. Berry. ''Yet Jewish leaders don't repudiate things that interfere with black aspirations.''
But Jewish groups that have opposed affirmative action say they do so on a philosophical basis.
''We see race-based preferential treatment as unconstitutional,'' said Jill Kahn, associate director of legal affairs for the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, one of the groups that actively opposes affirmative action programs that rely on goals and timetables.
''I think that among all civil rights groups, there is agreement that the goal is equal opportunity and the removal of any barriers to employment,'' she said. ''It is the method used to achieve this goal that we disgree about.''
For some Jews, quotas are reminders of a painful period in history when such limitations were used to restrict the number of Jews permitted in colleges and businesses and when covenants kept them out of certain neighborhoods.
Indeed, Jews and blacks now diverge sharply on political priorities.
While a secure Israel is still of paramount importance to most American Jews, many blacks believe it is unconscionable to expect them to support Israel while that country continues to supply arms to the Government of South Africa, and they feel solidarity with Palestinians.
''I think even those blacks who don't know the history identify with the Palestinians because they see them as an oppressed people with no land,'' said Ms. Berry.
The pressure to disavow blacks' statements about Jews is doubly distasteful, in the view of some blacks, because it seems to offer so few rewards. Jesse Jackson's apology in 1984 for having referred to New York as ''Hymietown'' is an oft-cited example.
''The perception is that Jesse has been singled out for too long for his 'Hymietown' remark,'' said Harry A. Robinson, a black man who is senior vice president of the National Conference of Christian and Jews.
Mr. Belafonte said that blacks expect more of America's Jews. ''There are some of us who believe that, given the Jewish religious ethic and historical experience, there should be greater sensitivity expressed on the part of Jews to the experience and struggles that blacks have had, so we hold them more accountable,'' said Mr. Belafonte.
''Still, Jews played a large part in opening doors that had been closed to blacks,'' he said. ''Had they not, we would not have been able to achieve a lot that we have. We need to talk very seriously and completely about this thing that is suffocating us. This anti-black perception in Jews and this anti-Semitic perception in blacks. We'll all be better for it.''

HEADLINE: The World;
In Quebec, Yet Another Splintering

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
In English-speaking regions of Canada, many spy an enticing irony in the crisis currently gripping Quebec. In the midst of the French-speaking province's renewed debate over independence, it has found itself confronted by an angry minority of its own, Mohawk Indians. Just as Quebecers have claimed to be a ''distinct society'' within Canada, so too are we, the Mohawks have proclaimed from the armed camps they have established across two highways near Montreal. If Quebec is a nation unto itself, say the Mohawks, no less so are we.
As the confrontations between masked Mohawk ''warriors'' and 1,500 provincial police officers entered their third week at the tourist town of Oka, 20 miles northwest of Montreal, and at the Mercier Bridge, just to the south, there was more than political embarrassment for Premier Robert Bourassa and the province's other political leaders. Together, the premier and the leader of the separatist Parti Quebecois have urged a new relationship with the rest of Canada since the collapse last month of a constitutional deal that would have opened the way for Quebec to assume broad political autonomy. Many people expect a commission report this fall to recommend that Quebec become a nation-state, in practice if not immediately in law. 
If the Mohawks have their way, their fight for historical rights will not only cut across the province's push to be ''master in its own house,'' but could halt it altogether. For the Mohawks are at the cutting edge of a drive by Quebec's 50,000 Indians and Inuit - the people hitherto known as Eskimos - for the restoration of traditional lands accounting for 85 percent of the province. Even if the natives end up with a much smaller proportion of the province's 595,000 square miles, many of their leaders will oppose Quebec independence. ''Our spirit is North American,'' says Konrad Sioui, president of the Assembly of First Nations of Quebec and Labrador. ''We don't want to be squeezed inside another border. We have suffered enough from them already.''
For many of the 19 million Canadians outside Quebec, the Mohawks have thus become allies of a kind. And even among Canadians sympathetic to Quebec's desire to protect its French culture, there has been a lesson in the television images transmitted nightly from Quebec. In the Mohawks manning barricades with assault rifles and submachine guns, in the angry crowds of commuters who have burned straw effigies of Mohawks at the Mercier Bridge, and in the tense lines of police officers anxious for an opportunity to avenge the 31-year-old officer killed in an attempt to storm the barriers in Oka, these Canadians believe, there is a blunt reminder for Quebecers of the miseries that can flow from any overzealous assertion of minority rights.
Still, the broader implications of the Montreal confrontations hardly ease the anxieties of the rest of Canada. What is happening at Oka, where a dispute over expansion of a golf course has escalated into the most serious confrontation over native rights in decades, may prove to be a watershed in the fight for similar rights across the country. Native groups have asserted their historic rights to roughly half of the country. Along with most of Quebec, the land claims would give the natives title to almost all of British Columbia, to virtually the entire region around Ottawa, and to broad areas of the prairie provinces, southern Ontario, and the Atlantic region.
As a matter of demographic reality, the most that the Government and the courts are likely to concede is a fraction of what the native groups have demanded: together, Indians and Inuit account for barely 5 percent of the national population of 25.5 million: 470,000 are registered Indians, 750,000 are of Indian descent but live off reservations, and 33,000 are Inuit. But the crisis at Oka has served notice that the days of native passivity and patience are at an end. Some Indian leaders have compared the resort to armed defiance in Quebec to the rioting that swept the black ghettos of America in the 1960's, and they have said that Canada, in seeking a remedy, faces a generation of soul-searching and commitment.
 
Economic and Political Implications
For Quebec, the economic as well as political implications are far-reaching. Among the land claimed by the Indians is the James Bay region, in the far north, where Mr. Bourassa is forging ahead with a mammoth hydroelectric development that he envisages as the linchpin of Quebec's economic expansion. In the 1970's, the first phase of the project barely survived a legal challenge by Cree Indians. The $7.5-billion expansion seems likely to meet a still more resolute challenge. The Cree have said any effort by construction crews to drive to the area will be met with armed resistance.
For now, the shock to Canadians of seeing Quebec held ransom by armed gunmen has been compounded by reports that as many as 40 of the 150 armed men at the Oka barricades are Mohawks from the New York side of a native reservation, the St. Regis-Akwesasne, that straddles the Canada-United States border.
All the same, in demanding more land and the right to self-government, the Mohawks appear to have struck a responsive chord. The federal Government, while branding the Oka gunmen as ''criminals,'' has offered to buy the 55 disputed acres to turn them over to the local Mohawks. In British Columbia, which has hitherto refused to acknowledge any ''aboriginal rights'' to land but which has seen road and railway blockades multipy in sympathy with Oka, the premier has signaled that the province will move toward a more sympathetic stand. But only time will tell whether these more generous policies will hold once the implications of ceding large areas of land begin to sink in for the non-natvies.

Convertibles in France
Q. We want to rent a convertible in France to go from Lyons to Paris. - Jaci Murphy, New York
A. The four big car rental companies all have covertibles in France, but in limited numbers and not always at all locations. You are advised to reserve your car as early as possible. There is an additional 25 percent V.A.T. charge, unless noted. 
Hertz (800-654-3001) does have some Ford Escort convertibles in Lyons and Paris. The rate is $93 a day plus 85 cents for each kilometer; for a week it is $1,159 with unlimited mileage.
Avis (800-331-1084) has convertibles, Volkswagen Golf or Opal Kadett, only in Cannes, Nice and Antibes. The cost is $193 a day or $966 a week, both with unlimited mileage.
National's European affiliate, Europcar (800-227-3876), has Volkwagen Golf and Peugeot 205 convertibles available only in Nice and Marseilles. The daily rate is $88.58 a day plus 90 cents a kilometer; the weekly charge is $1,457 with unlimited mileage, including tax.
Budget (800-472-3325) has some convertibles in France, but a spokeswoman said that the company would not confirm rentals of convertibles because there were so few of them. It's a good idea, she said, to ask if one is available when you arrive.
 
New Orleans Jazz Festival
Q. How do I get on the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival's mailing list? Are there bed and breakfasts or inexpensive hotels in the French Quarter? - Hank Kornfeld, Mahopac, N.Y.
A. The festival will next place April 26 through May 6, 1991. If you contact the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival (1205 North Rampart Street, New Orleans, La. 70116; 504-522-4786) and give your name and address, you will be sent a brochure including a mail order form, when brochures become available.
Travel New Orleans (434 Dauphine Street, New Orleans, La. 70112; 800-535-8747) is the festival's official tour operator and sells packages that include housing, admission to the festival and transfers to the grounds from the French Quarter, where most of the hotels it works with are situated. Package details should be available by September. According to a representative, the least and most expensive hotels are booked first, as early as October.
Bed and Breakfast Inc. (800-749-4640) is a reservation service that represents about 50 homes in the New Orleans area, with rooms $36 to $226 a night. The New Orleans Hotel Association (330 Exchange Alley, New Orleans, La. 70130; 504-525-2264) will mail a free New Orleans Lodging Guide on request.
 
Vienna, Turkey, Yugoslavia
Q. We want to visit Vienna, Yugoslavia and Istanbul. We do not want to be with a group all the time but don't want to be totally on our own either. We would also like to make excursions outside the cities. - Renee Reed, Tulsa, Okla.
A.This is possible, but requires stitching together several programs offered by tour companies that combine some structure with plenty of time on your own in the places you wish to visit. You can make reservations on your own, using the example below, but a travel agent might know of similar options and could make travel arrangments connecting the packages.
One possibility is combining two packages offered by American Express, in Vienna (and other places) and in Turkey, with one offered by Pan Am Holidays in Yugoslavia. American Express (800-637-6200) has a city package that includes hotel, daily breakfast, a city sightseeing tour, and airport transfers. Participants are met at the airport by an American Express representative. There are packages of three nights,$169 to $439 a person, depending on hotel and six nights, $299 to $809, with charges for additional days. For more structure, and a chance to see other places, the company has what it calls a freelance package with three nights in Munich, two in Salzburg and three in Vienna. Travel between the cities, which is included in the price, is by bus, but in 1991 it will be by train. The package includes sightseeing tours in each of the cities, eight breakfasts, one lunch and two dinners. A host or hostess will be available at your hotel at certain times to provide guidance. The cost is $1,075 to $1,239 a person, depending on hotel. The prices do not include fare to and from the starting and finishing point.
These trips could be combined with an American Express package in Turkey. An Istanbul city package, $279 to $415, includes two half-day sightseeing tours and daily breakfast. A package with additional stops, ''Incredible Cappadocia,'' includes four nights in Istanbul, and a night each in Ankara and Nevsehir. The cost is $770 to $963 a person and includes air fare between the cities, nine meals (mainly breakfasts), two half-day Istanbul tours, a half-day tour of Ankara and a day-and-a-half tour of Cappadocia. There will be a host or hostess available at the hotel.
These tours can be combined with a Pan Am Holidays (800-843-8687) package in Yugoslavia. While these tours usually include air fare from New York, the company will sell just the land package. Those on a six-night ''Glorious Dubrovnik'' package add tours outside the city for about $30 each. The current cost is $680 to $980 a person, depending on hotel, going down to $280 to $580 a person the last two weeks in October. ''Yugoslavia as You Like It,'' six nights, can begin in Dubrovnik, Zagreb or Belgrade and includes an economy-size rental car with unlimited mileage and hotel vouchers for 74 cities. The land cost is $770 a person in the summer, down to $430 in late October.
 
Brancacci Chapel in Florence
Q. I plan to visit Florence in late September expressly to see the restored frecoes in the recently reopened Brancacci Chapel. However, I read that the chapel is being closed again for further work. When will it be reopened for public viewing? - C. H. Huvelle, Litchfield, Conn.
A. In the Church of Santa Maria del Carmine, the Brancacci Chapel, which reopened June 7, is still open, according to Florence city officials. However, if you wish to see the chapel and its frescoes, painted mainly by Masaccio in the 15th century, you will need to visit by Sept. 16. After then, officials will decide if the chapel's altar is to be moved and, if so, where. It is possible that the chapel will stay open after then, with some restrictions, but there is no guarantee. Groups of up to 30 visitors are allowed in each 20 minutes between 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Monday to Saturday and 1 to 5 P.M. on Sunday. (Closed Aug. 15.) The cost of a tour is about $4.30. Information: 055 211876.

The anti-Reagan forces will have to try harder. Extremes of income and wealth are a fact of capitalism, but one that is really beside Phillips's point. HEADLINE: On Language;
When Parentheses Are Transgressive

BYLINE: By Richard Bernstein; Richard Bernstein is a national cultural correspondent of The Times. William Safire is on vacation.

 BODY:
Rewriting the (Post)modern: (Post)colonialism / Feminism / Late Capitalism'' read the brochure advertising a conference that I attended at the University of Utah in March. The program was full of fashionable academic jargon - phrases like ''reified theory,'' ''(post)structuralist tropics'' and ''the racial subject'' - all of it standard lexical fare in the arcane world of literary criticism.
The parentheses were placed not only around words but also around parts of words. There was one paper titled ''Locating Un(re)presentable Desire: Narrational Transformations and Postmodern Man.'' Another was ''It's Not (Post) Until it's Post(ed): (Post)modernism and the Terminological Endgames of Terrorism.'' 
Trendy academic language has always kept me mindful of certain phrases from George Orwell's ''Politics and the English Language,'' particularly the one in which he likens the users of prefabricated jargon to ''cuttlefish squirting out ink.'' Yesterday, the cult terms were ''intertexuality'' and ''the signifier.'' Today, it's parentheses carving up words like scimitars.
But a few months before the Utah meeting, my skepticism was challenged. At the convention of the Modern Language Association, the major professional body for academic literary critics, I ran into Philip Auslander, a professor of English at the Georgia Institute of Technology. ''Why shouldn't literary critics have a technical language to express their ideas, in the same way that physicists or engineers do?'' he asked.
Why indeed? What the lit crits argue is that they are looking at the world in a new way, a way that requires the invention of a new language. Nobody objects to the linguistic innovations of Freud or Einstein, necessary to express meanings that nobody else had expressed before. Why should the acolytes of the great French post-structuralists, like Roland Barthes, Jacques Derrida and Michel Foucault, be any different?
And so I went to Utah scribbling words and phrases into my notebook and asking conferees to explain them. My first question concerned those parentheses.
''They show that there are discontinuities in the discourse,'' said H. Aram Veeser, of the English department at Wichita State University in Kansas, using a bit of lit-crit jargon to explain another bit. ''The parentheses are a way for the word to deconstruct itself on the page,'' he continued. ''It shows the word fragmenting into its different meanings and parts.''
Teresa Ebert, a conference organizer who teaches English at the University of Rhode Island, called the parentheses ''a denaturalizing term''; they are part of ''resistance post-modernism'' and ''transgressive strategies'' aimed at the status quo. In other words, the parentheses are in and of themselves a challenge to conventional and dominant assumptions, a way of catching the reader's eye and making him think again about meanings he had always taken for granted.
This forms a good part of the academic enterprise these days and informs much of the jargon. A powerful tendency in the age of deconstruction is to question the way culture has traditionally been examined. And so, at the M.L.A., for example, there are a lot of expressions being used to describe power and the way it is wielded through the ''texts'' of our society.
Our basic values constitute what is commonly called the dominant discourse. A very dominant discourse is a totalizing discourse, or sometimes a meta-narrative. The damage reputedly done to those outside the power structure might be referred to as ''the ravages of totalizing narratives.'' To be a rebel in this sense is to fight the meta-narrative. This gives rise to some quirky definitions. Kerry McKeever of the University of Idaho provided a new one at the Utah conference. ''Terrorism,'' she said, ''is a way of wounding the body of a dominant discourse.'' ON THE OPPOSITE ENDJU of the linguistic-political scale are a host of terms that describe those on the receiving end of ''patriarchal authority.'' Most common at the M.L.A. convention was the marginalized subject - ''subject'' having become the preferred lit crit term for person, self, individual. In Utah, the word subaltern took precedence.
Subaltern, made fashionable in some circles by a group of scholars from Calcutta who publish a journal called Subaltern Studies, refers to anybody who is low on the totem pole: the inhabitants of the third world, women, homosexuals, members of minority groups. Anyone outside of patriarchal authority is by definition a subaltern subject. Why subject? We are not selves, is the answer. We are subjectivities. An endless parade of impressions pummels our consciousness with inconsistency, indeterminacy, contradiction. Thus we, too, are not stable but always shifting. The word subject, a conferee said, puts the stress on process, rather than on fixity.
There are many other trendy terms. Commodified is very big; it refers to the tendency of capitalism to transform everything into a salable commodity. ''A commodified subjectivity'' is a way of looking at a world strongly influenced by late-20th-century materialism.
And then there is the frequent use of the suffix ''ality,'' which is tacked on to many words, usually adjectives but sometimes nouns. The various Utah sessions produced such ''-alities'' as postcoloniality, positionality, ideality, intentionality, temporality, globality, marginality, circumstantiality, potentiality, institutionality, paradoxicality, conditionality and traditionality.
''The suffix makes what was a temporary qualifier into a permanent feature of the landscape,'' Professor Veeser said. ''I mean, if you just use the word 'postcolonial,' you have to specify a postcolonial this or a postcolonial that. But if you use postcoloniality you give substance to that formerly abstract, helping term. Now, it is empowered as a word. It gains independence, clout all by itself.''
Why then positionality rather than, simply ''position,'' which is already a noun, already an empowered word, one with clout? I asked this question of Professor Veeser with a little vignette from the M.L.A. conference in mind. The members of a panel on the ''canonicity'' of Shakespeare were all sitting on the left side of a table, a fact that the panel chairman turned into a political metaphor. ''We're all on the left,'' he said. ''That's our positionality.''
The use of the suffix in this instance has to do with the complexities of the modern world, a world in which people can no longer be easily identified with some simple, overriding concept like economic class. Each person is embedded in a whole complex of sometimes contradictory positions. The word positionality in this sense says: nothing is as simple as it looks.
And so, the big question: Was this lingo squirted out by Orwell's cuttlefish or is it really useful? I contend that positionality is as inky as a word can get. And yet there is a seductive quality to some of this terminology: it has a cultish sensuousness to it. As the lit crits might put it, you become part of the transgressive, rather than the dominant, discourse. You are a member of the club.
