HEADLINE: NOTED WITH PLEASURE

 BODY:

Never Learned the Game of Life
When Jim Bouton's book came out in 1970, we were shocked when he implied that sportsmanship in pro ball is a contradiction in terms. Now, two decades later, we read the revised version with nothing more than a shrug. This is from ''Ball Four'' (Collier).
 Why do ballplayers have to take drugs and have girlfriends in the first place? This may come as a shock to some people but it's because they're human beings. Young human beings. Think of a ball player as a fifteen-year-old in a twenty-five-year-old body. 
Being a professional athlete allows you to postpone your adulthood. You grew up in Heroworld. Parents change the dinner schedule for you, teachers help with grades, coaches fawn over you, cops ask for an autograph and someone else buys the drinks. Or worse. As basketball great Bill Russell put it, ''most professional athletes have been on scholarship since the third grade.''
 
Persecuted by Pastiches
 When Hemingway was still alive, it must have been an uncanny feeling for him to see so many credible imitations of his style. It's conceivable that these pastiches contributed to his suicide. This latest example is from MacDonald Harris's novel ''Hemingway's Suitcase'' (Simon & Schuster).
 ''Oh, you're so clever. You're so omniscient. You always know about everything. How canal boats work. Which horses to bet on. And especially about women.''
''Oh, I know a lot more than that. Hunting and fishing. Military strategy. The psychology of cats. I've got the whole Paris Metro system in my head. . . .''
''Couldn't we get out of town? I'm fed up with everything. I'm so bored I could scream. All I do is sit in the park and read. . . .''
I was sorry that being with me didn't make her happy. I had thought she would enjoy living in Paris and all the things you could do there. But she came from the Middle West and she never got rid of that part of her. I knew that the way I had treated her was rotten but I couldn't do anything about it. She didn't like my friends, except for George, and he had gone back to America now. I didn't really know what she liked to do. I never found out.
 
Freud's Away, Analysts Play
While we think of the founders of psychoanalysis as a dour or frigid group, that's not how Alix Strachey saw them in Berlin in 1924. This is from ''Bloomsbury/Freud: The Letters of James and Alix Strachey 1924-1925,'' edited by Perry Meisel and Walter Kendrick (Norton).
 [Theodor] Reik, in a positive sweat of - of - what is it, eigentlich? He could hardly contain himself, his fat & his exhilaration. I can never make out whether it is pure joy in his breast or a pin in his bottom that makes him bound like a jelly & snort like a porpoise. . . . On the other side of me was [Sandor] Rado, who plied me with more wine; & then Dr. [Hanns] Sachs who shrieked literary criticisms at me across him. The speeches, the usual performance by [Ernst] Simmel, & some dreary attempts at song & joviality by [Hans] Lampl. Finally a moonlight walk in small groups - I, fatally enough, paired off with Simmel again; but he turned out to be really not so bad. . . . Lectures next day from 9-12. Train, 3d.-class . . . in the company of Sachs (with whom more literary conversation - but; he's been 3 weeks in Paris & never heard of Proust).
 
The Poetry of Precariousness
 Space, which promised so much for poetry, turns out to be ''not 'wild' enough,'' as if science had tamed it before poetry could get a grip. This is from ''The Moon and Us,'' one of many essays in ''Other People's Trades'' by Primo Levi (Summit).
 Is it perhaps too soon, do we only have to wait, will the poet of space come later? There is nothing to assure us of it. Aviation, the penultimate great leap, is already sixty years old, and has given us no other poet than Saint-Exupery and a step lower Lindbergh and Hillary: all three have drawn inspiration from precariousness, from adventure and the unforeseen. The literature of the sea died with ships under sail; the poetry of railroads never was born, nor does it seem thinkable. The flight of Collins, Armstrong, and Aldrin is too sure, too programmed, not ''wild'' enough for a poet to find nourishment in it.
 
The Literature of 'Inspired Ideas'
European literary critics talk more in terms of ''inspired ideas'' than of techniques. Here is Hans Mayer, a professor of literary history, reminiscing about novelists and how they used their ideas or let their ideas use them. This is from ''Franz Werfel: A Life in Prague, Vienna, and Hollywood'' by Peter Stephan Jungk (Grove Weidenfeld).
Werfel never knew how to be economical with his ideas; he used them, so to speak, raw. ''The task of a writer consists in being able to make something out of an idea,'' Thomas Mann said. But it was just that ''making'' that Werfel never managed. . . . For Werfel, the decisive things were the emotional aspect, the romantic idea, the lyrical substance - the power of language. He did have a language of his own! Unlike Stefan Zweig, who is simply an intolerably poor writer. Zweig blows himself up, he inflates ideas that he doesn't even have. Whereas Werfel is prodigal with his ideas but often doesn't know how to make anything out of them. He was an infinitely greater natural talent than Musil, but Musil is the infinitely more interesting writer. I think I know what Werfel lacked: he hardly ever questioned himself.

HEADLINE: Goodbye to All That

BYLINE: By LEON V. SIGAL; Leon V. Sigal is a member of the editorial board of The New York Times.

 BODY:

THE END OF THE COLD WAR
European Unity, Socialism, and the Shift in Global Power.
By Bogdan Denitch.
123 pp. Minneapolis:
University of Minnesota Press.
Cloth, $25. Paper, $10.95.
 
THE COLD WAR IS OVER
By William G. Hyland.
222 pp. New York: Times Books. $18.95. 
 
SOVIET UNION 2000
Reform or Revolution?
By Walter Laqueur.
With John Erickson, Paul A. Goble,
Edward Luttwak, Gur Ofer and Arthur Waldron.
201 pp. New York:
St. Martin's Press. $19.95.
Mikhail S. Gorbachev did not stand idly by and watch the Soviet empire in Eastern Europe disintegrate. He intervened to push the process along. He stayed the hand of Soviet military and K.G.B. forces in Eastern Europe, and in so doing paralyzed their indigenous allies. And he prodded Communist Party leaders in the Eastern-bloc countries to cede power to reform-minded colleagues and share it with non-Communists.
Perhaps he hoped that local Communists could reform themselves in time to hold on to power, but he was not prepared to prop them up militarily if they could not. Let Poland be Poland, he decided, knowing that to do otherwise would frustrate reform in the Soviet Union.
Today, Mr. Gorbachev's Russian Reformation rumbles on. The transformations of 1989 have brought hope for many, foreboding for a few and daunting questions for everyone. What caused those upheavals? What will they lead to? And how should the United States respond? These three books, each in its own unsatisfying way, look backward for answers. The authors interpret the past so differently that it's hard to imagine they all lived through the same events. Walter Laqueur and company in ''Soviet Union 2000'' and William G. Hyland in ''The Cold War Is Over'' are exponents of an American anti-Communist orthodoxy. Bogdan Denitch in ''The End of the Cold War'' espouses a European socialist orthodoxy.
In the American orthodoxy, Soviet Communism's implacable hostility to the West and its ideals is the enduring continuity. Mr. Gorbachev's five-year rule is the discontinuity, a temporary aberration born of economic necessity and renewed pressure from the West that has forced Moscow to pull back for what Mr. Hyland calls a ''breather.'' But, in fact, the Russian Reformation has gone far beyond that.
In socialist orthodoxy, the continuity is the growing convergence of democratic socialism and Christian democracy along Swedish lines. The discontinuity was the Communist seizure of power in the Soviet Union, and the later imposition of Soviet hegemony in Eastern Europe, matched by United States hegemony in Western Europe. Now democratic socialism, not capitalism, will triumph across Europe. Mr. Denitch, a professor of political sociology at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, was unusually prescient in anticipating the collapse of Communism in Europe, but as he himself concedes, the Poles and other Middle Europeans are showing surprisingly ''visceral'' hostility to economic arrangements that bear the name ''socialist.''
The sharpest disagreement comes over whether it took two to make the cold war. The American orthodoxy offers a simple, one-sided version of cold war history: Hitler destroyed the old order in Europe, allowing Stalin to impose dominion on the East. The United States was merely reactive, often not in a tough enough way. A gradual thaw began in 1962, but there were few opportunities for real accommodation until Mr. Gorbachev's arrival.
Socialist orthodoxy sees a much more complex, two-sided clash, with a potentially democratic socialist Europe caught in the middle. A militant United States, in this view, passed up opportunities to compromise with an increasingly defensive Communism.
The American orthodoxy would be on stronger ground in the argument had the United States tried accommodation and been rebuffed. It did not, a point on which Mr. Hyland and Mr. Denitch concur. But that suggests the cold war was much more two-sided than Mr. Hyland cares to acknowledge.
So was its end. What Mr. Hyland, the editor of Foreign Affairs, dismissively calls the ''Vietnam syndrome'' was the increased public resistance to cold war interventionism that began in the late 1960's. If ever there was a place where direct military involvement was a sure thing, Nicaragua in 1981 was it. But the tortured extraconstitutional ways that Ronald Reagan went about it were a clear sign of the spent power of anti-Communism, despite his cold war rhetoric and military buildup. And Leonid Brezhnev's reluctance to send the Red Army into Poland in 1980 sent a similar message about the waning power of Communism.
What is to be done in the Soviet Union now? Mr. Laqueur, the chairman of the International Research Council of the Center for Strategic and International Studies, and the other authors of ''Soviet Union 2000'' at least raise some key questions.
Reform has historically been imposed from the top down. Can democratic politics and competitive markets, which must be nurtured from the bottom up, ever take root? Especially if the populace associates them with disorder and privilege? Radical reformers in the Soviet Union blame Mr. Gorbachev for braking the pace of reform, but can he or any other leader impose radical reform on an increasingly fractious country?
Mr. Gorbachev himself sows division among potential opponents to keep them from coalescing against him. That secures him in power within the Kremlin. But can he extend his power beyond its walls? Not through a Communist Party now splintering over his policies. Not through a statist bureaucracy that he is beginning to dismantle. Not through leaders in the republics, who allied with him against Moscow's ministries but are now turning against him. Not through a K.G.B. divided between the forces of modernization and the forces of order. Maybe not even through the reform coalition, increasingly riven by disputes between moderates and radicals.
The Communist ideology that rationalized power and privilege for three generations has collapsed. What norms can take its place to provide the Soviet presidency and new governing institutions with legitimacy? Surely not nationalism, which pits republic against republic and neighbor against neighbor. Probably not democracy, whose supporters are confined largely to the urban intelligentsia, and whose practitioners are hard to find even there. Perhaps the rule of law, but it remains to be seen whether the rulers, let alone the people, will abide by its strictures.
With the historian's conceit that the past is forever prologue, the authors of these three books paper over radical discontinuity by looking for enduring continuity. But the Soviet future could well resemble no known past - in the Soviet Union or elsewhere.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: Notebook;
The Race That Isn't a Race

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Sparky Anderson, the dean of major league managers, knows a pennant race when he sees one, but he's not sure what he sees when he looks at the American League East.
''I don't know if we're in the race or nobody else wants to be in it,'' the Detroit Tigers' manager said. ''I never knew you could be five games under .500 and be in the race. It's really funny. I'm not sure why we're in it, but we are.''
An official of another American League East club had a similar reaction to the so-called race. ''We're in it,'' he said. ''God only knows why.'' 
Perhaps someone on or near that level of authority could explain why what is occurring in the division should be classified as a race. One definition of ''race'' is the act of rushing onward. In the American League East, teams appear to be going backward.
In the last month or so, the Toronto Blue Jays have lost 16 of 28 games and the Boston Red Sox have lost 18 of 27 games. Yet the Blue Jays entered yesterday's games in first place, the Red Sox in second only one game back. Despite that 12-16 stretch, the Blue Jays doubled their lead, from half a game to a full game.
In approximately the same period, Anderson's Tigers have lost 19 of 34 games but have lost only half a game in the standing.
''We started 11-22, and it looked like it might be another nightmare,'' said Anderson, whose 1989 team lost 103 games and finished 30 games from the top. ''But we won a few and slowly pecked away. We got to get to .500. If we can do that, we'll truly be in the race.''
The Tigers have not had a .500 record this season. Once they passed the first 10 days, the closest the Tigers have been to the break-even mark was the 33-34 record they had June 19. It is since then that they lost 19 of 34 entering yesterday's game.
The Milwaukee Brewers had a 32-34 record June 23 and had lost 18 of 30 before yesterday. In that 30-game span, they lost only a game and a half in the standing. They had, in fact, fallen 11 games back and presumably out of the race, but the Blue Jays and the Red Sox magnanimously - not to mention ineptly - let them back in the race.
The Cleveland Indians were at .500, 37-37, on July 1 but then lost 15 of 24. Yet they remained six and a half games from first.
The Baltimore Orioles have probably benefited the most from the inability of the top two teams to create space between them and the other would-be contenders. The Orioles were at .500, 29-29, and three games out June 12. Then they won only 6 of 22 games and plummeted 11 games back. In the last three weeks, though, the Orioles have won 13 of 18 games, gaining ground on the leaders, who seemed to be running in place.
In reality, they weren't running in place; they were rushing backward. The Red Sox, in that same period, have had a 6-13 record, the Blue Jays 7-9.
''There's nobody overwhelming,'' Anderson said in an understatement from the master of overstatement. ''I like Toronto very much; you have to when you look at them. I like Boston as far as their offense. But it doesn't look like anybody is strong enough to pull away from everybody else. I don't think it'll take much over .500. We've played 100 games and no one has run away. If you haven't proven it by then, you're not going to run away.''
What does he think of the Tigers' chances of staying in the race in their effort to soar from last to first? ''As long as nobody cheats and wins 8 or 10 in a row,'' he said, ''we could be there.''
 
Beyond Hope
 No matter how poorly the American League East leaders have played, they could not possibly be bad enough to drag the Yankees into the race.
By sweeping a doubleheader from the Indians Friday night, the Yankees of Stump Merrill matched their victory total - 18 - under Bucky Dent. The Yankees played 49 games with Dent as the manager. They had played 47 under Merrill entering last night's game.
The records are remarkably similar, suggesting that it's not the manager but the team. George Steinbrenner, in making the change, said that he had made a mistake, that Dent wasn't ready to manage in the major leagues. What does the Yankees' subsequent lack of success under Merrill mean? That after 10 years of managing at every level in the minors he wasn't ready?
 
Earning His Salary
 Jose Canseco hit seven home runs in a recent span of seven games in eight days. Only five teams hit more home runs in that time, and they each played eight games. (The rest of the Oakland batters hit nine.) The Chicago Cubs hit only one home run, by Ryne Sandberg, while the Houston Astros (Bill Doran, Bill Doran) and the Chicago White Sox (Robin Ventura, Carlton Fisk) each hit two.
Canseco hit two in a game three times in that period, giving him six such games this season. The Athletics, with five by Mark McGwire, have had players hit two or more home runs in a game 14 times. Canseco himself has done it more often than 19 of the other 25 teams and has done it as often as three teams.
 
Drought Report
 A couple of Andys found Friday night to be dandy.
When Andy Hawkins won for the Yankees in Cleveland, it was his first victory since May 6. He had labored the longest of any regular starter in the majors without a victory. In between victories, he made 12 starts, losing five (including a no-hitter) and finishing with no decision in the other seven.
Andy Benes of San Diego won the same night. He had not won since June 4, having failed in eight starts (three losses, five no-decisions).
Marty Clary of Atlanta hasn't won since May 2, but he was out of the Braves' rotation for a while so his drought has reached only nine starts (seven losses, two no-decisions).
Chris Bosio of Milwaukee hasn't won since May 20 (10 starts). Mike Bielecki of the Chicago Cubs and Jeff Ballard of Baltimore haven't won a start since May 27, although Bielecki won in relief July 20 and Ballard, too, has gone on relief, starting only once in the last month.
Most notable among starters who have victory droughts is Mark Langston of California. Langston, best known for the five-year, $16 million contract the Angels gave him as a free agent last winter, hasn't won since June 5. He has lost eight starts and emerged with no decision twice.
 
Ryan Speaks and Owner Listens
 Nolan Ryan's influence in Texas, at least with the Rangers, extends beyond his no-hitters and his strikeouts and his victory total. The boss listens to him.
George W. Bush is the boss, and earlier this season he was hearing a lot of talk about Tom House, the team's pitching coach, who has introduced some unconventional training methods, such as throwing a football.
''People started getting on House,'' Bush said. ''Some called him an eccentric, a radical. The talk was maybe he was not training our people properly.''
Those raising the question cited two glaring examples: Jose Guzman and Edwin Correa. Guzman hasn't pitched since 1988 because of shoulder problems. Correa also had shoulder problems and did not pitch for the Rangers for two and a half seasons before leaving them as a free agent last winter and signing with Los Angeles.
''It concerned me,'' Bush said. ''I'm not at all skilled in evaluating Tom House so I went to my friend Nolan Ryan and said, 'Does this guy know what he's doing?' He said, 'Absolutely.' He believes in Tom 100 percent. That stopped my inquiry. If Nolan Ryan speaks highly of him, that's good enough for me.''
 
Labor Milestone
 Promising sign of improved labor relations:
 For the first time in 10 years, labor representatives of the owners and the players have managed to publish their labor agreement in printed booklet form.
The last one was printed after the 1980 agreement but was promptly outdated by the agreement the next year on compensation for free agents. No booklet was printed then, after the 50-day strike, nor in 1985, after a new agreement ended the two-day strike.
The new contract has been published, inside a powder-blue cover, only four months after the agreement was reached.
Possible further sign of improved labor relations:
Charles O'Connor, the owners' chief labor representative, and Donald Fehr, the union chief, will have a series of meetings beginning Tuesday with George Nicolau, the arbitrator, to negotiate a settlement on the damages the owners owe the players for their collusion against free agents.
The negotiations won't be easy because the principals will be talking about hundreds of millions of dollars. If they can reach agreement, it would bode well for future relations. If they can't, the matter would go back to Nicolau for a decision and their efforts to put their differences behind them would suffer.
Either way, the owners will pay dearly for the ill-conceived conspiracy. It could cost them $250 million or more, averaging nearly $10 million or more a club. That's not what the owners had in mind when they hired Peter Ueberroth as commissioner to improve their economic status.

HEADLINE: Golf Course Development Gets Rougher

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
TO the 222 million Americans who do not golf, the line that forms before dawn at the Tamarack Golf Course in East Brunswick, N.J., may seem eerie, perhaps even cult-like. But to many of the nation's 25 million golfers, such bleary-eyed rituals are par for the course.
''You want to play, you fight the crowd,'' said Malcolm McEwen, a 67-year-old New Jersey retiree and an avid golfer for 50 years. His Saturday regimen brings him to Tamarack at 3:30 A.M. He then waits more than two hours to tee off. ''It has never been so hard to get on a course,'' he added. Mr. McEwen's frustrations are rooted in two conflicting trends. One is the rising value of land. In urban and suburban population centers, where the lines to tee off are the longest, the great real estate rush of the 80's made large undeveloped parcels suitable for new golf courses scarce. Many existing courses have been eliminated as developers subdivided them for homes and offices. But just as land values have boomed, so has golf. Ten million more Americans turned out at courses across the country last year than 10 years earlier. 
The result is that one of the nation's most popular sports - and its most land intensive - is in a real estate squeeze. As golfers queue up for hours, developers and architects have spawned a small new industry trying to satisfy the clamor for more fairways and greens.
''I don't see any possibility that government can add many more public courses,'' said Jim Evans, superintendent of five courses at the Bethpage State Park on Long Island, where weekend players now begin arriving in campers at 9:30 the night before they tee off. Like the Tamarack Golf Course, which is owned by the county, the Bethpage courses are in particularly high demand because they are open to the public and inexpensive.
To be sure, many new golf courses have been built, and more are planned. The National Golf Foundation, a trade group, said golf-course development had proceeded slowly and steadily in the 80's, expanding the number of courses to 13,738 last year from 12,849 in 1980.
But it added that as land values rose, many existing courses were under intense pressure from home builders and office developers. Although 260 new courses opened last year, 100 others were lost, mainly to other forms of development.
Developers have added hundreds of courses by building them in ''golf communities'' - large residential developments in which homeowners pay a premium for a view of the links. If they play, they also have a private course at their disposal.
Examples of the golf communities abound. In Victor, N.Y., 15 miles south of Rochester, work is under way on Cobblestone Creek, a 412-acre project with an 18-hole golf course and 282 homes that will be priced from $350,000 to $650,000.
In Carlsbad, Calif., 30 miles north of San Diego, work has begun on Aviara, a 1,000-acre complex with an 18-hole course and 2,000 condominiums, town houses and detached homes priced from just under $300,000 to just under $600,000.
''In many cases, it just isn't economically feasible to build a course unless you can sell a lot of homes in the same development,'' said Geoffrey S. Cornish, an Amherst, Mass., architect who has designed courses across the country.
The economics are straightforward: a full-size 18-hole course takes at least 140 acres of land, and often more if part of the land is broken up by water, wooded areas that cannot be cut down, or other parts of the landscape that must remain undisturbed. Around New York, Boston, Los Angeles and other large cities, suburban land goes for $50,000 to $100,000 an acre, and sometimes more, meaning that the cost of the raw land would be at least $7 million.
Many developers of golf communities have built courses to satisfy municipal or state requirements for open space in their housing developments. They also charge enough for the homes to recoup their costs. Others are trying to capitalize on golf's growing popularity among business people by building courses as part of office complexes and conference centers.
''GOLF is becoming more intertwined with business activity, not the least of which is between American and Japanese executives,'' said Frithjof Lunde, director of planning for the Stabler Land Company, a Pennsylvania development concern that is spending $5 million to build an 18-hole course as part of a 1,800-acre office complex four miles east of Allentown, Pa.
Although rare, private courses that are not part of bigger real estate development, and are operated for members only, are still being built. In Jackson Township in central New Jersey, for example, Richard Sambol and his son, Herb, spent 10 years assembling a 400-acre tract and in 1987 opened the first 18 holes of the exclusive Metedeconk National Golf club. An additional nine holes are now under construction.
The developers declined to say how much they paid to acquire the land and build the club, but one aspect of the project sets its apart from most other new courses - it is intended as a magnet for corporate wealth.
Memberships cost more than $50,000 and many members are senior executives. One selling point is that they can fly to the course's private landing pad in their corporate helicopters from New York City, 120 miles to the northeast.
''We appeal to a special market niche,'' Herb Sambol said. ''Because of the economic and regulatory environment, the number of new courses is going to decrease and they are going to become more expensive for everybody.''
Even where land and money are available, building new golf courses or expanding existing ones is posing difficult political and environmental problems.
In an extreme example, the attempt to expand a course in the Canadian community of Oka, 40 miles west of Montreal, led to violence this month. Mohawk Indians, protesting that the expansion was planned on sacred ground, put up a blockade to keep bulldozers away, and on July 15 engaged in a fierce gun battle with law-enforcement officers. One officer was killed. Nothing similar has occurred in the United States, but legislative and community debate is intense over whether golf courses are the best use of large tracts of land. Some officials maintain that denser residential or commercial development is preferable because it generates more taxes, while others want undeveloped land kept just as it is.
Environmental laws are also a factor. Increasingly stringent rules on the use of pesticides and fertilizers, development in low-lying wetlands areas, and the protection of scarce plants and wildlife are standing in the way of some new courses.
''There is a growing awareness of the demand for new courses, but they are difficult animals to develop,'' said John Rossi, chief executive office of Gold Services, a subsidiary of the National Golf Foundation in Jupiter, Fla., which was formed last year to advise communities and developers on golf-course development.
The sport's popularity shows little sign of falling off. Several factors are bringing more players into the game, including the aging of the baby-boom generation, the rapid increase in the number of women who play regularly and steady growth in the number of retirees who have more time to learn the game, or play more often.
Even with increased investment in new courses, Mr. Rossi said, ''We aren't going to catch up with demand.''
The greatest demand is for courses open to the public, where players pay a daily fee or membership dues that are far less expensive than those charged by most country clubs and private courses. Of the nation's current inventory of courses, the National Golf Foundation said half are private and charge a daily fee, as do the 15 percent that are municipally owned. The rest are for members only.
The difficulties of developing municipal courses - even where land is available - are illustrated on Cape Cod, where the Town of Barnstable, which includes Hyannisport, expects to complete an 18-hole course by the spring of 1992. If it opens on schedule, the course will have been eight years in the making.
''The course has been a huge issue up here,'' said Joseph O'Brien, a Barnstable insurance broker who is heading a town committee in charge of developing the course. ''We have people on both sides of the coin. Some were sure that we should go after the kind of development that would bring in more money. The environmentalists didn't want the land touched.''
Part of the incentive to build the course in the central Cape Cod township, was that a wealthy local family of golf enthusiasts made the land for the course available cheaply. After Barnstable's town fathers gave preliminary approval for a course in 1985, the family agreed to sell the town its undeveloped 154-acre parcel for $15,000 an acre, far below what the land would have brought for commercial or housing development. But environmental questions became more complicated than the economics. As in most golf course developments, water became a critical issue because of the huge amounts necessary to sprinkle greens and fairways, and because of the potential damage to underground water tables from pesticides and fertilizers. Since Cape Cod relies on one aquifer for its drinking water, part of which lies beneath the Barnstable site, exhaustive planning was required.
Town officials said an environmental impact review determined that any threat to the aquifer could be avoided by careful use of chemicals, and by making sure they were stored on part of the property that did not sit over the underground water supply. But environmental studies revealed other problems - scarce and endangered species that required protection under state law.
That meant a series of changes in the course's design. Fairways were bent around areas where sand plain flax, Nuttall's milkwort and other protected plants grow. Holly trees were transplanted. To meet state rules, when the course opens, hay bails used for erosion and siltation control will be removed each spring to allow the migration of mice and other rodents.
Stephen Seymor, Barnstable's project manager, said the cost of environmental studies, architects' fees and construction would total $4.3 million, nearly double the amount the town paid for the land. When the course opens, Mr. O'Brien said, the town plans to offer memberships to residents for $400 to $500 a year.
Although they confront many hurdles, developers have seized upon golf communities as a way of marketing expensive homes. The approach has many variations, but is based on a premise that people will pay a hefty premium for their houses if they can look out over fairways and greens.
The first golf communities were built long before World War II, but the development strategy gained much of its momentum in the 1980's. And while recent studies by the National Golf Foundation and others have shown that fewer than half of those who buy homes in the communities are active golfers, the appeal is well established.
MR. CORNISH, the golf-course architect, said that in many parts of the country developers have been able to charge 35 percent more for homes beside a golf course.
Still, the golf communities are not easily built, particularly if they are on environmentally sensitive land. One example is in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., where a development group from Atlanta last year opened the Old Marsh Golf Club as the first phase of a development that will include 213 homes.
The developers, hoping to build a course and luxury homes on unusually pristine land, chose a site with an uncommonly sensitive environment. Their 450-acre tract is adjacent to a state wildlife refuge that is home to a host of protected species, including sandhill cranes, Southern bald eagles, alligators and deer.
Ground water from the marshy refuge flows directly into the Florida Everglades, the main source of drinking water for South Florida. The means any hazardous runoff from the course would find its way into human consumption, as well as that of wildlife.
David Pearson, a spokesman for the club, said the Atlanta developers and their architect, Peter Dye, spent five years designing and redesigning the course to obtain government approvals and avoid environmental damage. The project required many unusual construction techniques: at one point, teams of college students were hired to painstakingly plant marsh grass strand by strand in shallow lakes that had been excavated along fairways.
Drainage from the fairways was also a critical issue, he said. Unlike other courses, where the fairways are designed to allow rain water run-off at their sides, those at Old Marsh are designed with drains and underground channels so that rain water is trapped and filtered.
With work on the course complete, Mr. Pearson said half of the building lots in the development have been sold. Buyers have the option of building homes with their own architects, but houses put up speculatively by the Old Marsh developers are priced from $550,000 to $1.2 million.

HEADLINE: Computers Slowing the Pace of Permits

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
AT 10 A.M., dozens of people are milling about the hallways on the fifth floor of 60 Hudson Street, the lower Manhattan office of New York City's Buildings Department. Some are standing on lines, chatting. Others are leaning against tables or sitting on the floor, reading newspapers or doing crossword puzzles. All are waiting to speak with city examiners and clerks to process applications for building permits and certificates of occupancy.
Some, like Judith A. Faulkner, an expediter who represents architects and engineers, have been there since 5 or 6 A.M. They arrive in the dark to sign up before the office opens for 10-minute appointments to begin the filing process. By late morning, the waiting list has grown to 123 names. 
Architects and expediters say that these traditional inconveniences are nothing compared to new obstacles that have resulted from a computerized filing system installed in late March by the Buildings Department in Manhattan.
It now takes much longer to obtain the permits that are required before renovations or new construction can begin and the certificates that are needed before a new building can be occupied, expediters and architects said. The new system is more cumbersome and inflexible than the one it replaced, they said, and it is adding to the cost of applying for permits and of building in New York.
They say it used to take an average of a week to 10 days from the initial filing of an application, which is called prefiling, until a building permit was issued. Since the computer system was installed, they contend, it takes three to six weeks.
''They took a system that did not work very well and made it worse,'' Ms. Faulkner said. ''Now the old days seem like paradise.''
Stewart D. O'Brien, a deputy commissioner in the Buildings Department, said some delays were inevitable as the city made the switch. He contended, though, that adjustments had been made. Mr. O'Brien said the new system had reduced drastically the number of forms that applicants must file and had made applying for permits more rational and efficient.
Many complaints, he said, stem from the fact that people were familiar with the old system. ''It's been a certain way for 20 or 30 years and people are used to the old forms,'' he said. ''When you take a system and in effect turn it upside down, you are going to get a lot of resistance. Is it perfect? No. That's why we are making changes. But it is opening up the process.''
Architects and expediters who frequently apply for permits at the Buildings Department's Manhattan office disagreed sharply. They said the new system was less efficient and more inflexible than the one it replaced.
Andrew G. Antoniades is an architect who is president of the Architects' Council, which works with city agencies on behalf of the profession. He said the new system had cut down ''on a certain amount of paperwork,'' but that it had created significant new hurdles.
''I am getting a barrage of complaints about the system,'' Mr. Antoniades said. ''They have lengthened the process and complicated it.''
Many architects and expediters said it now takes a week or two after they file applications for city workers to punch the information into the computers. Only then can applications go to examiners for a substantive review. In the past, they said, an examiner would review an application within a day of its filing.
Many if not most applicants have to amend their filings, both to meet objections from the city and to revise plans. The new system has no provision for amending applications, many architects and expediters said, so that each time a change is required they must begin the filing process over again.
Many expediters and architects said they were forced to increase their fees, because of the additional time they have to spend pushing applications through the system. The delays have increased other costs for building owners and those who rent commercial space.
MS. FAULKNER cited one client, an optician who she said is paying $7,000 a month to rent an office suite. Because of delays in processing his application for a permit, he cannot start the renovation of his new office and so cannot use it, she said. And, of course, he must continue to pay the rent.
Mr. O'Brien, the deputy commissioner, said the backlog on entering applications into the computer had been trimmed, and that it now takes ''three days or less'' for a complete application to be typed into the computer. He also contended that the long daily waiting lists for appointments to begin the application process had been reduced by some small procedural changes.
Mr. O'Brien accused some expediters of having signed the daily waiting lists several times to create a misimpression that delays were worse than they really were. ''They were creating a list so imposing that anyone who walked in at 9 in the morning would say, 'I'm not spending my entire day here,' '' Mr. O'Brien said. ''Some of the expediters have been portraying things in this way because it's in their economic interest.''
The same computer system was installed last year in the department's offices in Queens and the Bronx. Mr. O'Brien said similar complaints were heard during those transitions. ''This is a major change for the industry and for us,'' he said. ''It's a useful management tool. We just have to hang tough until it is entirely implemented.'' Mr. O'Brien said he expected that things will soon be running more smoothly.

HEADLINE: Rival Proposals for Purchase of Jay Land

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

 BODY:
A LONG-AWAITED decision by county legislators over acquisition of the Jay Property in Rye may face yet another delay, political leaders indicated last week, even though two proposals offering a choice of action are now officially before them.
One plan, by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, would have the county buy 10 acres of the 23-acre site for a negotiated price of ''up to $6 million.'' The land was once owned by the family of John Jay, the first Chief Justice of the United States and a two-term New York Governor.
As part of the O'Rourke plan, the Jay Coalition, representing preservationists, environmentalists and others who have long sought to prevent development of the site, would be responsible for all costs of rehabilitation and upkeep of a 152-year-old mansion on the grounds.
The 1838 Greek Revival structure was built by the jurist's son, Peter, on the site of his father's boyhood residence. Known as the Peter Jay House, it has been empty for nearly a decade and is in need of extensive renovation. 
The alternative plan, put forward by Legislator Diane A. Keane, Republican of Rye and the Board of Legislature's majority leader, would have the county acquire the entire 23 acres through eminent domain. This plan has the backing of the Jay Coalition.
 
'A Two- or Three-Month Delay'
TThe state, Mr. O'Rourke said, has pledged $4 million, either as part of the $6 million purchase price that the County Executive said he had negotiated with the owner, Diane G. Millstein, or as part of a condemnation price, which would be determined in court.
But condemnation means ''a two- or three-month delay, at least,'' said Katherine S. Carsky, the Yonkers Republican who heads the pivotal Budget Committee, ''because the state says it will not provide its $4 million share until an appraisal confirms that the land is worth that much.''
The rival plans surfaced more than a week ago at an unusual news conference, where Mr. O'Rourke argued for his 10-acre purchase, Mrs. Keane pressed for her alternative and each criticized the other's plan. In the end, both proposals were sent to the Board. Last Monday, the Board accepted the competing plans and, without comment, referred them to the Budget Committee. An informal poll of legislators indicated no consensus for either proposal, with some undecided, a few in favor of purchase and several backing condemnation.
Nine votes, or a simple majority on the 17-member board, are required for either purchase or condemnation, and 12 votes are needed if the county raises its share, as it said it would, through the sale of bonds. If the amount is more than $10 million, approval also is required in a referendum.
A county appraisal last year put the value of 23 acres at $6.9 million, or roughly half the $13.9 million that Ms. Millstein had been seeking in negotiations for sale of the entire site. Mr. O'Rourke said in introducing his plan that Ms. Millstein is no longer interested in selling all of it.
Last year, the city of Rye assessed the 23-acre property at $612,500, or the equivalent of $13.6 million at market value, according to the Rye Assessor, Philip J. McGovern. He said it was an increase of 63 percent over the 1988 assessment of $375,000, equivalent to $6,087,000.
 
'Proper Value' on the Property
''It had been underassessed because we were waiting for this property to get through the planning and development stage,'' Mr. McGovern said. ''She was holding a piece of vacant land, which meant other taxpayers were subsidizing it, so we put the proper value on the property.''
He said Ms. Millstein's initial proposal was for ''office buildings and a conference center,'' but she later applied for permission to build 39 homes on half-acre lots. He said Ms. Millstein paid $1.2 million for the property in 1983.
The Jay Coalition, which claims the support of 61 environmental, historic preservation and civic organizations in the state, has fought development of the property, in part as a means of preserving the adjacent Marshlands Conservancy, a 137-acre coastal sanctuary owned by the county.
Some legislators indicated that they favored Mr. O'rourke's plan because it included a negotiated price, rather than the ''open ended'' nature of the condemnation cost. Under the O'Rourke plan, the county's $2 million share would be raised through the sale of bonds and the county would be responsible for closing costs.
The O'Rourke proposal also states that the Jay Coalition would not only be responsible for the restoration and upkeep of the Greek Revival mansion, but that Millstein Associates, the current owner, would have the right to repurchase the mansion for $1 million if the building was not restored within two years of the transfer of title.
Helen W. Paschal, a coalition leader, said Mr. O'Rourke ''assumed a commitment from the Jay Coalition that he knows full well was made contingent on acquisition of the entire property.'' She emphasized the word ''entire.'' Eva Stern, a coalition member who attended the news conference, said afterward that the County Executive's proposal was ''a slap in the face.''
She said the funds needed by the coalition to restore the mansion would come from preservationists who might resist contributing if the property had been ''compromised,'' by which she said she meant ''breaking up the historic district, which contains several properties, one of them being the Jay property in its entirety.''
 
Other Historic Properties
Other properties in the district, besides the Marshlands Conservancy, include the three-acre Jay Cemetery; Lounsberry, a 13.5-acre parcel owned by the city of Rye; and Whitby, 110 acres including the Rye Golf Club owned by the City of Rye.
Ms. Stern said there was probably no way the coalition could approach agencies that provided grants for preservation and upkeep ''until we've got the property,'' meaning acquisition by the county. She said she did not know if any grants would be available if only a portion of the property was acquired.
Several legislators said they preferred condemnation. Stephen P. Tenore, Republican of New Rochelle, thought that partial acquisition would be a bad precedent for the county. Echoing a sentiment voiced by others, he objected to the ''negotiated'' price, ''which comes down to $600,00 to $700,000 an acre.''
Legislator Timothy S. Carey, Republican of Montrose, wondered ''how the $6 million negotiated price for 10 acres sat with the county's own $6.9 million appraisal last year for all 23 acres.'' He also wondered whether the O'Rourke proposal was even feasible. ''Does it protect the Marshlands?'' he asked.
 
Healthiest Tidal Marsh in County
Environmentalists say the preserve has the largest and healthiest tidal marsh in the county, and that the construction of houses, with the attendant loss of wooded area, would jeopardize the quality and quantity of water flowing into the marshlands, threatening the ecosystem that makes it so unusual in a suburban area.
John E. Hand, the Yorktown Heights Republican who is chairman of the Board, said he was ''leaning'' toward Mr. O'Rourke's proposal, ''although some people on this Board don't like the price he negotiated.'' On the other hand, condemnation is ''even scarier, because that price can be open-ended.''
Herman Keith, a Yonkers Democrat, said he was not supporting condemnation ''because there would be no way to anticipate the final cost'' and ''we could pay much more than $6 million,'' he said. Ernest D. Davis, a Mount Vernon Democrat, was similarly wary of condemnation.
''The state says it's in for $4 million, but I'm not sure I'd step into the ring with the state backing me up, especially in these times of budget problems,'' he said. ''What if it comes in at $10 million - we'd have the state's $4 million and our $2 million, but where's the rest coming from? I'm not sure we can afford to gamble.''
 
Land for Future Generations
Martin L. Rogowsky, a Democrat of Harrison, said he favored condemnation. ''If we were totally in the dark, it would be one thing, but we're starting with a county appraiser's figure of $6.9 million for 23 acres, and since then the real estate market has softened considerably.''
''We have the chance to preserve a valuable piece of land for generations,'' Mr. Rogowsky said. ''And if I can support a $5 million bond act for new jail cells, I can vote for this proposal.''
Edward J. Brady, Republican of Thornwood, favored neither alternative and Sandra R. Galef, an Ossining Democrat and the Board minority leader, said she was undecided, especially about the firmness of the state's commitment. ''We have to know if the $4 million is really available,'' she said.
Patricia V. Hotchkiss, Democrat of a Bedford, and Daniel P. Thomas, a Yonkers Republican, raised similar questions about whether the 10-acre acquisition would be enough to provide the environmental protection.
 
Condemnation Could Triple Price
Andrew A. Albanese, the Eastchester Republican, said he was not looking favorably at condemnation ''because it can end up a lot higher than what we are prepared to spend,'' he said. ''We were told that condemnation awards could be three times the assessment figure.''
Bernard D. Fischman, a condemnation lawyer with the Manhattan firm of Shea & Gould, said it depends on the evidence, but ''normally, if you've got a reputable expert, the valuation, the final decision, is close to the range of the experts.''
''The thing that hurts the owner more than anything else is the purchase price paid for the property. For owners to collect more than they paid, they have to prove that the property appreciated in value since it was purchased,'' he said. Appreciation can measured in physical improvements, in a neighborhood that has appreciated in value or through inflation.
 
HOW THE PROCESS OF CONDEMNATION WORKS
Marilyn J. Slaatten, the County Attorney, and Bernard D. Fischman a condemnation lawyer with the Manhattan firm of Shea & Gould, outlined the process of condemnation that is being considered as an alternative in acquiring the Jay Property in Rye. In condemnation, they said, a government body can use its right of eminent domain to acquire property for a fair-market value regardless of whether the owner is a willing seller.
Once the Board of Legislators authorizes a condemnation procedure, the Board of Acquisition and Contract becomes the condemning body and its first task is to hold a hearing on the public use and benefit of the action.
Within 90 days of the hearing, the condemner - which would be the county, in this case - must publish findings of fact, setting forth the impact on the environment and establishing that the condemnation is for a public purpose. Anyone opposed to it has 30 days to file an appeal with the Appellate Division.
Such an appeal is expedited, going to the head of the court calendar. The judges decide if the findings were properly determined, and a decision is likely within two or three months. The court can approve the findings, order new findings or set them aside, which would mean the case is over - there would be no condemnation, unless the Court of Appeals decided differently.
Once the right to condemn is upheld, the county must make an advance offer in the amount of its approved appraisal. If the condemner has two appraisals, it must pay the higher amount. It is called an advance payment and it does not affect the owner's right to seek more money.
The case now would go to a trial court, where a judge fixes value. At this point, before the value is determined, the court orders the filing of a map and the transfer of title to the county.
At the trial, each side brings in experts, and for the most part the valuation is based on ''comparable sales.'' Since the property in this case is somewhat unique, with no closely comparable sale, it becomes a battle of experts. The property is valued for its ''highest and best use.''
The county cannot limit its liability, saying it will not exceed a certain amount, and must pay whatever amount the court fixes. The county can back out any time until title to the property changes hands, although in that case it must pay the property owner's expenses.

HEADLINE: Fewer Relocations, and Each Costs More

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
WHEN a 38-year-old engineer in Minneapolis was offered a new position in the New York City area, he hesitated, although professionally it was a big career advancement.
''He was worried about leaving his $160,000 house in a suburb of Minneapolis for a lesser one, costing twice as much, in a New York suburb; and his wife, a teacher, was reluctant about leaving her job,'' said Matthew M. Luca, president and chief operating officer of Prudential Relocation Management in White Plains.
The high-tech communications company wooing the engineer thought so much of the candidate, Mr. Luca said, that it eventually paid $90,000 in relocation costs to transfer the engineer and his family to a new home in Armonk, near its corporate headquarters in White Plains.
''Included was the cost of moving the couple's 22-foot sailboat, their second car, plus fees for career counseling for the wife, to help her find a new job in Westchester,'' Mr. Luca said.
The cost of transferring an employee into the Westchester area is more than double the average cost of $40,000 nationwide for relocating an employee, Mr. Luca said. And relocation efforts are being influenced by the changing demographics of the workforce, as well as the current housing market here. 
 
Fewer Moves, More Cost
''Understandably, companies in the Northeast are very selective about moving employees today,'' he said. ''And while they are moving fewer of them, they are spending more on each relocation.''
Mr. Luca said Prudential Relocation was formed in September 1989 with the Prudential's purchase of Merrill Lynch Realty and Merrill Lynch Relocation Management. ''Prudential was anxious to get into the financial-services industry and Merrill Lynch was selling because it was getting out of the real estate industry,'' he explained. ''We provide relocation services to more than 30,000 employees and their families for more than 400 major corporate clients a year.''
Mr. Luca, who spent 16 years as vice president of Merrill Lynch Relocation Management Services, said few companies were moving into New York, Connecticut and New Jersey because of the high cost of living in the area.
''The market is still suffering from the inflated real-estate prices of the 80's here. Houses are still overpriced and what has happened is an exodus of companies leaving the area to relocate in lower-cost states such as Georgia and Texas, where house prices are still low.''
The second-quarter report issued by the Westchester County Board of Realtors, based in White Plains, bears this out. The report showed a decrease of nearly 11 percent in closings from the second quarter of last year.
Henry W. Fries, president of the Board of Realtors, said, ''The logjam in the market may shake loose if we see additional price reductions, more than the 2 to 3 percent that was indicated in our report. Low interest rates alone are not sufficient. Sellers still have not confronted the reality that prices overshot the real market during the last few years of the 1980's.''
Prudential Relocation's latest management survey of corporate mobility policies among major American corporations showed that companies moved 12 percent fewer employees last year than in 1988, Mr. Luca said, with almost half the companies surveyed reporting difficulties in getting employees to transfer to high-cost-of-living areas.
''Today, employees voice concern about quality-of-life issues,'' he said. ''And in two-income families there are worries about the spouse's job.
 
The Big Picture Is Changing
Companies are facing problems that are linked to changing demographics: by the end of the decade it is expected that more than 50 percent of the professional work force will be made up of married women.
The number of dual-career families has increased steadily every year, said Rose Emerson, president of Courier Relocation Corporation of America, which provides career counseling to transferred spouses of large companies like Citibank, Kraft, General Foods and Union Carbide.
''Mobility is still an important facet of American business life,'' Ms. Emerson said. ''For example, each year we provide spousal job assistance to about 300 employees of Citibank alone.''
Ms. Emerson's company, based in Purchase, has career counselors in 94 different satellite offices nationwide who provide job assistance to more than 1,000 working spouses of client companies each year.
''Currently, about 15 percent of the spouses we work with are men,'' she said. ''But the number is growing as transferred female executives are becoming more numerous in such industries as financial services and communications. But in most industries - the oil companies in particular - we find that transferred executives are still almost always male.''
Mr. Luca said companies that offer working- spouse assistance are providing it ''in the form of out-of-pocket costs'' to the firm. ''That includes reimbursement for resume preparation, formal counseling, employment-agency fees and extra job-finding trips,'' he said.
 
Incentives for Mobility
But mobility ''isn't what it once was,'' Mr. Luca said. ''Several years ago, if you didn't accept a move, you were sidetracked in a company. Although flexibility is still important in going up the career ladder, increasing numbers of companies report that they are not getting their first choice of employees. Some companies in the county, notably those in the communications and financial-services industry, are offering employees additional incentives to move'' to this area, he said.
Much of the increase in relocation costs are in the rise of subsidy payments, he said. ''They consist of cost-of-living allowances, mortgage aid and tax-assistance payments. And the more progressive companies are also offering to pay for live-in help, which can cost a company about $10,000 a year.''
Some companies, he added, are finding that when it comes to house hunting, they can save money by offering the transferee a lump sum instead of paying for several house-hunting trips. ''If the employee finds a house on the first trip out,'' Mr. Luca said, ''the rest of the money is his.''
Increases in relocation costs, fueled by the high cost of housing, has directly contributed to the growth of some industries.
Edward S. Rosenfeld, president of International Furniture Rentals in Hawthorne, said his company had increased its sales volume significantly over the last several years.
''What has happened is that the soft economy and cutbacks mean that more companies are relocating executives on a temporary basis,'' Mr. Rosenfeld said. ''And when the market is flat, the trend now is to have a transferee keep his old house and rent it out furnished, and then move into a rented house in the new location and rent furniture. This helps a company's cash flow.''
Mr. Rosenfeld's company recently began construction of an addition, to expand its warehouse/distribution center in Hawthorne by nearly 40 percent.
''We've been helped by relocation specialists who are advising transferred employees to rent now, buy later,'' he said. ''In a down market, real-estate flexibility is important.''
And large companies, he said, are renting furniture as a cost-saving tactic. When J. C. Penney moved its headquarters from Manhattan to Dallas two years ago, Mr. Rosenfeld explained, ''they brought about 180 employees to New York for a year for training. By putting them in apartments with rented furniture, J. C. Penney saved about $1 million in hotel bills.'' Mr. Rosenfeld's company furnished the J. C. Penney apartments.
''Typically, for an eight-month stay in the metropolitan area, a company can save upward of $30,000 by renting an apartment for a transferred employee instead of paying for a hotel room,'' Mr. Rosenfeld estimated. ''And furniture rental costs are 100 percent tax deductible as a business expense.''
When asked how much it costs to rent furniture, Mr. Rosenfeld replied that the rule of thumb was to allot anywhere from 10 percent to 25 percent of the monthly apartment or house rental for renting furniture.
''And a lot of customers end up buying the furniture they have rented from us,'' he said.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: July 30, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 2407 words

HEADLINE: The New Arrivals; Immigrants Reshape New York;
Young Immigrant Wave Lifts New York Economy

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
For the fourth time in its history, New York City is being resettled and reshaped by migration.
The latest arrivals come largely from the Caribbean, Latin America, Asia and Africa. They have revived bleak sections of the Bronx and Brooklyn and built two new Chinatowns. They have taken fruit stands and stationery stores and fashioned them into commercial empires. They have filled low-skilled but crucial health-care jobs and may have preserved New York's garment industry.
But less evident than the proliferation of Chinese newspapers in street- corner kiosks or the Dominican flags flying from the aerials of livery cabs is the basic impact immigrants have had on the city's economy. The latest influx, which started in the 1960's, gained force during New York's remarkable economic comeback, providing a fresh source of youthful workers and helping to sustain the boom of the 1980's. 
Economists say the city still needs young people to balance a native population becoming older and smaller. But in the period of economic stagnation that has descended upon New York, there are questions about whether the immigrants will continue to arrive at their current rate, which approaches 100,000 a year, and, if they do, how well the city will be able to absorb them, at least until slack times end.
 
Inevitably, Some Hostility
Some worry as well about the prospects of immigrants already here, many of whom work in the machine shops and factories of the city's manufacturing concerns, a part of the economy that is shrinking rapidly. And the new immigrants have attracted hostility, as immigrants inevitably do, from sometimes less prosperous groups already living here.
Eighteen countries sent 5,000 or more people to New York from 1980 to 1986, led by the Dominican Republic, Guyana, Jamaica, China and Haiti. The latest influx is far more varied than two previous waves of foreigners who came to the city, the Irish and Germans between 1840 and 1860, and the Italians, Poles, Russians and Greeks from 1890 to 1915, or for that matter the migration of southern blacks and Puerto Ricans after World War II.
With perhaps 2.6 million foreign-born residents in the city, about a third of the population, immigrants are already a huge consumer market that generates economic activity and jobs.
 
'We Trust Each Other'
The new immigrants have not had much of an impact on welfare rolls, experts say, and many take jobs as restaurant workers, hotel housekeepers and hospital attendants that are often spurned by native-born residents.
They have formed networks to help newly arrived compatriots to find employment and housing and to make their way.
''We trust each other, we understand each other,'' said Sali Nezaj, an Albanian who found work in the Bronx 20 years ago as a superintendent in an apartment building and now owns buildings, hiring others from his country to work in them.
Immigrants have rebuilt whole neighborhoods of the city, including Mr. Nezaj's Kingsbridge in the Bronx, Washington Heights in Manhattan and Elmhurst in Queens, some of them home to previous waves of foreign-born settlers.
''The empty stores become full, and the full stores become better,'' said Louis Winnick, a senior consultant at the Fund for the City of New York, who has written a book about Sunset Park in Brooklyn, a neighborhood settled and resettled by the Dutch and English, Scandinavians and Irish, Italians, Poles, Greeks, Puerto Ricans, Dominicans and, most recently, Chinese.
Without the latest wave of immigration, he said, New York would be ''a boarded-up city.''
Even so, Vernon M. Briggs Jr., a professor at the New York State School of Industrial and Labor Relations at Cornell University, notes that some blacks who made up the third wave of migration are now returning to the South.
''I think immigration is part of what's pushing them back,'' he said.
 
From Many Lands, Youth and Ambition
In the 1970's, as the latest wave of immigration was gathering, New York City suffered a deep and demoralizing decline, as factories fled to the South and middle class residents to the suburbs. The decade that followed brought a sharp turnaround as the city gained jobs and people.
Had it not been for immigrants, many economists say, the 70's would have been worse and the 80's, though largely driven by a boom on Wall Street, less impressive. From 1980 to 1987, for example, 575,000 immigrants to New York City replaced 375,000 native-born residents, for a net gain of 200,000 people.
''Certainly, in the 80's, it would have been tough to sustain the kind of expansion we had without immigration,'' said Emanuel Tobier, a professor at the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at New York University.
The new settlers vary educationally as well as ethnically and have filtered into a wide variety of occupations, from Indian physicians to Filipino nurses to Romanian knitters to Albanian building superintendents to Chinese garment workers to Haitian cabdrivers. But they largely share one demographic characteristic: They are of working age. Some 60 percent are in the prime working years of 25 to 44.
The impact of so many relatively young people has been great. In the 1970's, immigration pushed up the potential labor supply slightly at a time the city's population was actually declining by about 1 million.
Among non-whites, employment rates also tend to be higher in foreign-born groups than in corresponding native-born groups. For example, 1980 census data indicates that 65 percent of black immigrants over 15 years old were employed, against 53 percent of native-born blacks in the same age group, and that 65 percent of Asian immigrants were employed, but 56 percent of native-born Asians.
''The people who come here are the most ambitious of the groups,'' Professor Tobier said. ''They may sometimes look like poorly educated people to us, but they are more educated than those who don't leave. And they have a higher sense of self-esteem, of what they can do in the world.''
''They have more of an incentive to work hard,'' he also said, ''and less to fall back on, in the sense of the welfare system. They come here and feel they have to rely on themselves, and their own effort. They're not plugged into the social service system.''
 
Ethnic Networking Helps New Settlers
Since the turn of the century, Ridgewood, Queens, has been a center of the knitwear industry, its hundreds of small sweater mills run by succeeding waves of immigrant labor. First were the Germans. Then, in the late 1960's, the Yugoslavs and Romanians came. Now there are growing numbers of Chinese and Hispanic workers.
At J and B Knitting Mills, at 1647 Centre Street, the time cards bear evidence of a changing ethnic mix -Lopez and Luki, Morales and Julevic, Chavez and Popopov. As she checked sweater labels on a large table before her, Vera Ljutec, who is 29 years old, said in Serbian that she had come to New York from Yugoslavia two years ago. Friends told her there was work in Ridgewood and helped her land a job.
Similarly, when Mr. Nezaj came to the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx 20 years ago, a relative who was an apartment superintendent helped him get a superintendent's job.
And so the city's new immigrants have gotten jobs the way immigrants always have - through ethnic networking, in which recent settlers are helped by earlier ones, and ethnic niching, in which various groups stake out particular kinds of employment.
Often the latest immigrants have followed older ethnic groups into specific industries and occupations. Ownership of neighborhood fruit stands has largely passed from Italians and Jews to Koreans, for example, and Chinese restaurants followed Greek coffee shops and are being followed in turn by South American establishments. Taxis once driven by Israelis and Eastern Europeans are now driven by Haitians, Dominicans, Africans and Arabs. Dominicans and Chinese have taken over from Jews and Italians in the city's garment shops. Dominicans are buying bodegas, often from Puerto Ricans.
The new immigrants are willing to work long hours and to take risks, carving out new markets for goods and services, from Mexican flower sellers to Korean manicurists to Senegalese street vendors, who are common throughout midtown, where rough-hewn wooden masks decorated with feathers and beads and solemn bronze busts of African kings look out blankly at pedestrians.
And it is hard to imagine how New York City's hospitals would have continued to function without the influx of immigrant labor.
At Mount Sinai Medical Center on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, many people from the Spanish-speaking Caribbean - especially the Dominican Republic - are housekeepers. There are Jamaicans working in the kitchen and in labs. West Africans, many from Ghana, work in the laundry and wheel patients on gurneys through the corridors. Many nurses are from the Philippines; others are West Indian. There are lab technicians from Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. Many were physicians in their homelands, but are not accredited here.
''You rely on your country people to get jobs,'' said Estela Vazquez, an organizer for Local 1199, the hospital workers' union. ''Whoever gets in, helps the others.''
 
Few Are Homeless, But Experts Worry
Even without a return of the economic growth of 1980's - a prospect that seems increasingly unlikely - the city will still need workers.
''Ninety percent of all job openings are replacements,'' said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
And non-immigrant New Yorkers of working age are expected to decline by more than 300,000 in the 1990's.
Should the bad economic news persist, some believe it will spread over the same networks that spread the word of prosperity in the last decade, and the flow here will slow. During the 1970's, they say, the influx of Puerto Ricans to the city reversed in response to the softening economy.
Regina B. Armstrong, an economic consultant to the Regional Plan Association, says she believes immigrants will keep coming to the city, propelled by political unrest and population pressures abroad and lured by family members and compatriots in New York. She forecasts a majority of the city's population to comprise foreign-born residents and their children by the end of the decade.
So far, the new immigrants are notably absent from the homeless population, and they are not numerous on city welfare rolls. In her book, ''Immigration in New York,'' published by Praeger, Elizabeth Bogen of the New York City Planning Department, former director of its office of immigrant affairs, found that immigrants made ''slightly less'' than their proportionate use of services and paid ''slightly less'' than their proportionate share of taxes. That, she said, was largely a result of their lower-than-average incomes and the city's graduated tax structure.
But Ms. Armstrong worries that many new settlers could become more dependent on government in a prolonged economic slump and that more immigrants may be lured into working off the books. As it is, there are hundreds of thousands of undocumented aliens in the city, many working without the knowledge of tax officials.
Immigrants are already making demands on a public school system in which at least 114 languages are spoken. At P.S. 89 in Elmhurst, Queens, a sign directing visitors is in English, Chinese, Korean and Spanish. Administrators cannot send newsletters to parents without several translators.
The Elmhurst district is one of the city's most diverse. Most of the school's 1,300 students were born in another country and almost all need to learn English, said Kay McCarthy, the assistant principal. Indeed, the school holds monthly workshops where parents are also taught English.
But given the percentage of new settlers in the child-bearing age group, the burdens on the city's schools would seem only to be beginning.
 
A Boycott Reopens An Age-Old Anger
The boycott of a Korean grocery by black residents of Flatbush, Brooklyn, was set off by the allegation that Korean merchants had assaulted a Haitian customer. But it is doubtless heightened by resentment of Koreans, who have taken over many stores in black neighborhoods, and by the more general fear that immigrants are competing for jobs, housing and other resources with black and Puerto Rican New Yorkers.
Demonstrators have complained about the lack of black-owned businesses in the area. The city's Human Rights Commission, which is trying to end the conflict, is studying ways to improve economic opportunities as well as improve relations between customers and store owners.
The issue of displacement has always shadowed major immigration. It seems especially troublesome, however, when about half a million New Yorkers of working age do not have jobs and are not even looking for them, despite living in a city that generated 350,000 new jobs in the 1980's.
While economists generally believe there is some competition between the foreign- and native-born, they disagree on its extent.
Some say immigrants have carved out their own sections of the economy, notably in personal services and manufacturing, while native-born blacks are more likely to be government workers. When they do work in the same industries and businesses, the two groups often focus on different markets.
On the other hand, immigrants are not often subject to the same degree of discrimination native-born blacks face, and have made inroads in some service industries that have resisted black workers.
But if the immigrants cause displacement, Roger Waldinger, associate professor of sociology at City College, says he believes there are offsetting benefits for the city's economy. For example, they are a major market for goods and services in their own right.
And labor experts say foreign-born workers may have helped the city retain industries that would have moved elsewhere in search of labor, particularly the garment industry.
Professor Briggs, however, says any gains have come at the cost of exploitive wages and dismal working conditions. He says he is troubled by what he believes is a revival of garment-industry sweatshops and a resurgence of child-labor law violations in ethnic stores and restaurants.
''We're recruiting third-world workers,'' he said, ''for third-world working conditions.''
