SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1388 words

HEADLINE: Labor Dept. Wants to Take On Job Bias in the Executive Suite

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 29

 BODY:
Even as it is fighting Congress over a major civil rights bill, the Bush Administration says it is looking for a way to curb job discrimination in a realm that the Government has never really touched: the white male echelon that rules the nation's largest corporations.
Women and minority members complain that in climbing the corporate ladder they collide with a ''glass ceiling'' of subtle discrimination that blocks their access to the highest rung. Confirming accounts that have arisen in legal circles here, Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole said last week that she was devising a ''glass ceiling initiative'' to try to speed the promotion of women and minority members to top posts and threatening cancellation of Government contracts with companies that do not cooperate.
Labor Department officials say female, black and Hispanic employees make up 30 percent or more of the middle management of big corporations, but less than 1 percent at the level of the chief executive and those directly beneath.
 
Lists of Executives Cited
Combing through lists of directors and highest executives at 799 major companies this month, Fortune magazine found 3,993 men and only 19 women. Other studies show smaller proportions of black and Hispanic executives. 
Because the Federal policy will not be fully defined until September or October, Mrs. Dole declined requests for interviews about it. In written replies to a reporter's questions, however, she said: ''I have made this issue a top priority, and it will remain so during my service as Secretary of Labor. For me, it is a matter of fairness and equity, born out of personal experience.''
She added, ''There can be little doubt that a woman or minority, no matter how well-schooled, what their wage or how thick their portfolio, enters many business organizations with limited or no hope of reaching the top.''
To discourage practices that limit careers, she said, ''we will be examining developmental programs, training, rotational assignments and reward structures - all the indicators of upward mobility in corporate America.''
 
Rigid Quotas Opposed
Mrs. Dole's plan seems at odds with the White House's resistance to job discrimination provisions in the civil rights bill that has passed the Senate and is now before the House. The White House calls the bill unacceptable, saying it would force employers to set rigid numerical quotas for hiring and promoting female and minority workers.
But Alixe Glen, a spokeswoman for the President, said Mr. Bush endorsed the general goal of workplace equity. And the Administration seems to have recognized a demographic fact: the relative decline in the number of white men.
 
Social and Cultural Conditions
As yet it is unclear how far the Labor Department will be able to go in differentiating illegal discrimination, conscious or unconscious, from social and cultural conditions that contribute to the preponderance of white men at the top. Nor is it certain how deeply department investigators can legally dig into a company's affairs. And it is not clear how much Mrs. Dole might commit in money and personnel to the initiative.
But her aides say that at least some patterns of discrimination can readily be found by such tactics as tracing the progress of men, women and minority members through the executive ranks, by examining compensation plans and executive advancement programs and by comparing a company's mix of top executives with those of other companies in similar places and industries.
And the aides note that with two other issues Mrs. Dole has singled out for emphasis, violations of child labor laws and of worker safety regulations, she has been collecting more in penalties for violations than any of her predecessors.
Within the Labor Department, 20 of Mrs. Dole's 32 top executive appointees, or 63 percent, are female, black or Hispanic, second to the Department of Health and Human Services, with 70 percent.
 
Johnson Executive Order
The department's tool in thwarting discrimination in industry is the Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs, and it is playing tougher than it has in years. The office enforces an executive order signed by President Lyndon B. Johnson in 1965 that prohibits Government contractors from discriminating on the basis of sex, race, religion or national origin. The office monitors the affirmative action programs of more than 10,000 companies that have about $200 billion in Federal contracts.
Last year, in its largest financial settlement involving a discrimination case, the contract compliance office won a $14 million back pay award for female and minority employees of the Harris Bank in Chicago.
Now, in trial runs leading to a full-fledged glass ceiling investigation, the Labor Department recently began dispatching investigators to the executive suites of a dozen major companies. Department officials declined to identify them.
At this rarefied level of corporate life, discrimination typically is subtler than the overt obstacles to hiring and promotion that show up at lower levels. Executives may be favored for promotion if they have had foreign assignments, for example, or advanced business courses - opportunities some companies offer only to men.
 
The Exclusion Factor
Or, among managers at a meeting, women may be asked to take notes, inhibiting their freedom to participate and compete. Or men may negotiate deals in places not open to women and minority members, like some private clubs.
Jeffrey A. Norris, a Washington lawyer who is president of the Equal Employment Advisory Council, which is financed by 200 leading companies, said many companies had set up procedures intended to open the highest ranks to women and minority members and do not object to the Labor Department's scrutiny. But he said some companies were afraid that the department would prove meddlesome and would inadvertently disclose corporate secrets, including salaries.
Some companies are challenging the constitutionality of the Johnson executive order. Charles J. Cooper, a Washington lawyer who was an assistant Attorney General in the Reagan Administration, said he was helping prepare a court challenge.
Corporate opposition to the Dole initiative is easy to find. ''I'd hate to see the Government poking into this,'' said Lester Korn, head of Korn/Ferry International, an executive recruiting concern.
 
Late Entrance in Work Force
Barbara J. Laski, vice president and treasurer of the Capital Holding Corporation in Louisville, Ky., who is one rung removed from the 33 men and 2 women who run the big insurance and financial services company, said, ''I don't think you can regulate that kind of thing.''
Critics of the Labor Department plan say the disparity for women arises because large numbers of them did not enter the work force until the 1970's and few have reached the age - 50 or 55 - when people are usually promoted to the top jobs. But by now a few in their 30's or 40's might have been expected to have reached the top, as a few men normally do.
Black and Hispanic executives, longer in the work force, are often hindered by economic, cultural and educational obstacles, as well as by illegal discrimination, Labor Department officials say.
The compliance office acknowledges that finding subtle forms of discrimination at a company's highest reaches can be difficult. In trying to arrest it, the office pays more attention to the manifestations of discrimination than to the causes. All Federal contractors with more than 100 employees must file annual affirmative action reports with the office, showing the breakdown of women and minority executives at nine levels of the corporate structure.
 
How the System Works
If a company's breakdown diverts sharply from patterns among other employers in the area and in its industry, the office sends the company a letter asking for further details that it uses to try to determine whether the disparities might result from discrimination. It then sends two to five of its 685 investigators to spend up to a week at the company, looking into the disparities.
''We look at how people who are where they are got there,'' said Leonard J. Biermann, the office's deputy director.
The office's findings can be challenged to an administrative law judge.

HEADLINE: U.S. and Asian Allies Deadlock Over Boat People

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 29

 BODY:
Three days of talks between the United States and its Southeast Asian allies have failed to break a deadlock on how to treat thousands of Vietnamese refugees who continue to arrive on foreign shores every year.
The impasse over whether nations have the right to forcibly repatriate selected refugees back to Vietnam threatens to tear apart international agreements under which Hong Kong and nations like Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand and the Philippines admit Vietnamese who flee their country, despite risk of becoming victims to pirates or stormy seas.
The Southeast Asian nations want to begin to clear out the 125,000 Vietnamese who inhabit squalid camps in their countries, and prevent more people from leaving Vietnam. But the United States, which finances much of the refugee relief and grants a large number of Vietnamese permanent refuge, has opposed involuntary return of refugees, even among those classified as economic migrants. 
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d presented the six foreign ministers of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean, what was described as a modified American position on Vietnamese ''boat people'' under which refugees would be encouraged though not required to return to their homeland.
 
Counseling Is Suggested
Mr. Baker suggested that while the United States could not support involuntary repatriation, it would not oppose returning ''those who do not object'' after screening and counseling. He also said the United States was committed to resettling or returning all asylum-seekers by late 1992.
But today, at the close of the Asean meeting, officials who say their countries have the sovereign right to accept or not accept refugees sternly dismissed Mr. Baker's position as a thinly veiled restatement of the old American position against forced repatriation.
In private meetings, the Asian foreign ministers told Mr. Baker that if Washington did not move closer to their position, they might eventually be forced to scrap the Comprehensive Plan of Action on Indo-Chinese refugees, under which several Asian countries and Hong Kong offer Vietnamese asylum with the financial support of Western industrialized nations. The agreement, they say, guarantees resettlement for poltiical refugees, not economic migrants.
''The gap between Asean and the United States remains quite big,'' said Datuk A. Kamil Jaafar, Secretary General of the Malaysian Ministry of Foreign Affairs. ''The Baker position does not represent a movement forward.''
 
Baker Plan Called Unworkable
Helen Barber, the acting director of the Southeast Asia Bureau of the Philippine Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said the Baker position ''is not workable,'' because it does not distinguish between political refugees and migrants who leave Vietnam to escape poverty.
Mrs. Barber added that the Comprehensive Plan of Action ''is in danger; it can fall apart if there is no movement by the United States.''
The principle of first asylum has suffered a severe setback over the last 15 months as Malaysia pushed off an estimated 8,700 boat people trying to land on its shores. Scores of those refugees have been robbed, raped or killed by pirates after they were refused entrance.
The discord between the United States and the Asian nations was highlighted three weeks ago when a 28-nation conference on boat people in Geneva was postponed because participants saw no hope for bridging the gap on forced repatriation.
Such discord prompted Thorvald Stoltenberg, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, to shuttle around Europe, Asia and the United States to try to come up with a compromise arrangement before the Asean meeting to save the principle of first asylum.
The outlines of Mr. Stoltenberg's proposal were endorsed by Mr. Baker before the Asean meeting.
Southeast Asian diplomats said they find the Stoltenberg proposal vague, and they indicated that they hoped the United States would further modify its position on the refugees.
 
Accept Refugees, U.S. Urged
Raul Manglapus, the Philippines Foreign Minister, said the United States should simply accept all the Vietnamese refugees.
''The United States,'' he said, ''has all the land in the world to absorb them.''
Other Asian diplomats privately expressed hope that the United States would improve relations with Vietnam. An end to the economic embargo of Hanoi, they suggested, would improve the Vietnamese economy and dampen the desire of many to leave.
Mr. Baker's attendance at the Asean meeting was very much a mission to soothe tensions on the refugee issue and explain recent shifts in Cambodian policy. He privately told the foreign ministers that the Administration was in part obliged to respond to Congressional pressures when it dropped diplomatic support for the Cambodian guerrilla coalition, but that President Bush continued to share their desire to limit Vietnamese power in the region.
The foreign ministers told Mr. Baker that they would like him to consult with them more on Indochina policy in the future, but they resisted expressing harsh public criticism of American policy on Cambodia.

From left were Raul Manglapus of the Philippines, Ali Alatas of Indonesia, Mike K. Moore of New Zealand, Mr. Baker and Gareth Evans of Australia. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Hanoi Aide, Praising U.S., Sees Hope of Cambodia Pact

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam, July 29

 BODY:
Reacting to the American policy shift on Cambodia 11 days ago, Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach of Vietnam said today that he was optimistic about a settlement of the Cambodian conflict. He said Hanoi agreed with Washington that the main issue now was how to get to ''free, fair and democratic elections under international supervision.''
The comments by Mr. Thach in an interview here marked a considerable change in tone and emphasis for the Foreign Minister.
For years, negotiations on Cambodia have been bogged down over what Mr. Thach now calls ''the petty, transitory details'' - how power should be shared by the four rival Cambodian factions before elections. Still, Mr. Thach was not specific today about what type of transitory phase Hanoi would accept. 
On July 18, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d announced that Washington was withdrawing its diplomatic support at the United Nations for a Cambodian opposition coalition including the Communist Khmer Rouge. Mr. Baker said the United States would open talks on Cambodia with Vietnam, which backs the Cambodian Government in Phnom Penh. The talks are scheduled to begin Aug. 6 in New York Moves on the Chess Board Mr. Thach said the timing of the American move surprised him, adding: ''But sometimes when one pawn moves, it changes the whole chess board. So now, on the Cambodian problem, others will move also.''
It made the game more complicated, he said. ''but if you are a good player, you take your chance.''
Asked if he was a good player, and if he would take his chance, he shrugged, smiled and said: ''Yes. Why not?''
Mr. Thach went out of his way not to gloat over what some in Southeast Asia regard as a major American concession to Hanoi, calling the United States decision ''very wise'' and saying, ''If we are too ambitious, we kill the goose to get the golden egg.''
Mr. Thach, a jovial and skillful negotiator, said, ''Now I am thinking how to cooperate with America and facilitate this issue of Cambodia, and how to cooperate and have fair, free and democratic elections under international supervision.''
 
Importance of Elections Stressed
''The decisive point is general elections,'' he said. ''Everything else is petty details. All will be solved by general elections.''
Hanoi installed the present Cambodian Government in 1979 after it invaded Cambodia and ousted the Khmer Rouge, under whose rule more than a million Cambodians died. The guerrilla coalition seeking to oust the Vietnamese-backed Government is dominated by the Khmer Rouge, and includes two non-Communist factions. The coalition is nominally led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk, head of one of the non-Communist forces.
As recently as two months ago, a promising opening between Vietnam and China, the principal backer of the Khmer Rouge, turned sour over the shape and responsibility of an interim Cambodian authority to run or represent the country.
The way in which power is shared is widely expected to influence the fairness and outcome of the elections.
Asked if Vietnam was prepared to see the Cambodian Prime Minister, Hun Sen, lose elections, Mr. Thach laughed and said, ''If you play a game, you must work for the best and be prepared for the worst.''
Vietnam, he stressed, had two main interests now in Cambodia: a neutral, indepedent and nonaligned country that posed no threat to its neighbors, and a rapid move to supervised elections to resolve the Cambodian conflict and end the external supplies of arms to the combatants.
Asked if that meant Vietnam would urge Phnom Penh to compromise on the formation of an interim authority, or supreme national council, and allow a major role for the United Nations, Mr. Thach hedged.
 
Cambodian 'Sensitivity' Noted
''The Cambodians must decide for themselves,'' he said. ''They are the key. Outsiders can advise, but cannot dictate to them.''
With a slight smile, he added, ''You know how sensitive the Cambodians are about their sovereignty.''
Pressed for Vietnam's position on a council and the United Nations role, he said: ''I don't say yes, and I don't say no. In these matters I will support any agreement among the Cambodian parties. I should only have a say on the external aspects.''
In these responses, too, Mr. Thach seemed eager to say nothing that would bias or forestall the coming talks with the United States.
Hanoi and Phnom Penh have always objected to a major United Nations role in a settlement, for instance, saying the organization was biased so long as the opposition coalition held Cambodia's seat. So for Mr. Thach, the American shift about the seat is enormously helpful, even if Washington was recoiling from the Khmer Rouge rather than trying to bolster Mr. Hun Sen.
 
Hun Sen's Position Undercut
The effect, however, apparently is what matters, particularly when Mr. Hun Sen's position had been undercut by governmental corruption, low morale and his failure to deliver peace.
Mr. Thach's position in the Vietnamese leadership is thought to have been strengthened as well. He insisted that Vietnam had to withdraw its troops from Cambodia last year to receive Western aid, investment and technology that had largely been blocked by an American-led embargo.
But Mr. Baker's announcement, with its implicit promise of more rapid normalization, was the first tangible dividend for Mr. Thach's policy.
As for the Khmer Rouge, Mr. Thach said, ''I don't think anyone wants the genocidal regime reinstalled.''
He played down reports of Khmer Rouge military successes, saying the Cambodian Government held all main towns, cities and highways. He compared the Khmer Rouge to ''a skin disease, uncomfortable, but not cancer.'' Still, he said, ''the economic situation in Cambodia is not so good,'' with rising inflation, lack of confidence and reduced aid from other countries.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
4 European Nations Planning a New Focus on North Africa

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, July 26

 BODY:
Increasingly alarmed by the potential for unrest in North Africa, four southern European nations have begun organizing a major international initiative to bolster political stability and economic development in the Mediterranean region.
Officials from the four countries -Spain, France, Italy and Portugal -acknowledge that they are essentially motivated by self-interest. Specifically, they fear that a surge of Islamic fundamentalism and deepening poverty could bring them a new wave of Muslim immigrants.
But they also argue that after the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe and the disintegration of the Warsaw Pact, the southern rim of the Mediterranean could emerge as the greatest single threat to Western Europe's security. 
''Europe's focus is beginning to turn from East-West to North-South,'' a Spanish official said. ''And when we talk about security, we mean security in the broadest of senses, from migratory flows to food supplies.''
 
Informal Forum Established
To address that challenge, the four countries are promoting the idea of a conference on security and cooperation in the Mediterranean, modeled after the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which for the last 15 years has served as a forum for East-West negotiations.
As a first stage, the four countries have established an informal Forum for Regional Cooperation in the Mediterranean with Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, Libya and Mauritania, which as members of the Arab Mahgreb Union, are also discussing the idea of forming a common market of their own.
Eventually, the plan is to involve more countries from Europe and the Mediterranean. This month, a Spanish delegation briefed State Department officials on the state of negotiations with the idea of insuring Washington's participation in an eventual Mediterranean conference.
So far, the discussions have been taking place at a technical level, mainly among officials from Spain, France, Italy and Portugal. But the four countries hope to make their initiative formal at a meeting of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe in Spain in late September.
 
Anti-Immigrant Sentiments
Traditionally, France was the European country with deepest ties to North Africa, with large immigrant populations from former colonies like Algeria, Morocco and Tunisia living in its territory. Today, France is also the European country where anti-immigrant sentiments run strongest.
But in recent years, as their societies have become more prosperous, Spain and Italy have begun receiving more immigration from North and West Africa. That has resulted in new racial tensions and occasional acts of violence against Arab and African workers.
And, experts say, North African migration to Europe continues to be stimulated by troubled economies and booming populations. According to World Bank projections, for example, the combined population of Algeria, Morocco and Tunisia will grow from 54 million, in 1987, to 127 million in 2025.
After the Islamic Salvation Front won a majority in local elections in Algeria last month, there was also new fear in France and other southern European countries that Islamic fundamentalism could begin to destabilize Muslim countries that for many years have had political stability.
 
'Shock Treatment' Initiative
Amid warnings that the region should not be neglected in favor of Eastern Europe, awareness of the need to help North Africa has been growing in the 12-nation European Community. Abel Matutes, head of Mediterranean policy at the European Commission, recently proposed a $3.3 billion package of assistance for eight countries of the region.
Arguing that a more ambitious ''shock treatment'' was needed, Spain began consulting its southern European neighbors this year about a broader initiative. Spanish officials said Italy immediately agreed to co-sponsor the idea, while France and Portugal joined later.
Borrowing the method used successfully by the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, the four countries are now working with the idea of creating three separate topic areas -economic cooperation, security and the human dimension.
A senior Spanish official said that formula would permit a global approach to the region's problems, incorporating everything from population growth and urban concentration to Islamic fundamentalism, unemployment and immigration. ''The idea is to pull everything together,'' he said.
 
Assurances on Naval Forces
As with the European Conference's 1975 Helsinki accords, he said, the Mediterranean Conference could also eventually draw up ''a common code of conduct,'' which would cover political and human rights and establish democracy as a universal objective.
Other diplomats said the four co-sponsors had started dealing with the five members of the Arab Mahgreb Union, but they recognized that any regional conference would have to include countries of the eastern Mediterrean as far as Turkey and even Balkan countries like Romania and Bulgaria.
They said the co-sponsors had already sought to reassure France, Britain and the United States that any debate on security by such a conference would not lead to a questioning of their right to maintain naval forces in the Mediterranean.
''We're thinking of a process that will have many different stages and will inevitably be extended,'' the senior Spanish official said. ''And from our point of view, the most important thing is economic cooperation. Remember, it was 15 years before the European Conference bore fruit.''

HEADLINE: Premier of Trinidad Offers to Quit if Rebels End Coup

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, July 29

 BODY:
Trinidad and Tobago's security chief said today there was scant hope of an early breakthrough in negotiations for the release of Prime Minister Arthur N .R. Robinson, who was taken hostage on Friday in a coup attempt by Muslim rebels and reportedly wired to explosives.
Gunfire and widespread looting continued for the third day, turning the capital's downtown streets into a virtual combat zone. A curfew was extended throughout this two-island Caribbean nation in an effort to restore order.
A senior official at Port of Spain's main hospital said that at least 300 people had been wounded since the group of Muslim militants began its attempt to topple the Government on Friday. The leader of the group, Abu Bakr, said his aim was to end Government corruption. 
Appearing on national television, Security Minister Herbert Atwell described the negotiations with the group holding Mr. Robinson and key members of his Cabinet at the Parliament building as a ''touch-and-go situation.''
 
Exploring 'Reasonable Options'
''We are going to exhaust all reasonable options for a peaceful solution,'' he said, adding ''I am in no position to give any hope'' for an early solution. Asked how long he believed the standoff would last, he replied: ''If I could answer that, I could win the lottery. I can give no indication.''
It was the Government's first statement on its negotiations with members of the radical Jamaat al- Muslimeen group, and it flatly contradicted rebel statements that Mr. Robinson had agreed to resign and that an accord was near.
Flying with President Bush from Kennebunkport, Me., to Washington, the United States national security adviser, Brent Scrowcroft, also denied a report today of a deal involving the 63-year-old Prime Minister's resignation.
Mr. Robinson, who was wounded in the leg when the rebels stormed the Parliament, has served as Prime Minister since 1986. Elections are not due until the end of 1991.
 
Curfew Extended
Announcing tougher security measures in Trinidad and Tobago, which has a population of 1.3 million, Mr. Atwell said that a national curfew was being extended from 12 to 18 hours a day and that military and police units had begun joint patrols.
Mr. Atwell, who was not in the Parliament when the rebels burst in firing AK-47 assault rifles, said the Government had decided to impose a 24-hour curfew around the Parliament and the television station where the rebels are holed up.
In storming the Parliament building and seizing control of a state-run television station on Friday, the Muslim rebels said they had toppled the elected Government.
The army and the police have remained loyal to the Government and surrounded the buildings held by the rebels. A tense standoff resulted.
Despite the capture of Mr. Robinson and other officials, ''the Government is functioning and is taking every step to restore security,'' Mr. Atwell said.
 
Accord Had Been Predicted
The extremists led by Abu Bakr are known as the Jamaat al-Muslimeen. About 250 of the group's members are believed to be involved in the coup attempt.
The rebels said late Saturday that they were close to an agreement that provided for Mr. Robinson's resignation, new elections within 90 days and an amnesty for the coup plotters.
But almost 24 hours after that statement was issued by a rebel spokesman, the state radio station quoted a rebel leader as saying that the negotiations were taking longer than expected.
As gunfire continued to crackle today in Port of Spain, a senior official at the capital's main hospital said that about 300 people had been wounded, most of them by gunfire, since violence flared Friday.
Stewart Smith, assistant administrator of the city's state-run General Hospital, said about 200 of those people were still being treated. The Caribbean News Agency reported over the weekend that 22 people had been killed.
 
Measures Against Looters
Announcing the deployment of police and military patrols, the Acting Police Superintendent, Leonard Taylor, said late today, ''There has been serious looting and we are going to take stronger measures to prevent it.''
The radio said that the police were under orders to shoot looters, who have rampaged through the center of the capital and left practically every shop empty.
The rebels denied reports that they had demanded a plane to fly Abu Bakr and his followers to Libya, a country that the rebel leader has visited several times.
The Government radio said that negotiations for an end to the hostage crisis were continuing, with a senior Anglican cleric, Knolly Clarke, acting as a mediator. Ignoring the Signs? A senior police official said today that the Government had ignored police warnings that the Muslim group was planning violent operations with the backing of Libya.
The official, who declined to be named, said that the police raided one of the group's communes earlier this year and discovered a cache of weapons. Last December, he said, three Libyans visited Trinidad to train Muslim militants.
Although detailed information on these activities was relayed to the Government, no action was taken, he said.
Trinidad and Tobago, a multiracial, oil-producing republic off the Venezuelan coast, has been hit hard by a fall in oil prices. Unemployment has jumped to 20 percent.
 
Foreigners Seek to Leave
Commercial flights to Port of Spain were suspended again today.
At the Hilton Hotel, dozens of foreigners, including a number of Americans and Europeans on vacation, crowded into the lobby seeking information on when they could leave.
The capital's residents were advised to stay off the streets.
The Bishop of Trinidad and Tobago, Clive Abdulah, appealed today for an end to the looting. ''Those who have set up a whole convoy of vehicles to take away large iterms such as refrigerators, TV's and video recorders should stop,'' he said in a radio broadcast.
Residents of the capital said that the coup attempt was precipitated by a police raid last month on swampland reclaimed and developed by the Muslim group on the outskirts of the capital over the past decade.
The group had built schools, a mosque and other buildings on the land, which the Government says the group does not own and is seeking to have them vacate.
 
Rebels Trained in Libya
WASHINGTON, July 29 (Special to The New York Times) - The leaders of the Muslim group holding the Prime Minister of Trinidad and other hostages received training in Libya last fall, State Department officials said today, but it is unclear whether the militants acted alone or had foreign backing for their coup attempt.
''These people definitely have a Libyan connection,'' said a department official who spoke on condition of anonymity. Among those who were trained in Libya were the group's leader, Abu Bakr, and two aides, the official said.
Mr. Abu Bakr was described by a State Department official as a ''do-gooder'' who has tried to cultivate a following among the country's poor.
An official of the Trinidad Defense Ministry, interviewed by telephone today, described the group as ''radical'' and ''fanatical,'' but said that it had not been actively involved in politics.
In an interview with the British Broadcasting Corporation monitored today in Barbados, Mr. Abu Bakr said he had visited Libya several times.
''I am a personal friend of Colonel Qaddafi,'' he said. ''I am a Muslim and they are Muslims. I have also had help from other Muslim countries, such as Saudi Arabia.''
State Department officials expressed disbelief that the group had any ties to Saudi Arabia.

HEADLINE: Urban League Leader Calls Equality Essential to U.S.

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN

 BODY:
Citing projections that members of minorities will make up a larger and larger part of the nation's work force, the president of the National Urban League said last night that the United States must grant them equality not merely out of a moral imperative but for ''its own economic self-interest.''
''Unless they are brought into the mainstream,'' the president, John E. Jacob, said, ''this country's living standard will nose dive and we'll lose out to the Japanese and Germans, who make better use of their people.''
''America has only one hope of entering the 21st century as a world power and a global economic force,'' he added. ''That is its ability to achieve racial parity and to make full use of the African Americans and minorities it has so long rejected.'' 
Mr. Jacob gave the keynote address before an audience of 3,000 on the opening day of the civil rights group's 80th anniversary conference at the New York Hilton. The organization was founded in New York in 1910 to help rural blacks make a successful transition to urban life.
 
No Shyness About Politics
The Urban League and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People are the nation's two largest black organizations. While politics is the principal arena of the N.A.A.C.P., the Urban League has concentrated its efforts on economic and social issues.
But Mr. Jacob did not shy from politics. In addition to emphasizing American self-interest in achieving civil rights, Mr. Jacob said American blacks must increasingly rely on political muscle rather than constitutional protections as interpreted by the courts. Nothing has brought this home more clearly, he said, than the recent resignation of Justice William J. Brennan Jr. of the Supreme Court and the nomination of Judge David H. Souter to replace him.
''As the Supreme Court becomes a conservative playground,'' Mr. Jacob said, ''the front line defense of our rights will be the Congress and state and local legislatures.''
He said he was not prepared to pass judgment on the qualifications of Judge Souter until more is made public about his views. But Mr. Jacob added, ''It is clear that the aspirations of African Americans will depend more on the executive and legislative branches than on the courts.''
 
Speeches by Office Holders
Mr. Jacob took note of the political achievements of blacks in recent years in announcing that Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York and Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia will be among those to address the convention, which ends Wednesday evening. Both men are the first blacks to hold their offices.
The Urban League president acknowledged that his ideas about American self-interest or political muscle were not original. Black political power has been building for decades; in addition to Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Wilder, there are some 7,000 black elected officials in the United States.
As for self-interest, Mr. Jacob quoted Gunnar Myrdal, the Swedish economist and sociologist, as writing 50 years ago in ''The American Dilemma,'' a benchmark book on race relations, ''America is free to choose whether the Negro shall remain her liability or become her opportunity.''
Mr. Jacob said, ''That stark choice is still present today. America can decide whether African Americans represent a liability because of continued denial of opportunity or whether we become the engine of America's future economic growth.''
 
A Changing Work Force
The nation's demographics are changing, he said. ''A predominantly native-born white male work force is a thing of the past. In the 1990's, more than four out of five new workers will be women, immigrants, Hispanics, or African Americans.''
The implications for educational programs, child care and equality are many, he said, adding, ''It means that job discrimination is not only a civil rights issue - it's a form of economic suicide.''
Mr. Jacob warned that in the past, ''America has often allowed racism to dictate wrong choices.''
''So it is possible that America would rather endure economic decline than assure future prosperity by moving toward racial parity. But history also teaches that vested interest drives America's actions. So while moral considerations may take a back seat, America may just move to racial parity in its own economic self-interest.''
In his speech, Mr. Jacob outlined several steps he said would enable members of minorities to achieve racial equality by the year 2000. Among them were these:
* Spending the expected savings on military programs because of changes in Europe - which he put at $150 billion a year - to help reduce the nation's growing deficit, roll back taxes for ''working people'' and expand social programs.
* Starting an urban Marshall Plan as a centerpiece of the expanded programs to concentrate on repairing roads, bridges and mass transit systems and on making ''investments in human capital'' to ''prepare our work force for the brave new world of the future.''
* Convening a ''national summit meeting'' on employment issues to insure that ''everyone, and especially today's excluded minority youth'' receives the education and skills ''to make it in our society.''
* Approving the Civil Rights Act of 1990, which seeks to reverse six Supreme Court decisions that civil rights groups say are hampering Federal efforts to fight job discrimination. President Bush has threatened to veto the measure.
''All elected officials have to be held accountable for their actions on that bill,'' Mr. Jacob said. ''A veto will end the President's chances of capturing significant black votes in 1992.''

HEADLINE: An Office That Has the Capital's Ear

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 29

 BODY:
When Congress suspects that an Administration has ignored or covered up a problem, it dispatches a collection of faceless auditors to investigate. Typically, the General Accounting Office finds the problem worse than anyone suspected.
Whether the issue is the savings and loan debacle, the cost of cleaning up radioactive waste or the cause of an explosion aboard the battleship Iowa, White House officials often concede the validity of G.A.O. findings.
If Congress seems to have the upper hand in a political tug-of-war with the President, that is partly because it can call upon the accounting agency, a cadre of professional experts who, for the better part of the agency's 69-year existence, have consistently turned out top-quality research.
As head of the General Accounting Office, Comptroller General Charles A. Bowsher makes authoritative pronouncements on a mind-boggling array of volatile questions. With Mr. Bowsher entering the 10th year of his 15-year term, the G.A.O. is at the zenith of its power, as demonstrated by recent events. 
 
Getting Their Attention
Concern in Congress and the Bush Administration over the savings and loan bailout jumped noticeably in April when Mr. Bowsher said the cost, including interest, could total $500 billion over 30 years. The figure was roughly twice as much as previous official estimates.
Tests performed for the G.A.O. forced the Navy to reconsider its conclusion that the explosion aboard the Iowa last year resulted from a suicidal act of sabotage by a desperate young sailor. The accounting agency said it was more likely that gunpowder bags, rammed into the breech of a gun at high speed, had ignited accidentally.
And the G.A.O. was the first Government agency to sound an alarm over safety and environmental hazards at the nation's nuclear weapons plants, years before Congress or the Energy Department focused on the problem.
With 5,100 employees and a current annual budget of $364 million, the agency is busier than ever. It issued 880 reports and 3,800 legal rulings last year, and in the last 12 months it began 1,500 audits and investigations at the request of Congress.
 
Can Act on Its Own
The G.A.O. can initiate studies on its own, but a steadily increasing proportion of its work, now 82 percent, is produced in response to Congressional requests. The agency often negotiates with lawmakers to insure that Congressional assignments mesh with its work plan, focusing on what the agency calls ''issues of national significance.''
The G.A.O. is required to perform work requested by the heads of Congressional committees and, as a matter of policy, its guidelines say, ''We assign equal status to requests from ranking minority members.'' It also responds to many requests from junior members of Congress as resources permit.
By most accounts, the agency, often described as an investigative arm of Congress, deserves its reputation for incorruptibility and intellectual honesty. Accounting and financial management have long been its strong suit. By its own estimate, the G.A.O. saved $79 billion for the Government over the last five years.
But it is not just a financial auditor. Most of its work is program evaluation. Nearly every important piece of legislation passed by Congress directs the G.A.O. to study its effects. Three-fourths of the agency's recommendations are adopted. Biased Toward Congress? If the accounting agency has one institutional weakness, its critics say, it is a subtle, pervasive bias in favor of Congress: a predisposition to favor Congressional action as the solution to problems.
The agency rarely investigates Congress, even though many people say there is at least as much mismanagement and misconduct on Capitol Hill as in any Federal agency. Asked if he ever considered doing a comprehensive audit of Congress, Mr. Bowsher said, ''I'd love to do it, but in my 15th year.''
Mr. Bowsher, a former partner at Arthur Andersen & Company who once served as Comptroller of the Navy, is paid $96,600 a year and can be removed only for neglect of duty, malfeasance or misconduct. Mr. Bowsher, 59 years old, was appointed by President Ronald Reagan from a list of eight candidates recommended by Congress.
Harry S. Havens, one of 11 assistant comptrollers general, acknowledged that close ties between the G.A.O. and Congressional committees, which often use the agency's research for partisan political ends, ''could pose significant risks to credibility'' for the watchdog agency. Republicans in the Reagan and Bush Administrations complain that the G.A.O. is used by senior Democrats in Congress to ''micromanage'' the executive branch.
 
A Critic Speaks Out
Former officials in the executive branch give the G.A.O. high marks, with a few exceptions, like James C. Miller 3d, Mr. Reagan's second budget director, who said: ''The work is spotty, uneven. All too frequently, G.A.O. has been politicized by members of Congress to do a hit job.''
John S. Herrington, who was Energy Secretary in the Reagan Administration, complains that the accounting office has become ''a kingdom, a law unto itself.'' At the same time, he said, ''I give G.A.O. high marks for its work on nuclear waste and weapons production.''
The secret of G.A.O.'s success is its institutional culture, its methodological rigor and technical expertise. Dozens of engineers, economists, social scientists, psychologists, biochemists, geologists, actuaries, statisticians and computer scientists have joined the accountants and lawyers who form the backbone of its staff. Such expertise enables the G.A.O. to answer tough questions about chemical weapons, spacecraft computers, pesticide residues, global warming, cancer drugs and controlling infection in military hospitals.
The G.A.O. also puts extraordinary emphasis on recruiting and training and has established special links with 60 college campuses, using senior agency officials as recruiters. It had 7,000 applications for 200 professional jobs this year. Young auditors who join the G.A.O. seem to believe deeply that government can and should work. Many have worked at consulting firms for higher salaries, but prefer the G.A.O. because, they say, its standards are higher and they do not have to chase after business.
 
Access to Much Data
The G.A.O. works under the discipline imposed by knowing that nearly all its work will become public. It benefits from having access to Federal tax returns and classified government documents. But it may not declassify documents, and it can use tax returns only for the purpose of auditing the Internal Revenue Service.
''We have a legal right to virtually any information where the Federal dollar is involved,'' said Ira Goldstein, assistant comptroller general for operations.
As a condition of receiving Federal grants and certain contracts, private companies, universities and state and local governments must let the G.A.O. audit their books for any misuse of Federal money. The Central Intelligence Agency is the only Federal agency not subject to review by the G.A.O.
 
Clashes With Pentagon
The accounting agency is meticulous. In an annotated copy of each report, auditors list the source of every factual statement. A G.A.O. employee verifies each reference, and the draft report is reviewed by G.A.O. officials.
Despite such safeguards, G.A.O. reports often anger policy makers, and none more than at the Pentagon. About 25 percent of the agency's work focuses on the Defense Department.
Eight years of work by the accounting office documenting technical flaws in the Bigeye chemical bomb recently forced the Defense Department to cancel its production. ''Testing of the weapon was really inadequate,'' said Eleanor Chelimsky, an assistant comptroller general.
John E. Krings, director of weapons testing and evaluation at the Pentagon from 1985 to 1989, complained recently that some G.A.O. investigators had ''low levels of engineering competence and minimal knowledge'' of the military purpose for which weapons were designed. But Representative Dante B. Fascell, Democrat of Florida and chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, praised the G.A.O. for ''carefully and objectively evaluating'' poison-gas munitions.
The G.A.O. was created in 1921, but it traces its roots to 1789, when Congress established a Comptroller in the Treasury Department to ''examine all accounts'' of the Federal Government. The Comptroller General has a mix of duties, some esoteric, some anachronistic. They include prescribing accounting standards for Federal agencies, settling financial claims by and against the Government and issuing authoritative opinions on the legality of Federal spending.
Mr. Goldstein, the assistant comptroller general, said, ''The duties are all tied together in a latticework that reinforces the stature of G.A.O., its image as a powerful organization.''
The G.A.O. brings the same methodical rigor to its own business as to investigations of other agencies. In 1986, when AIDS was stirring panic and prejudice, Mr. Bowsher appointed a panel of 11 G.A.O. officials to devise a policy for the agency. Their report said that G.A.O. employees with the disease should be treated humanely and should not be dismissed or subjected to discrimination.

Havens, left, and Ira Goldstein, assistant comptrollers general at the Congressional investigating agency, in Mr. Bowsher's office. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: How Not to Honor Malcolm X

 BODY:
An unusual coalition of preservationists, civil rights advocates and militant groups is threatening a worthwhile project that would benefit all New Yorkers. At issue is the future of the Audubon Theater and Ballroom, where Malcolm X was assassinated 25 years ago.
The old building in northern Manhattan is abandoned and falling apart. But Columbia University and the city, which owns the site, have long had plans for putting it to good use. 
The structure includes a huge theater and, on the second floor, the Audubon ballroom and another ballroom. The original plan was to replace the building with a six-story, $25 million biomedical laboratory. The laboratory was seen as the cornerstone of a research park that would give the Washington Heights neighborhood, and by extension the whole city, a badly needed economic transfusion.
Columbia and City Hall said they would make sure that the new building contained an appropriate memorial to Malcolm X. But that wasn't enough for civil rights activists, who wanted a larger memorial, or preservationists, who wanted to preserve the Audubon ballroom and terra-cotta facade.
Their criticisms persuaded the Dinkins administration to offer a compromise. The new plan would preserve about 40 percent of the ballroom. City Hall hasn't provided firm projections of the extra costs; estimates range from $6 million to $9 million. Nor has it said where the money would come from. If City Hall can clarify these points, its compromise merits the support of the Board of Estimate, which is scheduled to vote next month.
But even the revised plan doesn't satisfy the critics, who have united behind a proposal from the Municipal Art Society that would save the entire ballroom and facade. That plan, supporters claim, would accommodate Columbia and a larger memorial. They say it would cost about $4 million. The city says it would add an unaffordable $10 million to $15 million to the project.
City Hall's analysis is persuasive. Its compromise plan is fair. Now it's up to Mayor Dinkins to guide it through the Board of Estimate.
The Mayor cannot do it alone, though. He needs help, especially from Ruth Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President. Unfortunately, Ms. Messinger favors the Muncipal Art Society's approach. And under an obscure state law, she has veto power over such projects in her borough. Ms. Messinger would do the city no favor by attempting to act unilaterally. The project has citywide implications, and so deserves a full, unprejudiced hearing before the Board of Estimate.
If for any reason the compromise is blocked -either by Ms. Messinger or the board itself - all New Yorkers, including those most committed to honoring Malcolm X, may wind up with nothing but the shell of an abandoned building. And that would only honor intransigence.

HEADLINE: Reunified Germany Offers Hope for the Future;
The Constant Phoenix

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''Victory With Vision in Europe'' (editorial, July 7), your comparison of the Soviet Union in the putative wake of the cold war to a defeated post-World War I Germany is interesting, but debatable. Soviet armies never invaded Western Europe, nor were subdued in all-out combat. 
Moreover, to state that ''Germany was truncated geographically, and doomed to poverty by reparations'' is more perception than fact. By and large, Germany remained intact; overseas colonies, and border areas returned on the principle of self-determination, were not inherently part of the Fatherland.
As for reparations, myth may have triumphed over reality. The estimated damages caused by invading German armies were repeatedly scaled down, and of that only the smallest fraction were ever paid. Such token amounts were subsidized by American aid tied to war-debt payments from our allies. And far from being doomed to poverty, Germany emerged as the most prosperous European country by the end of the 1920's. Its civilian infrastructure undamaged by foreign invasion, it also benefited from billions in dollar investments (public and private).
Why was Germany increasingly popular in the world of capitalism? In the 1920's and beyond, it was fear of Bolshevism. And in the aftermath of the cold war, the German economy may emerge as the prime beneficiary. Nor is its future irrevocably with the West.
 
JOSEPH BRANDES
Professor of History
William Paterson College
 Wayne, N.J., July 10, 1990

LENGTH: 246 words

HEADLINE: Reunified Germany Offers Hope for the Future;
Beyond Metternich

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Clifford A. and Charles A. Kupchan recommend the Concert of Europe as a model for a new European order (Op-Ed, July 6). The system constructed in 1815 was devised to roll back as much as possible of the revolutionary gains of the previous quarter-century, restore aristocratic privilege and block political progress. 
The German Confederation, the part of the system presided over by two of the powers, Prussia and Austria, was an alliance of increasingly repressive police states. All written works of less than 320 pages were subject to precensorship, and all others to the possibility of postpublication bans and confiscations. Writers and scholars were hounded and sometimes terrorized. The law threatened student fraternity members with fortress imprisonment and leaders with death. Jewish disabilities, relieved in the Napoleonic period, were restored.
Since, as we should know by now, a tyranny cannot manage an economy, tens of thousands of potentially useful citizens were driven to emigration. The effect was to choke off and distort the political maturation of Germany, with consequences that have been felt into our own times.
If this system has been a model for anything, it is for the order of things in Eastern Europe that is crumbling. Whatever one may think of the level of political enlightenment we have reached, surely we are beyond Meternich.
 
JEFFREY L. SAMMONS
Prof. of German, Yale University
 New Haven, July 8, 1990

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
The Wrong Medicine

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
The clear possibility of a recession has been raised by revised Government figures showing that the economy struggled only to a 1.2 percent annual growth rate in the second quarter. So why are White House and Congressional negotiators urging each other on to a tax increase?
Both personal consumption and personal income fell, in the latest summary, as did business investment in new plant and equipment, and housing construction. It's hard to see a tax increase as the right response to these indicators, particularly when the increase is to be coupled with a big cut in Government spending -both deflationary. 
Even if a tax increase and a cut in spending were the right medicine, the Republican package leaked to the press last week - granted that it was billed as only an opening proposal -hardly seems what the doctor should order. It would couple a cap on the deductibility of state and local taxes from Federal income taxes with stiff increases in consumption levies on beer, wine and liquor, and cut more than twice as much - $16 billion -from Federal retirement payments (excluding Social Security) as from military programs - $7 billion.
If the economy needs stimulus, as it plainly does, why increase consumption taxes and reduce retirement payments? What good is a relatively minor reduction - $54 billion - in the Federal deficit if the steps to achieve it kick the economy into the threatened recession?
Capping state and local tax deductibility at $10,000 also could hit some middle-income taxpayers hard enough to curtail their consumption - especially in the Northeastern states, where taxes are high and many economists believe a recession is already under way. Such a cap, moreover, is a bad idea in itself, without regard to its possible effects on buying power.
If the deductibility of state and local taxes were limited, then clearly state and local governments would find it more difficult to raise taxes, or in some cases to keep them at present levels. Yet the Bush Administration has been trying to shift much of what used to be Federal spending to the states and cities - in transportation, for example, in education, even in the so-called ''war on drugs.'' It makes little sense to urge the states to spend more on roads and prisons while limiting their ability to raise revenue.
The cap would have greater effect in the Northeast, where taxes are steep and services have been established at high levels, than in the lower-tax states of the South and West. At the same time, the savings and loan bailout will mostly benefit the South and the West, at the expense of other regions - and it just happens, or maybe it doesn't, that the South and the West are where the Republican Party's strength is centered.
Republicans complain endlessly that the corporation tax is double taxation on stockholders. But if the deductibility of state and local taxes is capped at $10,000, and any amounts paid above that level are taxed again by the Federals, that's much more clearly the kind of double taxation to which Republicans supposedly are opposed.
The proposal was touted as a whack at the wealthy that would make unnecessary an increase in the upper brackets of the Federal income tax. But numerous Americans who are not really at the highest income levels pay more than $10,000 in state and local property and income taxes and also would be disadvantaged by the cap. But in some circumstances, very wealthy Americans might not pay much more than $10,000 in non-Federal taxes.
Besides, more and more evidence accumulates that the Reagan-Bush Republican years of the 1980's have been one long bonanza for the rich -the most graphic accounting being Kevin Phillips's ''The Politics of Rich and Poor.'' If a tax increase is really necessary, therefore, the fairest version would be a high-bracket income-tax adjustment to recapture some of Uncle Sam's handouts to the rich. Americans who did not share in the gravy would then be able to drink their beer untroubled and deduct the full value of their state and local taxes from the Federal bill.
In view of the new and depressing economic statistics, however, those bipartisan negotiators seem to be talking about giving a sick man the wrong treatment. Bringing on a recession in their zeal to cut the deficit would be like giving a patient pneumonia in order to cure a common cold.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Which Mayor Knows Best On the Boycott?

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Who's right about how best to end the boycott by black protesters against a Korean-owned grocery store in Brooklyn: Mayor David N. Dinkins or his predecessor, Edward I. Koch?
Mr. Koch is appalled by what he says is the failure of the Dinkins administration and of New York's civic and religious leaders to champion the besieged store owner and to denounce racist remarks by some demonstrators. He expressed outrage that the police refuse to enforce a court order requiring the demonstrators to stay at least 50 feet from the store.
What also galls the former mayor is his perception that public figures who have acquiesced to Mr. Dinkins's quiet diplomacy are guilty of hypocrisy. 
''I am sure that if black merchants were being boycotted and picketed by whites in Bensonhurst, the leaders would be denouncing the community and demanding action,'' Mr. Koch wrote in his New York Post column. ''Can you imagine the firestorm that would have erupted last year if, when Al Sharpton and his supporters marched in Bensonhurst after the killing of Yusuf Hawkins, and were greeted by white bigots shouting 'Nigger!' and holding up watermelons, I had said that those name-calling bigots were simply exercising their constitutional rights?''
Mr. Koch is probably right, but that may be beside the point.
The boycott of the store on Church Avenue in the Flatbush section began in January after an altercation between a black shopper and the store's Korean employees. Despite the boycott's racial overtones, some demonstrators say the underlying issue is economic empowerment in a community where blacks own few businesses.
''These things take on their own momentum,'' said Bill Lynch, Mr. Dinkins's deputy mayor.
Have the bigots been denounced?
Yes, but probably not as strongly as those in Mr. Koch's hypothetical protest might have been. Mr. Dinkins has, at times, deplored racist remarks by the demonstrators. But Mr. Koch complained that some officials have defended the demonstrators' free speech rights and others, whom he named, have been largely silent. Among those, Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, said she hadn't been asked and didn't think it was desirable to intervene in another borough; Hazel N. Dukes, who heads the state branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said she would comment when a mayoral fact-finding commission reports next month; Laura D. Blackburne, the N.A.A.C.P. counsel who heads that commission, said, ''condemning racist language is not useful if nothing else is done.'' Should the court order be enforced? Responding to a civil suit by the store owner, a State Supreme Court justice barred picketing within 50 feet of the store. The frustrated store owner asked the court to compel the police to enforce the order. The judge did; the city appealed. Police officials said the only alternative site for the demonstrators is across the street, in front of a church building, and that moving them there would probably cause a violent confrontation that could prolong the boycott.
''To protect the right to peacefully protest is not to approve the sentiments expressed by the picketers,'' said Victor A. Kovner, the city's Corporation Counsel. What would Mr. Koch have done? Better yet, what did he do? Mr. Koch said if he were still mayor, the Human Rights Commission would be suing the demonstrators and the court order would have been enforced. During a 1988 boycott of another Korean-owned store in Brooklyn, he told merchants he would support them if they sued, but said the city would not initiate a suit. They were short of money, though, and Mr. Koch's Police Commissioner, Benjamin Ward, warned them that court intervention could galvanize the demonstrators and expand the protest. ''They did it his way and went out of business,'' Mr. Koch recalled. He said it had not occurred to him then to go to the store and buy provisions for Gracie Mansion, as he has suggested Mr. Dinkins do.
That Mr. Dinkins campaigned as a conciliator and, like most of the demonstrators, happens to be black, has not carried much weight in swaying militants whom he neither knows nor wishes to antagonize. At some point, failed diplomacy may be perceived as weakness.
That Mr. Koch's message was morally correct does not mean he would have been the ideal messenger. He had so antagonized many blacks that his presence or even his public posture might have triggered larger demonstrations and further polarized the city.
''Maybe,'' Mr. Koch acknowledged, ''but at least you would have done the right thing.''

HEADLINE: After Heady 1980's, Homeowners Face a Hangover of Foreclosure

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HACKENSACK, N.J., July 26

 BODY:
Mortgage foreclosures are soaring in the New York metropolitan region as growing numbers of property owners are overwhelmed by crushing real-estate debt.
Just months after the giddy boom years of the 1980's, with their rising home values, generous bank lending policies and firm optimism about the regional economy, banks have started declaring defaults on thousands of delinquent mortgages and forcing owners to scramble for new financing or face property losses.
Officials in the region say they are stunned by the depth and suddenness of the increase in foreclosures.
 
Worst Market in 50 Years
In many cases, officials attribute it to declining real-estate values, people including well-paid professionals carrying too much debt and the slumping construction industry. 
''There's no precedence for the numbers were getting now,'' said Myron C. Weinstein, chief of the foreclosure office of New Jersey Superior Court. ''We're getting 1,400 new filings a month and I don't think anybody knows the upside anymore. No one really knows the cause of the magnitude of the jump, except that this is the worst real-estate market in 50 years.''
''I'm seeing the most dramatic surge in the last 25 years,'' said Roger Sirlin, a Westchester County lawyer who represents mortgage lenders in southern New York. ''The foreclosures are bridging the entire socioeconomic spectrum. Right now, I'm foreclosing on doctors, lawyers, architects, dentists, stock brokers and real-estate people. I'm foreclosing on loans as high as $1.6 million. The average is around $200,000.'' In Connecticut in the last two fiscal years, bank foreclosure filings have almost tripled, to 9,248 for the year ending on June 30, from 3,482 for the year ending on June 30, 1988, said Larry Moore, a spokesman for the Connecticut Judicial Department.
Across New Jersey, similar filings rose to 11,816 in 1989, from 8,182 in 1988, Mr. Weinstein said. As of June, there were 8,478 filings, an increase of nearly 50 percent over the same six-month period last year, he said.
New York State's court system does not keep statewide figures. But county officials report sharp increases. Between January and June, judges in Westchester issued 166 judgments of foreclosure, the last step before sale of a property at auction. For all of 1989, there were 112 such judgments. Suffolk County has had 655 similar judgments through June, well ahead of the pace that produced 853 in 1989. In 1988, Suffolk had 439 judgments. In Rockland County, banks filed 251 foreclosures between January and June. There were 193 for the first six months of 1989.
In all three states, foreclosures for single-family homes have increased since 1988 while decreasing nationally, said Thomas Holloway, senior economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association of America in Washington.
Regional court officials say their figures represent all commercial and residential properties. They include hundreds of single-family houses in the cities and suburbs; an unfinished town house project, Knickerbocker Village, in Old Tappan, N.J., that was sold at a sheriff's auction for $100; condominiums in North Salem, N.Y., Monmouth Beach, N.J., and near Atlantic City; a shopping center in Aberdeen, N.J., and a nursing home in Spring Lake Heights.
Beneath the figures are stories of deep debt and personal hardship and, for some, despair and tragedy. Last month in New York, a Vietnam veteran whose foreclosed home is up for auction on Aug. 3 committed suicide. #3 Months Behind on the Mortgage The man, a self-employed house framer, built his home three years ago and was unable to make his $3,000-a-month mortgage payments when his $200,000-a-year business soured, said his widow, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. She attributed his suicide to his war experience and his mounting debt.
She said she is three months behind on the mortgage payment and on an $800-a-month loan for two trucks. The banks refused to restructure the debt, she said.
''The banks didn't want any partial payment,'' she said. ''They wanted the whole thing.''
A banker in his mid-50's in Westchester County said he lost his condominium when he became overwhelemed by debt, particularly college loans for his five children. At one point, their education costs were $38,000 a year, against his annual salary of $47,500. Garnishees have cut his net weekly income from $583 to $192 and he is 10 months behind in his $1,202 mortgage payment. ''It all came down too heavy on me,'' he said. ''I just ran out of money. I've always made good on every penny of my debt and I'll pay this off if they just give me a chance.''
 
Banks 'Feeling the Pressure'
In Monmouth County, N.J., where 113 foreclosed properties have been sold at sheriff's auction between January and July 23 - as opposed to 120 for all of 1989 - a young woman returned to her foreclosed home in Hazlet after giving birth only to find that a bank that had bought her house at auction had begun eviction proceedings. A judge eventually blocked the eviction.
Experts closest to the spurt in foreclosures offer several explanations.
''In Connecticut several banks have experienced losses and Federal regulators are looking at loan portfolios,'' said Judge Aaron Ment, Chief Court Administrator for the state. ''My sense is the banks are feeling the pressure: Federal regulatory pressure and shareholder pressure and management pressure.''
Experts also say a decline in property values after their dizzying appreciation of the mid-1980's has left some owners, particularly those who bought at peak prices, watching their property values slide toward - or even below - their mortgage amount. In those cases, some willingly abandon their properties.
 
Too Much Debt, Too Little Value
''That was the real story in Texas and Oklahoma; real property lost value and people walked away,'' said George Sternlieb, founding director of the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University. ''We're just seeing the beginning of this and no one has a handle on how long it will last.''
Another reason cited is that property owners are overextended.
Mr. Sirlin, the bankers' lawyer in Westchester County, said nearly all his foreclosures are on adjustable-rate mortgages issued in 1987 and 1988 that carried first-year interest rates of 7 percent and subsequent annual increases of two percentage points, with a maximum of 14.9 percent.
Banks, he said, were eager to lend in the late '80's and, because of a lack of Federal requirements, assessed a borrowers ability to repay only on the initial 7 percent rate.
''People can't afford the second interest bump and they're falling behind two or three months' payments,'' he said. ''That's the typical scenario.''
Banking authorities say all three elements are at work now.
''Banks are scrutinizing portfolios more closely because of pressure from regulators,'' said E. Robert Levy, executive director of the New Jersey Mortgage Bankers Association. ''I would emphasize that financial institutions and mortgage companies do not desire to foreclose. They make every effort to work things out. Foreclosure is expensive, time consuming and requires a lot of reserves to be set up.''

HEADLINE: Heritage and Pageantry At Powwow in Queens

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
More than 300 years after the Matinecock Indians traded away much of what is now eastern Queens, dancers in buckskin pants and feather headdresses swayed to the rhythm of drums during the weekend against a backdrop of Little Neck Parkway traffic.
Well into Saturday night and again yesterday afternoon, 250 Indians from the Mohawk, Hopi, Winnebago, Apache, Lenape and 20 other tribes gathered for the Thunderbird American Midsummer Powwow at the Queens County Farm Museum in Floral Park.
Men wearing war paint and waving spears slung themselves close to the ground in a warriors' dance, miming creeping up on an enemy. Women spun in a frenzy until their shawl fringes floated. ''Fancy dancers'' improvised wild moves, trying to outdo each other. Singers alternated between the slow, low-pitched wailing characteristic of the Southern Plains and the fast falsetto chant of Northern tribes. 
About 35 vendors sold Navajo rugs, Hopi kachina dolls, silver and turquoise, fry bread, corn soup, sassafras tea, Indian tacos and souvenir tepees to the 7,000 non-Indians who attended.
 
An Urban Powwow
''It's a little strange to have a powwow with all these buildings around,'' said Earl Kaye, an Arizona Navajo selling leather items and beadwork.
A powwow is traditionally a social gathering, not an open-air market. The origins of the word are disputed; some texts argue that it is Algonquin for ''rejuvenate,'' while others say it evolved from a grass dance ceremony among the Omahas.
Whatever its history, the assembly is an important way of maintaining traditions and teaching non-Indians about Indian life, organizers said.
''It's good to come together and educate the public,'' said Lance Richmond, a Mohawk from Brooklyn. ''A lot of people think Indians don't exist in New York.''
 
Like Powwows of the Plains
The powwow has been at the farm each July since 1982. The gathering was organized by the Thunderbird American Indian Dancers, a New York troupe founded in 1963 to preserve Indian music and dance, and proceeds go to scholarships.
The powwow was modeled after ones on the Plains, said Louis Mofsie, the Thunderbirds' director. ''We do Western-style powwows because they're the most popular and the dancing is less structured.''
The bookstall and newsstand of the Native American Authors Distribution Project was especially popular. The project started about five years ago in Greenfield Center, N.Y., said Ron Welburn, a Cherokee managing the booth, adding, ''We're the only Native American distributor.'' Passers-by perused copies of The Cherokee Advocate, Akwesasne Notes and other newspapers.
Many booths flew American flags with the head of an Indian warrior superimposed on the stripes. ''A Navajo group in New Mexico came out with it about a year ago,'' said Doug Burdick, a Blackfoot jewelry-maker from Pennsylvania. ''Indians see it as, like, their own flag.''
 
'On the Graves of Indians'
Political views were visible at the farm's ad hoc campground. Several vans sported bumper stickers declaring: ''America was built on the graves of Indians.''
Such powwows are also opportunities for local Indians to affirm their identities.
''In the 1950's and 1960's, part of downtown Brooklyn was an Indian neighborhood, but now there's no concentrated area,'' said Rosemary Richmond, the director of the American Indian Community House, New York's largest social-service agency for Indians. ''That's part of the problem. It makes it difficult to organize Native Americans or reach them with services.''
The city has about 20,000 Indians, with another 5,000 in the suburbs, Ms. Richmond said. Many came to New York early in this century to be ironworkers on skyscrapers.
Housing, health care and unemployment are Indians' principal problems here, she said. ''There are many homeless Native Americans, and many others don't have private doctors and health insurance.'' The National Urban Indian Council has estimated that unemployment among urban Indians is as high as 60 to 80 percent. Tuberculosis, cirrhosis and teen-age suicide are more common among Indians than the general population, according to the Federal Indian Health Service.
Another more subtle but equally intractable problem was in evidence at the powwow: white children streaking their faces with paint and dancing around patting their lips.
''There are many stereotypes to combat,'' Mr. Mofsie said. ''When you tell people you're an Indian, they say, 'You don't look like one. You don't live on a reservation. What are you doing in the big city?' But half of all Indians live in metropolitan areas because there are no jobs on reservations. And the 'woo-woo,' patting the lips: That probably came from Hollywood, but it's very insulting.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Spectators watching performers at the Thunderbird American Midsummer Powwow in Queens. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
