HEADLINE: Bruno Kreisky, Austria's Leader For a Record 13 Years, Dies at 79

BYLINE: By PETER B. FLINT

 BODY:
Bruno Kreisky, who dominated Austria's public life as the nation's longest-serving Chancellor from 1970 to 1983, died yesterday at Lainz Hospital in Vienna. He was 79 years old.
Mr. Kreisky, who consolidated the neutral nation's prosperity and gave it a vigorous voice in international affairs, died of heart disease, hospital officials said.
The former Chancellor, an urbane and pragmatic Socialist, was first elected to Parliament in 1956 and was Foreign Minister from 1959 to 1966. He was chairman of Austria's Social Democratic Party from 1967 to 1983 and its honorary chairman until 1987. 
He at times evoked criticism abroad, particularly from Israel for meeting with Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader. He defended the contacts as efforts to achieve an Israeli-Arab peace and called it hypocritical to trade with Libya while snubbing its leader.
Mr. Kreisky, who won a majority in Parliament for the Socialists three consecutive times and who speedily fulfilled a pledge to resign if he lost that majority, was widely respected in Europe and overseas as a leading postwar Social Democrat.
 
A Tribute From Brandt
In a statement yesterday, Willy Brandt, a longtime friend and former Socialist Chancellor of West Germany, said that with Mr. Kreisky's death, ''Austria loses one of its most distinguished postwar politicans, European democracy one of its most convincing leading figures.''
Franz Vranitzky, Austria's present Socialist Chancellor, said: ''We have lost one of the greatest Austrian politicians of this century. With his international reputation, he gave Austria a position in the world that far outstripped the size of our country.''
Mr. Kreisky, who was widely popular among Austrians, stressed European detente and ''active neutrality'' for Austria while he negotitated an association agreement with the European Economic Community and made Vienna a leading center of international forums, including summit talks. He also accelerated Austria's policy of aiding Soviet Jews in migrating to Israel and elsewhere.
More than 200,000 Jews from the Soviet Union passed through the Austrian capital in the 1970's and 1980's, according to Paul Hofmann, a former correspondent for The New York Times. In his book ''The Viennese: Splendor, Twilight and Exile,'' published in 1988 by Anchor Press/Doubleday, he offered the following conclusion: ''For many years the state of American-Soviet relations at any given time could be gauged from the volume of Jewish emigration flowing through Vienna.''
 
A Jewish Agnostic
Bruno Kreisky was born in Vienna on Jan. 22, 1911, to Irene Felix and Max Kreisky, a textile industrialist. The family was of Jewish descent, but the son later described himself as a religious agnostic.
The young man attended schools in Vienna and, at the age of 15, joined the Socialist youth movement. The Social Democratic Party was outlawed in 1934, and in 1935 he was arrested and imprisoned for 18 months. On his release, he entered the University of Vienna and earned a doctor-of-laws degree.
After the Nazi takeover, he was again arrested, in 1938, for political activities. He escaped to Sweden, where he spent the war years, working in a consumer sales cooperative and occasionally serving as a correspondent for Swedish newspapers and also as adviser on Austrian affairs for the Swedish Government. It was in Sweden that he met and married his wife, Vera Alice Fuerth.
At war's end, Mr. Kreisky returned to Austria, joined the Foreign Service and was assigned to the legation in Stockholm for four years. In 1953, he became State Secretary for Foreign Affairs, and in the next two years was involved in negotiations that led to the restoration of Austrian independence under terms of maintaining a neutrality similar to that of Switzerland.
 
Neutrality 'No Easy Escape'
In 1959, he became the first Socialist to serve as Foreign Minister in a coalition government. He was deeply committed to making Austria's neutrality more than a simple avoidance of commitment.
In 1960, he wrote: ''A policy of neutrality is by no means an easy escape from international responsibilities. The governments of neutral nations are called upon to cooperate, within the limitations imposed upon them by their status and size, in solving the great questions of our day.''
Mr. Kreisky was a folksy, well-read, low-key man who kept his telephone number listed in the Vienna directory for many years after becoming the head of government.
His durability led to the nickname ''Emperor Bruno.'' In insisting in 1980 that he would resign as Chancellor if it meant haggling within a coalition, he offered this explanation:
''To work in a coalition government is a terrible waste of time. A coalition government is mostly a government of confrontation. This is not my business.''
 
A Period of Prosperity
In 1973, responding to Israeli criticism of his evenhanded attitude toward Israel and Palestinian Arabs, he said he could see no other possible policy for Austria but ''equidistance between the Arab states and Israel.''
During much of Mr. Kreisky's tenure, Austria prospered, with a moderate yearly inflation rate of about 5 percent, and close to full employment. Labor-management conflicts were quietly settled by negotiation and compromise.
In foreign affairs, he once said, ''The Austrians' task is to win maximum trust in the West, and at the same time only evoke a minimum of mistrust in the East.''
Mr. Kreisky's wife died last year. Survivors include a son, Peter, and a daughter, Susanne.

HEADLINE: Review/Concert;
Where Chamber Music Is Learned and Performed

BYLINE: By BERNARD HOLLAND, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MARLBORO, Vt., July 29

 BODY:
For 40 summers, music's young professionals and advanced amateurs have been coming to the tiny campus of Marlboro College to get away from concert halls, managers, press agents and the people who write reviews like this one.
Guided by mutually agreed on schedules of hair-raising complexity, this year's assembly of 68 musicians splits into ever-changing smaller groups of two, three, four and more, and then disperses to the old white framed buildings of what was once a farm. Here chamber music is learned and played.
Seventy-six pieces in various states of preparation and ranging alphabetically from Bach to Zemlinsky have emanated from the barns, cottages and farmhouses standing on this gentle Vermont hilltop this week. Three were performed before an audience on Saturday night, and three more were performed this afternoon. 
The concert on Saturday offered Mozart's Divertimento for six winds in F (K. 213) led crisply by a young oboist, Rudolph Vrbsky. But it was Janacek's song cycle ''The Diary of One Who Vanished'' that provided the evening's most startling beauty and originality.
In this story of a plowman beguiled and undone by a gypsy lover, Gregory Hopkins sang with a decisive tenor, using the original Czechoslovak text and negotiating vocal lines of punishing difficulty with great confidence.
Mary Westbrook-Geha was the strong mezzo-soprano. Supporting them and an offstage vocal trio was Luis Batlle, a splendid Uruguayan pianist who first came to Marlboro in 1956.
The programs were chosen on Thursday with one late-hour change on Friday. Pieces needing more work may never leave the practice room all summer. Invitees to Marlboro are enjoined by letter from any expectation of public performance so that words like ''rehearsal'' - which imply a concert deadline - are shunned.
Terminology is important to Marlborians. Roughly one-fourth of this year's musicians are called seniors (those older than 50) or invited artists(those older than 35). Calling them teachers and their younger colleagues students is to invite the horrified looks of administrators here.
The elders, they say, are carefully placed with young artists in what is called a society of equals. The venerable violinist Felix Galimir moves from string quartet to string quartet playing second violin and distributing his wisdom and experience through word and osmosis.
Isidore Cohen of the Beaux Arts Trio shared a Beethoven trio on Saturday (the E flat, Op. 1) with Dena Levine, a pianist, and Jean-Guihen Queyras, a cellist. This was classic Marlboro: Mr. Cohen's dignified playing in the slow movement held a staying hand against two excellent young players bursting at the seams with expressive energy, yet it was the older player who turned up the heat in the finale.
In much the same vein, David Soyer, the cellist of the Guarneri Quartet, and Kerry McDermott, a violinist at the New York Philharmonic, joined much less experienced musicians in the Schubert C-major quintet this afternoon.
The seniors welcome interpretive ideas, but they are by definition on the high end of this society of equals. It is difficult, for example, to imagine the gauntly elegant octogenarian Rudolf Serkin taking more interpretive advice from his junior colleagues in the Beethoven Op. 70 Piano Trio than he is currently giving.
Indeed, Marlboro's terminology is fragile to the point of euphemism. It is easier, however, to forgive the niceties when one understands that it is the tone of words like ''teacher,'' ''student'' and ''instruction'' that its directors are trying to avoid.
Accustomed to authoritarian training as virtuosos, for example, young East Europeans here are reveling in the chance to be musicians. ''They are getting a sense of family and a sense of freedom not that common in the East Bloc,'' said Frank Salomon, who with Anthony Checchia has managed Marlboro for more than 30 years. ''They love the unlimited rehearsals and the unlimited food.''
Marlboro has been recruiting throughout Europe for two years. This year's group includes an Albanian violinist living in Paris, a Soviet pianist living in New York, two East Germans and two Czechoslovaks. One German, Jan Vogler, is principal cellist at the Dresden Staatskapelle Orchestra.
Participants live dormitory style on campus and dine together, taking their turns waiting tables and cleaning up. The waiters on Friday night included Mr. Cohen, the flutist Carol Wincenc and Donald Weilerstein, a violinist with the Cleveland Quartet.
Marlboro seniors get expense money and a small honorarium but otherwise donate their time. The younger musicians pay as they are able: either now, in the future, or not at all. The festival's relatively modest $10 million endowment helps absorb all this, but as its administrators say, the free services of professional musicians is of enormous economic benefit.
The concert on Friday, which was not precisely a Marlboro event, offered Blanche Moyse conducting her own chorale and small orchestra in blunt, rough-cut performances of four Bach cantatas. Marlboro fellows infiltrated the orchestra and took major wind parts. All five singers at this summer's festival served as soloists.
Miss Moyse is a member of one of the three distinguished musical families that formed Marlboro in 1951. Her father was the French flutist Marcel Moyse, who with Adolf and Herman Busch and Mr. Serkin decided that music needed a place outside the pressures of a concert career.
The Guarneri Quartet was formed here in 1964, and two of its members, Mr. Soyer and Arnold Steinhardt, return regularly. Practically every major chamber ensemble quartet in this country - from the Emerson Quartet to Tashi - have members with Marlboro training. A lone exception is the Tokyo Quartet, whose violist, Kazuhide Isomura, remarked not long ago, ''It's like operating without a license.''

CORRECTION-DATE: August 1, 1990, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about the Marlboro Music Festival in Marlboro, Vt., misstated the professional affiliation of a musician at the festival. The musician, Donald Weilerstein, was a founding member of the Cleveland Quartet but left the ensemble last year.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Slow Book Sales? Off to the Shops!

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Isabel Geffner spent two days at the Shakespeare & Company bookstore on the Upper West Side of Manhattan last week, unpacking boxes of books, stocking shelves, setting up displays and fielding questions from customers about what to read on vacation and where to find a book entitled ''Sex After Sixty'' - a ''gift book,'' the customer stressed.
While these were routine tasks, Ms. Geffner was not a routine employee. She is, in fact, the associate publisher of the Dell Publishing Company and is usually pre-occupied with manuscripts, authors, agents, deadlines and policy issues worth hundreds of thousands of dollars to her company.
Her stint at Shakespeare & Company is part of a new - and publishing executives say bold - experiment by Bantam Doubleday Dell. Under the program, 60 top executives are being sent this summer to work for two to three days in bookstores across the country to learn more about how books are actually sold after they have rolled off the presses. 
The experiment - which involves independent and chain bookstores -is a response to the current slump in book sales. While it will cost Bantam Doubleday Dell only $100,000, publishing executives say the program borders on the revolutionary in an industry that has been slow to accept change and adopt new practices in the increasing competition for the public's leisure dollars.
''What's exciting is that the program includes people who will benefit the most from a foray into the real world,'' said Joel Turner, the owner of Under Cover Books in Shaker Heights, Ohio.
The unusual experiment was devised by Jack Hoeft, the president and chief operating officer of Bantam Doubleday Dell.
''I have a feeling that not enough people in publishing get out of their offices and into bookstores, unless it's their neighborhood bookstore,'' he said. ''Our hope is that by doing this, we'll come back with a better understanding of how and why people buy books, and how we can help bookstores sell more of our titles.''
Even Mr. Hoeft will be gettting hands-on experience today and tomorrow, working at Ives Bookstore in Fort Myers, Fla.
As unsold books - ''returns,'' as they are known in publishing - have begun to flood back at rates as high as 60 percent on some titles, and as profit margins become razor thin or nonexistent, book publishers have intensified the search for greater efficiency and economies.
They are also seeking to strengthen their ties to bookstores, where retail sales this year are expected to reach $7.2 billion. While this is up from $5.1 billion in 1987, the American Booksellers Association reports, sales have slumped markedly in the second quarter for some publishing houses.
To cut costs, many publishers have installed computerized ordering systems, increased their discounts to booksellers and absorbed the cost of shipping books to the stores.
 
'Lots of Preconceptions'
But until Mr. Hoeft ordered his troops out from behind their desks and into the bookselling trenches, no publisher thought it was necessary for so many executives to experience the retail side of the business.
''We have lots of preconceptions but not a lot of knowledge,'' said Stuart Applebaum, a vice president of Bantam Doubleday Dell. ''Various executives make ambassadorial visits to a few major accounts for a few hours, but it's rare that we roll up our sleeves and do the nitty-gritty work that makes a bookstore.''
If the experiment works, the company will expand it to include another 100 of Bantam Doubleday Dell's 1,500 employees. Mr. Hoeft said he would consider the investment worthwhile if it caused his executives to think about such things as why stores order certain books and not others, how they display them, whether display makes a difference and what the company's competitors do differently and better.
Mr. Turner of Under Cover Books said the few days that the executives spent in the stores were likely to be less important than the lines of communication they established. ''When a problem comes up somewhere down the road,'' he said, ''a publisher will say, 'I'll phone the store where I worked and get their view.' ''
Bantam Doubleday Dell, which is owned by Bertelsmann A.G., the West German media giant, publishes a total of 1,400 new titles a year and sells them through more than 100,000 retail outlets in North America. Its three publishing houses sell the books to stores at an average discount of 44 percent off the suggested cover price.
Working through the American Booksellers Association, Bantam Doubleday Dell had little trouble enlisting the cooperation of 60 stores in 26 states and the District of Columbia, from E. Shaver Fine Books in Savannah, Ga., to Chaucer & Company in Santa Barbara, Calif. Eleven chain stores are included, three each from Crown Books and the Waldenbooks chain, two B. Dalton stores, and one each from Barnes & Noble, Doubleday and Brentano's.
 
Getting Their Hands Dirty
Mr. Hoeft told participating bookstores to treat the executives like any new employee; that is, they can get their hands dirty. The executives are prohibited only from ringing up transactions (to avoid any potential misunderstandings from handling money) and from pushing particular titles (to resist the temptation to play favorites with the company's books), and they are asked to write two-page reports on their experiences.
The experience of Ms. Geffner at Shakespeare & Company, a large store in an affluent neighborhood, convinced her of its value.
She said she learned much about book buyers and sellers. She developed a new appreciation for the importance of covers in selling books. And she learned that bookstores prefer four-color posters for their windows, rather than blowups of prominent book reviews.
Felice Rose, the store's general manager, also learned a few things. ''We get frustrated seeing all the money pumped into best sellers, but I learned that the publishers do, too,'' she said. ''Yet they have to publish best sellers in order to publish quality books that don't sell as well.''
 
'Lot of Unglamorous Work'
Marly Rusoff, an associate publisher of Doubleday, is eagerly awaiting her two days at Baxter's Books in Minneapolis. Ms. Rusoff once owned Rusoff & Company Book Dealers in Minneapolis.
''But bookselling has changed so much in the 12 years or so since I was in it,'' Ms. Rusoff said. ''We didn't have computerized inventories then, and children's books are a lot more important than they ever were. But I'm sure there's still a lot of unglamorous work involved, and knowing the small margins bookstores operate under, they can always use free help with the unpacking.''

HEADLINE: Tool Orders Rose 27.2% Last Month

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Reflecting a surge in exports, orders for American-made machine tools rose 27.2 percent in June from the level of May, the industry's trade association says in its monthly report. But economists cautioned that the rise did not reflect significantly higher spending on capital improvements in the United States.
According to the report, which is being released today by the Association for Manufacturing Technology, machine tool orders rose to $262.7 million in June from the May level of $206.4 million. The June orders were 9.1 percent higher than those in June of last year. 
For the first half of 1990, machine tool orders were down 4.8 percent from the period a year earlier.
 
Indicators of Capital Spending
Machine tools are power-driven devices that cut or shape metal parts used in products ranging from appliances and vehicles to aircraft and construction materials. The strength of tool orders generally reflects the strength of industrial production, and economists consider patterns of machine tool sales to be important indicators of capital spending by manufacturers.
The level of new orders has fluctuated widely in the last few months. Some analysts said after increases in March and April that the gains reflected slight rises in capital spending by domestic manufacturers, particularly in the aircraft industry.
But economists cautioned that one large order by a single company or from any large foreign customer could affect the overall picture on orders. They said the June figures continued to show that American manufacturers were reluctant to raise their spending on capital investments from what had been sluggish levels.
 
Weakness in Profits Cited
''The level of new orders for machine tools indicates that the sense of sluggishness is being ratified,'' said Neal M. Soss, chief economist for the First Boston Corporation. Mr. Soss added that the recent weakness in corporate profits was likely to translate into a continuation of lower capital spending and weakness in tool orders.
In recent months, as car sales have slumped, auto makers have sharply curtailed their orders for machine tools. That has particularly affected tool producers, because the auto industry typically accounts for about a third of domestic tool sales.
New orders from foreign customers rose 75.5 percent in June, compared with the figures of May. Domestic orders were up 20.5 percent in June.
For the first six months of the year, foreign orders increased by 35.5 percent, compared with the period a year earlier, and domestic orders dropped by 10.5 percent.
Shipments of machine tools climbed 28.3 percent in June, to $350.2 million. Domestic shipments rose 27.8 percent and foreign shipments were up by 32.5 percent. For the first six months, shipments of machine tools increased 10.6 percent, compared with the period last year. Shipments to foreign customers increased 16.9 percent while domestic shipments rose 9.7 percent for the first half of 1990.
''We are very pleased to note that both foreign and domestic orders were strong in June,'' said Albert W. Moore, president of the association. ''The second-quarter 1990 total orders were the highest since the first quarter of 1989.''
''Analysts had forecast an improved order picture in the second half of 1990,'' he added. ''We hope that we are seeing the beginning of this predicted upturn.''
 
Worries on Interest Rates
But Mr. Moore added that interest rates continued to cause concern for machine tool makers. ''Our industry is particularly sensitive to interest rates as capital equipment spending requires large outlays,'' he said. ''Many of our members and their customers have suffered from increasingly stringent credit conditions.''
He added that recent indications by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, that interest rates might be eased offered hope that the American economic expansion would continue, ''and that potential customers for manufacturing equipment will not be discouraged by a lack of credit.''
The level of metal-cutting tools, which include boring mills and lathes, increased 35 percent in June from May's level. That segment of the industry typically accounts for three-fourths of new orders. Orders for metal-forming tools were up 11.7 percent in June from May's level.
The machine tool order backlog stood at $1.56 billion in June, down from the May level of $1.65 billion.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
So Far, No Shock For Consumers

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
AMERICAN consumers rarely cause a recession. Even when their incomes are barely rising, which is the case today, they somehow manage to spend enough to keep the economy afloat. Only a national shock seems to frighten them into cutting back so drastically that a recession becomes unavoidable. And so far in 1990, that shock has not come.
As Paul Samuelson, the Nobel laureate in economics, puts it, ''People try to maintain their living standards even in hard times, and they don't ration their spending until they feel forced to do so.'' 
What often forces them are widespread layoffs and rising unemployment. That alarms not only the newly unemployed, but also the millions of people still holding jobs. They postpone purchases and give up amenities and an incipient recession becomes a full-fledged one. This has been the pattern in six of the eight recessions since World War II. Only twice has the consumer initiated a recession without warm-up blows from layoffs, unemployment or other events that were already moving the nation toward recession.
The first consumer-led recession was in 1974, in response to suddenly rising oil prices that threatened to disrupt household budgets. Six years later, when President Carter restricted consumer credit to fight inflation, many Americans responded by putting away their credit cards for a while. Consumers account for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, and when they ration this vast buying power, the economy inevitably contracts.
''There has to be a shock to make consumers slow down enough to participate in a recession,'' said David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services. Absent the shock, economists have great difficulty anticipating how consumers will behave during a prolonged period of sluggish economic growth, such as the present one.
The usual economic data fail to offer reliable guidelines. Commerce Department figures released on Friday, for example, showed that personal disposable income - what Americans have left to spend from all sources after paying their taxes - had risen at an average annual rate of only 1.5 percent over the past year, adjusted for inflation. But personal consumption almost kept pace, rising by 1.1 percent since June 1989.
From the viewpoint of the economy's health, the most important consumer spending involves durable goods, like cars, appliances and furniture. When this is cut sharply, the manufacturing sector responds by shutting down factories and laying off workers. But while spending on nondurables, like clothing, gasoline and restaurant meals, keeps weakening, spending on durables seems to be holding its own. True, the Commerce Department data released Friday showed a big cutback in durable-goods spending in the second quarter. On average, however, these purchases in the first six months of 1990 have remained above 1989 levels.
Clearly, the consumer is hard to anticipate: income might be weak, but spending holds up anyway. What is more, Americans have in reserve enough extra borrowing power to increase their spending, if the spirit moves them. Installment payments eat up a relatively low 11 percent of the average American's disposable income, largely because monthly payments have been stretched over longer periods. And delinquency rates on various forms of consumer credit have declined this year, surveys show.
''We consider this a sign that consumers are being cautious and are bringing their payments up to date,'' said Virginia Stafford, a spokeswoman for the American Bankers Association. The declining delinquency rates are also a sign that consumers can increase their borrowing and spending, if their caution should dissolve.
The key, then, to what happens next is the consumer's sense of well-being, a state of mind not tied very tightly to income. The Government's Index of Leading Economic Indicators, which tries to forecast the next swing in the national economy, recognizes this. Among the index's components, the one dealing with consumers reflects surveys of ''consumer sentiment,'' not income or spending. These surveys show a decline in consumer confidence this year, but not to recessionary levels, except in New England and the mid-Atlantic states.
In sum, consumers are not in shock in most of the nation, says Fabian Linden, who surveys consumer sentiment for the Conference Board, a business organization. ''But more people are saying that jobs will soon become harder to find,'' he said. ''There is less impulse-buying because there is less security about jobs.''
Another factor is also at work: even without a shock to their confidence, consumers are not likely to become big car buyers in the early 1990's, and motor vehicles account for more than 15 percent of all consumer spending. The problem is that car ownership has reached the level of almost one car for every driver in America, says Wynn Van Bussman, a Chrysler Corporation economist.
''To convince people to spend more on cars, you have to convince them to buy more options such as stereos and safety devices, and they are doing this,'' Mr. Van Bussman said. But when it comes to stimulating the economy, buying more options does not provide the punch that comes from adding to the number of cars on the road. ''It is a force that is holding down consumer spending,'' Mr. Van Bussman said. But not to recessionary levels.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Lower Interest Rates Called Likely

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A strikingly weaker view of the economy than the one that existed just a few short days ago has altered psychology in the credit markets, increasing the chances that interest rates will move lower in the weeks ahead, analysts say.
The touchstone for the shift in sentiment was provided by the Commerce Department, which released three years of revised economic statistics on Friday that showed growth was much weaker than had previously been thought.
In its revisions, the department pared the relatively healthy 2.6 percent growth rate recorded last year to a decidedly more anemic 1.8 percent, lowered its figure for growth in the first three months of 1990 to 1.7 percent, from 1.9 percent, and estimated on a preliminary basis that the expansion slowed to a 1.2 percent annual rate in the second quarter.
 
Change in Perception
''When you revise growth in 1989 from a 2.6 percent rate to 1.8 percent, it changes the perception about where you had been,'' said Steven Slifer, a senior vice president and financial market economist at Shearson Lehman Government Securities. 
''Moreover, it seems we have slowed down further in the first six months of this year, and I have difficulty seeing where we are going to get strength in the second half,'' he added.
To market participants, the weaker gross national product numbers also provided a useful explanation for the Federal Reserve Board's unexpected decision to ease monetary policy earlier this month.
 
Resolve Was Questioned
Ever since the Fed moved to lower the rate on overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market to 8 percent, from 8.25 percent, bond traders have been uneasily questioning if the central bank had lost its resolve as an inflation fighter.
''I think the Fed probably had a pretty good idea about these numbers when they eased policy,'' said Robert M. Giordano, a partner and director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company. ''And the chances of getting another easing move before we get a budget deal has probably improved.''
Even as the weaker economic statistics seem to have vindicated the Fed, they have made negotiating a meaningful cut in the Federal budget deficit much more difficult, Mr. Giordano and other analysts said.
''You can't get away from the fact that any significant cut in the deficit at a time when the economy is soft may not be able to take place,'' said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank.
 
Smaller Reduction Favored
Gail Fosler, chief economist at the Conference Board, said the weaker economic statistics ''argue for a budget reduction package that is smaller, not larger,'' than the $50 billion reduction that had been expected for the last few months.
The magnitude of the Government's borrowing needs will likely be noticed again on Wednesday, when the Treasury is expected to announce the size of its quarterly refunding auctions. Most analysts are expecting that the Treasury will announce that it intends to sell a record $31.5 billion worth of new 3-year and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds.
The exact time of the auctions is still a matter of conjecture, since Congress has not yet approved an increase in the Treasury's debt ceiling.
 
Delay of at Least a Week
Market participants who have spoken with Treasury officials said late last week that an increase in the debt ceiling does not appear likely until Aug. 10. Such a delay would postpone the expected auction dates by a week at least.
The flood of new Treasury issues is likely to prevent long-term interest rates from declining as much as short-term rates, analysts said. But the prospect of further easing moves by the Federal Reserve and continued weak economic growth should help drum up demand for the new securities.
''As recently as last Thursday, the market psychology was that the supply would be a problem,'' Shearson Lehman's Mr. Slifer said. ''Now, with these new economic numbers in hand, the perception is very different.''
 
New Reports This Week
In addition to the refunding announcement, market participants will be presented this week with a number of important new reports on how the economy fared during July. The most important is expected on Friday, when the Labor Department will release employment data. Most analysts expect that, excluding dismissed census workers, July's nonfarm payroll employment rose by 125,000.
Analysts at Salomon Brothers are projecting that most of the job growth was concentrated in private, service-producing industries. Continued sluggishness in the construction and manufacturing sectors suggests that goods-producing employment fell by approximately 35,000 jobs in July, the analysts said. That would bring the cumulative decline in those sectors to 156,000 jobs.
''An increase in nonfarm payroll employment of 125,000 would be consistent with economic growth of between 1 percent and 1.5 percent,'' Mr. Fine of Chase said. ''That is a little weaker than the Fed had been expecting.''

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Overseeing East German Transition

BYLINE: By FERDINAND PROTZMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST BERLIN

 BODY:
A year ago, Walter Romberg was a mathematics professor with an interest in economics. Today, he is East Germany's Finance Minister, faced with melding his nation's moribund economy with West Germany's economic juggernaut.
His spacious office here in the House of Ministries reflects the hectic pace and the sheer volume of work. A long table and his desk are piled with neat stacks of files and papers. 
The rush is not to the liking of Mr. Romberg, who is more accustomed to the deliberate pace of academe. ''I think it would have been better for all sides if the process had gone much slower,'' he said in an interview. ''What we did in three months we should have done in three years.''
 
A Difficult Process
Rebuilding East Germany's aged and obsolete industries and infrastructure will be a painful process, he said, but it will create many opportunities.
''I think there is a great need for service companies, for skilled trades, for construction companies,'' Mr. Romberg said. ''There are many, many possibilites. There are already many new companies, some small, some larger. The question will be how many of these companies are capable of surviving. The sharp competition is just beginning.''
He said East Germany needs to develop a stronger regional economic structure. To that end, Mr. Romberg is promoting a plan for an Oder-Neisse economic development region along the border with Poland, using foreign capital.
''The Polish are interested, and we also know there is interest from the French to work with us on this,'' he said. ''Maybe we can get the United States interested.''
The all-German elections in the fall will seal unification and probably put Mr. Romberg out of a job, but he is somewhat optimistic. ''The economy in the past months has become ever more unstable,'' he said. ''But, on the whole, I think we have already accomplished it.
''The change from the old economic, financial and political order to the new structure is very complicated. For many people, the trouble will be to adjust to the new structure. Some of them will only discover the trouble when the new structure is there. In that sense, it is a political-psychological problem. Economic stability is very important. It can provide stability for the transition.''
 
Survival Factors
Survival in the new era depends on several factors, Mr. Romberg said. Productivity, economic efficiency and marketability being the most critical. ''You can have good machines and make good products,'' he said, ''but if you can't sell them, it's no good.''
And what of Walter Romberg, mathematician? Is there political life after unification? Does he wake up in the morning with a sense of shaping history?
Mr. Romberg laughed. ''Sometimes more, sometimes very little,'' he said. ''At the moment the burdens on me are very great. There is much stress. But some things are fun. As for the future, I'll see. It depends on whether I can be useful.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Walter Romberg, the Finance Minister of East Germany, is a former mathematics professor who now faces the task of melding his country's economy with the economy of West Germany. (Gunther Schneider for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1128 words

HEADLINE: Growth in Jobs Shifts to Losses in New York Region

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
After slowing to a crawl for more than two years, the regional economy has shifted into reverse, shedding 8,000 jobs in private industry in New York City and 7,000 such jobs in northeastern New Jersey in the five months ended in May.
In a gloomy briefing yesterday, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, said that the downturn that followed the stock market plunge of October 1987 had deepened in intensity and spread through more of the economy and that it now blanketed the New York metropolitan region.
 
'Growth Engine' Loses Steam
In addition to the job losses in the city and New Jersey, Mr. Ehrenhalt said, job figures for Long Island and the northern New York suburbs were essentially stagnant.
''The overwhelming reality is that all parts of the region are in the same boat,'' he said. ''The growth engine has run out of steam.'' 
In suffering its first drop in private employment since 1982, the region lost 5,500 jobs in finance, insurance and real estate, businesses that propelled the boom of the 1980's; 15,000 jobs in manufacturing, which has now lost 326,000 jobs since the end of 1979; 9,200 jobs in construction, and 6,500 jobs in wholesale and retail trade.
Those losses were partially offset by more than 20,000 additional service jobs, but a growing share of the new jobs was in nonprofit health care and social services, as opposed to business and professional services like law and accounting, which attract wealth to the region.
 
Government Jobs Added
There were 25,000 government jobs added in the region, which gave the region a gain of about 12,000 jobs. But 19,000 of those new government jobs were part-time positions with the Census Bureau.
While government employment in the last few years has tended to compensate for private job losses in the region, the tight budgets anticipated by states, cities and towns are likely to limit any new hiring.
Mr. Ehrenhalt declined to describe New York and New Jersey as in a recession, saying the term was technically reserved for the national economy and usually associated with deeper drops in employment. He also said the region's unemployment rate of 5.2 percent compared favorably with the national average of 5.5 percent.
But he added that in some respects the local economic condition was ''of more concern.'' Recessions, he said, are ''very often associated with inventory buildups, and then when it's over, the economy comes back.''
''I think here in the region we're facing an exhaustion of whatever growth impulse there was, problems in many major sectors of the economy and issues that really at this moment have no end in sight,'' he said.
 
'A Fine Line'
Referring to a possible recession, Sylvia Ashrafiuon, an economist with the regional services division of the WEFA Group, a forecasting organization in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., said: ''It's a fine line, and we haven't crossed it yet.''
''Basically, the New York area is slow,'' she said. ''There's no better way to describe it.''
But she said she expected the region's economy to improve next year as many worried consumers, who are now delaying spending, can no longer put off making purchases.
In the first full year after the stock market plunge, private employment in the region edged up eight-tenths of 1 percent, confounding some economists who expected a sharp drop. In contrast, it rose 3.4 percent in the nation.
In 1989, the national rate dropped to 2.4 percent and the regional rate declined to three-tenths of 1 percent. From December 1989 to May 1990, the national rate was 1.5 percent and the regional rate was minus five-tenths of 1 percent.
 
'More Significant Influence'
Besides the region's internal problems, Mr. Ehrenhalt said, the slowing national economy ''is now a more significant influence.''
In some cases, the region's strengths have turned to weaknesses. For example, New York City's financial-related industries have lost 35,000 jobs from December 1987 to May 1990 and would lose 15,000 this year at the current rate of decline.
Total payrolls in the securities fields, which rose sixfold from $2.1 billion in 1979 to $12 billion in 1988, fell to $10.8 billion in 1989, preliminary data showed. Average annual pay in these fields dropped from $78,625, to $75,243, though that was still more than double the citywide average.
Long Island, with a concentration of defense-related industries, gained 16,000 factory jobs from 1982 to 1986. But in the last three and a half years it lost 24,000 such jobs and remains vulnerable to further cuts in defense spending.
''Employment is flat or tilting down everywhere, whether we look at Long Island, which had the most rapid growth in the 1980's, or the northern suburbs, or New York City, which added more than a quarter of a million jobs prior to the slowdown, or northeastern New Jersey,'' Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
His briefing covered employment in 23 counties in New York and New Jersey from December 1989 to May 1990. But Connecticut is hardly better off, with a job-growth rate of one-tenth of 1 percent last year.
That gave it the seventh worst record in the nation, after the other New England states and Michigan.
 
A Bright Spot
One of the few bright spots in the region was inflation, which soared during the first quarter to an annual rate of 10.3 percent but fell to 1.5 percent in the second quarter. Wage and salary increases in the Northeast moderated from 6.4 percent in 1989 to 4.8 percent in 1990, which will make the region more competitive in a nation that is averaging increases of 4.5 percent.
More than half the counties in the region have unemployment rates below 5 percent, although some in New Jersey have rates so low that they are suffering labor shortages that impede growth. In all of New York City's boroughs except Manhattan and in Hudson, Passaic and Essex Counties in New Jersey, the rates are higher than the national average.
 
Growth Rates Compared
The decline in the region in the last few years was especially telling when its employment record was compared to those of the Los Angeles-Long Beach area and Chicago. From December 1979 to December 1987, New York had an annual growth rate of 1.8 percent, against 1.5 percent for Los Angeles and minus seven-tenths of 1 percent for Chicago. Since then, New York has had an annual growth rate of six-tenths of 1 percent, against 1.8 percent for Chicago and 2.4 percent for Los Angeles.
But Mr. Ehrenhalt, who in past briefings has cited New York's resilience, was not entirely bleak about its prospects. He said the region was rich in expertise in the scientific, technical, financial and communications fields that, he said, are ''at the forefront of world economic development.''

HEADLINE: The Textile Bill's Awful Bill

 BODY:
The Senate has overwhelmingly approved a textile bill that would impose a vicious cost on U.S. consumers, violate existing American trade agreements and undermine international trade talks. Three big strikes, yet the House is poised to approve similar legislation, perhaps this week.
The best hope for the nation is that the House vote will fall far short of the two-thirds majority needed to override President Bush's threatened veto of this ruinous legislation. 
The House and Senate bills would restrict the overall growth of imports of textiles and clothing to 1 percent yearly, compared with recent growth rates of about 6 percent annually. With foreign competition blunted, it's estimated that domestic producers would eventually charge consumers $50 billion more each year. That would amount to $200,000 for each job saved in American textile manufacturing.
Even that formidable figure disguises the full harm. The legislation would destroy as many jobs as it would save. Retailing jobs would be lost because higher prices would cause sales to fall. And jobs in export sectors would be lost once the third world reacted to its loss of sales in the U.S. All the legislation would accomplish is to take a lot more money from families trying to buy affordable clothing and put it in the hands of politically powerful textile owners. The bill is testimony to their power, and to the callous indifference of many legislators.
Textile trade is currently governed by an international agreement under which the U.S. has negotiated bilateral pacts with exporting countries. All of these agreements would be violated by the proposed legislation, and without provocation.
Also imperiled would be the Uruguay Round of international trade talks. The U.S. is now lobbying for developing countries to open their economies to more imports of goods, services and foreign investment. In exchange, they would receive greater access for their exports of food and manufactured goods, especially low-cost apparel.
By shutting off the U.S. market - and preventing the President from negotiating tariffs on textiles, apparel and footwear - Congress would leave the third world little to gain from further talks. The Uruguay Round would die, delivering a crippling blow to world trade and economic growth.
The House and Senate bills would devastate these third world exporters, scuttle international trade talks and seriously hurt American families with low incomes. That's an astounding amount of damage, all for the sake of bailing out one non-competitive group of producers.

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
Gorbachev Must Hurry

BYLINE: Flora Lewis

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
Mikhail Gorbachev pulled the plug that choked the Soviet system. Now other people are swarming to the surface with ideas that go far beyond his program for reform. They are no longer talking about reform, but about ''a fundamental new approach.''
Those are the words of Leningrad's Mayor, Anatoly Sobchak, to a group of Americans last week. ''Every undertaking must start with the individual, and end with the individual, with the human being,'' he said. ''For the last 70 years, everything here has started with a party decree and ended with a party decree.'' 
Mr. Sobchak is one of the new local leaders who are challenging the center. He quit the Communist Party after its last congress and criticizes Mr. Gorbachev for staying on as General Secretary. The idea that that was necessary to prevent a conservative takeover was wrong, in his view, because it means Mr. Gorbachev will continue to lean on party structures instead of speeding the end of the Communist monopoly by building his base at various levels of government.
The Leningrad leader is an ally of the Russian Republic's President, Boris Yeltsin, Moscow's new Mayor, Gavriil Popov, and others who are emerging in many parts of the country. These alliances themselves bring merit to some reassessment of Mr. Yeltsin, because these others do not share the bumptious, nationalistic, apparently anti-Semitic aspects of Mr. Yeltsin's record that have made him unappealing in the West. Maybe we have judged too hastily, and taken too earnestly the argument that Mr. Gorbachev's caution is the only alternative to chaos. People do talk about the possibility of chaos, even civil war. But the danger seems to come more from impatience for both autonomy and material improvement than from party hard-liners or the military.
The military is deeply split, by generation, nationalism and grass-roots disaffection. Moscow officials confirm a report that there have been 15,000 ''suicides'' in the ranks in the last five years.
Mr. Sobchak argues that holding the country together has to be in two stages, first accepting demands for separatism, which are burgeoning, and afterward seeking reintegration ''on a voluntary basis.'' Things wouldn't have reached this point, he says, if serious moves had been launched a year ago to restructure the Soviet Union. Now Mr. Gorbachev talks about it, but it hasn't started.
Instead, he has reasserted central control of the banking system, which doesn't work and brakes local initiative. It would be worse if all the republics issued their own currency, but what is happening to the ruble now is destruction of the currency.
Mr. Sobchak, like practically everybody, pleads for Western help to start reversing the economic collapse. But he has strong feelings about how it should be delivered. ''Don't give it to the Government,'' he said. ''Our civil servants are masters at wasting billions on grandiose plans 'to build Communism.' It should go company by company, project by project,'' which means a high degree of intrusion, but that doesn't bother him.
This is a difficult issue for Western decisions. The West cannot remake the Soviets to its own specifications, and it cannot be indifferent to the risk of a vast, violent upheaval in a country with such an awesome arsenal and such fierce passions.
But it is not evident that the risk would be greater by supporting new forces that are pressing Mr. Gorbachev to move faster in dismantling the Communist system. He still seems to be trying to make it work.
People like Mr. Sobchak, who is a likely prime minister if momentum does pick up at the center, are rethinking from the start. ''We have a psychological even more than an economic problem,'' he said. ''Our people were taught that only our enemies have private property, so we have a nation of paupers.''
As for his city, a magnificent jewel that still looks west, he acknowledges there is a movement to change its name back from Leningrad to St. Petersburg. ''But that wouldn't change people's lives at this point; it should only be done by referendum.''
Is he waiting for Lenin to be removed from his Red Square mausoleum and buried there? he was asked. ''In a year or two, the body will be where it belongs and the news will be on the third page,'' he answered.
Events are racing ahead of Mr. Gorbachev now. Though he provided the initial spark, he is no longer the spark plug. The West should encourage him to hurry, not support more equivocation with untied credits.

HEADLINE: Flower Sellers' Ruthless Competition

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

 BODY:
At an intersection near Times Square, passers-by on either side of Broadway can follow the scent of flowers in every direction. There are vendors with bouquet-laden shopping carts. There's a couple who make flower arrangements under an umbrella. There's a mobile fruit stand with a floral section. There are arguments.
''I've told him: 'I don't interfere with your business. I'm here and you're there,' '' a shopping-cart florist said the other day, reliving one of his turf skirmishes with the fruit-stand owner.
Flowers seem to be everywhere these days, and behind every carnation, gladiolus and pompon, a competitive war is raging. Take the roses. Once a symbol of the special occasion, roses can now be bought - usually at decidedly everyday prices - at grocery stores and most produce markets, from street vendors who push carts or carry boxes, at stores that sell other flowers and those that sell roses alone. 
 
Buying on Impulse
Across America, more cut flowers are being sold than ever before, industry people say. Partly, it's economics: more flowers imported from newcomers to the market, like Italy, or cheaper new crops from traditional producers like Colombia, now a major source of roses.
In New York, the flower business has been swept up in the new wave of immigration, tackled first by the Korean grocers, and, most recently, itinerant shopping-cart sellers from Mexico.
All of which may have actually helped shops at the top of the market, as more people buy on impulse and for themselves, and some of the newly hooked buyers move up to floral arrangements and fancier flowers.
''The economy is not doing well, and my business is still growing,'' said Ruben Consa, owner of Environmental Designs at Fifth Avenue and 53d Street, which specializes in contemporary arrangements that use metal sculptures and whose clients include hotels and fashion houses.
But if Mr. Consa's business niche resembles a serene garden, for the neighborhood florists and inexpensive vendors, it's a jungle out there.
 
Lethal Competition
In Flushing, Queens, about 20 flower shops recently banded together and went to the police. They want the eviction of vendors who pop up on popular flower days like Mother's Day and Easter. The shop owners charge that the vendors are unlicensed, pay no taxes and sell an inferior product. With almost no overhead, they say, the vendors are lethal competition.
''That kills us,'' said Frank D'Iorio, owner of Georgewood Florist at 158-15 Northern Boulevard. ''That would put small flower shops out of business because these shops make their money during holidays.''
At the corner of 90th Street and Lexington Avenue, Nicholas Adamis has posted a ''Business for Sale'' sign on the window of his small flower shop after 31 years. Like other small-business men in New York City, Mr. Adamis has had to contend with higher taxes and skyrocketing rents. He now pays $3,250 monthly for the same 350 square feet of commercial space he first rented for $175 a month, he said.
But Mr. Adamis's special bane has been cutthroat competition. Four roses-only shops - Roses Only, Rose Garden, Rose Farm and I H Roses -sprang up in the last year near Mr. Adamis's store, Dorothy's Flower Shop.
 
No Middleman
Many of these ''boutiques'' grow their own roses and cut out the middleman, which enables them to charge as little as $4 a dozen. The 63-year-old florist, whose cheapest roses go for $24 a dozen, said he hasn't charged $4 for a dozen roses since the 50's.
''It doesn't pay to be in the business,'' he said.
Old-time florists, many of them Greek immigrants, said that the new breed of competitors surfaced about 10 years ago when a newer immigrant group, the Korean greengrocers, added flowers to their fruit and vegetable displays. Today, most of the 1,300 produce markets in New York City sell flowers, with many expanding varieties as they gain more experience in flower care, said Sung Soo Kim, president of the Korean American Small Business Service Center of New York.
Chang Yang, who since 1985 has offered several kinds of flowers at his Golden Food produce market on Third Avenue near 82d Street, said the profit margin for flowers is higher than that for produce, although they are more perishable and are a riskier investment. His sales have also dropped as competition has intensified, he said, but he said the markets' edge is still convenience.
''Even though customers don't stop by to buy flowers, they may want candy, but they see the flowers and they buy them,'' he said.
 
Arranging in the Basement
About two years ago, vendors selling from shopping carts appeared in noticeable numbers, other florists said. Most are immigrants from Mexico like 21-year-old Alfonso Santos.
For $200 a month, Mr. Santos and nine other vendors are allowed to use the basement of a Washington Heights apartment building to prepare their merchandise and load their carts.
On any given morning, the men stand amid roses, gladioluses, carnations and pompons they have picked out at the West 28th Street flower market much earlier, and silently trim, arrange and package as a radio plays mariachi music. Then they head for subway stations to fan out around the city.
Many of the vendors work for another vendor and take a 40 percent cut on sales ranging anywhere between $70 and $300 a day, they said. Mr. Santos, who works for himself and sometimes has vendors working for him, said he nets about $100 on a good day, but he has been arrested about 20 times in the last two years for selling without a permit. Each time the police throw away his cart and jail him for one to five days before releasing him, he said.
Mr. Santos said he would rather work in a restaurant, but he is undocumented and employers will not hire him.
''What other option is there? You have to make a living,'' he said.
In March of 1988, the first roses-only store, Rosa Rosa Inc., opened on Lexington Avenue between 63d and 64th Streets. A second Rosa Rosa opened on West 72d Street between Broadway and Columbus Avenue last April, and a third store operates in Southhampton, L.I. during summers only.
The stores are owned by a Dutchman who grows the roses in Guatemala and who didn't find any takers when he first tried to sell his crop to wholesalers in New York City, said Jorge Zambrano, who manages the stores. By taking care of their own growing, packing and distribution, Mr. Zambrano said, the stores are able to offer roses for $5 to $9 a dozen.
Lines of 15 or more waiting customers became a fixture at the first store soon after it opened, Mr. Zambrano said. The lines are gone now that about 20 other similar specialty shops have also opened, he said. But there are plans to expand to other areas of the country, said Mr. Zambrano, who argued that his stores' strength is quality.
Quality is an issue raised by established florists, who argue that they still offer the best grade, selection and advice.
But quality can be uneven at all retail levels, flower lovers and experts said. They said that only a careful consumer can get the best deals.
Just how many street flower vendors there are is hard to gauge. The city's Department of Consumer Affairs requires that they get a general vendor permit for which they would have to pay $200 annually and post a $2,500 bond. But a cap of 853 permits that can be issued has already been met and department officials acknowledged that unlicensed vendors outnumber those who are licensed.
The more the better, customers said. Enzo Caterini, 28, an Upper East Side resident, said he used to pay florists $2.50 to $3 for each stem of yellow roses, his favorite. Now he buys a dozen for $8 from a nearby rose boutique and sometimes drives to the Upper West Side for purchases ''because they are $1 cheaper. Maybe it's the rent,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Yankees, Sanders Have a Parting

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN

 BODY:
The brief, controversial and uncertain major league baseball career of Deion Sanders came to an abrupt halt yesterday when the Yankee organization ended contract negotiations that would have extended his commitment to baseball and could have led to a legal struggle.
Sanders, suddenly a former outfielder for the Yankees and soon to be a defensive back for the Atlanta Falcons who was becoming the focus of a developing legal dispute between the two organizations, announced that his Yankee season had ended and he was going on vacation.
Less than 90 minutes before last night's game between the Yankees and the Detroit Tigers, his season having suddenly ended with a batting average of .158 in 57 games and his third home run of the season in his final game Sunday afternoon, Sanders sat at a table in the Yankee clubhouse and wrote telephone numbers to leave for selected teammates.
Before his departure, however, he challenged a statement by the Yankee organization he had requested the contract extension and criticized teammates who had complained about an inexperienced teammate possibly earning a major contract. 
 
Steinbrenner Says No
The Yankee statement, issued yesterday afternoon, said that a request by Sanders for a $1 million contract for the 1991 season had been rejected by George Steinbrenner, the principal owner. The statement came several hours before Steinbrenner was permanently banned by the baseball commissioner, Fay Vincent, from any further involvement in the management or day-to-day operations of the team.
Steinbrenner was quoted in the statement: ''Under no circumstances could we offer Deion that kind of salary for the 1991 season. Even so, we still would like Deion to continue with the Yankees and wish him well in whatever he chooses to do.''
Sanders maintained that the Yankees had raised the economic possibilities in an effort to persuade him to remain with the team. ''They threw a lot of money at me,'' he said.
He said that the failure to reach an agreement with the Yankees was partly the result of the threat of legal pressure by the Falcon organization, which was intensified yesterday, and by the unrelated concerns of Steinbrenner. who had been awaiting a decision on his status from Vincent.
When asked what he would miss about his brief stay with the Yankees, Sanders said: ''The challenge of the game. The challenge of the game. And leaving on not a great note. Leaving on a bad note. People will say, 'He was no baseball player.' ''
Sanders said yesterday that he had decided earlier in the season that he would leave the Yankees and report for a full season with the Falcons in the hope of becoming a Pro Bowl caliber player.
''Then, once I thought about the situation,'' he said, ''I thought I really want to prove to a lot of people I can play this game and play it well.''
In a letter to George Bradley, the Yankee vice president, the Falcons' legal adviser, Marion H. Allen III, informed the team that the Falcons would seek a court order to recover the $2 million signing bonus Sanders had been paid, a total salary reduction of $600,000, $10,000 for missing the team's minicamp, $1,500 a day for absences from the current training camp and additional money for missed games and subpar performances due to missed practices.
On Sunday, after what eventually became his final game of the season, Sanders said that the threats of the Falcon organization were an unsuccessful tactic meant to scare him. ''I don't scare when I've got Mr. Steinbrenner in my corner,'' Sanders said then.
Yesterday, he acknowledged that the threats may have had a bearing on the Yankee decision to end negotiations.
''That might have scared them a little bit,'' he said.
Now that his plans had been changed, Sanders said he would the Falcons, but did not say when.

HEADLINE: Impersonator Wants To Portray Still Others, This Time, Onstage

BYLINE: By ALEX WITCHEL

 BODY:
It shouldn't surprise anyone that David Hampton wants to be a professional actor, considering the success he has had as an amateur. Posing as Sidney Poitier's son, he gained access to the homes of many prominent New Yorkers in 1983, and his deception inspired ''Six Degrees of Separation,'' John Guare's hit play, which opened in June at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center.
Mr. Hampton has just returned to New York after an absence of seven years to see the play and, he said, to begin an acting career.
In an interview last week, Mr. Hampton, who is 26 years old, talked about his life since his 21-month prison term for attempted burglary ended with his parole from the state prison at Dannemora in New York State in October 1986. He addressed what is perhaps the most pressing question on the minds of everyone who has seen the play: Why did he masquerade as someone else? 
Simple, he said. He wanted to get into Studio 54.
Mr. Hampton was then 17 years old and unemployed. He said he came to New York from Buffalo to pursue a career ''in the arts'' but was ''not pounding the pavements hard enough to get an acting job.'' Dancing in club competitions was a way to make money.
 
'I Said, ''We'll Lie'' '
''A friend and I really wanted to get into Studio 54,'' he recalled. ''We waited on line and when we got to the front the bouncer looked at us and said, 'Fifty dollars apiece.' I didn't have the money, so we said thank you and walked away. Then my friend said: 'We have to get in there. There are celebrities in there we want to meet.' And out of the clear blue sky, I said: 'We'll lie. Think of who you can be.'
''My friend was Caucasian, and we thought about it, and I said, 'You can be Gregory Peck's son.' For me, it boiled down to a choice of being the son of three people: Sidney Poitier, Sammy Davis Jr. or Harry Belafonte. I look like Belafonte the most, but I had read in People magazine that he had a son, named David, who is a model. And I thought Sammy Davis Jr. was too glitzy, too gaudy. Poitier has so much more class. He was the only one to have won an Oscar, in 1963 for 'Lilies of the Field.' ''
''We got back on line and even though it was only an hour and a half later, the doorman didn't recognize us,'' he continued. ''We told him who we were, and we were swept into the center doors like we owned the place.'' He paused. ''It was a magical moment.''
''Three days later,'' he said, ''I was hungry, and I found myself with little money. So I tootled up to one of the bistros on Columbus Avenue and told the doorman I wanted a table for two, that I was to meet my father there, and the last name was Poitier. Once again, magic happened. They did cartwheels: drinks were sent over to my table. To make a long story short, my 'father' didn't show up that evening, and the meal was on the house.''
''I was ignorant of the criminal charges of doing that,'' Mr. Hampton said. ''I didn't know conning people was a crime. I thought I could do these things, and once I had success, I could look back on it 20 or 30 years from now and laugh.''
 
A Matter of an Address Book
Of course it didn't happen that way. Which is where the address book, filled with the names of those prominent New Yorkers Mr. Hampton deceived, came in. Though it has been reported that Mr. Hampton had stolen an address book from a Connecticut College student, Robert Stammers, Mr. Hampton said that was untrue. While staying with a friend at the college he met Mr. Stammers, he said, who left the address book with him so he could enter his address and telephone number.
''I didn't realize I still had it until I was back in New York, and found it in my knapsack,'' Mr. Hampton said.
Once he found it, ''with its glamorous East Side addresses, the ball got rolling,'' he continued.
''The story about being Sidney Poitier's son got bigger and better,'' he said. ''Whether you're Ivan Boesky or the guy playing three-card monte on the street, once you're accomplished at what you do, you can get lazy, overconfident and sloppy. You forget what you've said. But you're having so much success that you think it can never end. That along with greed, was my downfall. I kept procrastinating about finding a job, and I became a minor celebrity at the places I went.''
Among the people who admitted Mr. Hampton into their homes were John Jay Iselin, who was then the president of Channel 13, and his wife, Lea, a lawyer, and Osborn Elliott, who was then the dean of the Columbia School of Journalism, and his wife, Inger.
 
'You Get Paranoid'
''In a way, I was happy that the game was over,'' Mr. Hampton said of his arrest on Oct. 18, 1983, at the age of 19. ''It gets tiring after a while. You get paranoid.'' Mr. Hampton was arraigned on charges of petty larceny, criminal impersonation and fraudulent accosting. He pleaded guilty to a lesser charge of attempted burglary.
When his parents learned of his activities ''they were mortified,'' he said. ''They thought I was pursuing an acting and dancing career,'' he said. ''Both my parents were the first in their families to go to college. My father is a lawyer and my mother was a nurse who went back and got a degree in communications. They were always headstrong and conservative people. I wanted a career in the arts, but they wanted me to be a doctor, lawyer or stockbroker. But I felt those 9-to-5 types of things were too easy.''
After he served his prison sentence, he said, he moved back to Buffalo. He said he did menial work at the Langston Hughes Institute there for almost a year. He then went to London, where he said he lived for two and a half years working off the books as a waiter and bartender in various places and traveling through Europe. Tired of getting paid ''like an illegal alien,'' he said, he returned to the United States early last year, settling in West Hollywood, Calif., where he got a job delivering groceries. He said he then moved to Venice, Calif., where he painted houses and started writing ''an autobiographical type of work.''
It was while he was on vacation in Hawaii in June, he said, that a friend called and told him about the success of the Guare play.
 
And More Paranoia
''It was rather shocking,'' Mr. Hampton said. ''I had been planning to come back to New York, thinking that by now I would be anonymous and no one would know me. Because after an experience as traumatic as incarceration, I perceived that everyone knew about me, which does create a bit of paranoia.''
Of course, ''Six Degrees of Separation'' is a play, not a piece of journalism. Mr. Guare has said in interviews that a newspaper story about Mr. Hampton interested him enough to use it as the starting point for a fictive work. But the distinction between fact and fiction seems lost on Mr. Hampton, who said he had not yet seen the play. Based on what he has read, he said: ''I am slightly upset by the way my character is being portrayed. I have never been homeless, and I have never been a street hustler. I grew up in a correct middle-class environment.''
Mr. Hampton said his move to New York City was permanent. ''I really want to succeed in the arts,'' he said. ''I don't wish to become a victim of my notoriety. I would rather be known for positive achievements than as a slickster in an Off Broadway play.''

Mr. Hampton, an aspiring actor, inspired the show by posing as Sidney Poitier's son to meet prominent New Yorkers and to advance his career. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Consumer Spending Up 1% in June

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 30

 BODY:
Personal spending rose 1 percent in June, the strongest gain in five months, the Government said today. The Commerce Department report suggested that consumers have been keeping the nation's weak economy out of a recession.
''This seems to indicate the consumer is not dead,'' said Mark M. Zandi, an economist with Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa. ''As long as the consumer hangs in there, I believe we will avoid a recession.'' 
The Commerce Department also said personal income rose four-tenths of a percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.64 trillion, after gaining three-tenths of a percent in both April and May.
The department said consumer spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.64 trillion, the biggest jump since a similar 1 percent gain in January.
 
A Source of Concern
Consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, has been a source of concern in recent months. Spending rose just two-tenths of 1 percent in February and April and three-tenths of a percent in March. Spending was unchanged in May.
As measured in the gross national product, the nation's total output of goods and services, second-quarter personal consumption, which includes all spending except interest payments, actually fell three-tenths of a percent. But the second-quarter figures, released Friday, included June estimates that might be revised.
The higher spending level resulted in a drop in Americans' savings rate - savings as a percentage of disposable income - to 4.9 percent. It had been 5.4 percent in May and 5.1 percent in April.
 
Commerce Department Revision
All of today's figures reflected major changes in last year's numbers as a result of the Commerce Department's annual revision announced last week. The biggest change involved the department's $57.9 billion overestimate of wages and salaries, which lowered the 1989 savings rate to 4.6 percent, from 5.4 percent.
Americans' income after taxes increased five-tenths of a percent, up from a three-tenths gain a month earlier. Wages and salaries rose $13 billion in June after a $10.1 billion increase in May.
Personal consumption rose $34.5 billion, including a $9.6 billion gain in spending on durable goods - items expected to last more than three years. This included a robust $6.1 billion rebound in automobile sales, which had been sluggish for much of the year.

HEADLINE: Stocks Up on Belief in an Interest Rate Cut

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
A growing belief that the Federal Reserve may take steps to lower interest rates to revitalize the economy pushed stock prices higher yesterday.
But a parallel prospect - that weak consumer spending would become weaker - prompted market sentiment that now might be a good time to get out of stocks that are still close to their highs for the year.
By the end of the day, even though investors remained extremely skittish about the economy and the potential for further earnings surprises, the Dow Jones industrial average surged 18.82 points, to 2,917.33. 
In Tokyo, shares closed sharply higher today after falling for the previous seven sessions. The Nikkei stock average closed up 592.71 points, or 1.95 percent, to 31,035.66.
On the New York Stock Exchange, trading volume yesterday sank to a slow 146.5 million shares, from 149 million on Friday. Declines outstripped advances 792 to 717, and 88 stocks set new lows, among them A.T.& T., which fell to 36 before ending the day at 37, up 3/4.
''We're facing a dramatic change in growth in personal consumption spending,'' said Michael Metz, chief market analyst for Oppenheimer & Company, the Wall Street investment house.
He told clients that among retailing stocks he considered vulnerable were Home Depot, the do-it-yourself stores; Nordstrom, the apparel chain; Dillard Department Stores; Circuit City Stores, the electronics chain, and Blockbuster Video, the video rental chain.
The next casualty, he maintained, would be the casino group, including Circus Circus and Golden Nugget.
Circus Circus fell 3 1/8, to 59 7/8, while Golden Nugget fell 1 1/4, to 32. Home Depot fell 1, to 35 3/4. Three others fell only slightly and Circuit City rose 3/8, to 27.
Saying he thought it was time to take profits in some of the big blue-chip growth stocks that have not had disappointing earnings, Barton M. Biggs, director of worldwide strategy for Morgan, Stanley & Company, urged clients to sell 50 percent of their stakes in Boeing, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Coca-Cola, Johnson & Johnson, Wal-Mart Stores and Waste Management.
He said he urged them to switch into other growth stocks that have already had disappointments, including Sallie Mae, McDonald's, Reuters Holdings, Walt Disney, Compaq Computer and AMP, a producer of electronic connectors.
Explaining the market's rise, traders said a study of Friday's weak gain in the gross national product, the value of the nation's goods and services, suggested that the economy was deteriorating rapidly and that the Fed would almost certainly step in.
On the theory that stock prices would also rise, traders who had sold short Standard & Poor's 500-index futures were forced to buy them back to avoid big losses. Around 2 P.M. Central daylight time, when the futures market in Treasury bonds closed in Chicago, program traders began buying stock in New York, driving prices up. This in turn brought more short covering in the S.&P. 500-index futures, and the rally was on.
Birinyi Associates said two series of buying programs starting a few minutes before 3 P.M. and extending for most of next 20 minutes lifted the market 24 points. Six buying programs in all lifted the Dow a total of 41 points.
With crude oil prices expected to go up, oil stocks were up yesterday. Exxon rose 1 1/2, to 50 3/4; Texaco 1 3/8, to 62 7/8, and Chevron 1 3/4, to 79 - all helping the Dow make its strong showing. ARCO rose 2 3/4, to 127 3/4, and Mobil rose 5/8, to 65 1/8.
