HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Continue Strong Rise

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Continued strong demand for Treasury securities sent prices soaring and interest rates tumbling yesterday.
Dealers said portfolio managers were among the more aggressive buyers, with many venturing out to the longer maturities for the first time in weeks. The activity also stimulated demand for corporate debt securities.
 
Long Bonds Down to 8.40%
After some late profit-taking, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds were being offered at 103 24/32, up 25/32. This caused the yield to drop to 8.40 percent, from 8.47 percent late Friday and 8.53 last Thursday. The yield yesterday was the lowest since July 5, when it was also 8.40 percent. 
A measure of the demand was that the buyers ignored three developments that would normally have depressed the prices of fixed-income securities. One was the weakness in the dollar, which makes domestic investments less attractive to foreign investors. Another was a report that the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal entity entrusted with bailing out the savings industry, would need to borrow at least $100 billion in fiscal 1991. The other was a 1 percent rise in consumer spending in June reported by the Commerce Department.
''What we witnessed today was increased carry-over buying that was sparked by the weak second-quarter G.N.P. figures released last Friday,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., the senior vice president of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ''But today's major buyers weren't traders or speculators. They were investment portfolios managers and, significantly, their orders ranged out to the long end of the Treasury market.''
The Government reported on Friday that the nation's gross national product grew at an annual rate of only 1.2 percent in the second quarter. This, together with downward revisions for the previous two quarters, led economists to warn the economy was sliding toward a recession.
''All this has intensified the pressure on the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates,'' Mr. Sullivan continued. ''It has also minimized the inflation threat that has long preoccupied the Fed.''
Because the value of fixed-income securities rises when inflation and competitive interest rates decline, any increase in the number of the unemployed would encourage more demand for long-term Treasury and other high-grade debt issues. The Government is scheduled to release its July employment data on Friday.
 
Long Notes at 8.34%
Among other representative issues traded in the secondary market, the long notes, the 8 7/8's of of the year 2000, climbed by 17/32, to 103 17/32, as its yield dropped to 8.34 percent, from 8.41 percent on Friday. With many of the buyers yesterday focusing at the long end, the 8 1/2's of 1997 rose by 13/ 32, to 101 5/32, to yield 8.28 percent; the 8's of 1992 gained 3/32, to 100 4/32, to yield 7.93 percent.
Tomorrow, the Treasury will announce the terms of its mid-quarter refunding. It is expected that a record $31 billion or more of 3-year and 10-year notes, as well as 30-year bonds, will be auctioned next week.
The Treasury held a record auction yesterday of $18.4 billion in three- and six-month bills, or $400 million more than at last week's sale. The average discount rate on the 90-day bills was 7.50 percent, up by a basis point, or hundredths of a percentage point, from the week before. The average discount rate on the six-month bills fell to 7.37 percent, from 7.40 percent. One-year bills slipped by 4 basis points, to 7.24 percent.
The Federal Reserve did not intervene in the credit markets yesterday, and the Federal funds rate, which is what banks charge each other for overnight loans, traded all day at 8 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues Its Decline On Signs of Slower Growth

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell broadly against major foreign currencies yesterday, continuing a decline prompted by the latest signs of a weakening United States economy and the prospect of lower interest rates.
''Global investors don't think the dollar is very attractive right now,'' said Earl I. Johnson, a vice president with the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
Traders said the dollar closed at its lowest level since January 1988 against the West German mark and at nearly a two-year low against the British pound. It fell more than a yen against the Japanese currency. 
Chris Mendell, a vice president with the Security Pacific National Bank in Los Angeles, said that as differences in global interest rates have narrowed, rates of return for investors in Europe and Japan have become higher or comparable to those in the United States.
 
Continuation From Friday
The market activity yesterday was largely a continuation of that on Friday, when the dollar tumbled in reaction to reports of slow growth of the gross national product in June.
The financial markets believe that with the United States economy continuing to slump, the Federal Reserve Board will push interest rates lower to help stimulate growth. But such a move would come at the expense of the dollar. Currencies are supported by higher interest rates, so a drop in United States yields makes the dollar less competitive.
Against the West German currency, the dollar fell to 1.6040 West German marks, down from 1.6120. That is the lowest since it closed at 1.5880 on Jan. 5, 1988.
 
Sterling Gains
The British pound climbed against the dollar, following up on a more than 2 cent rise on Friday. Sterling rose to $1.8465 in New York from late Friday's $1.8375.
Against the Japanese currency, the dollar fell more than a yen, to 147.83 in New York, from 149.10 late Friday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar tumbled 2.15 yen to a closing 148.60 Japanese yen, and it was quoted in London at 148.15 yen.
Other dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.3602 Swiss francs, down from 1.3620; 5.3725 French francs, down from 5.3990; 1,174.25 Italian lire, down from 1,180.00, and 1.15245 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15195.
 
Gold and Silver Mixed
In the precious metals market, the August gold contract fell 20 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York to $367.80 an ounce. Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $367.70, up 40 cents from Friday.
In London earlier, gold rose to a late bid of $367.25 an ounce, up from $367.15 late Friday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $367.50 an ounce, down from $367.15 late Friday.
Gold in Hong Kong fell 18 cents to close at $367.86 an ounce.
Silver prices for current delivery slipped 2.9 cents to $4.803 an ounce on the Comex. Silver rose in London to a late bid of $4.83 an ounce from $4.80 late Friday.

LENGTH: 820 words

HEADLINE: Careers;
Shortage of Skilled Workers Is Expected

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
IN 1967, Herman Kahn, the late founder of the Hudson Institute research organization, took a look ahead in a prescient book titled ''The Year 2000.'' He accurately predicted that United States corporations would have increased needs for skilled employees and training programs, that Japan would play a leading world economic role, and that commerce and industry in this country would extend in unbroken lines along highways between major cities, like the route from Boston to Washington.
Now the Hudson Institute has joined with Towers Perrin, a management consulting firm, in a report called Workforce 2000, based on a survey of 645 companies.
This study, which relies primarily on a questionnaire that is usually answered by lower-level corporate managers, could hardly be as in-depth or imaginative as Mr. Kahn's effort. But Jill Kinan-Lovers, a Towers Perrin vice president, said that the use of task forces for personnel planning is increasing among companies and that if these groups filled out the survey, ''we are getting more accurate results than we might have expected.'' 
The survey offers some instant surprises. It indicates that there is a labor shortage now, at a time when many people talk about additional reductions, like a recently announced plan to cut 17,000 jobs at the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.
In five years, the shortage will be worse, the survey predicts. For example, 21 percent of the respondents expect ''great difficulty'' hiring professional personnel, and 43 percent expect ''some difficulty.'' The dearth of secretarial-clerical personnel is expected to worsen, with 24 percent of the companies expecting ''great difficulty'' and 43 percent expecting ''some difficulty'' finding the help they need.
Furthermore, 52 percent of the financial institutions included in the survey indicated that they had ''some current difficulty'' finding supervisory and management personnel -another surprise in the face of huge dismissals by Wall Street investment firms and by many big banks in New York, Boston and elsewhere.
''I expected an overall shortage in the near future, but I was surprised that so many companies indicated a shortage right now,'' Mrs. Kinan-Lovers said, adding that the study might be more aptly called ''Workforce 1990.''
Another surprise was that many companies, while acknowledging difficulty finding skilled employees, said they were not prepared to give on-the-job training, especially remedial training to improve writing and verbal skills. Only 8 percent provide such training. But 78 percent said they had tuition reimbursement programs.
''Companies will have to do more training, especially remedial training,'' Mrs. Kinan-Lovers said. ''They will do it mostly in house and they will work more closely with local educators.''
The survey also showed, she said, that companies are expected to divide more jobs into parts, so that, for example, the more challenging parts of a job can be handled by those better trained and qualified.
Many ''leading edge'' companies, she said, want good publicity about their personnel policies - companies like International Business Machines, Hewlett-Packard, American Express, and Marriott. Better publicity obviously helps them attract more skilled employees, she added.
To recruit in a tight market for skilled workers requires innovative techniques, Mrs. Kinan-Lovers said. For example, she continued, the Lotus Development Corporation went through a period of rapid growth and needed to attract a large number of professional and technical employees.
''You have to compete for good technical managers,'' she said, adding that Lotus offered one unusual employee benefit: it hired a massage therapist to help employees handle stress.
''Another exciting innovation is cafeteria menus, which now offer a wider variety - from hamburgers to sushi,'' she said.
One Japanese company, Fujitsu Ltd., provides free Japanese language training courses for American employees, she said.
Dr. Edward Lewis, president of St. Mary's College, a liberal arts institution in St. Mary's, Md., said he deplored the low corporate interest in on-the-job training that the survey indicated.
''Managers must learn how to handle diversity among employees,'' he said in an interview last week, adding that he expects almost a third of the labor force to consist of minority group workers by the year 2000.
''Companies must realize that employes with many different backgrounds do not have the same assumptions that their managers have,'' he continued.
A former English professor, Dr. Lewis cited Shakespeare's character Prospero in ''The Tempest'' ''In the play, Prospero learns that a ruler must be a teacher. All levels of management in the year 2000 will have to teach. I wish that students working for master of business administration degrees would learn more about handling people problems and less about the theoretical.''

HEADLINE: G.M. Greets 1st Saturn Car With a Closed Ceremony

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 30

 BODY:
Eight years after committing the General Motors Corporation to a compact-car project called Saturn, Roger B. Smith drove the first customer-ready version of the car off an assembly line in Spring Hill, Tenn., today - the day before he is to retire as chairman.
Typically, Mr. Smith's last hurrah as G.M.'s top executive would have received a media splash, especially since it fulfilled a promise he made five years ago to drive the first Saturn off the line before he retired.
But no outsiders were allowed to view the ceremony, and photographs were taken by a company photographer and cropped to reveal as little of the car as possible. The event was attended only by factory employees, top G.M. executives and Owen Bieber, the president of the United Automobile Workers union, who sat in the passenger seat beside Mr. Smith, a spokeswoman for Saturn said. 
The suspicion raised by this secrecy - that the Saturn car was not ready - was vigorously denied by the spokeswoman. Saturn executives have said they are reluctant to show the car before it goes on sale, which is expected in October.
Last month, problems with plastic door panels that buckeled in the heat at G.M.'s Arizona test track threatened to prevent Mr. Smith from meeting his deadline. The company said that problem was corrected.
 
An Analyst's Appraisal
Christopher Cedergren, an analyst for the automotive market research firm J. D. Power & Associates in Westlake Village, Calif., said he drove a Saturn car two weeks ago in Arizona. The vehicle ''is certainly the best thing G.M. has developed on the small-car front,'' he said.
''G.M. is playing the Japanese game,'' he continued. ''They are not showing the car to anybody other than dealers. I think they don't want to raise anyone's expectations and then have people be disappointed.''
A spokesman for the Saturn division said, ''Our rollout plans call for the vehicle to be shown to the public in the fall, and not before then.''

LENGTH: 664 words

HEADLINE: America Is No. 1. It'll Stay No. 1.

BYLINE: By Alfred Balk; Alfred Balk is author of the forthcoming book ''The Myth of American Eclipse: The New Global Age.''

 BODY:
Since the late Reagan years, we've heard a media and political refrain: the U.S. is in decline; it has lost world political and economic leadership; Japan is the coming No. 1 power.
Is this rational? After all, we have twice Japan's population and gross national product, and our political, cultural and economic weight has Americanized the world.
This fear makes sense only if we fixate on the immediate postwar years, in which we alone among industrial powers remained unscarred. Before World War II, there were five great powers. Recovery - the fruit of U.S. policy to promote world stability - has restored that multipolarity in a far richer world with different players, with America the reigning superpower and chief broker of a new global order. This is decline? 
Long-term trends suggest that it is not. From the late 60's through 1989, our share of the gross world product remained at 20 to 25 percent.
In the year 2010, according to an '88 Pentagon projection, our gross national product will be twice that of Japan or China or the Soviet Union.
Manufacturing muscle? From the 60's through the 80's, manufacturing provided at least 24 percent of our G.N.P., requiring ever fewer workers as reindustrialization has advanced. Productivity? Real productivity per U.S. worker is by far the world's highest - and 50 percent above Japan's International competitiveness? In the 70's and 80's, as trade has expanded, our share of world exports remained at a stable 17 percent. It is capital goods - production equipment - not autos or electronics, that caused more than half of our 80's trade deficits; oil is our fastest rising import, accounting for one-third of our trade imbalance.
Science-and-technology capability? Our university, corporate and governmental research complex is pre-eminent in all ways. We far outspend anyone else in research and development. Our scientists lead Japan and Europe combined in postwar Nobel Prizes. We write more than a third of all scientific and technical articles published. From '76 through '86 we doubled our scientist population.
High-technology industries? U.S. companies account for two-thirds of all commercial aircraft. The world's largest microchip manufacturer is not Japanese but American (I.B.M., which produces only for itself), and we excel in several classes of chips. The U.S. controls more than 60 percent of the world's computer industry compared to Japan's 20 percent. We lead in supercomputers; microprocessors and software are virtually American monopolies.
Global investment? One-fifth of our corporate assets are outside the U.S. General Motors and Ford are No. 1 and No. 2 in the auto world in sales, assets and profits, obtaining more than half their profits overseas. Foreign branches of U.S companies, far larger than anyone else's, in '87 recorded more than $1 trillion in sales: four times our exports and seven times our trade deficit that year. Today, the U.S. leads the world by far, because we have the largest economy and science-and-technology establishment; the new ''world language'' is English; the most contagious ideal is democracy; the benchmark currency is the dollar, and the trust and good will we enjoy can only be envied by Germany and Japan, our main rivals.
Why are we so insecure? Partly because of the new interdependence. Partly because interest groups (high-tech, for example) frighten us; psychologically, we need an adversary (exit Soviets, enter Japanese), and our quality of life, social programs and political dialogue are deficient.
We don't know our own strengths. If we are to restore our national spirit and fulfill our destiny in a global ''American century,'' it is this malaise, not the delusion of impending eclipse, that we should address. We have the wealth, international status and the know-how to solve problems in a variety of fields. If the media and other opinion leaders opened our eyes to our true status, the speed of our ''revival'' might surprise us.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed
